HEADLINE: From Necessity, New Forest Industry Rises

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: MAD RIVER, Calif.

 BODY:
It was a charmless stand of scrubby black oak that Louie Myers strode into as dusk settled on Mad River Ridge the other day. But his eyes lit up. They began to dart. He scanned the wood like any animal-world forager, and he smiled.
Asked what so captivated him in the sparse growth typical of these remote Northern California mountains, he declared: "I see money. Lots of money. And I don't have to cut down a single tree to get it!" 
 On one tree trunk, Mr. Myers found a luxurious bed of moss, the kind that stores need in bulk for their Easter baskets. On a low branch hung salable strands of usnea moss, a natural antibiotic. The ponderosa pine nearby could provide decorative boughs at $3 a bunch, he said, and the burl of a fallen oak would fetch a decent sum from furniture-makers.
"There's 10 different items here but you're not going to see them unless you know what you're looking for," said Mr. Myers, a 45-year-old Vietnam veteran and rural jack-of-all-trades. "Like, there's yarrow all over the place."
His skill goes back to the hunters and gatherers at the dawn of humanity, but it has been resurrected under a trendy new name: wildcrafting. And, researchers and the people of this depressed logging region say, it has a promising new postindustrial future, as a way to help forest communities around the country get by as lumber jobs evaporate.
Harvesting the forests' riches without cutting the trees is already an industry that brings in hundreds of millions of dollars a year nationwide, experts say. Though it is by no means a replacement for the financial heft of the lumber industry, wildcrafting began to take off at the same time that court and Government decisions began to curtail logging on public land sharply in the early 1990's, and it is now looked to as a modest economic life preserver for some of the rural unemployed, particularly here in the Northwest.
For part-time gatherers like Mr. Myers, wildcrafting can provide a welcome injection of cash: surveying the stand of black oak, he estimated optimistically that he could pull $20 worth of forest products out of it in less than half an hour. The revenue is considerably more for the processors and sellers.
The market for forest products other than trees has mushroomed by nearly 20 percent annually over the last several years, estimates Catherine Mater, an expert on the forest industry. The growth is fueled particularly by the exploding popularity of alternative medicine and herbal remedies, she said, citing projections that United States sales of medicinal herbs, which totaled $1.5 billion in 1995, would reach $5 billion in 2000.
"I feel like when I go into a forest system now, it's like watching a fast-paced Ping-Pong set," said Ms. Mater, who works for the family concern of Mater Engineering of Corvallis, Ore. "I'm seeing so many things I never saw before."
In 1995, American exports of commercial moss and lichen alone amounted to $14 million, said Nan Vance, a United States Forestry Service scientist who studies wildcrafting under the more prosaic title "non-timber forest products."
And that is only a tiny corner of a category that includes ferns and shrubs for floral arrangements, Christmas greens, foods like mushrooms and more than 100 medicinal herbs with names like feverfew and St. John's wort.
Rare wild ginseng can bring up to $400 a pound, Ms. Vance said, and some forest mushrooms are so valuable that they have sparked violence and gang attacks among the Asian, Hispanic and white harvesters who follow the Northwest's "mushroom trail," mainly in summer and fall.
Wildcrafting is especially attractive to forest communities because in the long-smoldering conflict between conservationists and lumber companies, it is part of an evolving middle way.
"We're scrambling," said Lynn Jungwirth, a community advocate and resident of the nearby town of Hay Fork, where a lumber mill is about to close and leave more than 100 unemployed. "We're saying, 'Let us be the stewards, and get some of the product and hit the niche markets. We have to re-create our own economic base.' "
Here in northern California's Trinity County, where nearly 90 percent of the land is Government-owned forest, dozens of people, most formerly dependent on income from the lumber industry, are in effect beating their chain saws into pruning scissors, following the example of counterparts in Washington and Oregon.
"It's a good ethical thing to be doing," said Irene Hetrick, a supervisor at Blue Heron Botanicals in Mad River. "We're not hurting anything or polluting -- and we can make a living at it."
Blue Heron, part of the 30-member High Mountain Herb Cooperative, buys the discoveries of Mr. Myers, among others, and markets more than 50 types of herbs. "We had 17 people full time last year, three of them women who would have been on welfare otherwise," Ms. Hetrick said.
The American Indians who once inhabited these woods knew intimately the properties of each growing thing. Yet the Forest Service, which requires that wildcrafters on public lands have permits, is still studying how much of the forest products can be harvested without harm.
Forest rangers and environmentalists worry that the lure of big money from top-dollar products like mushrooms is leading to over-harvesting -- much of it illegal -- and trampling that damages the forest floor.
"We're really at the very beginning here," said Yvonne Everett, an ecologist studying the potential of wildcrafting around Hay Fork. "We're very unsophisticated, and the most important piece is that the Native American knowledge here is about wiped out."
With Federal and private grants to aid communities hurt by logging cutbacks, farmers in Mad River are also experimenting with cultivating forest herbs, as on the acreage that 72-year-old Millie Pollard has planted mainly with echinacea, an herb that is said to bolster resistance to disease and whose seeds can bring more than $100 a pound.
The herb appears to be thriving, but Ms. Pollard said that if she were a bit more spry, she would be venturing into the woods to gather the stuff instead of trying to grow it.
"If I were young, I'd be head over heels into the wildcrafting," she said. "You're out, you're grubbing from daylight to dark, you're seeing all kinds of new places all the time."
For all the primitivist fun of it, researchers say, wildcrafting, like many agricultural occupations, is unlikely to provide much more than subsistence-level income for those who do the gathering. But the market could take off with improved processing and refrigeration.
In the short term, Ms. Everett said, wildcrafting "is not going to make a big difference."
"But in the long term," she said, "it's the direction we're going in, and we'll manage the forest more holistically, moving away from a lumber monoculture. In the long run, it's going to be economically very, very important to forest communities."
Wildcrafters like Mr. Myers are often in the woods and at conferences, learning what is what and -- as they put it -- making up for all those years when they could not see the forest for the trees.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRATS;
The President and His Party Seem Closer After Past Battles

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
The relationship between President Clinton and his fellow Democrats in the House has, from time to time, read like a case study in "Can this marriage be saved?"
There were bad feelings on both sides from the 1992 campaign, the 1993 budget battle, the 1994 health care debacle and various miscellaneous slights and slips in between. But last year's budget struggle and the approach of the election has, by many accounts, brought the two sides closer. 
 Democrats on Capitol Hill still have jitters, worried that the White House will act first and foremost to protect its own political interests. But they also recognize that to a large extent, their fates are linked.
"We're not talking about a traditional political marriage here at all," said Geoffrey Garin, a Democratic pollster. "This is much more about understanding where their interests are in common."
As Representative Bob Wise, Democrat of West Virginia, puts it, "While we have our differences and our different operating styles, we are lashed to one another."
To begin with, Democrats need a net gain of about 20 seats to reclaim control of the House, and a big, enthusiastic Democratic turnout for the Presidential campaign could help turn the tide in many of the more competitive districts. Mark Gersh, a Democratic analyst, said that would be particularly true in the Pacific Northwest, New York and parts of New England -- parts of the Democratic base where the President will do especially well if he is successful nationally.
The idea of Presidential coattails is often much maligned, but Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, the Connecticut Democrat, said, "I used to be Secretary of State in my state, and I know the numbers. Your fates are tied, no question about it."
Congressional Democrats also learned last fall just how valuable the Presidency can be in carrying their message; public opinion took a significant turn when Mr. Clinton took up the Democratic indictment of the Republican budget as too extreme and too stringent with Medicare, education and the environment.
"We worked for nine months to get the Medicare message out there," Mr. Wise said. "It was beginning to percolate, but when the President picked it up, it just flew."
Officials at the Democratic National Committee continue to meet regularly with House and Senate Democrats and the White House to coordinate their message.
They are also combining efforts on fund raising. Mr. Clinton and Vice President Gore are the House Democrats' best draws as they struggle to raise money as a minority for the first time in 40 years. "The President is doing everything that we've asked him to do," said Representative Martin Frost, chairman of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. "He did a New York event for us that raised somewhere between $1.5 and $1.9 million. He did an event for us in Washington that raised half a million."
That rapprochement stands in sharp contrast with the experience of 1994, when many Congressional Democrats felt they had paid a harsh price for the President's unpopularity and his handling of issues like health care and gays in the military. Dozens of Republicans ran campaign commercials of Democratic members metamorphosing into Mr. Clinton, and the President was considered a drag on the Democratic ticket in much of the country. Today, Mr. Clinton's political health is much improved.
For all of that, Democrats on Capitol Hill still worry. Many would like to see the President put more emphasis on the economic security issues that House Democrats hope to make the centerpiece of their campaigns. "Their reluctance is a source of some frustration," said one House Democratic strategist.
Big tactical differences could also evolve as the election approaches. For example, the Democrats need to hold on to some open seats in the conservatively realigning South, but it is entirely possible that the Presidential campaign will decide to write off some Deep South states like Alabama -- although at this stage, talk of writing off any state is anathema to both parties.
Finally, there is the painful memory of "triangulation" -- the strategy that many Congressional Democrats detected on the part of the White House last year that involves distancing the President from his own party on Capitol Hill, positioning him as the centrist broker between the Congressional Democrats and Republicans.
At the root of all these fears is the issue posed by one strategist close to Congressional Democrats: "There's a real tension between whether Bill Clinton is going to run to build a Democratic majority or run to re-elect himself. He feels very strongly about establishing himself as a 'New Democrat.' What he should also appreciate is that having a bully pulpit could also articulate a message for the whole party."
In the end, though, many Democrats argue that the Republicans will drive the White House and the Democrats on Capitol Hill together, whether they like it or not.
"There's a much better feeling than there was six months ago," said Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn. "As Republicans move to the extreme, the Democrats have much more in common. Having Gingrich as a foil has helped both Congressional Democrats and the President."

HEADLINE: Homecoming of Ethnic German Immigrants Sours

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: SOHREN, Germany

 BODY:
Emmi Schleicher arrived in Germany from her native Kazakstan six years ago and thought she had finally come home to the land her ancestors left over two centuries ago. Since then, she has learned a painful lesson.
As an ethnic German in Kazakstan, she said, she faced nationalist hostility among Kazaks who called her a foreigner. Now she confronts another kind of animosity from Germans who do not accept her as a German and who say she and others like her receive social benefits they do not deserve. 
 "In Kazakstan they said we were Germans and should go back to Germany," said Mrs. Schleicher, 32, who was a librarian in Almaty, Kazakstan, and collects admission at a public swimming pool in this small town in western Germany. "Now we are in Germany and people here curse us as 'the Russians.' "
She is not alone. Since the late 1980's, in one of Europe's greatest population shifts since the end of the cold war, more than a million ethnic Germans from the former Soviet Union have taken advantage of German laws permitting them to reclaim full citizenship, and thus automatic access to Germany's bountiful welfare system that provides unemployment pay, housing allowances and state pensions.
But their arrival has coincided with economic straits for many Germans, who are facing record unemployment at a time when the abundance of social benefits is being called into question. A result has been a greater readiness among Germans to attribute their woes to their immigrant kin, and an equal readiness among politicians to play to those passions for votes.
The animosity threatens Germany's social fabric with perhaps the most emotional collision of identities since neo-Nazis rampaged against foreigners, particularly the country's two million Turks, after reunification in 1990.
"Burning houses have shown that the readiness to accept people is not without limits," Oskar Lafontaine, leader of the opposition Social Democrats, said, referring to attacks on foreigners elsewhere in Germany. With three important state elections scheduled for March 24, he is campaigning for limits on immigration by ethnic Germans.
The hostility has a particular twist here in Sohren, a town south of Coblenz where many of the 1,200 immigrant Germans have moved into apartments vacated when some 15,000 United States troops and their dependents pulled out from the nearby Hahn air base two years ago.
"For 40 years we lived in good, neighborly relations with the Americans," said Heinz Michel, Sohren's Mayor for the last 22 years. "But right now, all these people moving in at once is just too much."
For many of the new arrivals, the hostility has come as a shock after the upheaval and persecution their families faced since 1941, when Stalin banished them to Siberia and Central Asia to punish them for Hitler's invasion of the Soviet Union.
Throughout the cold war, German leaders routinely campaigned for the right of ethnic Germans to return home. German governments even paid millions of dollars to the dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu to allow ethnic Germans to leave Romania.
West Germany even made it a constitutional right for ethnic Germans to acquire full German citizenship, even though it had been 200 years since the czars invited Germans to Russia, where they were prized for their agricultural skills and organization.
The end of the cold war changed the equation.
German reunification cost taxpayers hundreds of billions of dollars. An economic slowdown added to unemployment and strained the state's ability to finance pensions and other social benefits. The opening of Eastern Europe's frontiers threatened Germany with an unchecked flow of poor migrants. Hostility to outsiders inspired the German authorities to enact a string of laws to keep the numbers of foreigners -- and ethnic Germans -- within tight limits.
Since Jan. 1, 1993, the number of immigrant Germans accepted in Germany has been limited by law to 220,000 a year. And now Mr. Lafontaine wants that number halved, a demand that has struck a responsive chord among many Germans. One recent opinion survey said about 70 percent of Germans support his campaign.
The end of the cold war also meant a drastic reduction in the number of American forces in Germany. At the height of the cold war, American military personnel stationed in Germany numbered around 250,000. Now the total is 76,000.
In Sohren, where the original inhabitants number some 2,000, the American presence injected thousands of jobs and $180 million a year into the local economy. When the last Americans left two years ago, Mayor Michel said, "we became poor."
The arrival of the immigrant ethnic Germans, by contrast, has produced only a sense of division and strain. In the area surrounding Sohren, immigrant German children already outnumber the children of the original inhabitants in some schools. Five new kindergartens have been built, and resentment has grown.
"They have a completely different mentality," Mayor Michel said of the immigrant Germans. "They have trouble with the language. Most of them have no work. The living standards we have are totally strange to them. We have no jobs to offer them."
Neither do they shop, visit the bars or spend money as the Americans did, people at several stores on the town's main street said.
Mayor Michel said that when Mr. Lafontaine brought the issue into the public spotlight, "he destroyed the only little bit of reconciliation that had happened in this town."
Indeed, in other places where immigrant ethnic Germans are housed in former NATO barracks until they find homes, German officials worry that disaffected young men among them, speaking no German, are rapidly forming a crime-prone underclass that will arouse even greater German hostility.
In her new three-level house that she shares with 10 other people from two generations of in-laws, Mrs. Schleicher does not see it that way.
"Our people are disappointed, upset, confused," she said, speaking only slightly accented German. "They are people who have lost themselves. Here, they thought they would find a home where they wouldn't be discriminated against. But they have been disappointed."
Her father-in-law, Johannes Schleicher, 69, a former truck driver, seemed to agree. In 1941, he said, he and his family were ordered out of the autonomous republic set up for ethnic Germans in the Volga region and sent to Siberia. They built a house, he said, but then the family was sent on to Kazakstan. They built a house there, too.
Now, propelled by anti-German sentiment in Kazakstan and lured by the better economic prospects here, he has come to Germany. So the family pooled their pensions, their wages and their own labor to build yet again. "Where am I supposed to go?" Mr. Schleicher said. "Back to the Volga? The Russians don't want us there."
Such was Germany's desire in the early 1990's to avert massive immigration of ethnic Germans from the former Soviet Union that Bonn offered tens of millions of dollars to Moscow to rebuild its onetime republic on the Volga. That plan foundered on the refusal of Russians now living there to give up their land and the reluctance of ethnic Germans to return.
According to official statistics, the immigrant ethnic Germans as a social group are notably younger than average in Germany's aging society, meaning that they draw proportionately less in pensions and contribute more to the work-force paying social security contributions.
At the same time, the statistics suggest that unemployment last year among immigrant ethnic Germans, while disproportionately high in some areas like Sohren, was lower than the average in states like Baden-Wurttemberg, where the most contested of the March 24 state elections is taking place.
In Mrs. Schleicher's neat living room, with its new furniture, its television and a garden gnome as decoration, the perception is different.
Sure, the older people said, they are drawing pensions of around $900 a month -- 30 percent less than the German average -- to which they have made no direct contribution. But they said their children wanted to work and pay their dues, even with jobs other Germans would not look at, and well below what they were qualified to do in the Soviet Union.
"People say we've brought unemployment here," said Olga Borge, another immigrant. "But the Germans who come here from Kazakstan want to work. If there's work and they can get it, they do it, whatever it is. Sometimes, it makes you weep."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Looking to San Francisco Voters To Send Message to Steinbrenner

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
There are two enormously appealing arguments for the proposed 42,000-seat baseball park at San Francisco's China Basin: one, a 335-foot home run down the right-field line will splash into the bay, and two, the $255 million park will be built entirely with private money. If voters clear the way by granting a zoning exemption on Tuesday, perhaps we can also consider the plan a message to New York: Let George Steinbrenner pay for his own sandbox.
In fact, the Giants' president, Peter A. Magowan, recently told a business meeting in San Francisco that other owners who "conned money out of the cities that they're in . . . and those who are planning to con money" were rooting against the plan. 
 Of course, Magowan has his back to the water. Even under threat of the team's leaving, San Francisco voters have rejected -- four times -- stadium plans that would cost them money. The club had one foot in Tampa, Fla., in 1992, when Magowan, an owner of the Safeway stores, put together a group that bought the team and kept it in Candlestick Park.
He also put together a China Basin coalition that included a prominent gay liberal female politician, a conservative straight male politician and a leading black clergyman. Winning is still no sure thing.
"Nothing comes easily in San Francisco," said Magowan. "It's a skeptical, fragmented city. It took 20 years to decide to build the Golden Gate Bridge. But after the fabulous success of ball parks in Baltimore, Cleveland and Denver, people can see that something can be good for the economy, which appeals to nonsports fans, and still be nice for fans."
Maybe. Economists like Andrew Zimbalist of Smith College insist that teams merely divert entertainment dollars and don't really bring in torrents of fresh cash, as owners, including Magowan, claim. However, economists like Roger G. Noll of Stanford say that teams do boost a community psychologically, and may stimulate other investment.
The edifice complex is the disorder of the season. In Cincinnati, the Citizens for a Major League Future asserted that Schott City would be so much bratwurst without the Reds, and last week won public financing of new baseball and football stadiums. In Detroit, the battle still rages over replacing historic Tiger Stadium with a modern ball park that will supposedly revive downtown and certainly make the owner, a pizza king, even richer. Dispatches also keep arriving from Boston, Seattle, Milwaukee and Minneapolis.
The Giants' approach is interesting, both financially and socially. The club began romancing the electorate in a highly enlightened way, sending players out on charitable missions, refurbishing inner-city fields and, most notably, becoming the first major professional sports organization to identify itself with the battle against AIDS. Players wore iron-on red ribbons and game proceeds went to research.
"That was something the city and baseball never saw before," said Magowan, "macho ballplayers with their arms around people with AIDS."
The financing model is based on successes in other sports. The first $100 million will be raised by selling concessions, the better seats and even the right to name the stadium. (Magowan is quick to remind purists that Wrigley is also a brand of chewing gum.) Many seats will be one-backside condos; an owner will be legally obligated to maintain the seat by paying the season-ticket price, but is free to sell it.
Once a guaranteed income stream is established, Magowan expects the rest of the stadium cost to be easily raised from lenders.
Meanwhile, as the opening of the baseball season looms with Steinbrenner's deadline for a stadium deal, the Yankees seem poised to scuttle down to a West Side Manhattan site or sideways to New Jersey. In either case, city or state taxpayer money will be used to help Steinbrenner make more money from luxury boxes, parking and concessions.
Comparing New York to San Francisco is useless, but comparing Steinbrenner to an owner who at least recognizes that community commitment is good business seems like a valid exercise. Magowan -- who, by the way, is no maverick, as he is on the owners' strategic planning committee and thinks the Fox TV alliance will bring the sport innovative publicity -- has said that a baseball team is like a public utility. It's a concept that leads to this: If we can demand moral standards from players and spectators, we certainly need their role models -- our most visible entrepreneurs -- to show us the way to waterfront property without stealing from the school, hospital, police and fire funds.
There are many reasons to wish the Giants a victory on Tuesday, one of them provincial -- as Steinbrenner comes barking and whining with his hand out again, we can tell him this time to put that hand in his own pocket first, or go splash in the bay.

HEADLINE: Fighting Poverty Programs;
Hartford Faces Vote to Bar New Nonprofit Services

BYLINE: By JONATHAN RABINOVITZ 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, March 23

 BODY:
While advocates for the poor say that more social-service programs mean more people turning their lives around, city leaders here have a different perspective: they say that more social service programs drain the economy, breed dependency and mean more poor people moving to Hartford, where one in four people is already on welfare.
Accordingly, the City Council has taken what many consider a hard-line approach to stem the growth of poverty: a six-month moratorium on all new homeless shelters, rehabilitation homes and other treatment or social-service centers. 
 With thousands of middle-class people having left Hartford in recent years and roughly one in 30 buildings abandoned, city officials complain that Hartford is being taken over by what one official calls "Poverty Inc., the social service industry." Although no one knows the total number of social-service agencies operating in the city, Hartford, which has one-fifth of the region's population, serves three-fifths of its needy in residential programs alone.
"We have more than our fair share," said Mayor Mike Peters, who described his city, the state capital, as "the dumping ground for every project for the needy."
The moratorium, which was approved last year, and a bill to broaden it, which faces a vote on Monday, have led to protests from service groups that say they are already struggling to meet the needs of the city's poor. With no definitive surveys, they dispute officials' claims that the poor are gravitating from other areas to take advantage of Hartford.
"I agree that it's time for other communities to step up to the plate, but that doesn't make it right for Hartford to erect barriers to people who need to be served," said Nancy Hroneck, a lawyer with the Legal Aid Society of Hartford County.
The proposal comes as Hartford -- a city of 124,000 and the home of some of the nation's largest insurance companies -- is struggling to remain the prosperous hub that it was for more than two centuries. Known for its generous social services, the city has recently made it tougher to get welfare benefits and is questioning its traditional role as the region's social service center.
Hartford is certainly not alone in adopting strong measures to restrict the poor. Cities across the country, including Hartford, have barred panhandling and loitering. A recent study by the National Law Center on Homelessness and Poverty found that at least 30 cities have used zoning and building codes to exclude service agencies.
Last year, Huntsville, Ala., used its code to close two shelters. St. Paul limited daytime centers for the homeless to onlythe heaviest commercial districts. Middletown, Conn., has a moratorium on mental health and substance abuse programs.
Two years ago, New York State stopped developing programs that offered extended stays to homeless families, and several New York City community boards are seeking a moratorium on group homes or shelters. It is unlikely that New York City could adopt a sweeping measure like Hartford's. "I don't doubt that some in the administration would love that kind of approach, but it's not transferable to the reality of New York," said Councilman Stephen DiBrienza, a Democrat of Brooklyn who heads the Council's General Welfare Committee.
A moratorium, he noted, would clash with court orders that require New York City to find shelter for anyone in need. He added that the scope of New York's problems made such a broad approach impractical.
Indeed, Hartford's approach goes beyond what most cities have tried.
In January 1995, the Hartford Council passed a resolution blocking new special-needs buildings until there was a "regional cooperative solution." In November, it imposed a six-month moratorium on new rehabilitation homes, transient lodgings or centers for "welfare and charitable purposes."
Now, the Council is seeking to extend the limit another six months and expand it to include community centers and medical and health service programs, like support centers for people with AIDS or mental illnesses. The Council is scheduled to vote on the new proposal on Monday.
The Connecticut Civil Liberties Union has warned that the plan will not survive a lawsuit, saying it discriminates against the disabled, like the mentally ill. When Peekskill, N.Y., blocked new housing for the mentally ill, a Federal judge rejected the city's argument that it was a "dumping ground," saying that "past efforts do not create grounds for refusing to provide any more."
So far, no lawsuit has emerged in Hartford, and while advocates say the moratorium has had a chilling effect, no agency has had a proposal turned down because of the law.
Deputy Mayor Frances Sanchez, the original moratorium sponsor, says the new measure is intended to allow for time to develop a more thoughtful approach on social services. But more than a year after the first moratorium was imposed, the city has made little progress on new guidelines, and advocates for the poor worry that it is merely a tactic to drive the needy out of Hartford.
"It sends the message that poor people are the problem," said Mary McAtee, executive director of the Connecticut Coalition to End Homelessness.
 
From Yuppie Haven To 'Poverty Inc.'
On a recent afternoon, Ms. Sanchez and Councilman Art Feltman, both Democrats who have championed the moratorium, offered a tour of South Green, a neighborhood a few blocks from downtown that was once an emerging yuppie haven.
In the space of a few blocks were the empty windows of several upscale restaurants that had closed in the last year and a row of abandoned buildings. Condominiums going for $130,000 in the 1980's cannot be sold for half, they said.
The main presence in that area now, Ms. Sanchez said, is what she calls "Poverty Inc., the social service industry" -- two homeless shelters, a check-in center for just-released prisoners, a health clinic and a methadone clinc. "They're spreading like kudzu throughout the city," Mr. Feltman said.
Ms. Sanchez shook her head. "You constantly see new faces around here," she said. "We have enough programs. They say they promote self-sufficiency. That's bull."
It is not clear whether the decline of South Green is a result of nonprofit social service agencies, some of which have been there for years. Foes of the moratorium note that many middle-class Hartford residents moved to the suburbs when real estate prices fell in the late 1980's. They also say that too many one-bedroom apartments were built in Hartford and that the city has lost at least 7,000 jobs since 1992.
Statistics are sketchy on whether the poor from elsewhere are overrunning Hartford. Social service agencies say most of their cases are Hartford residents. A survey of 13 nonprofit groups by the Hispanic Health Council, a local nonprofit group, found that 90 percent of their clients were Hartford residents.
Irene Glasser, a sociologist at Eastern Connecticut State University who is studying Hartford's homeless, said that one shelter's records showed that 68 percent of the families had been living in Hartford more than a year. Another shelter's records indicated that 73 percent gave Hartford as their last address.
Service providers say it is natural that some poor people would gravitate to the city. They note that Hartford has better access to public transportation and many inexpensive rental units. It is a city's role to help all these people, advocates say.
"Whether they live here for one week or 28 years, they are still residents of Hartford," said Elizabeth Toledo, the coordinator of a drug treatment program for women at the Hispanic Health Council.
Cities around the country worry about bearing too heavy a social service burden, yet Hartford's problem seems more acute.
According to the Census Bureau, Hartford is one of the smallest of the nation's 522 urban centers, and it does not have as broad a tax base as larger cities. To further complicate matters, Connecticut has no county government to share the costs of services, as in most other states.
In his 1993 book "Cities Without Suburbs" (Johns Hopkins), David Rusk ranked Hartford second in the country in the poverty gap between a city and its region, a situation he said would ultimately lead to the city's decline. The percentage of Hartford families below the poverty line was four times as high as in surrounding towns, he wrote.
In the 29 towns in the capital region, Hartford has all the AIDS residences, the only shelter for battered women, all three methadone clinics, the only check-in centers for released convicts, and four of every five emergency shelter beds.
An inventory of residential programs by Hartford's Planning Department showed an increase to 52 from 42 over the last two years, about 25 percent. This growth, officials say, imposes a fiscal burden by turning millions of dollars worth of land into tax-exempt property.
Some Are Calling Issue a Scapegoat
Advocates for the poor counter that the small nonprofit groups are being used as a scapegoat for the city's broader budgetary troubles. They say their groups create jobs and improve the property they own.
And although they do agree that Hartford officials have identified the problem -- an unfair distribution of services -- they say the moratorium is the wrong solution.
"I don't think this is going to enlighten the suburbs," said Laura Thornton, director of Peter's Retreat, a home for people with AIDS.
The moratorium also comes while the state and city are cutting welfare, and advocates for the poor say there is a shortage of services.
In recent months, St. Elizabeth House, which offers housing for people with AIDS, support services for the mentally ill, an emergency shelter and a longer-term residential program for the homeless, has seen the demand grow. Its transitional program has its longest waiting list ever, and this winter, the emergency shelter had to turn people away.
"You're going to have to have more services, because the demand for services is growing," Pat Kohnke, who runs several of St. Elizabeth's programs, said.
Still, the debate is not rooted in the need for services as much as the philosophy behind them. On the one side are moratorium supporters who say the services perpetuate dependency; on the other are those who see them as a force for good.
At a public hearing this month, John Bonelli, a former City Council candidate who has led the social-service advocates, testified: "I am shocked by those who keep arguing that these are destroying the city. They are building community."
A few days before the hearing, Councilman Feltman dismissed that argument. "You've got an infinite demand for services, and there will never be enough," he said. "If you served everyone from Hartford, there will be others from outside. We'll never run out of clients."

HEADLINE: Businesses Should Be Loyal To Employees, Clinton Says

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: CINCINNATI, March 23

 BODY:
Harking back to the workplace reforms of the Progressive Era, President Clinton came to this old industrial state today to urge American companies to share success with their workers in the form of better benefits and training and announced that he would hold a conference in Washington to showcase good companies next month.
Mr. Clinton used a speech at Xavier University here and similar remarks in his weekly radio address to the nation to expand on his recent comments on the need for greater corporate responsibility to help workers adjust to a rapidly changing economy. It is the latest of a series of issues -- from violence in Hollywood to school uniforms -- on which Mr. Clinton has acted as a kind of civic cheerleader in chief. 
 "Let me be clear: the most fundamental responsibility for any business is to make a profit, to create jobs and incomes by competing and growing," Mr. Clinton said in the radio address. "We recognize, too, that not every business can afford to do more than worry about the bottom line, especially a lot of small businesses. But many of America's most successful businesses have shown that you can do well by doing right by employees and their families."
Today he outlined five ways that what he calls enlightened businesses, in mostly voluntary cooperation with workers and the Government, should help improve employees' lives: by being "friendly to families" by offering flexible work schedules and child care, by giving better health and pension benefits, by offering improved education and training, by working "in partnership" with employees to cope with fluctuations in profits and productivity and by insuring a safe workplace.
It was no accident that Mr. Clinton chose to deliver such a message here today. In 1992, he carried Ohio with 40 percent of the vote, with 38 percent going to George Bush and 21 percent to Ross Perot. Ohio has 21 electoral votes and, by every standard, it is shaping up as one of a handful of Midwestern industrial states where this year's contest could well be decided.
With Patrick J. Buchanan on the campaign trail complaining about the economic dislocations of global trade, the White House is determined not to let anxieties about the economy -- the issue that Mr. Clinton rode into office in 1992 -- boomerang on him this year. Accordingly, on a one-day trip to Cincinnati and Columbus to raise money for the Democratic National Committee and the Ohio Democratic Party, Mr. Clinton took the chance to reassure voters that he still feels their pain.
But despite calls by some advisers, like Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich, to reward companies who treat their employees well with new tax breaks, Mr. Clinton made it clear that his approach remains almost completely oratorical.
"The Government can't make all companies do this," he said here. But he added that companies should ask themselves, "are there things the Government could do -- not to make me do this, because you can't freeze the future -- but at least to create a climate in which it would be easier for me to do this and still do well."
White House aides said that details of the corporate conference remained to be worked out but that, at a minimum, a sampling of chief executives would be there, perhaps joined by labor leaders and students. Today, Mr. Clinton praised innovative programs by companies like Procter & Gamble.
"We're going to talk about not how we can complain about the disruptions the global economy is bringing to America, but how we can do something about it to guarantee more economic security to the American families that are out there doing the best they can and working hard," he said.

HEADLINE: Criminal Case Is Ruled Out In Collapse

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
The Manhattan District Attorney's office has concluded that it cannot file criminal charges against the owners of a Harlem apartment building that partially collapsed a year ago, killing three people.
After a yearlong investigation, prosecutors have decided that even among the most abused buildings, structural failure like that at the Harlem building that collapsed is so rare that it cannot be viewed as a predictable result of neglect. Therefore, they said, owners cannot be held criminally responsible. 
 "We had to conclude that the collapse was not reasonably foreseeable," the legal standard for prosecution, said Daniel Castleman, chief of investigations in District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau's office. Even if the owners had ordered a structural inspection of the building, at 142 West 140th Street, before it fell, he said, "They would have found structural problems, but probably not serious enough to force evacuation of the building and indicate imminent collapse."
Since most buildings collapse as a result of improper new construction or demolition work, not merely age or neglect, the decision is unlikely to apply to many cases.
After years of neglect and thousands of tenant complaints, the six-story building on West 140th Street, which had stood for 69 years, simply crumbled.
The outer wall gave way on the morning of March 21, 1995, pitching sleeping residents and their belongings to the ground amid a rain of bricks. Three people were killed, several others were injured and all of the tenants were left homeless. Mr. Castleman said the failure was caused by a weakening over time of a stone and mortar wall that formed the eastern foundation of the building, possibly because the mortar was improperly mixed.
With the District Attorney's office bowing out, the city will resume a contempt-of-court action against the owners, Marcus I. Lehman and Morris Wolfson, seeking jail terms and $1 million in fines for their failure to comply with court orders to fix several buildings they owned, said Harold M. Shultz, deputy commissioner of the Department of Housing Preservation and Development. That suit had been filed before the building collapsed, but it was put on hold pending the outcome of Mr. Morgenthau's investigation.
The maximum jail term the two could face for contempt is six months, but Mr. Shultz noted that the sentence is usually less. He said he did not disagree with Mr. Morgenthau's conclusions, but he added, "It would be better if we could get more under these circumstances, because these circumstances are particularly egregious."
Just after the collapse, prosecutors said the owners might face charges of criminally negligent homicide, a felony with a maximum sentence of 1 1/3 to 4 years in prison.
Former residents of the building and relatives of the victims were taken aback by Mr. Morgenthau's decision.
"These men ought to go to jail, and I was waiting to go to court to testify against them," said Roslyn Wiley-Haughton, a tenant of the building who now lives in the Bronx. She disagreed strongly with the District Attorney's conclusion. "It was foreseeable," she said. "There was evidence all over the place that the building was falling down."
When she was told that there would be no prosecution, Catherine Baylor, the sister of Ozzie Payne, a 76-year-old woman who was killed in the collapse, exclaimed, "What?" and then began to cry. "I can't even tell you how this makes me feel," she said.
Maurice Sieradzki, a lawyer who had sued the owners several times on behalf of tenants for a variety of problems in the building, said the result of the District Attorney's investigation was unfortunate but legally correct. "I did not see any criminal culpability," he said.
The owners, Mr. Wolfson and Mr. Lehman, could not be reached for comment. Their lawyer, Benjamin Brafman, said that they "have been fully exonerated."
Several independent engineers had said shortly after the collapse that the conditions described by tenants could have been warnings of impending disaster. But Mr. Castleman said that an engineering firm specializing in building failures, which was hired by the District Attorney's office, concluded that there was probably no way to predict what happened.
In connection with the investigation, the Housing Department looked through decades' worth of records of building collapses and found that virtually all were caused by improper new construction or demolition work. Mr. Shultz said that "you had to go back to the late 1960's" to find a case like the one in Harlem where a building simply crumbled.
For instance, he said, the collapse on March 18 of part of a building on East 54th Street probably occurred because of recent construction work on the building next door.
Last September, the company owned by Mr. Lehman and Mr. Wolfson, Mount Wilson Realty, sold all of its apartment properties -- including the site on 140th Street, where what remained of the building was demolished -- to Baruch Singer, owner of a company that had managed the building before it collapsed. City officials said there were 12 properties in all, 9 in Harlem and 3 on West 108th Street between Central Park West and Manhattan Avenue.
TRW-REDI Property Data, a real estate research firm, found records of eight of the sales, showing that Mount Wilson Realty received $2.4 million for the buildings, well below the more than $4.8 million it had paid for them in 1987 and 1988.
At the time of the collapse, there were 337 housing code violations registered against the building on 140th Street, 56 considered potentially life-threatening though not related to the collapse. Housing inspectors had logged thousands of violations in the building since Mount Wilson bought it. Inspection reports read like a catalogue of decay, listing rat infestation, floors that caved in, leaking pipes, lack of heat and gaps between floors and walls, among other problems. Housing officials said that even before it collapsed, they considered the building to be unusually bad.
But Mr. Brafman contended that many violations were counted two and three times, and that in any case many were the tenants' fault. "In a high-crime neighborhood, it is simply impossible to keep the buildings in a completely violation-free condition," he said.
Though housing inspectors found many signs of structural problems, which were noted in their reports, they did not pass that information on to the Department of Buildings, as they are required to do. Since the collapse, all the city's housing inspectors have been given training in recognizing hints of structural distress, a program that Mr. Shultz said had resulted in dozens of warnings to the Department of Buildings.
People in the real estate business have said that Mr. Lehman and Mr. Wolfson were amateurs who paid inflated prices for Harlem real estate, hoping that the gentrification boom of the 1980's would keep moving uptown. The partners could not keep pace with their costs, and when the recession hit, their chances of recouping their investments evaporated.
Mr. Sieradzki, the lawyer, said he did not personally know Mr. Wolfson but had concluded that Mr. Lehman was "basically a decent guy" who was in over his head in the real estate business.

HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S LEADER WINS ITS ELECTION AND A MANDATE

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 23

 BODY:
President Lee Teng-hui swept to an election victory today that exceeded all expectations and served as a forceful rebuke to mainland China. This island's voters gave Mr. Lee a strong mandate in their first democratic balloting for President.
Final results showed that 54 percent of the nearly 11 million Taiwanese who cast ballots voted for Mr. Lee. His tally was more than double that of his closest challenger in a field of four candidates. 
 A strong sense of crisis over mainland China's threatening series of military exercises apparently caused significant numbers of voters to defect from Taiwan's largest opposition group, the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, to Mr. Lee's camp.
In Beijing, the official New China News Agency interpreted the election results as a sign that the voters of Taiwan opposed the idea of separation from the mainland. [Page 16.]
Mr. Lee's efforts to create a more independent international image for Taiwan have given him a broad appeal among voters of conflicting ideologies, including those who would like Mr. Lee to dump the island's longstanding commitment to a "one China" policy in favor of independence.
"This was a plebiscite without the label of plebiscite, and I hope that China got the message," said Parris H. Chang, a pro-independence member of Taiwan's legislature. "And the message is that Taiwan does not want to reunify with the mainland."
But other people watching the election closely said Mr. Lee would take the mandate and seek a new dialogue with Beijing in the hope of reducing military tensions.
Those tensions caused the Clinton Administration to send two aircraft carrier battle groups to waters near Taiwan to signal China that it should not interfere in Taiwan's democratic process.
[In Washington, a White House spokeswoman, Mary Ellen Glyn, said, "We congratulate the people of Taiwan on their first election." She added: "We hope to see tensions in the Taiwan Straits greatly reduced in the days to come."
[But American officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said that no formal congratulations would be offered, because the United States does not have diplomatic relations with Taiwan.]
Mr. Lee had said before the vote that the next president's main job would be to work on cross-strait relations, and many took that to mean that Mr. Lee was preparing a post-election effort to cool tensions.
But the 73-year-old leader has given no clue as to whether he is willing to make substantive concessions to Beijing, like moderating Taiwan's drive for a seat at the United Nations. Beijing considers that effort to be part of an unacceptable "two China" strategy.
The pro-independence candidate, Peng Ming-min, 72, a longtime dissident who was only allowed to return to Taiwan from exile in 1992, turned out the poorest showing the opposition has made in the last three islandwide elections. The Democratic Progressive Party chairman, Shih Min-teh, announced his resignation at a news conference tonight, saying, "Someone has to take the responsibility" for the loss.
Two other tickets, headed by Lin Yang-kang and Chen Li-an, both breakaway members of Mr. Lee's governing Nationalist Party, polled 15 percent and 10 percent, respectively.
In a victory appearance at his campaign headquarters in downtown Taipei, Mr. Lee greeted a cheering and flag-waving crowd and said: "This is a historic moment. The door of democracy is now completely open."
Speaking in turn in Mandarin Chinese, English and his native Taiwanese dialect, Mr. Lee made only one reference to the campaign of military pressure mounted by mainland China during the last 10 months to weaken his hold on power.
"In this very difficult and dangerous moment with threats coming from the outside, we have completed our mission," he said.
The election was cheered in other parts of the region.
"This is a proud day for all Chinese people around the world," said Martin Lee, head of Hong Kong's Democratic Party. "It is the first time in China's history that a leader is elected on a one-person, one-vote basis on Chinese soil."
During the day, a crush of voters streamed to polling places registering a turnout that surpassed 76 percent, election officials said.
The results reflected a remarkable response to Mr. Lee's plea for a mandate to open a new round of negotiations with Beijing over Taiwan's future.
"From now on we should focus on economic development and strengthen the cross-strait economic and trade ties and cooperation," said Taiwan's Economics Minister, Chiang Pin-kung. Taiwan's central bank governor, Sheu Yuan-dong, also sought to reassure the island's investors and business community that pressure on the value of the Taiwan dollar caused by the flight of capital in recent weeks would return to normal.
Some analysts said that the true measure of Taiwan's rebuke to Beijing's Communist Party leadership could be seen in adding Mr. Lee's and Mr. Peng's tallies together, which represented 75 percent of the votes cast.
"The message from 75 percent of the voters is that what the mainland tried to accomplish by coercion and the threat of force, failed badly," said Mr. Chang, the legislator.
While Mr. Lee's vote tallies were strong throughout Taiwan, his total in this capital city was among the weakest, at 39 percent. Mr. Lin and his running mate, former Prime Minister Hau Pei-tsun, registered their strongest showing in Taipei, with nearly 25 percent of the vote.
By contrast, in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, a hotbed of independence sentiment, Mr. Lee took nearly 51 percent of the ballots and Mr. Lin took only 13 percent.
Appearing on Taiwan television tonight from a studio in Washington, the former American Ambassador to China, James R. Lilley, said that the election would serve to make China recognize "that power does not grow out of the barrel of a gun," as Mao Zedong once said, "it grows out of the ballot box." But Mr. Lilley added that he believed that Mr. Lee is now well-equipped with a mandate to "start talking to China again and get the relationship going again" in order to reduce military tensions in the area.
In conceding defeat, all of the other candidates congratulated Mr. Lee and his running mate, Lien Chan. Though deep personal animosities were visible during the campaign, each sought to take the high road, although Hsieh Chang-ting, the Democratic Progressives' vice presidential candidate, seemed to be reminding the winning ticket of its obligation to pro-independence voters who crossed over.
"We hope the people who got elected will not betray the people who voted for them," he said. Less than a week ago, Mr. Hsieh reminded voters that President Lee had referred to himself as Moses last year and had promised to lead the people of Taiwan out of the "red" sea, meaning a sea dominated by China.
Mr. Hsieh had warned voters in the pro-independence party not to cross over to support Mr. Lee because the defections might go to Mr. Lee's head.
"Lee Teng-hui thinks he's Moses right now, but if he gets a mandate, he will think he is God," Mr. Hsieh said.
But it seems that many voters did not take this advice.
"Of course I voted for Lee Teng-hui," said Chen Bo-jui, a 42-year-old businessman, after he cast his ballot in midmorning. "He is a strong leader, and we have to be strong in order to talk to mainland China. Otherwise, they will just tell us what to do."

HEADLINE: From a Defeated Ex-Leader, a Warning

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 23

 BODY:
If there was a big loser in today's presidential election, it was Hau Pei-tsun.
Even as he sought voters' acceptance in his effort to defeat President Lee Teng-hui by running as the vice presidential candidate on an opposing ticket, Mr. Hau, a 77-year-old former Prime Minister, had come to symbolize "mainlander" domination of Taiwan. 
 As a young general, Mr. Hau had helped to establish the authoritarian rule of the Republic of China in its home in exile on Taiwan, serving as chief military aide to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in the 1960's, and then as Defense Minister and Chief of Staff of Taiwan's military forces.
To millions of native-born Taiwanese, though they share the ethnic Chinese background of the mainlanders, Mr. Hau and the Nationalists have always carried the taint of occupiers, whose dream of reunification with the mainland they have never fully accepted.
Neither have they accepted Mr. Hau's presence on the political stage.
Mr. Hau has already been ejected from the governing Nationalist Party, after losing a power struggle to Mr. Lee in December. Taiwan's political humorists have enjoyed twittering in recent weeks that if Mr. Hau's New Party ticket led by Lin Yang-kang were to win, he would set himself up as shadow president.
Speaking in a 90-minute interview this morning after he had cast his ballot in the race that President Lee won decisively, Mr. Hau spoke openly of his deep sense of betrayal by the native-born Mr. Lee.
At various times he referred to the 73-year-old President as a "traitor," a "liar," a "cheat" and a "dictator," and he warned that Mr. Lee's victory would usher in a period of sustained conflict with mainland China that could wreck Taiwan's economy and draw the United States into a larger confrontation with Beijing.
"I was the first one who discovered that Mr. Lee really favors Taiwan independence in his mind," he said, though the President has never publicly endorsed a separation. And now that Beijing has become convinced of the same thing, he added, "This Taiwan independence movement is actually encouraging nationalism on the mainland."
During the presidential campaign, nothing undermined Mr. Hau's credibility as much as Beijing's use of military force to intimidate voters, subjecting him to the charge that he and other mainlanders were "apologists" for Beijing's bullying tactics.
Mr. Hau just smiles when he hears the charge and moves on to what still concerns him: that during Mr. Lee's new four-year term the tension with the mainland "will not be eased."
He said he fears that the mainland will try to strangle the island militarily, and that it would not be easy to defend Taiwan against that strategy, even with American naval power.
"As a military man, I believe it is not necessary for Beijing to prepare an amphibious assault against Taiwan to do harm," he said.
"I estimate that Beijing's missile tests were designed to demonstrate the capability of using missiles and submarines to mount a blockade against Taiwan. And once those tests last more than six months, it will do serious harm and undermine the economic development of Taiwan."
Mr. Hau, who gained recognition by his defense of Little Quemoy Island during a 44-day shelling engagement with mainland Chinese forces in 1958, said the Clinton Administration's "show of force" in the waters near Taiwan "has only raised the temperature between the two sides and will only serve to irritate Beijing further."
Mr. Hau said his understanding of history and of the use of military power are causing his alarm.
In nearly 2,000 years of Chinese history, China's emperors have fought to hold its diverse territories together, Mr. Hau said, and if Beijing were to lose Taiwan to an independence movement, it would only incite people in other regions under its control -- the Tibetans, the herders of Inner Mongolia and the Muslims of the Xingjiang region -- to seek their own independence.
A rush toward reunification is not the answer, he said, and would only force Beijing to advance its own schedule for reunification and risk conflict.
"Taiwan is part of China, but, of course, that doesn't mean we are part of the People's Republic of China," he said. "Once the mainland sets a timetable for reunification, that is a disaster for the Taiwanese."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
You, Too, Can Balance the Federal Budget

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ANYBODY can balance the Federal budget over seven years. I did it in a couple of hours.
This is all it required: 
 1. The hubris to make crucial policy judgments about matters I know absolutely nothing about (what the consequences would be, say, of reducing the number of Navy aircraft carriers to 10 from 12).
2. The willingness to raise other people's taxes (those who drive a lot) and reduce Federal benefits I never expect to have (farm-price supports).
3. The determination to maintain the tax breaks (mortgage interest deduction) and Government subsidies (mass transit) that I enjoy.
4. The ability to make the decisions by myself without having to strike compromises with people (my family and friends, to say nothing of people who live across town or across the country) who have interests, needs and views different from mine.
5. The knowledge that (unlike the politicians who have been unable to agree on a budget plan) I never have to run for re-election.
 
 
 
Billion Here, There
 I used a game called Debtbusters 2002 developed by the Concord Coalition, a nonpartisan organization that promotes a balanced budget (202-467-6222). It lists dozens of deficit-reduction options that President Clinton and Congress have considered in four areas: domestic spending, national security spending, taxes and entitlements. The player is supplied with brief arguments for and against each option and the amount of spending that would be saved (or revenue gained or lost, in the case of tax changes) if the option is selected.
The object is to check off options that add up to $850 billion, enough, the authors of the game say, to balance the budget in seven years.
The best place to start is benefit programs, called entitlements, since that category accounts for two-thirds of all Federal spending. There are two main types: those like Social Security and Medicare that are available to the elderly regardless of their means and those like welfare, Medicaid and food stamps for the poor.
I decided to spare the poor and go after the elderly, whose benefits have risen most rapidly in recent years (see No. 5, above).
Big bucks can be saved ($281 billion) by making benefits like Social Security and Medicare subject to the income tax to the extent they exceed an individual's contributions. Other hits on old people: Hold the annual cost of living increase in Social Security benefits to half a percentage point below the rate of inflation ($59.7 billion); gradually raise the Social Security retirement age ($72.6 billion); raise the Medicare premium for outpatient services for individuals with incomes above $50,000 and couples with incomes above $65,000 ($25.9 billion).
Other entitlement savings not primarily involving the elderly or the poor: reduce farm subsidies ($31.6 billion, see No. 2); restrict veterans' compensation for those with relatively minor impairments like flat feet and eliminate payments to new applicants with disabilities unrelated to military service ($7.6 billion); increase fees for using Federal resources and services ranging from mining on Government land to obtaining a communications license ($29 billion).
Total entitlement savings: $507.4 billion.
The next biggest category of Government spending is the Pentagon. The cold war is over, and big cuts here seem easy (see No. 1). These are the ones I made:
Cancel development and production of various high-technology aircraft like the F-22 advanced tactical fighter, the C-17 transport plane, the F/A-18 attack aircraft, the V-22 vertical takeoff plane and the Comanche helicopter ($42.8 billion); reduce the number of aircraft carriers, destroyers and frigates and cancel the third Seawolf submarine ($15.9 billion); reduce the troop strength of the Army ($16.7 billion); reduce nuclear delivery systems and other nuclear weapons programs ($9.4 billion); consolidate military infrastructure, whatever that means ($7.7 billion).
Total military savings: $92.5 billion.
Cutting other Government programs is harder. Whole programs can be abolished without saving much money. But this is not the time to be daunted (see Nos. 3, 4 and 5). These were my cuts:
Cancel the space station ($13.8 billion); consolidate the Departments of Education and Labor ($3 billion); abolish the Commerce Department ($7 billion); eliminate funding for several arcane education programs like the one that gives school districts extra money for pupils whose parents live or work on Federal property ($4.8 billion); cut in half funding for the arts and humanities ($3.6 billion); eliminate community development block grants and some rural development programs ($31.6 billion, see No. 2); limit low-income energy assistance to the most needy ($5 billion).
Total savings from miscellaneous cuts: $68.8 billion.
Now for taxes. Unlike President Clinton and the Republicans who control Congress, I see no need for tax reductions. In fact, I chose these tax increases (See No. 2): Raise the gasoline tax by 25 cents a gallon ($108.7); raise the cigarette tax by 75 cents a pack and the tax on alcohol by about 50 cents for each six-pack or bottle of wine or spirits ($98.7 billion); eliminate the deduction for mortgage interest for interest payments above $20,000 a year ($56.5 billion).
Total tax increases: $263.9 billion.
Time to take stock. The spending cuts and tax increases I have so painlessly checked off total $932.6 billion, $82.6 billion more than necessary to balance the budget under the rules of the game.
So since I may want to retire at 65 (see No. 3), let's forget about raising the retirement age ($72.6 billion). And to avoid fights with members of my family who disagree with me (see No. 4), let's not cut funds for the arts and humanities ($3.6 billion).
That leaves a surplus of $6.4 billion over seven years. I'll give it to the Pentagon. You can't be too careful about the nation's defense needs (see No. 1).

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Virtual Recruiter: Software That Reads Resumes

BYLINE: By GLENN RIFKIN 

 BODY:
THE next time you get hired or transferred, the person you may want to slap on the back or in the face may not be a person at all. That is because your fate was decided by a computer.
Companies like Hewlett-Packard, AT&T, Texas Instruments and Ford Motor have turned to virtual recruiters, software programs that let employers turn the resumes they receive into a data base that can be searched to fill job vacancies. For example, if a company is looking for an engineer with five years' experience who can speak Spanish, the computer will provide a list of candidates who qualify. 
 This makes it easier for companies, but it puts pressure on job seekers not only to have the attributes the employer wants, but also to describe those qualifications on their resumes in a way the computer will recognize. And misspellings in a resume, which often used to be merely embarrassing, now can automatically cost you the job.
Giving so much control to a computer raises concerns that a machine will miss the subtleties and nuances of what makes a good employee. "There is something to be said for using a professional staffing person, because the hiring manager using the software quite often looks just at experience, but doesn't go under the surface to find out what kind of person you are, whether you are a team player, the intangibles," said Jac Fitz-enz, director of the Saratoga Institute, a human resources research and consulting firm in Santa Clara, Calif.
But, he said, a human recruiter cannot look for standard qualifications as fast or efficiently as a computer can. The software helped Elizabeth Richards, who had been working as a marketing representative, get a new job last fall. She was hired by the Overnite Transportation Company of Richmond, a $1 billion division of Union Pacific, after giving the company her resume at a job fair. On her resume, she had included a job she held earlier in her career as a compensation analyst, writing "base pay plan design, incentive plan design" to describe the post.
That is the job she got. Overnite was looking for a compensation analyst and, after scanning her resume into its data base, a recruiter typed "base pay plan design, incentive plan design, strong administrative skills and five to seven years experience" as the search parameters. Up popped Ms. Richards's resume.
When the company called her in for an interview, Ms. Richards was startled to find that the company had been so astute as to look beyond her current marketing duties to notice her old job.
"Without the software system, there would have been no connection," she said. "If you file paper resumes by hand, the resume would likely have been filed by the day it came in rather than by my background. I believe so many companies lose potential applicants in the piles of paper."
Resume tracking software, which is sold by companies like the Restrac Corporation in Dedham, Mass., and Resumix Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif., for $80,000 to more than $1 million, not only searches by key words, but also helps give the information some context. Resumix, for example, contains 10 million terms related to various industries. The terms represent skills for different professions, like "general ledger" for accountants and "application design" for software developers, that help recruiters conduct their searches. Restrac and Resumix said about 400 companies used their software.
Overnite said the Restrac system had changed the way it finds new employees, saving $1.5 million on recruiting costs like advertising and agency fees since it installed the software three years ago. The system also sends rejection letters automatically. "Our recruiters don't have to deal with paper at all," said David Huffer, director of staffing at Overnite. "Their efficiency goes up because they can spend more time with candidates and hiring managers."
Hewlett-Packard installed the tracking software about five years ago. This year the company expects the system to handle 330,000 resumes. James R. Green, manager of the company's employment response center, said the data base was accessible on the desktop computers of all the company's hiring managers.
THE system has another bonus for job seekers: resumes remain in the data base and a candidate who lost out on one job can easily be identified for a future opening.
"Now when we say we'll put your resume on file, we really mean it," said Edward Kleinert, administrator for human resource information technology at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, which uses Restrac to screen the 25,000 to 30,000 resumes received annually.
AT&T, which recently announced it would lay off thousands of workers, is using the software to help those employees find different jobs within the company.
A data base was created that contains the resumes of laid-off workers and any openings within the company. Another data base holds more than 100,000 job openings at 3,000 other companies.
"It is emotional enough to be in a job that is being phased out and find your financial future is clouded," said Burke Stinson, an AT&T spokesman, "but it can be like rubbing salt in the wound to learn that a job that you were quite capable of doing, 100 or 1,000 miles away, was just filled by someone from the street."
Starting in June, it will be even easier for workers to get resumes into data bases of the companies using the Restrac system. Its clients will be able to connect to the Monster Board (http://www.monster.com), a huge job- and resume-posting site on the World Wide Web, and download resumes directly into their data bases.
"There's been a dramatic change in the way hiring was done 20 years ago," Mr. Fitz-enz said. "With scanning systems and key-word search and retrieval software, large companies are able to put all applications from around the country into one central data base, and any hiring manager can access it to look for job candidates. Companies are getting far greater cost economies from it."
 
First, Forget The Green Paper
 Quirky typefaces, colored paper: job applicants have long schemed to make their resumes stand out. But as more and more companies scan resumes into their computers and use software programs to judge them, these and other rules are changing.
"Maximize the use of your industry's jargon and acronyms," the Restrac Corporation advises job applicants who want to create computer-friendly resumes. The reason is that the software that examines the resumes uses a "key word" search system to find promising ones.
As for eye-catching graphics, avoid them. "Use a standard font," Restrac suggests. "Use white paper." And "don't try to dress up your resume with borders, boxes or graphics." Human recruiters may or may not be impressed with such tricks, but computers never are. "The computer can't read them," the brochure notes.
At least one old rule of writing a resume has vanished in cyberspace: confining it to one page. "Multiple pages are fine," Restrac says, but "print your resume on one side only." Computers can read quickly, but they can't turn the sheet over.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Think That I.P.O. Looks Good? If It's Offered to Pay Debt. Look Twice.

BYLINE: By MARCIA VICKERS 

 BODY:
INVESTORS buy initial public offerings because they want to get in on a venture's ground floor. As the company uses the offering's proceeds to build the business up, people hope that their returns will ride higher and higher, too.
But, more and more, the money from new issues is used not to expand a company; it is designated to pay for debt. In 1995, about 34 percent of all such proceeds went to repay or refinance bank loans and fixed-income debt, according to the Securities Data Company. That share is the second-highest annual number since 1986. 
 The stock market's surge holds the explanation for the trend, said Linda Killian, an analyst with Renaissance Capital, a research firm in Greenwich, Conn. Given the high value of stocks today, she said, "it makes more sense, for companies that are able to do it, to raise equity capital to pay debt rather than increase debt via a bank loan or other means."
Of course, interest rates are now relatively low, which makes bank loans cheap. But low interest rates also help the stock market -- and today's market levels are apparently attractive enough to overshadow economical rates on loans.
Thus, the general lesson is clear: companies' growing fondness for refinancing debt through new issues is a sign that they, as sellers, are getting a good price for their stock. The flip side, of course, is that investors, as buyers, may be paying top dollar.
Nevertheless, some new issues are much better investments than others. With more than $15 billion in initial offerings scheduled for the second quarter of this year -- a quarterly record -- how should investors react when a new offering they like will devote a big piece of the cash raised to debt?
With caution, most analysts say. In nautical circles, "two square red flags with black centers represent hurricanes," said John Fitzgibbon, editor of the IPO Aftermarket Report, a newsletter. "Investors should use the same warning signals when reading that an I.P.O.'s proceeds are going to repayment of debt."
One general reason for this wariness, of course, is that investors commonly expect new-issue money to fuel growth and propel share prices higher. If the money goes to debt instead, the assumption vanishes.
But investors must also dig deeper to see if, for a particular offering, the focus on debt is a plus or a minus.
"You have to look at companies on a case-by-case basis," Mr. Fitzgibbon said. "It can be tricky." Investors should examine the size of the company's debt, its overall financial strength and the reasons the debt was incurred.
For Irv DeGraw, Shells Seafood Restaurants offers an example of a new issue that should make one wary. The company, a chain based in Tampa, Fla., plans to raise $7 million -- and wants to use 30.6 percent of that amount to pay debt and 38.3 percent to finance current operations.
"Shells is issuing an I.P.O. in order to save itself," said Mr. DeGraw, research director at IPO Insider, a newsletter in Sarasota, Fla. "They are desperate for the cash."
SHELLS is usually packed on weekends, according to analysts, and the management -- former Red Lobster executives -- is seasoned. But the company, which has been around since 1985, has had a history of cash-flow problems. And in a recent audit of the company, the accounting firm Deloitte & Touche concluded that the financial position of Shells was weak enough to raise doubts about its ability to stay in business. Because the company is still in the offering period, executives at Shells declined comment.
Similarly, when Revlon went public last month, its likely need to use the proceeds to pay large debts was a big concern.
But sometimes the focus on debt should not raise alarms.
"Paying down debt often frees up a company to make acquisitions and acquire working capital to expand the business or use for internal growth," said Robert S. Natale, director of equity research at Standard & Poor's.
Consider Orthodontic Centers of America, a provider of management services to orthodontists that went public in December 1994. The company sought $20.9 million in the offering, and scheduled 17 percent for retiring regular debt and 59 percent for paying off debt incurred in expansion. But the company had grown fast, and continued borrowing for such an enterprise can raise its debt to risky levels. So, using 76 percent of the offering's proceeds to pay debt freed the company to continue growing. For industry observers like Mr. DeGraw, that kind of debt situation is auspicious.
As investors try to separate the worrisome from the welcome in this area, though, they can be stopped by vague terms -- like "general corporate purposes" -- used in offering documents to describe the destination of the cash raised. But that problem may diminish if the Securities and Exchange Commission adopts a rule, as it has proposed, to make the language of prospectuses plainer and more specific.
