SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 688 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
A Little-Known Strategy for Bond Buyers

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
KURT GUTFREUND, the president of a Chicago company that makes children's clothing, is like many other bond buyers. He doesn't like to take risks, and he puts a high priority on yield.
So why did Mr. Gutfreund recently sell $250,000 of triple-A municipal bonds, bought just two years ago and carrying a coupon yield of 6.75 percent, and buy an equivalent sum of bonds paying only 6.35 percent? 
 Mr. Gutfreund was simply taking advantage of a strategy that can give him a bigger pot of money. The method involves "pre-refunded" bonds. Here is how it works: The issuer of Mr. Gutfreund's bonds, the State of Florida, recently took steps to effectively back the bonds' principal and interest with Treasury securities up to the issue's first call date, June 1, 2001. The state said it would call, or redeem, the bonds then.
These actions conferred on the bonds a shorter maturity but also the high creditworthiness of the Treasuries that now backed them. Thus, their price rose to roughly 10 percent more than the price Mr. Gutfreund would have received if he held the bonds until the 2001 maturity date. By selling the old bonds at the higher price, Mr. Gutfreund received about $26,000 more in gains on principal -- even after paying a commission on the sale -- than he would have if he had never sold them.
True, the new bonds, $250,000 of a city housing issue from Atlanta, have a yield of only 6.35 percent, so Mr. Gutfreund will get about $5,000 less in yield between now and 2001 than he would have with his original holdings. There will also be a commission to buy the new bonds. And more of Mr. Gutfreund's total returns from the pre-refunded strategy will be capital gains, and thus taxable; only the yield on municipal bonds is always federally tax free and possibly free of state taxes.
But, even after these effects, Mr. Gutfreund will come out ahead. "It's a terrific strategy," he said.
Sharon A. Alister, his broker at Dean Witter Reynolds, agreed. "This is one of the most underused and unknown, and yet profitable, strategies that is available to the individual investor," she said.
Now may be the time for investors to pay attention. When interest rates fall, as they did during most of the early 1990's, issuers of both tax-free and taxable bonds often like to pare their interest payments by issuing new bonds at lower coupons. The pre-refunding procedure helps issuers, like Florida, accomplish this switch.
There are no statistics to show how many bonds are candidates to be pre-refunded. Last year, however, Ms. Alister noticed a pre-refunding almost every month for the 25 or so different bond issues that are typically held in an average portfolio for her clients.
True, interest rates have risen recently, and that has reduced refinancings. But there are still more pre-refundings coming, and if rates resume their fall, as Ms. Alister thinks they will, there will be more.
For an issuer to try pre-refunding, the difference in yield between the new and the old bonds must be at least 1.25 or 1.50 percentage points, Ms. Alister said.
"For me, any bond that is paying 6.5 percent or higher is an attractive candidate," she said. "However, because I think interest rates are still going to go lower, I'm also on the lookout for bonds that are paying 6.375 percent."
This strategy may not appeal to investors who need high income from regular coupon checks. At a 6.35 percent yield, Mr. Gutfreund's new bonds produce $1,000 less in payments each year than his old ones did. Also, while price jumps are typical with pre-refunded bonds, the rise can vary greatly from issue to issue, sharply affecting the tactic's attractiveness.
Ms. Alister also noted that the pool of potential pre-refunded bonds was smaller than it was when interest rates first moved down, and that the strategy was harder with taxable bonds than with tax-free ones.
What about buying a pre-refunded bond instead of selling it? "With these bonds you often get gilt-edged credit quality and good current yields," said George D. Friedlander, a managing director and fixed-income strategist at Smith Barney.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kurt Gutfreund, a clothing maker, has tried a pre-refunded bond deal. (Steve Kagan for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3088 words

HEADLINE: EARNING IT;
Life of a Cold Caller: Riding on a Smile and a Thick Skin

BYLINE: By BARBARA WHITAKER 

DATELINE: TREVOSE, Pa.

 BODY:
EVELYN WILEY'S desk is unadorned. No family pictures. No mementos or favorite sayings. The only thing distinguishing it is a small hand mirror perched on the keyboard of her computer.
She keeps it there to see if she's smiling. If she is, chances are she's selling. 
 "They always listen when I smile," Ms. Wiley said.
No small challenge. Ms. Wiley is one of those people America loves to hate: a telephone solicitor. Each day, she interrupts dozens of people she doesn't know, trying to sell them something they didn't ask for and probably feel they don't need.
But Ms. Wiley, a "30-something" Philadelphia woman who has worked as a telephone solicitor for nearly a year, sees her role in a different light. To her, she is nothing less than a telephone help mate.
"I feel important," she said. "I know it's disruptive, but my approach is: I have a great offer for you."
In a sense, telephone solicitors are the door-to-door salesmen of the 90's, intrusive and uninvited. Instead of peddling brushes and vacuum cleaners, they push everything from credit cards to insurance to newspapers (this one included). They may ask for charitable contributions or suggest a change in your long-distance carrier. Whatever they are selling, they always seem to call at dinner time.
And like door-to-door salesmen, they face rejection, suspicion and, at times, outright rudeness, with angry hang-ups replacing slammed front doors.
In short, theirs is a job that is arguably at the bottom of the retail food chain, traditionally filled by retirees, homemakers and college students looking for part-time work.
But as the job market has tightened, telemarketing has increasingly become a haven for older white-collar workers set adrift by the latest recessionary shock or round of downsizing. Many of these people are in it for the long haul.
And if you think they aren't racking up the sales, despite all their annoyances, think again. A day spent watching Ms. Wiley and others at the ICT Group Inc. calling center here, just outside Philadelphia in Bucks County, was notable not for the number of hang-ups, but for how many people took the callers up on their offers.
In just over two hours on a Tuesday in February, Ms. Wiley and 11 colleagues -- cold callers to the public but who prefer to be known as telephone service representatives, or T.S.R.'s -- persuaded credit card holders around the country to accept more than $100,000 in cash advances, using a reduced interest rate as the bait. That put them well ahead of their goal of "selling" $2,600 an hour in advances per sales representative, reaching an average of $4,400 instead.
That kind of success helps explain why, despite problems in the industry with fraud, deception and public scorn, the cold-calling side of telemarketing has grown into a multibillion-dollar business.
Sales to consumers by so-called outbound telemarketers -- retailers or the representatives they hire, like ICT, that initiate calls to customers -- soared to an estimated $159 billion last year, from $117 billion in 1990, according to the Direct Marketing Association, a trade group based in Washington. When calls to business customers are added in, sales came to $385 billion last year, the association says. (That is not counting the billions of dollars taken in by fraudulent operators. Nor does it include the huge amount of business done by catalogue companies, which are characterized as inbound telemarketers because the consumer calls them.)
"It's the kind of business that I think people like to complain about, yet people are spending $385 billion on goods and services purchased by the telephone, which speaks to the fact that it offers a service people are not getting other ways," said Donna Krampf, director of consumer public relations for the trade group.
MS. WILEY'S employer has been on a roll for years now. Revenues for ICT, which is involved in telemarketing management and research services as well as sales, have grown from $2 million in 1987 to $52 million last year. Among companies that specialize in outbound calls, ICT was ranked eighth last year in billable minutes by Telemarketing and Call Center Solutions Magazine.
"We've been doubling in size every two years," said John J. Brennan, ICT Group's president and chief executive. "The market is very good, and we've done a lot of diversification to broaden our approach."
The company, which is based in nearby Langhorne, Pa., operates 20 outbound calling centers, 3 of which have opened this year. Two of the centers are abroad, in Dublin and St. John, New Brunswick.
Compensation for sales representatives varies in the industry, depending on skills and the part of the country where the caller is working. At ICT, the pay averages $6 to $8 an hour to start. For those with special skills, like licensed insurance agents, the rate is generally $8 to $10 an hour to start. And medical benefits, seldom provided before, are now being given more frequently to people in that group.
The company and its clients also frequently offer incentives to push the employees. Callers working at least 40 hours a month can increase hourly wages by a maximum of $4.75 if they consistently perform above their peers.
In addition, the callers can eventually move into supervisory or management jobs, which pay better salaries. At ICT, supervisors earn annual salaries of about $25,000, a call center manager will make $30,000 to $40,000 and a director of regional operations can make up to $60,000.
New employees not cut out for the job will generally leave within the first two weeks, said Amy Brennan, the office manager at the Bucks County calling center. Generally, about 5 percent drop out by that point. To keep the turnover that low, she says she is very selective. What does she look for? "It's voice inflection, it's tone, it's their attitude in the interview," said Ms. Brennan, who is not related to the company's president.
"I don't really expect to sit with anyone and have them say, 'This is my dream job,' " she added. "But sometimes they come and find they like it."
Looking back to her early days on the job, Ms. Wiley confessed to wondering if it was going to work out. A business school graduate who also went to a community college for two years, she selected a job in telemarketing over secretarial and clerical positions because she liked the idea that she would be using her communication skills.
Her first week, however, was a disaster as she tried to persuade people to change long-distance companies.
People either hung up on her or took the time to tell her off. "They're telling you their company is better," Ms. Wiley remembered. "They'd go into, 'Let me tell you about your company' . . . 'It cost me X amount of dollars to talk to people next door' . . . 'Stop calling here.' "
It was at that point, she recalled, that she turned to a mirror for some role playing.
"I acted like I was the customer," she said. "I asked questions and answered myself back. I used my rebuttals, and I felt real confident."
So she took the mirror to work.
"It was excellent because it was a very hard program, and I reached the goal in one day," she said. "I've been carrying my mirror ever since."
ALTHOUGH the callers receive training to help them present themselves and the product in the best possible way, how they deal with rejection must come from within.
"You have to be strong," said Ms. Wiley, expressing a view echoed by other sales representatives. "I think it's a built-in thing."
Those familiar with the business say Americans have an ingrained sense of politeness and generally beg off without getting ugly, although people in New York City (rude) and Wisconsin (suspicious) are known to be more difficult.
When the rejection is bad, a supervisor might come over for a personal pep talk. Management prepares for particularly difficult selling campaigns -- in which just one sale is expected every two or three hours -- by selecting the best people and backing them up with a higher number of supervisors. Financial or other incentives -- ranging from unexpected boxes of candy to complicated bonus arrangements for those who sell more than the office average -- are also used to "sweeten the pot," Ms. Brennan said.
Morale boosters might be something as simple as passing an envelope containing a $10 bill to the person with the most recent sale. At the end of a designated period, the person with the envelope can keep the money.
ICT employs 3,000 service representatives, including 540 who have been with the company for three years or more.
As the business has grown, the sales force has become older, Mr. Brennan said. He began to see a change in the recession of 1991, when the average age of new hires went to 31, from 21. "When people started losing jobs," Mr. Brennan said, "they got involved in this."
Larry Twine, 55, is one of those people. He took his job out of necessity. He had worked as a securities analyst for 28 years and then became a consultant. But the stock market crash in 1987 ended that career, he said. After a long stretch of being told he was over qualified for a variety of jobs, he joined ICT in 1990.
His approach to the job was to learn as much as he could about telephone sales so that he could perform as professionally as possible. To earn as much as possible, he obtained licenses to sell insurance in half the states. Now, he consistently leads the office in sales.
Mr. Twine and the others at the calling center use computers and well-honed phone lists to reach their unsuspecting clientele. The computers dial the numbers, giving the calls to the sales representatives while they are still ringing. The computers will adapt their pace to the amount of business being done by the representatives.
The system is a vast improvement over the days without computers. Now, sales representatives spend 40 minutes each hour talking with customers, compared with 25 minutes in the old days, making it possible to do the same volume of work with roughly half the number of people.
The calls start going out at 9 A.M. (Federal regulations prohibit calls between 9 P.M. and 8 A.M.) Callers sit side by side in identical cubicles staring at computer screens that detail basics like the name and address of the person called as well as the information needed to discuss the sale.
MR. TWINE sits poised to talk as the computer connects him to a phone ringing in Santa Barbara, Calif. A man picks up. Mr. Twine introduces himself and -- working from a script -- tells the man he has "good news" for him. He would like to send him a check for his available credit card balance at an annual percentage rate of 9.9 percent. The rate remains in effect until the loan is paid off.
"Many might tell you, 'I have too much credit,' " Mr. Twine said later. "But you've got to ask, 'What's the rate you are paying?' "
"When you explain what you have, they can find a need," he said.
In this case, the customer gives what is known in the business as a "hard no." It is definite and leaves little room to maneuver, unlike someone who says, "I don't think so."
The soft-spoken Mr. Twine takes his cue and signs off, but only after double-checking that he can't interest the man in the offer. The computer then dials up homes in Toledo, Ohio; El Paso; Oceanside, Calif., and Rome, N.Y., but no one answers.
Finally, the silence is broken. Not by a customer, but by Maurice Watson, a 25-year-old colleague who comes over with his sales sheet requesting that Mr. Twine check it out.
"Does this say $42,000 before lunch?" Mr. Watson asks, tweaking Mr. Twine.
"He's having a great day," said Ms. Brennan, after witnessing the exchange. "He's taking advantage of it by rubbing it in everyone else's face."
Noting that he extended $40,000 in credit the day before, Mr. Watson seems to have surprised even himself with his $42,000 before lunch.
But offering consumers a cash advance at 9.9 percent less than two months after Christmas is kind of like offering a hungry child another cookie. Many are going to think about it, and several will find it hard to refuse.
Still, Mr. Watson runs into some interesting twists. First there is the man in New Mexico who wants to consult with a friend about the offer.
"Can I call you back?" the man asks.
No. If Mr. Watson lets him go, he will probably lose the sale. Then it dawns on the customer that he has access to a cellular phone with a different number. He calls the friend, setting up a rather bizarre three-way exchange.
Mr. Watson can hear the man saying, "I can't call him back, so I was wanting to know your thoughts on it." Then the customer comes back, "What kind of information do you need?"
Mr. Watson says he needs to know only how much of an advance the man wants.
Within a few minutes, Mr. Watson is wrapping up the deal to hit the man's credit card limit by sending him a check for $4,600.
Then it's right back to business for Mr. Watson. A wrong number, then someone in Monroe, N.C., answers.
"I'm in pain up to my elbows," the customer says. Or was it paint? Mr. Watson doesn't press.
He moves on. After two calls are not answered, he gets a man who has just come home from the hospital after open-heart surgery. Mr. Watson starts to back off until the man mentions his medical bills.
"I'm sorry to hear about your condition," Mr. Watson says, "but this could help you to pay some of those medical expenses, and there's no time limit."
The customer counters that his wife has the credit card in her name, and she is going to pay things off that way. "I think right now I'll stick with that," he says.
"Hope you get better," Mr. Watson concludes. "Thank you for talking with me."
The call epitomized what makes telephone solicitors successful. Although Mr. Watson was working from a script, he adapted it to suit the situation. Every representative has to find the right approach, and quickly.
Consider the ICT sales representative in Dublin who was calling the United States for a campaign. Although he was speaking English, it might as well have been Japanese to the man he reached in Texas.
The customer asked whether he could put someone on the line who could speak "West Texas." The caller left the phone for a second, thought back to the American Westerns he had seen on television and then resumed the call doing his best John Wayne impression. He made the sale.
OVER time, sales representatives come up with their own winning styles.
Hank Kulig, a career salesman who was downsized from his job selling corporate lighting, said he just stuck to the facts. For the credit card campaign, he has written notes on his script ticking off the various ways a cash advance can be used: home improvements, special purchases, vacations, medical expenses.
When a man in Indiana says he has no need for the money, Mr. Kulig stresses the 9.9 percent rate and the fact that this kind of deal never seems to be there when you need it.
"You can always return it," Mr. Kulig says of the cash advance.
"It sounds awful good, but I don't need any right now," the man responds.
"You don't need a check for $3,000 or $4,000?" Mr. Kulig asks, making a last run at it. When the man continues to decline, Mr. Kulig asks him to "keep us in mind" and leaves him with an "800" number for customer service.
All representatives are monitored at random throughout the day. Three times each day they will be scored on their performance by quality assurance monitors, who will examine everything from their diction to the "rebuttals" they use to keep a resistant customer on the line to their overall professionalism.
"We're like your mother," said Karen Furman, one of the monitors.
The sales representatives are also being watched closely by the higher-ranking supervisors.
Plagued by phone scams conducted by fraudulent operators, legitimate companies are constantly refining their approach to raise the level of consumer acceptance, Mr. Brennan said.
Ms. Krampf, the public relations director for the marketing association, concurred, noting that companies attribute their success to their ability to pinpoint their audience, providing information and services that those consumers actually want.
Still, consumer skepticism is warranted. Authorities estimate that $40 billion in fraudulent or deceptive sales are made each year in the United States.
To protect the interests of consumers and legitimate telemarketers, the Federal Trade Commission adopted the Telemarketing Sales Rule, which went into effect at the beginning of this year. Two major facets of the rule, which parallels Federal Communications Commission regulations, set the restrictions on when telephone soliciting may take place and require companies to stop calling customers who say they want to be left alone. The rule also details what telemarketers must disclose during a call, like their identity and the nature of the goods or services being offered.
Sales representatives say they have no problems with the regulations because they are only hurt by illegitimate operations.
Amelia Hartzel, head of quality development for ICT, said trainees are taught not to push people who say they are not interested.
"It's not fair, and it's not correct," she said. There is, however, that business of the differing ways of saying no.
"There is the soft no and a hard no, and you really teach them the difference," she said. "One is 'Convince me,' the other is, 'Get out of my life.' "
At the end of the day, it is those get-out-of-my-life calls that make the job so difficult. "Per hour," Ms. Hartzel said, "you get more rejection in this job than any other."
Sales representatives say they try not to take it personally, but sometimes it's difficult. It takes a certain kind of person to follow through, they say.
"After about 30 or 40 rejections, sure you can get a little frustrated and want to go get a cup of coffee," Mr. Kulig said. "You ask, 'Is it me or the program?' You just can't let it bother you."
Looking down the road five years, Evelyn Wylie believes that she and her husband, Troy, whom she met on the job and married during a lunch break, will still be in telemarketing, only not at ICT.
"Troy and Evelyn Telemarketing Service," she said. "We've already discussed it."
But facing an afternoon in which 43 minutes of calling had led to four refusals, five "reschedules" and no sales, Ms. Wylie focused her attention on her mirror and smiled.
"I'll catch up," she said.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 6; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1267 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH;
Mark G. Holowesko: Templeton Foreign Fund

BYLINE: By VIRGINIA MUNGER KAHN 

 BODY:
SCANNING the globe for undervalued stocks often takes money managers to exotic locales. Mark G. Holowesko, an acclaimed manager of several Templeton foreign funds, is no exception.
So you might expect his fund portfolios to be larded with obscure stocks from tiny markets and far-off lands. But some of his favorites are household names readily available here. In fact, one is a United States company that does big business abroad -- the Boeing Company. Boeing's shares surged nearly 10 percent last week on news that the company was gearing up production to meet increased demand for commercial aircraft worldwide. Even now, the stock remains undervalued, Mr. Holowesko said in a phone conversation last week from his office in the Bahamas. 
 As his Boeing position suggests, Mr. Holowesko is not wedded to a portfolio with a certain percentage of assets in country A and a lesser percentage in country B based on their relative economic conditions, markets and currencies. More in the vein of Peter Lynch, Warren E. Buffett and John Templeton, his mentor and the company founder, Mr. Holowesko is a stock picker. "Basically, we want the stock selection to drive the country allocation," he said.
To select stocks, he looks for what is cheap, instead of hot companies with rapid earnings growth. And market volatility, the bane of small investors with short time frames, can work to his advantage. In volatile markets, he said, it is easier to find share prices that fail to reflect their companies' true values. When a market plunges, he may see an opportunity to snap up bargains. When Latin America's markets were devastated last year, Mr. Holowesko acquired a substantial stake in Telebras, Brazil's telephone company. Since then, he said, that holding has gained 35 percent in value.
All his funds score high in long-term performance. The Templeton Foreign Fund, which invests primarily outside the United States, ranks in the top 10 percent of all foreign funds over the last 10 years, according to Morningstar, the fund tracking company in Chicago. It returned an average 15 percent a year, with 30 percent less risk of a decline than the average equity fund -- quite a feat for a foreign portfolio.
His two other charges, Templeton Growth and Templeton World, rank in the top third of all global funds, providing annual returns over the last 10 years of 13 percent and 12 percent, respectively, again with less downside risk than other equity funds. Over all, Mr. Holowesko, who is 36 and has been with Templeton 11 years, manages $26 billion, with 10 percent to 20 percent of that in cash.
Although Mr. Templeton, a pioneer in international investing, stepped down in 1992 from daily management of the fund family, now part of the Franklin/Templeton group, his passion for finding values lives on at his firm.
A list of "the cheapest stocks in the world," with 80 to 200 names, is generated by Mr. Holowesko and 38 other portfolio managers and analysts in Templeton offices from Paris to Ho Chi Minh City. Everyone is responsible for recommending bargains in the countries and industries he follows.
Stocks on the list are usually cheap relative to their earnings growth or are cheap in relation to what the companies would fetch if sold.
If earnings growth has not yet been recognized by the market and it appears to be sustainable over three to five years, Mr. Holowesko becomes interested. When pressed for a benchmark, he said he liked to buy stocks trading at three to five times their projected earnings over the next three to five years and then to sell those stocks at 8 to 10 times earnings.
When it comes to companies worth more to prospective buyers, he must focus on those whose values can be unlocked. Many stocks trade for substantially less than the potential sale value of their companies -- and for good reason. Either the company is not generating a good return on assets or it is controlled by an investor uninterested in realizing its potential value. But if management is willing to restructure, sell assets or even sell the company, Mr. Holowesko and his colleagues get excited.
Though he avoids country allocations and macroeconomic analysis, there are certain investing themes in his portfolios. Right now, a major theme is the revamping of cyclical European companies. The recession that hit Europe in 1991 and 1992 scared many of these companies, he said, and they are reorganizing and reducing debt, much as American companies did in the 1980's.

 
 
Back to Basics
 His favorite play in this area is Volvo, the Swedish car and truck maker. Several years ago, the company tried to turn itself into a mini-conglomerate. "It was pretty much a disaster," he said. In the last 18 months, though, a new management team and a new board have focused on the core business.
Spinning off other lines of business will result in a significant infusion of cash. After subtracting that cash from the stock's current price, the core auto business is selling at just 5.7 times its value, by Mr. Holowesko's calculation, and that is too low. The stock, traded in Sweden, is worth 28 percent more than its current price, he said. Volvo's American depository receipts closed last week at $23.75 apiece on Nasdaq.

 
 
Lighting Up the Sky
 Another favorite group is United States companies that make planes, computers and industrial equipment. "About half of all U.S. capital goods exports go to developing markets," Mr. Holowesko said. "America is very, very competitive in this area."
His largest investment in this category is Boeing, whose stock appears in the World and Growth funds. Concerns about a floundering domestic airline business and the cost of developing the 777 line depressed the stock from 1992 through 1994. Mr. Holowesko's team bought the stock in 1993, expecting Boeing to benefit from a booming Asian market, where it was already supplying planes to Singapore Airlines and others.
Now, with the domestic airline business improving and demand for planes in Asia growing, Boeing may well reap the benefits. Its only major competitor is Airbus Industrie, and lately, Boeing has won key contracts, Mr. Holowesko noted. Even though the stock price has doubled since his purchase, he sees room for more gains. The stock closed Friday at $88.875 a share, but is worth more than $100, he said.

 
 
A Surprise in Japan
 The search for undervalued companies relative to their earnings power has led Mr. Holowesko to the Sony Corporation, the Japanese consumer electronics giant. It is a surprising investment in part because Templeton is well-known for skirting Japan in recent years because of high valuations there. And Sony is selling at what Mr. Holowesko figures is 26 times 1997 earnings. Though that is not cheap, he still considers the stock undervalued.
Sony's profits are expected to grow about 85 percent in the next 12 months, he said.
Perhaps more important, the company is a leading developer of the digital versatile disk, which will allow people to play music, watch a movie and retrieve information by computer all from one entertainment center. Only a few companies can provide the entire package, Mr. Holowesko said, adding that another is Philips Electronics N.V., also a favorite stock.
Sony's earnings growth, which should exceed 20 percent a year over the next three to five years, and the promise of the new technology are not reflected in the stock price, he said. Within five years, he expects the stock price to double. The A.D.R.'s closed at $60 apiece on Friday on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: A Forum on the Tax Deductions for Corporations

 BODY:
"Tax Reformers, Take Your Mark" (Feb. 11), Reed Abelson's article on the tax deductions available to corporations that have made expensive mistakes, drew many responses from readers. In general, the letters defended these deductions, and for a variety of reasons. Some said the breaks were justified because a business cannot be expected to succeed in every project it undertakes. Others said no business would deliberately lose a huge amount of money just to save part of it in taxes. And others contended that the corporate deductions were not different from those available to individual taxpayers.
 
To the Editor:
True, when a corporation or any other form of entrepreneurial enterprise makes a mistake or suffers a serious accident, most often it can include the cost of the incident in its cost of doing business. As a result, the business reduces its profits and therefore its Federal and, often, state income taxes. 
 But the great bulk of business tax-saving incidents are not planned and occur while the managers or owners are engaged in risking capital -- the essence of the capitalist system.
We all depend on the success of business ventures for the economic well-being of the nation; the question of tax breaks is a matter of public policy. We could throw the major burden of the income tax on businesses and thus lighten the load on consumers, but the simplest logic makes clear that the increased cost of doing business would lead to higher prices if companies are to make a profit.
For whatever reason, we -- that is, our Representatives and Senators in Congress, the President and business lobbies -- have shaped the present system. The negotiations among these three groups are a matter of deep concern to every citizen; sometimes these groups lean too far to favor business, but sometimes they lean too far to favor consumers. In either case, individuals can sometimes affect the details of these negotiations through various organizations.
Let us not forget that individuals also enjoy tax breaks. Look at the personal I.R.S. Form 1040, Lines 23a through 30. One of the most interesting tax breaks is indicated on Line 29, "alimony paid." If I make a mistake in choosing a mate such that the marriage ends in the personal equivalent of a corporate bankruptcy, then a local divorce judge, over whom the I.R.S. has no official power, can order alimony payments, which I can then deduct from my Federal income for tax purposes.
In other words, the enormous divorce rate we're now suffering -- a serious symptom of social dysfunction in America -- is subsidized by the Federal tax code.
The rest of these "adjustments to income," which reduce adjusted gross income and thus tax owed, are analogous to corporate and other business deductions. The I.R.S. also subsidizes individual mistakes that involve capital losses (see Schedule D), within limits.
 
LEONARD S. STEIN
Evanston, Ill., Feb. 12

SECTION: Section 3; Page 42; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 297 words

HEADLINE: A Forum on the Tax Deductions for Corporations

 BODY:
"Tax Reformers, Take Your Mark" (Feb. 11), Reed Abelson's article on the tax deductions available to corporations that have made expensive mistakes, drew many responses from readers. In general, the letters defended these deductions, and for a variety of reasons. Some said the breaks were justified because a business cannot be expected to succeed in every project it undertakes. Others said no business would deliberately lose a huge amount of money just to save part of it in taxes. And others contended that the corporate deductions were not different from those available to individual taxpayers.
 
To the Editor:
Who could have predicted that a low-fat hamburger marketed by McDonald's would be a flop while a product with three pieces of bread and two patties of meat would be a smashing success? Coca-Cola, despite a setback from its new Coke, and McDonald's have done quite well for shareholders over the years, and presumably the I.R.S. has shared handsomely in these successes. 
 For every losing innovation there are many more winners: an extra sliding door on a Chrysler mini-van; a closer-shaving Gillette razor; a new Windows operating system. To tax successful projects of these companies but not to allow an eventual deduction for the marketing and development costs of the failures would reduce incentives for innovation. Under the law, the cost of these failures can only offset income earned from the successful ventures.
Further, to ask Congress to write laws seeking to distinguish among expenditures of corporations as wise ones or follies can only lead to unnecessary complexity and an unenforceable tax system.
 
ANDREW B. LYON
College Park, Md., Feb. 12
 
The writer is associate professor of economics at the University of Maryland.

HEADLINE: West Virginia Sheds Image and Opens for Business

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: SLANESVILLE, W. Va., March 21

 BODY:
Coal mining, poverty, old cars on concrete blocks, children running around barefoot: West Virginians know too well the outside world's perception of their state.
Eleanor Milliken, a retired inspector for Westinghouse, says she just laughs now when her son-in-law from Silver Spring, Md., says, "You can tell girls from West Virginia because they have no teeth." 
 But to Mrs. Milliken and many other West Virginians, the time has come to stop the jokes and change the stereotypes. They have had it with the hillbilly image of ol' ma and pa settin' there on the porch rocker.
And so have state officials, who have designated this year in West Virginia as Homecoming '96, a chance for cities and towns to show off a little and celebrate as the old images are beginning to fade. So far, almost 290 communities have signed up, planning street fairs, parades, motorcycle rallies and pig roasts as a way to trumpet all the change.
Gov. Gaston Caperton came here, in the northeastern corner of the state, today to help register two Hampshire County events: Slanesville's Apple Butter Festival in October and Springfield's Peach Festival in July.
"People are beginning to have a real sense of pride in themselves about who they are, and not be ashamed," Mr. Caperton, a Democrat and former insurance executive who is completing his eighth and final year in office, said in an interview before the ceremony. "This gives the state the opportunity to show off what we've done, brag a little and get people excited about their communities."
There is much to cheer about. With the luxury of working with an overwhelmingly Democratic State Legislature, as well as an entirely Democratic delegation in Congress, Mr. Caperton has pushed through major changes in business and education policies that have led to new population and job growth in West Virginia -- which has 1.8 million people, 96 percent of them white -- after years of decline.
Since 1989, his first year in office, the state has used tax incentives to add 75,000 jobs and attract 500 new businesses, an overall investment of more than $2.7 billion that makes West Virginia a leading state in the rate of job creation when many industries around the country are reducing employment. West Virginia has made especially strong gains in attracting companies in the plastics, chemical, wood-products and health-care industries.
At the same time, the state is spending more than $500 million for public school construction and renovation, and a $46 million program is putting computers in every classroom from kindergarten through fifth grade. The legislature appropriated $16.3 million this month to extend that program through the 12th grade, an effort that Mr. Caperton said would make West Virginia the first state to have computers in every public school classroom.
The state also gave teachers raises to improve their standing, to the 33d-highest-paid among the states and District of Columbia in 1994, up from 46th in 1987, according to the National Education Association. And high school curriculums now require students to prepare for college or learn specific job skills.
"He deserves high marks for what he has done," Robert Dilger, a professor of political science at the University of West Virginia, said of Mr. Caperton's initiatives. "But it almost didn't matter who was governor when he came in. West Virginia had no room to go but up. The state had just about bottomed out."
It was not until Mr. Caperton ordered his first audit of state finances, just weeks after his inauguration, that he learned the extent of the state's indebtedness, $500 million in unpaid bills, including the gas bill for the Governor's official residence in Charleston. "They were about to shut the gas off," he said.
In a move that was widely unpopular at the time, the Governor raised taxes by $300 million and cut $100 million in spending across the board. But Mr. Caperton also convened task forces to plot a course toward financial stability, with a dual focus of strengthening the state's business base and educational system.
"It was like turning around a ship going in the wrong direction," he said. "It takes a huge amount of energy, and the hardest thing is getting people to believe that they can do it. They were not used to success."
Many still are not. Pockets of poverty around the state endure, particularly in mountainous central regions once heavily dependent for employment upon the coal industry, now highly mechanized and more efficient. While the state's annual unemployment rate is the lowest in 20 years, 7.8 percent, it remains the highest of any state.
Further, many West Virginians are too old or disinclined to take advantage of new technology in their schools or new industries, and some parents object to the longer bus rides their children take to reach a newer school.
But over all, the gradual changes are nudging aside images of hillbillies and moonshine, especially in areas that have enjoyed the higher rates of economic development: around Charleston in the south, Clarksburg in the north and the eastern counties between Maryland and Virginia that have become a favorite weekend and retirement spot for people from the Washington area, about 60 miles east of here.
The key, Governor Caperton said, is finding niches. So he set up a trade office in Nagoya, Japan, rather than compete with other states in Tokyo. As a result, six Japanese manufacturing plants have opened in West Virginia in the last few years.
By the same rationale, the Legislature appropriated $18 million to enter the wholesale artwork business. In a plan that tested Mr. Caperton's lobbying skills in the Legislature, the state intends to buy art and crafts, as well as fruits and vegetables, from West Virginians and sell them at a 59,000-square-foot complex called Tamarack, planned for the southern town of Beckley.
"This is controversial," he said. "But it's a whole new industry. We expect to attract 500,000 visitors a year and create 3,000 jobs."
With all these projects as Mr. Caperton is about to leave office, state officials decided that a yearlong festival was the appropriate send-off.
Slanesville, which is using the Homecoming '96 festival to raise money for a new community building, is no stranger to big events. In 1991, President Bush and Mr. Caperton flew in helicopters to the elementary school here to honor Rae Ellen McKee as national teacher of the year. Today, Mr. Caperton returned by car to present official Homecoming '96 highway signs to Slanesville's festival leaders, Jean and Don Sowers and Springfield's chairwoman, Jean Horne.
The school's fourth graders sang songs. Local officials spoke. Mr. Caperton told the small crowd from Slanesville and other nearby communities, "Homecoming is a time to reflect on who we are and where we came from." Then he cut a cake.
Later, after the Governor had left, the Sowers, Ms. Horne and a few other local residents thought about West Virginia's growing mix of images and wondered if they would ever change for good.
"Tourism plays such a large part of what's going on," said Janet Harlow, who runs an art studio in Augusta, referring to the growing popularity of skiing, white-water rafting and other outdoor activities. "I tell friends they should come here and see the natural beauty of the place, buy a vacation home, retire here.
"But I also tell them," she added ruefully, "we don't have one leg shorter than the other just because we walk on mountains."

HEADLINE: Talbots Makes Debut On Litchfield Green

BYLINE: BY SUSAN PEARSALL 

 BODY:
LAST WEEKEND, one of Litchfield's venerable brick buildings, part of the business district that faces the green, took a retail identity for the 21st century. Built in 1890, the "Beach Block" (as it is known in the archives) now sports a fresh coat of bright, white paint on its fluted pilasters, display windows full of tastefully dressed mannequins, planters filled with hardy red geraniums, a distinctive red door and signs bearing the logo "Talbots."
This is store number 472 for the women's clothing chain based in Hingham, Mass., and one of 11 such stores in Connecticut. It is the first chain store on the green and it has caused considerable controversy in the town of 7,365, where small, independent shops have been the rule. 
 Supporters said Talbots would draw more people in and boost the local economy. Opponents feared one chain store would start a trend that would raise rents and drive out local merchants.
It appears both sides had valid points. Since August, when Talbots signed a 10-year lease with officers of the Greater Litchfield Preservation Trust, which purchased the building in 1994, representatives of two chain retailers -- Yankee Candle of Deerfield, Mass., and Eddie Bauer of Redmond, Wash. -- have inquired about leasing stores on the green.
And on March 15th, opening day at Talbots, employees greeted a steady stream of shoppers and the curious. "It was as if the whole town came out to welcome us," said Margie Brandfon, a Talbots spokeswoman.
John and Mary Kenny of Goshen, she an occasional Talbots catalogue shopper, were there. "I thought it looked lovely," said Mrs. Kenny, but she bought nothing. Perhaps when a sale is in progress, she said.
"It blends in very well with the rest of the block," John Kenny said. "And I think it's something that Litchfield has needed."
But Susan Levine, the elected warden for the borough, warned that "if they do very well, rents will go up everywhere." Parking could become a problem, too, she said.
The rent question is a worry just now for Janus Nelson, the owner of The Workshop for 25 years. Her store sells women's clothing and home accessories, and her lease is coming up for renewal this summer. "I can't help but be a little apprehensive," she said.
Ms. Nelson and a friend went down to Talbots' opening to say hello and ogle the store, with the antiques scattered among the merchandise. "I certainly would like to be able to do what they did," she said.
Among those who skipped the opening were Michel and Ellie Robert, the Litchfield couple who spent more than $12,000 last summer for advertising, warning that one chain store inevitably leads to more.
"Chain stores on the green are primarily for the benefit of tourists, not the residents," Mr. Robert said in a meeting at his home, a historic mansion near the green. "Residents are not going to shop at Talbots. If you want to grow a neighborhood, you need to have the kinds of stores that cause the residents to interact with each other."
Although Mr. Robert had threatened to file a lawsuit against the trust if it signed a lease with Talbots, he has abandoned that approach, calling it too time-consuming. In January, he set up a nonprofit group called Friends of the Green to offer financial and marketing assistance to local merchants opening shops on the green. So far, 36 people have joined the group, which has raised $70,000, most of it donated by Mr. Robert, a management consultant, and taken its first new merchant under its wing.
Last December, Steffie Wilcox was thinking about selling her hair salon and retiring after 22 years on South Street when she was approached several times by Yankee Candle. "But I refused everything," she said, "because I still was bound and determined for it to be a hair salon."
Friends of the Green offered to pay the difference between Ms. Wilcox's $25,000 asking price and offers other hair stylists might make. "Within a matter of days, we had three candidates," Mr. Robert said. The group decided on Margaret Cznera of Torrington, paid Ms. Wilcox $15,000 and gave Ms. Cznera a $25,000 low-interest loan for renovations. Margo's Hair Design is expected to open in April.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Veterans of the 80's Return to the Wars

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
THEY were among the real estate industry's household names in the 80's, the ones on the buy or build side of almost every New York City deal. And then the recession came, and the old-time entrepreneurs -- dealmakers like Francis Greenburger, Dick Berry, Joe Newman, Larry Silverstein, Joe Bernstein, and his brother, Ralph -- seemed to simply stop doing deals here.
Some, like Joseph Newman, lost the real estate empires they had so painstakingly built over the prior decades. Others, like Stephen Green, held onto what they had, but turned their energies to lower-profile activities like third-party management. Others, like Bernard Mendik, spent most of their time refinancing and refurbishing buildings. Still others, like Richard Berry, set their sights outside of beleaguered New York, and snapped up land in the Sun Belt, in Philadelphia, even overseas. 
 And now, slowly, they -- or their sons and daughters -- are coming back. They are putting flesh on the skeletal plans to convert downtown's obsolete office buildings to residential use, building shopping centers in the under-stored parts of New York, even laying foundations for new buildings. "In the last six months we've seen people we haven't heard from for at least five years," said John D. Busi, director of Cushman & Wakefield's New York appraisal division.
Sales brokers are noticing the same thing. "The people who have sat on the sidelines for years are jumping back in with both feet," said Daun Paris, president of Eastern Consolidated Properties.
Few of their deals are big and splashy. But the types of buildings they are buying, the prices they are paying and the speed with which they are moving are having an impact on the real estate market -- and on the New York economy -- that is far greater than the deals alone would indicate.
For the returnees were, and again are, the industry's risk takers (albeit this time around, most are risking other people's money). Institutions, for the most part, buy buildings for the cash flow they already provide. Entrepreneurs buy buildings that they feel they can turn into winners.
"The institutions buy what looks good on the cover of a brochure," said Mr. Mendik, who just formed a joint venture with RB Realty, the financier Robert Bass's company, to buy New York office buildings. "We buy what will eventually look good on a brochure."
This is no minor distinction. The return of the old-timers to the market has made long-standing plans to revitalize neighborhoods doable, and swaths of buildings saleable.
"Two years ago, when I had a building to sell, I'd go to insurance companies, pension funds or foreign investors," said Michael Myers, chairman of the brokerage Corporate Realty Partners. "Today, I'd go straight to the New York entrepreneurs."
In fact, many of those entrepreneurs are going to the brokers. "I call every broker every week, asking if they have something for me," said Norman Sturner, whose Murray Hill Properties bought 1140 Avenue of the Americas, at 44th Street, and 225 East 43d Street, as the recession was ending.
The impact is particularly noticeable in lower Manhattan, where real estate experts have for decades suggested that obsolete office buildings be converted to residential use.
Indeed, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's much-heralded downtown plan includes juicy tax abatements to spur investors to undertake such conversions.
Institutions, leery of the risk involved whenever a building's use is changed, are not scrambling to get with the program. In contrast, Mr. Greenburger, whose Time Equities company lost several buildings to lenders in the recession, is about a month away from completing the conversion to residential of 47 West Street, a commercial building he held onto at Rector Street. In November he bought 56 Beaver Street with the same plan in mind.
Rockrose Development, the corporate name under which the Elghanayan family operates, bought 127 John Street for the same reason, and is eyeing several other Wall Street area properties. Joe Newman's Broadway Management and several others are looking for properties to convert.
They are moving fast when they find them. "I looked at 56 Beaver, and in half an hour told my broker I wanted it," said Mr. Greenburger, who paid $2.9 million for the building. "It was a beautiful building in excellent condition, and the price was right. This was an easy decision to make."
In fact, another buyer outbid Mr. Greenburger for the building, but that buyer's financing fell through. When that happened, Mr. Greenburger had a deal and financing in 72 hours, from a lender he says he dealt with extensively in the 80's. "It was a relationship loan to me," he said.
Such stories do not surprise Steven Spinola, president of the Real Estate Board of New York. "Tax problems are not the only reason we don't have REITs in New York," he said, referring to the Wall Street mechanism by which many owners take their buildings public. "Entrepreneurs make decisions fast. They don't want to deal with boards of directors, or to cede the power to run buildings their way."
WHILE most of the action is in the residential arena, Manhattan's office buildings are getting their share of attention, too. Louis Feil's organization recently bought 250 Park Avenue South, at 20th Street. Donald Trump now owns 40 Wall Street. The Bernstein brothers have bought land adjacent to Heron Tower, at 70 East 55th Street.
Douglas Durst, the late developer Seymour Durst's son, says he is ready to build an office tower on Times Square. Arthur Zeckendorf Jr. and his brother William have been assembling land on Eighth Avenue, not far from their massive office and apartment complex at 50th Street, and in July, along with several partners, bought 770 Lexington Avenue, an 18-story office building at 60th Street.
Harold A. Fetner, the 35-year-old son of the late developer Sidney Fetner, is most excited about the two apartment houses he is about to build on the Upper East Side. But he is buying two office buildings, too.
"We've never owned office buildings in Manhattan, but we have some foreign investors who say this is what they want," Mr. Fetner said.
Mr. Newman is converting 820 Second Avenue, the 44th Street building he recently bought, to commercial condominiums. He paid about $110 a square foot for the building; he has sold most of it to the Government of Syria for $225 a square foot.
"We knew the proximity to the U.N. would make this feasible," he said. Now he is looking for other commercial buildings, either to convert or manage traditionally. "We want buildings that were selling for $200 million in the 1980's and are asking maybe $60 million now," he said.
Nor is the activity limited to Manhattan. After a several-year hiatus, Forest City Ratner, Bruce Ratner's company, has resumed building new office towers at Metrotech, his huge office complex in downtown Brooklyn. He has also committed $180 million to retail development in the boroughs outside of Manhattan, and says he has identified another $180 million worth of developable sites. "We are doing more retail development now than we have in our entire history," he said.
The Queens-based developer Joshua Muss is looking for apartment buildings in neighborhoods like Flushing, where rents are fairly high. He is even considering selected sites for new office buildings.
"The boroughs are sadly underbuilt for first-class space," he said.
But what brings these people back now?
A myriad reasons. Many cite confidence in Mayor Giuliani's policies, particularly his tax abatement and revitalization programs. Many cite the low vacancy rate for rental housing. Many cite the availability of bargains. And many cite a light-at-the-end-of-the-tunnel mentality.
Rockrose, for one, spent much of the recession scrambling for tenants for the then-vacant and debt-ridden Carnegie Hall Tower, on West 57th Street. Now the building is fairly well leased, and in no danger of foreclosure, so the Elghanayans are back in buying mode.
"It is hard for someone like me to let a good opportunity go by," said H. Henry Elghanayan, Rockrose's chief executive. "But I couldn't start a new project when Carnegie Hall tower was still unleased."
Other entrepreneurs say they saw that tunnel light several years ago. "It took me two years to catch my breath, to realize that, even in the worst real estate depression I'd ever witnessed, our buildings were leasing," said Stephen L. Green, who says he is about to close on two Manhattan office buildings. "If money had been available, I would have started buying again in 1992."
And some developers are simply resuming projects that had been on indefinite hold. The Rudin family recently converted 55 Broad Street, the vacant downtown office building they have long owned, into a center for fledgling interactive technology companies. This year, Mr. Muss expects to finally build Renaissance Plaza, the office-and-hotel complex in downtown Brooklyn that he has tried to finance for 13 years. He is expanding a shopping center he owns in Jackson Heights, Queens, and adding 30,000 square feet to an office building in Flushing.
"I'm working with lots of properties we've owned for a while," he said.
Similarly, for nearly a dozen years Larry Silverstein, who lately has done most of his property buying in Washington, D.C., and Michigan, has wanted to build rental housing on the square block he owns that spans 11th to 12th Avenues and 41st to 42d Streets. First, there were zoning problems, then there were legal problems, then the recession hit. This year, finally, he expects to "get the shovels in the ground" for two 40-story apartment houses, with 900 units each.
But the biggest factor drawing the entrepreneurs back to market is that the lenders have finally loosened their purse strings, even for people who could not pay their debts in the recession.
"Many of them could have worked through their problems if the Fed had not clamped down on the banks," said Benjamin V. Lambert, chairman of Eastdil Realty, a real estate investment bank. "These people still have an enormous amount of intangible equity: their track records from the 70's and 80's."
Moreover, a new set of lenders have come to town: venture capital funds like Tiger, Odyssey and the like. Unlike the more traditional lenders, they are willing to buy buildings that are in less than tiptop shape.
"These funds will invest or lend money on their perception of how well a building can do in the future, because that's the only way they'll get their 20 percent returns," said Joel G. Shapiro, a real estate partner at the accounting firm BDO Seidman.
INCREASINGLY, the funds are partnering up with people who have long track records in turning buildings around. For example, under Mr. Mendik's arrangement with RB Realty, RB will provide most of the capital. Mr. Mendik will scout out and renovate the buildings. "We are talking about buildings that need substantial work, and that's where our talent comes in," Mr. Mendik said.
On the surface, all the hustle and bustle may sound like the 80's redux. It is not. Most of the entrepreneurs learned from their mistakes and those of others, and know what to avoid this time around.
"I won't put up another condo," said Donald Zucker, whose last major condominium building, the Fortune in Murray Hill, hit the market in early 1992, and still has not sold out completely. "With a condo, interest rates eat you up alive, and once you've sold the units, the building is gone. With a rental, even if you have to take low rents in a terrible market, you can usually hang on until the market turns around."
Mr. Zucker, who spent the last few years building houses in Smithtown, L.I., now is putting up a 12-story, 195-unit rental building at Houston and Elizabeth Street.
Many others say that this time, they are less likely to go it alone. "In the 80's the banks were so forthcoming and our own business generated so much money that we didn't need outside funds," said Mr. Greenburger. "Now we look for outside equity."
And many have learned to set a ceiling on what they will pay, even for a property they really want. Mr. Newman, who spent the past few years laboring under a staggering $1.75 billion in debt -- and lost his entire portfolio of 12 million square feet -- recently partnered with C.S. First Boston to buy Cityspire, the infamous "whistling building" at 156 West 56th Street. He says he had been interested in the building for more than a year, but balked at the owner's asking price of $50 million.
"It just wasn't worth it," said Mr. Newman, who got the building for $38 million.
How long the New York entrepreneurs will keep buying and building is anyone's guess. An imminent building boom a la the 1980's is unlikely. That kind of money is not available, and even if it were, land prices and construction costs are still too high to make much new construction feasible.
Mr. Zucker, for one, would love to put up more rental housing, but the numbers just don't work. "I can't find a piece of land in a location that will give me the kinds of rentals I need to support the cost of construction," he said.
Competition for existing buildings is intense, as would-be investors who are not well-versed in real estate follow the old-timers' lead.
"When experienced investors come back into an area, it is a good indication of a trend," said Rosina K. Abramson, a Manhattan real estate lawyer who has several clients who are looking for New York property. "They see so much money chasing deals in New York that they are interested, too."
The influx of new buyers is already driving prices up. "Every building I'm bidding on has five other bidders," Mr. Newman said. He should know: Mr. Myers was pretty sure he could get Cityspire for his clients for $34 million; Henry Elghanayan bid on it, too; only after topping their prices did Joe Newman and First Boston get the building.
Such tales are echoed all over town. Mr. Silverstein bid on Financial Square, a downtown building, but lost it to Germany's Paramount Group last year. Paramount paid $135 million. "Even $115 million would have been pushing it," Mr. Silverstein said.
Mr. Myers offered a portfolio of 14 Greenwich Village properties to about 80 people, and got 29 offers. The portfolio went for $14 million, nearly 40 percent more than Mr. Myers had anticipated. "Two years ago I'd have brought it to half the people, gotten maybe 5 or 10 offers, and sold it for $10 million or $11 million, tops," he said.
As happy as the uptick is making sellers, it is scaring the would-be buyers. Hal Fetner bid $22 million for 345 Park Avenue South, near 25th Street; another investor group got it for $24 million. "You're definitely seeing prices go up, and it's making me nervous," Mr. Fetner said. "Too many people are showing up with foreign investors in tow, who don't care about returns. I can't compete against them."
INDEED, some of the local entrepreneurs already are walking away from deals. Mr. Sturner was about to pay $65 million for 850 Third Avenue, at 51st Street, when the Chicago financier Sam Zell made a last-minute $70 million bid. Mr. Sturner refused to meet it.
"One thing we've decided not to do, which we did in the 80's, is chase deals," he said. "Back then, you paid anything because you knew someone else would pay you more."
Still, even if prices keep climbing, it is unlikely the New York entrepreneurs will move back to the sidelines any time soon. They just seem too delighted to be wheeling and dealing in their hometown again.
F. Anthony Zunino and Richard Berry (hence the name ZuBerry, their corporate entity) bailed out of almost all of their New York properties in 1986. They spent most of the recession developing garden apartments in Houston. They loved how easy it was to get approvals to build or alter, and they certainly made money, but the culture shock got them.
"Out there you send tenants cards on birthdays, people move if you raise your rent a nickel, and the amenity that excites them is a huge TV in a club room where they can watch Monday night football," Mr. Berry said. "It is just hard to work outside of New York when you have New York blood in your veins."
Since 1994, ZuBerry has sold most of its Houston property. It has taken a big equity share in 641 Avenue of the Americas, a 20th Street building with a lot of architects, public relations firms and other service-company tenants. It bought 116 West 14th Street, a small office building that it has converted to loft apartments and four floors of commercial space. And it bought a handful of other small commercial buildings, many with off-beat tenants, that the partners will operate as is.
"It is good to operate in the hip world again, where the people you deal with have interesting things to say," Mr. Berry said.
Others note that nothing beats being able to reach out and touch their buildings. When Sidney Fetner died eight years ago, his son decided to branch out of New York. He built a 50,000-square-foot warehouse in Springfield, Va., and has a warehouse project going in Dayton, Ohio, right now.
"I felt with computers and airplanes, I could manage," Hal Fetner said.
Manage he did -- but, he discovered, the psychological oomph was gone.
"I realize now how much I enjoy driving by my property and smiling, or taking my friends, or even my bankers, to my building, and saying, 'This is mine,' " he said.

HEADLINE: The Smart Way to Ease Big Cities' Crush

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Thomas Friedman's March 20 column, "Bangkok Bogs Down," captures well the unsustainability of urban growth patterns in the developing world, but gets the prescribed cure wrong: "Big Government." 
 Big Government in the United States and everywhere else has solved urban congestion problems by building more road capacity. This has led to more congestion, not less.
What is required is "smart government." The sustainable solution to Bangkok's congestion does require more mass transit and some road improvements, but above all it requires a market in tradable vehicle-use permits like the one we developed to attack Mexico City's congestion and air pollution problems. This market would allocate the available "ecological budget" in an equitable and cost-effective manner.
Without such ecological limits, the world's large cities are destined to become like Bangkok, and several, such as Mexico City and Sao Paulo in this hemisphere, are well on their way.
 
HAYNES C. GODDARD
Cincinnati, March 21, 1996
The writer is on the faculty at the Instituto Tecnologico Autonomo de Mexico in Mexico City and at the University of Cincinnati.

HEADLINE: The Downsizing Myth

BYLINE: By H. Erich Heinemann; H. Erich Heinemann is head of Heinemann Economic Research, a division of Brimberg & Company, an institutional brokerage.

 BODY:
The United States is not downsizing. It is upsizing. The economy is not growing as fast as some economists wish it would, but it is expanding.
Although you might not know it from the media reports, the current expansion is five years old. In that time, companies have been hiring steadily. Since March 1991, the total number of civilian workers has risen about eight million. And contrary to the reports about managerial downsizing, half the new jobs have been classified as managerial or professional. 
 Of course, cutbacks at large companies like AT&T are painful. But the overall job market may actually be more stable than earlier in the postwar period. For instance, layoffs as a percentage of employment -- measured by initial claims for unemployment insurance -- have averaged 18 percent thus far in the 1990's, close to a 50-year low.
Blue collar workers haven't benefited from this upsizing in the job market, but they haven't been hurt either. The number of production jobs in manufacturing has held steady at about 12.6 million -- almost the same number as in 1946.
And real wages? Pundits claim that salaries have gone down. But they use figures from the Bureau of Labor Statistics that are misleading, because its calculations exclude benefits and bonuses, the fastest-growing parts of workers' compensation. When they are included, the average real compensation is now about $16.75 an hour (in 1992 dollars), up more than 2 percent from last year.
Real consumer spending for goods and services per hour worked -- the mirror image of compensation -- has risen at a rate of about 1 percent per year since the mid-1970's.
Of course, deap anxiety exists. But the change in the economy is what is causing the problem: Jobs have been moving from Fortune 500 companies to small business, the engine of expansion. And women, who have won almost two of every three new jobs in the last 30 years, have displaced men, especially older men.
This transition is painful, but it is the slow growth in living standards that is the country's main economic problem. The only reliable solution to the slow pace of upsizing is more investment and more productivity. That's what the politicians should be be working on.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Treasury Issues To Be Offered During Week

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financings this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and two- and five-year notes being auctioned on Wednesday and Thursday.
At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.95 percent and the rate on the six-month issue was 5 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.75 percent, and the five-year note at 6.05 percent.

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 536 words

HEADLINE: A Look at Europe's Future

 BODY:
The 1991 Treaty on European Union set out an ambitious plan for political, economic and monetary union by the end of this decade. With the decade more than half over, much of that agenda remains wishful. Europe's governance structures are unwieldy. Its quest for a common foreign and security policy stumbled badly in Bosnia. Only 3 of the European Union's 15 countries now meet the deficit target for the single currency.
This week, the 15 member governments open what amounts to a yearlong constitutional convention with a mandate to revise the treaty. The conference agenda is ostensibly open, but participants have already agreed to focus on procedural issues like faster decision making, unanimous versus majority voting and increased cooperation in law enforcement. These are important, but Europe also needs to address the larger questions and should consider scaling back, or at least delaying, some of its unrealistic goals. 
 The clearest example is the commitment to launch a common currency by 1999. Germany and France are wedded to this goal as the embodiment of true union, even though neither would now meet the stringent economic standards for participation. Among other criteria, countries must reduce their deficits to 3 percent or less of gross domestic product. Germany's deficit stands at 3.6 percent, France's at 5 percent. Britain, Italy, Spain, Greece and Portugal are even further from the target.
While it is theoretically possible for countries like Germany and even France to reach the target next year, it makes little sense. Both should be reducing their double-digit unemployment rates, not chasing arbitrary monetary and fiscal targets. France's Government triggered widespread labor unrest last year with its initial plans for budgetary austerity. Unemployment rates and budget deficits are even higher elsewhere in the European Union.
Creating a common European currency would be a convenience to international businesses and would force close coordination of economic policies. But it is not a necessity for continued union.
Forging common European foreign and defense policies is an admirable goal and one that could ease the burden on the United States to intervene directly in places like Bosnia. But the plan, which will be reviewed at the conference, needs more careful groundwork. As Bosnia showed, European countries are not yet prepared to take difficult decisions, submerge national interests or deploy troops effectively. France's recent decision to seek European defense coordination within NATO might make more effective European military cooperation possible in the near future.
The dream of European unity has achieved much in the last four decades. As it evolved from a narrow coal and steel community to a broad political and economic union, it has overcome the traumas caused by German aggression in two world wars and built a remarkably close partnership between Germany and France, long bitter rivals. It has brought increased trade and prosperity to Europe and America alike.
A realistic retreat now on currency targets will not shatter the European dream. On the contrary, it will conserve strength for the expanding challenges of the future.
