HEADLINE: Financial Crisis Is Gripping Smaller Cities of New York

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: UTICA, N.Y.

 BODY:
This pretty, rusting city beside the Mohawk River is going broke. A few months ago, it used $3 million set aside for a new courthouse and other construction projects to pay bills. This month, it managed to pay its employees only because the state speeded up a chunk of aid.
And so, facing a deficit said to exceed 10 percent of Utica's $36 million budget, Mayor Edward A. Hanna proposed the unthinkable. He proposed eliminating spending on the Utica Public Library, the zoo and the children's museum. Even worse, to many here, he proposed laying off police officers and firefighters. 
 The Mayor's prescription provoked such a storm of outrage that the city's Common Council basically ignored it and, last week, rolled back the cuts -- without, as even the Council president acknowledged, resolving the lurking deficit.
"By August, we're going to be absolutely broke," the Mayor said after the Council's vote, voicing a fear his opponents say is exaggerated but one supported by fiscal monitors such as the state's Comptroller, H. Carl McCall.
And Utica may not be alone. A fiscal crisis, like the one that racked New York City in the 1970's, has gripped the state's smaller cities, making this city's convulsions far from extraordinary.
With alarming frequency, cities like Utica, Rome, Schenectady and Niagara Falls have found themselves staggering under the crush of budget deficits. In the last two years, the finances of Troy and Newburgh degenerated so badly that the state stepped in, creating fiscal oversight agencies like the ones that have monitored New York City and Yonkers for two decades.
The crisis, simply, reflects the fact that the cost of providing municipal services has risen as rapidly as revenue from taxes and state and Federal aid has fallen.
More broadly, however, it reflects the gnawing decline of the state's urban cores, as the economy lurches along, property values fall and companies, jobs and finally people pack up for the suburbs or other states. And that, according to the cities' advocates, threatens to erode the state's overall economic viability.
"It's not just an isolated problem in a few cities," said Peter A. Baynes, the deputy director of the New York State Conference of Mayors in Albany. "It's really something that's happening across the state."
The crisis has forced many cities to raise taxes, despite the prevailing antitax climate, or to make cuts in core services once thought politically untouchable. In some cases, they have done both, causing considerable voter anguish while barely denting the problem.
Schenectady raised property taxes 4 percent and laid off 19 firefighters earlier this year. Last week, the new Mayor of Troy, Mark P. Pattison, let go eight police officers, including the entire mounted unit, despite having raised property taxes 21 percent and water rates 38 percent. And Troy still faces a deficit.
 
Cities' Declines Worse Than State's
In a survey of 25 of New York's cities, released last Friday, Moody's Investors Service found that "most are struggling to maintain fiscal balance" and concluded that would continue.
"While the state's economic growth has lagged behind that of the nation, cities' declines have been greater and more extensive than the state's," the credit-rating agency said in its weekly report, "Credit Perspectives." And, the report said, "New York cities will likely continue to function under a high level of stress for at least the next several years."
The scope of the crisis seems small compared with the more prominent woes of the state's larger cities, particularly New York City, where Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has had to wrestle down annual budget gaps of $2 billion to $3 billion. In many ways, however, the solutions are more elusive.
While the crisis predates the current budget impasses in Washington and Albany, today's political realities have all but erased hope for a bailout from above. Nor is there much hope that the state's economy will turn around soon. According to budget experts, the fiscal troubles in the smaller cities may hamper a recovery by forcing out more jobs and people.
"That's really the fear," Mr. McCall said. "As you increase taxes and depress services, then you lose population. The downward spiral continues."
New York's cities, like those throughout the Northeast, have been struggling for decades, of course, as urban ills have spread and the middle class has fled. But the new crisis stems from two specific, related events in the early 1990's.
First, the state, under Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, began to cut its aid to local governments, which relied heavily on it to supplement their budgets. The aid, known as revenue sharing, has fallen by nearly half since 1989, to slightly more than $500 million this year.
At the same time, the state's economy fell into a recession from which it has not yet recovered. That has eroded property values, the major source of tax revenues, especially for smaller cities. It has also driven out factories and businesses, further cutting tax revenues by shrinking the tax base.
 
64% of Cities Had Property-Value Fall
In a report last month, the Conference of Mayors found that 64 percent of the state's cities had a decline in property values in the last year alone, accelerating the trend that began in the early 1990's.
Edward C. Farrell, the group's executive director, said the erosion had forced cities to raise property taxes on the properties that remained to keep the same revenue level. With the reductions in state aid, he said, the cities can no longer raise enough to pay the rising cost of basic services, like garbage collection and public safety.
Even with rising taxes and budget cutting, some cities have not been able to keep up. In the last five years, six cities -- Gloversville, Jamestown, Newburgh, Rome, Troy and Utica -- have had to borrow money to cover operating deficits. Deficit financing, which requires approval from the State Legislature, provides an infusion of cash but at future costs and thus, to fiscal monitors, reflects grave instability.
Gov. George E. Pataki's new budget proposal offers little prospect of immediate help for the cities, although for a second year the Governor did not cut revenue sharing any further. Instead of aid, he proposed easing state mandates on things like construction projects and union arbitration. Those proposals, however, face opposition in the Legislature and, even if passed, might not produce significant savings quickly.
The Governor's budget did include $25 million in emergency aid for "distressed" local governments, but he reduced it to $10 million when revising his budget this month. And it remains unclear which cities would get it. "All of our members," Mr. Farrell said, "assume they qualify as distressed."
Utica's troubles are not unlike those facing most of the state's Rust Belt cities, the hubs that had thrived on industry since the 19th century. Since 1970, however, Utica has lost nearly 60 percent of its manufacturing jobs, according to the Moody's report, as well as 20,000 or so residents, leaving it with 68,000 today.
 
Buildings Are Empty On a Main Street
The outward signs of Utica's decline are everywhere. Along its commercial spine, Genesee Street, buildings stand empty, including the downtown's 14-story pride, the Bankers Trust Building. The city has 300 abandoned buildings, many in need of demolition.
Since the recession began, according to the Conference of Mayors, the city's property tax base has eroded 7.2 percent. The result, city officials said, was a $2.6 million drop in property tax revenue, to around $15 million a year.
All the while, the cost of services has continued to rise, mainly driven by salaries and benefits for unionized employees, including those for firefighters and police officers, which are mandated by the state's binding arbitration process.
Utica's fiscal problems, brewing for years, became more public last November, with the election of Mr. Hanna, an iconoclastic 73-year-old businessman who won a three-way race for Mayor as an independent.
After taking office in January, he declared the city on the brink of bankruptcy and proposed his painful budget for the fiscal year beginning in April, cutting the city's spending by $1.5 million in all.
"Listen, a city is not a city without the library," Mr. Hanna said, referring to his plan to eliminate city support for the library on Genesee Street, cutting $483,000 of its $700,000 budget. "But that's how broke we are."
Mr. Hanna's budget shocked almost everyone. Angry protests arose. A campaign to save the library began. A petition to save the Utica Zoo went around. More important, the unions lobbied the Common Council to reverse proposed layoffs of nearly 100 of the city's 600 employees.
"The condition of the city is not great," said Anthony F. Zumpano, the president of the Utica Professional Firefighters Association. "But it's not time to throw in the towel yet."
By the time it voted at a crowded meeting last Wednesday night, the Council had restored most of the Mayor's cuts. (The library still lost a little money and announced it would close its two neighborhood branches.) The Council did so by doubling parking fines to $20, hoping to raise $200,000, and by tapping Federal grants set aside for community development.
In approving the budget, however, Council members acknowledged that they had still neither covered a $1 million deficit left from this fiscal year nor repaid the $3 million taken from the capital fund. What is more, the new budget did not take into account at least $1 million in expenses expected in the coming year.
"We are human beings," Councilman Roger F. Amodio, a Republican, said, explaining the Council's reluctance to cut so drastically, even if holes remained. "We've done the very best we could with a bad budget."
It may not be enough. Unless Utica soon finds a way to cover its deficit, it may run out of cash to pay its bills, including those for the construction of its courthouse, for two new fire trucks to be delivered this spring and even for the payroll.
Utica's scramble raises the specter of a state takeover, like the one in Troy last year. That city, on the Hudson near Albany, had run up deficits for six straight years until it accumulated a $12 million deficit, more than a quarter of its budget, and risked defaulting on its bonds.
Two years ago, the Legislature created a board, headed by the State Comptroller, to review Troy's finances. Last year, with little improvement apparent, the board's powers were expanded to give it near-veto power, forcing the Mayor and Council to face up to the city's problems.
With the creation of the Troy Municipal Assistance Corporation, like the one that bailed out New York City in the 1970's when it could no longer borrow money to pay its bills, the city may manage to avoid a default. But it is not out of the woods. More cuts and higher taxes are likely.
"I don't think people have a real sense of the depth of the crisis," said Mr. Pattison, a Democrat who became Mayor in January.
Trying to avoid a repeat of Troy's near-collapse, the Comptroller has proposed legislation that would create a more uniform process for reviewing cities' finances, rather than leaving it to the Legislature to address case by case. Mr. McCall has said he hopes the process would identify crises in the making, like Utica's, and provide help before cities reach the brink.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Sunlight And Shadow

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO

 BODY:
California, land of the possible. So it used to be: the state where optimism was policy and the policy worked. Not today.
Two Republican Governors 50 years apart define the change. Earl Warren was an optimist whose political method was to appeal to the best in human nature. He himself had risen from poverty by way of the University of California -- which had nominal tuition then for state students -- and he worked to make that kind of opportunity available to all Californians. He was a tough prosecutor before he was Governor, but he also sought to reduce crime by easing social inequalities. 
 Pete Wilson first made his political mark as a progressive Mayor of San Diego. As Governor, he has increasingly turned to the politics of division, appealing to the anger of voters on such issues as immigration and affirmative action. His three-strikes law is making California the world capital of incarceration.
Education was a key aspect of California's spectacular growth in the decades after World War II. Governor Warren built large numbers of schools, enough to keep up with the rapid rise in the state's population. The rich sent their children to public schools.
Today California is near the bottom of state school rankings by average number of pupils per teacher. In spending per student, by 1992 it had fallen to 36th among the states. Private schools are booming.
Higher education was also a priority of Governor Warren and his successor, Democrat Pat Brown. The many campuses of the University of California and California State made up the best public system in the country. And it was all virtually free.
In the last five years, fees have quadrupled in the state system, so it is no longer the same ladder of upward mobility. Despite the higher costs to students, the university is pinched for funds because state support has been severely limited.
The growth industry in California is prisons. As recently as 15 years ago the state spent six times as much on higher education as on prisons. Last year the prison budget was larger -- and the disparity is going to grow.
It now takes about 10 percent of the state budget to operate the prisons. According to a study by the Rand Corporation, it will be 18 percent six years from now. Given mandatory spending for other things under state budget rules, that will leave just 1 percent for the universities.
Prison guards, who have a powerful union, now earn more than public school teachers. In fact, a guard at San Quentin has the same annual salary, about $45,000, as an assistant professor at the University of California.
Seventeen new prisons have been built in the last 15 years. Fifteen more will be needed by the year 2000, to house among others the flood of inmates serving 25 years to life under the three-strikes law. The construction cost will be around $5 billion.
You could not have a starker statement of a society's outlook than the figures for education and prisons in California. Of course crime is a serious problem. But political leaders worth the name would be thinking, urgently, about ways to deal with the problem other than incarcerating nonviolent criminals and holding convicts through harmless old age.
A study by the California Higher Education Policy Center, published last year by the Public Agenda Foundation, quoted a California businessman.
"In the 1950's and 60's," he said, "California had the greatest educational system that had ever existed on the face of the earth. Today I will pay more tuition for my child to go to third grade in private school than I paid for college and law school combined. I personally don't care because I am rich. I got a chance to be rich because education was available at virtually no cost. But what about the family that is situated today the way mine was? You create a lack of promise that has widespread implications."
The downgrading of education is dangerous for a reason beyond the effect on class divisions. Education is the crucial element for success in the new world economy. For California to fall behind the Asian states that make education a priority is to blight its future.
What happens in California, it used to be said, is a preview of what will happen to all of America. We have to hope that that is no longer true.

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
A Nostalgia For Death And Taxes

BYLINE: By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
The year is 2000. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, having eliminated term limits, is looking ahead to his next campaign, and Gov. George E. Pataki, halfway through his second term, is planning ahead, too.
Each has a team of advisers who meet weekly to plot strategy. They are all looking for the same thing: salable issues and slogans to satisfy the public mood. But they are having a hard time. What used to be so easy is no longer. A few things have changed in recent years. The old campaign promises have been kept too well. 
 Congress killed the biggest campaign issue. It pushed through that constitutional amendment, quickly approved by the states, mandating the death penalty for the killing of any law enforcement agent -- Federal, state or local. Prosecutors would no longer have any discretion in the most sensitive and highly publicized capital cases. Which meant candidates had been robbed of a no-lose campaign issue.
"The death penalty did it for us twice," recalled Arthur J. Finkelstein, Mr. Pataki's top campaign adviser. "Remember that D.A. from the Bronx? I'll always believe he re-elected George single-handedly." Mr. Finkelstein sighed when he thought about Robert T. Johnson, the Bronx District Attorney who objected to capital punishment, even in the death of a police officer. "A gift," said the nostalgic strategist.
Michael C. Finnegan, the Governor's counsel, bemoaned the loss of another issue. "We can't take on judges anymore, either," he said. "No more 'junk justice.' " The rage of the mid-1990's collapsed when both Congress and the New York State Legislature approved mandatory sentences across the board. Even mandatory bail. Now, sitting on the bench is about as challenging, and discretionary, as being Vanna White on "Wheel of Fortune 2000."
Of course, these laws have put many more people behind bars, even street peddlers and marijuana users. The state is still building more prisons and the city has added more police officers, so many that no mayoral candidate can promise "more cops" anymore.
"O.K., forget the bench," said former Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. "What about welfare cheats?" At Gracie Mansion, Mr. Giuliani was asking his welfare expert, Richard Schwartz, the same thing. Probably nothing there, Mr. Schwartz said. "We've really eliminated welfare as we knew it."
The whole country stole that issue. First, the states cracked down, led by former Gov. John Engler of Michigan, now the Vice President. Then Congress followed, turning welfare grants into block grants to the states and letting the states compete at reducing benefits. First, they put recipients of Home Relief -- childless, single adults -- into workfare programs; then, they eliminated Home Relief altogether and turned to women with children.
In New York City by 1999, 73.2 percent of the work-eligible women on welfare were in workfare programs. Mostly, they clean parks and municipal restrooms, replacing the city employees whom Mr. Giuliani dispensed with in his drastic downsizing. This has put a drag on the economy and reduced the city's population. "But the parks have never looked so good," the evergreen Parks Commissioner, Henry J. Stern, attests.
Mr. D'Amato grew wistful about taxes. "From Reagan on, that was always an easy one, wasn't it -- cut, cut, cut," said the former lawmaker, who concluded his Whitewater investigation late in 1998 and surprised everyone by retiring to a house with a pool in Island Park, L.I.
Before he left Washington, Mr. D'Amato saw Congress make off with the tax-cut issue: having bid down all income taxes, the politicians had no alternative but to raise revenue with a European-style VAT -- Federal, state and local value-added taxes on every sales transaction. Taxes are now so well hidden it doesn't pay to attack them.
Mr. Pataki turned out to be one of the last leaders elected with promises to cut income taxes. Many services declined, fares and tolls shot up and public schools suffered. But he kept his word, and New Yorkers, especially those rich enough to avoid subways and pay for private schools, were appreciative.
"We could promise better education," said Peter J. Powers, the First Deputy Mayor. "Or better transportation and health care."
"No money," Mr. Giuliani said.
"We could promise a better state university," Mr. Finnegan said. "Or a revamped hospital system and revinvestment in our infrastructure."
"No money," the Governor said. "Prisons are all the structure we can afford."
"Yeah," Mr. D'Amato said. "Besides, how are you going to put a 'better curriculum at the State University of New York' in a 30-second commercial? Or 'reinvestment in our infrastructure'? Forget about it."
They sighed. Oh for the days of stubborn prosecutors and independent judges. Oh for the return of death and taxes.

HEADLINE: Public Radio Being Pressed to Turn Its Success Into Independence

BYLINE: By ROBIN D. SCHATZ 

 BODY:
Deep in Appalachia, the residents of hardscrabble Pocahontas County, W. Va., (Pop. 9,000) do not think twice about where to tune their radio dials for country music, local news and helpful announcements about funerals, lost hunting dogs and school lunch menus.
Their favorite station is also their only local station: WVMR-AM of Dunmore, a public radio station where one of the most popular disk jockeys is Virginia Sheets, or Grandma Ginny, a 75-year-old livestock farmer who reads children's books on the air and is the host of the "Senior Power Hour." When a blizzard and subsequent floods ravaged the region in January, WVMR became the county's emergency command center. 
 "We're not alternative radio; we're primary radio," said Gibbs Kinderman, the general manager, who gets by with a mostly volunteer staff and an annual budget of about $100,000.
At WXPN-FM in Philadelphia, the public radio station licensed to the University of Pennsylvania, the acting general manager, Vincent Curren, faces problems that appear very different from those of Mr. Kinderman. Operating in an intensely competitive environment in a city of 4.5 million people who have access to 50 different AM and FM stations, Mr. Curren, who has a $2.2 million budget this year, must make his contemporary popular music station stand out. One creative solution: He is cooperating with the city's two other public radio stations in an experiment to promote one another's programs.
From struggling rural stations to big city-slicker stations that command healthy audience shares and generous donations, the success of public radio -- the 627 stations that receive support from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting -- has been one of the industry's best-kept secrets.
Public radio's dependence on Federal financing has been steadily declining in the last 15 years as many stations have improved their operations and attracted more money from businesses and listeners. Federal financing now accounts for an average of 14 percent of the budgets of public radio stations, compared with more than 30 percent in 1980.
"Public radio is very much a growth enterprise," said Tom Thomas, a consultant to the Station Resource Group, a research group in suburban Washington serving the public radio community. "In terms of numbers of people listening, the quantity of original programming being produced and the investments of communities through the public and private sector, we're doing better this year than last year and have been on a long-term, sustained period of growth."
But pressures are mounting for both large and small stations to increase their self-sufficiency and better serve their communities in the face of an increasingly inhospitable political climate, according to Mr. Thomas and other experts.
The Corporation for Public Broadcasting, the federally financed nonprofit organization that helps finance programming and operations for public radio and television, has been under fire by Republicans in Congress who question whether public broadcasting should be supported by taxpayer dollars.
In the last three years, Congress has rescinded $100 million in appropriated funds, according to the corporation and has proposed more cuts. The corporation, which currently gives about $275 million to public radio and television (about three-quarters of the money goes to television), is awaiting reauthorization by Congress, but its survival is no longer taken for granted.
As a result, public radio station managers are becoming shrewd business operators, starting entrepreneurial ventures to raise funds, reaching out for corporate underwriting dollars and considering consolidation and other cost-sharing moves with other public stations.
"I believe in a few years there will be little or no public funding," said Mr. Curren of WXPN, which has lost half a million dollars in Federal appropriations during the last three years. "That's what I'm using as a planning scenario."
Public television, with much bigger budgets and audiences, tends to dominate the debate over public broadcasting. But public radio is growing faster than the more mature public television sector, which is facing a barrage of competition within the television industry and from other forms of entertainment.
The recent boom in public radio has been impressive: according to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, financial support for public radio from businesses grew about 69 percent from 1989 to 1994, to $76 million, while support from subscribers grew about 68 percent, to $101 million. During the same period, business support for public television grew about 15 percent, listener support 13 percent.
In the last 10 years, the audience for public radio has doubled, from 9.8 million in 1985 to 19.7 million last year, while that of public television has been relatively flat, growing from 92.8 million to 95.2 million.
"Radio provides a medium that's accessible even as you're going about your daily life," Mr. Thomas said. Listeners are increasingly tuning into public radio's magazine-style programs, like "Morning Edition" and "All Things Considered," for analysis of national and global events, not to mention high-quality locally produced programming.
But public radio stations have already glimpsed the future. Regulations just passed by the corporation require the 403 grant recipients, which operate the 627 stations, to demonstrate that they really matter to their communities. By the year 2000, roughly 60 of those receiving grants will have to increase either their listening audiences or the percentage of their support from businesses and listeners to retain their eligibility for Federal financing, according to Rick Madden, director of radio projects and programming at the corporation.
Clearly, according to that criteria, public radio is doing something right. Besides doubling its listening audience in 10 years, consultants and station managers note that public radio is getting a highly educated, affluent audience with a high percentage of males 25 to 54 years old, the kind of listener most commercial stations "would give their eye teeth for," said Kurt Hanson, president of Accuratings, a Chicago-based rating service. Many public radio stations are now going to corporations armed with such demographic data to entice them to underwrite programs.
In Seattle, for example, the two public radio stations, KUOW-FM and KPLU-FM, have begun a joint underwriting program offering corporate sponsors a chance to reach the station's pooled audiences.
Last fall, Accuratings found that public radio was one of the fastest growing formats in a survey of eight major urban markets, including Boston, the home of WBUR, a real Horatio Alger of public radio. When Jane Christo became general manager at the tiny Boston University station in 1979, it had only about 70,000 listeners a week and an annual budget of $350,000 a year.
By focusing its format tightly on news and information and creating strong local programming, Ms. Christo increased the station's weekly audience to 414,000 in 1995, according to data from Arbitron, the leading ratings service. She also weaned it of university support and pumped its budget up to $6.5 million, of which only 10 percent comes from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting. Arbitron says the station is now the leader in the 25- to 54-year-old age group during several key time periods.
Business innovations abound elsewhere, too. In St. Paul, the highly successful 29-station Minnesota Public Radio network, which produces the popular "Prairie Home Companion," raises about $150 million a year from its mail-order business, which it reinvests in station purchases and other activities. Aggressive fund-raising by the network includes an emphasis on direct mail solicitations.
Even though the largest stations could manage to survive without Federal support, a loss of Federal support could put smaller and less prosperous stations like Mr. Kinderman's "at a substantial risk," Mr. Madden of the corporation said.
Still, some say public accountability is long overdue. Even Mr. Kinderman of WVMR, which gets about one-third of its budget from the Government and which cannot eke out much more from its depressed county, thinks it is healthy "to question the established verities and say what are the things that are worthy of public support."
"We struggle here economically," he added, "but that's appropriate because everyone else in our community is struggling, too."
Sometimes, when Mr. Kinderman is driving past the scenic landscape that drew him to Pocahontas County and hears an inexperienced disk jockey playing a "not very good" country tune on his station, he questions his commitment to public radio.
"But when the blizzards and the floods come, you know why you're doing it," he said.

HEADLINE: Nature Groups Say Foes Bear Friendly Names

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
Northwesterners for More Fish. The words conjure up visions of earth-shoed activists and leaping trout joined in battle against the greedy pillagers of the land.
That is just the kind of image a group of Washington consultants had in mind when they named this "grassroots coalition" for their new clients: big utilities and other companies in the Northwest under attack by environmental groups for depleting the fish population. 
 To environmentalists, Northwesterners for More Fish is just the latest example of "greenscamming," the increasingly common practice of giving environmentally friendly names to groups whose agendas have little to do with the welfare of the environment.
Examples of such groups abound. In Riverside County, Calif., a public relations firm organized Friends of Eagle Mountain on behalf of a mining company that wants to create the world's largest landfill in an abandoned iron ore pit. The National Wetlands Coalition was formed to fight the Endangered Species Act.
And a measure on the California ballot this Tuesday pits the Californians for Balanced Wildlife Management against the California Wildlife Protection Coalition over the hunting of mountain lions. The first group wants to kill them and the second wants to save them.
Even as the public has become disillusioned with large corporations, government and other American institutions, the environmental movement has remained widely popular. The widespread use of environmentally friendly names is industry's grudging tribute to the environmental movement.
A Gallup Poll last year showed that 63 percent of Americans considered themselves "environmentalists," while 34 percent did not. Sixty-two percent said they would give priority to the environment over economic growth while 32 percent said they would give economic growth priority over the environment.
"No one wants to dance with the devil, so they try to come up with a name that's not too devilish," said Bennett Beach, a spokesman for the Wilderness Society. "I suspect that as the country's becoming more and more environmentally sensitive, it's more difficult to be burdened with a name that speaks the truth about your intentions."
One nemesis of the Wilderness Society is the National Wilderness Institute, a group formed in recent years to roll back wetlands regulation in the Endangered Species Act. Though groups like this one assert that environmental regulations are overly burdensome and unnecessary, they recognize the value of an environmentally friendly name.
Other groups that environmentalists consider foes are the Wilderness Impact Research Foundation, a Nevada organization that represents logging, ranching and related interests; the American Environmental Foundation, a Florida property-rights group; the Abundant Wildlife Society of North America, which advocates for hunters, loggers and miners, and the Global Climate Coalition, an association of corporations concerned about regulations to control global warming.
"People sometimes create groups that try to fudge a little bit about what their goals are," said Hal Dash, the president of Cerrell Associates, a public relations firm in Los Angeles that has represented clients with environmental problems. "They want to create a patina of good guy-ness."
Mr. Dash, who represents the American Automobile Manufacturers Association, said he "fiddled with a lot of names" that he might have used for his client in a California campaign regarding requirements for electric cars.
"But we decided in our case it was silly, and the best thing to do was be the American Automobile Manufacturers Association," he said. "The press has spent less time worrying about a front group and more focusing on the issue."
In the case of Northwesterners for More Fish, the organization is barely three months old, and environmentalists are trying to "out" it.
One of its chief organizers is Eddie Mahe Jr., a veteran Washington political strategist and former deputy chairman of the Republican National Committee. Mr. Mahe and five other Washington insiders developed a plan several months ago to organize the groups as a grass-roots coalition in the Northwest, according to a planning memorandum given to The Times by environmentalists.
Its aim is to defeat environmentalists who say that utilities, aluminum companies and the timber industry are destroying fish habitats on the Columbia and other rivers. Chief among the environmental groups is Trout Unlimited, perhaps the inspiration for the new group's name.
Northwesterners for More Fish has a budget of $2.6 million for the next year to pay for the costs of establishing itself "as a credible group supporting positive solutions to enhancing fish populations," according to the memorandum. The group aims to limit Federal efforts to protect endangered fish species if the efforts might interfere with industries that rely on the river.
The budget includes $800,000 for television and radio advertisements and $100,000 to influence members of the news media. "The goal of this operation will be to identify supportive media and feed them information to complement and reinforce the paid media effort," the memorandum said.
"While the public can and should be swayed by having the facts on the issue, the message must also appeal at a gut, emotional level," the memorandum said.
Mr. Mahe's office referred calls about the group to a consultant in the Seattle area, Kay Gabriel, who said that she was not free to say what companies were paying the bills for the group. She said the group advocates "barging" fish around dams.
The Washington Water and Power Company provided a luncheon buffet for an organizing meeting of Northwesterners for More Fish in Spokane on Feb. 16 that followed a briefing by Senator Slade Gorton, Republican of Washington. Also present was an aide to Senator Larry E. Craig, Republican of Idaho.
It could not be learned who attended the session, but the list of invitees included mostly representatives of aluminum, chemical, mining, oil, power and timber companies.
"They don't give a damn about fish," said Glen Spain, the Northwest regional director of the Pacific Coast Federation of Fishermen's Associations. "This is an ersatz organization. It's like a Styrofoam dummy; it has no relationship to anything but the industries and their vested Federal coffer porkbarrel products."
Mr. Spain said his organization was actually a federation of fishermen's associations.

HEADLINE: U.S. May Buy Fast Computer From Japan

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
A Japanese computer maker may be on the verge of achieving what had previously been unthinkable in this country: selling a supercomputer to a United States Government laboratory.
Two of the three finalists now bidding to supply a $13 million to $35 million supercomputer to the National Center for Atmospheric Research, or NCAR, are Japanese electronics giants: Fujitsu Ltd. and the NEC Corporation. 
 According to several people familiar with the contract review, Fujitsu and NEC are seriously challenging the United States leader in the field, Cray Research Inc., which was recently acquired by Silicon Graphics Inc.
The impending announcement of a winner has piqued interest by both the United States and Japanese Governments, because supercomputers have long been symbols of national technical prowess and have remained at the heart of bitter trade disputes between the two nations.
In Japan, there are more than 100 United States-designed supercomputers in Government-financed laboratories. But a Federal agency has never turned to Japan for a supercomputer and NCAR has seldom strayed from a Cray -- of which it now has five. So an award of the contract to a Japanese computer maker could establish a beachhead in territory that for three decades has been the unassailable property of American computer makers.
The director of the center, Robert Serafin, said that precedents and trade politics would take a back seat to computing performance as the evaluation proceeded. "We have undertaken the equivalent of an international procurement," said Mr. Serafin, who declined to handicap the contestants. "We're playing it straight as far as the technical and scientific factors are concerned."
The Colorado-based laboratory is preparing to buy a new computer to do advanced global climate modeling into the next century.
The award, which will be made next month or in early May, will come after a yearlong review in which NCAR scientists have put dozens of supercomputers through painstaking performance tests. Because of the political sensitivity of the contract, NCAR has been unusually diligent in its testing procedures, industry experts said.
Cray has long dominated the market for weather-forecasting supercomputers, but its status was shaken last year after the European Center for Medium-Range Weather Forecasting in Berkshire, England, bought a $40 million system from Fujitsu. The European market is believed by many industry executives to be less biased by national political issues and a better gauge of pure technical factors.
The supercomputing business of the American national laboratories like NCAR has been the sole province of American companies -- beginning in the mid-1960's with the Control Data Corporation and then Cray Research, and more recently with start-up companies like Thinking Machines and Maspar.
And trade politics has long played a role. In 1987, for example, the United States Government successfully pressed the Massachusetts Institute of Technology not to buy a computer from NEC.
In 1990, Japan and the United States signed a trade agreement declaring that each nation would open its supercomputer market to the other. But even after that, in September 1990, an indication by the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory that it might evaluate a Japanese machine drew such criticism from Congress that lab officials backed down.
Since then, the inability of Japanese computer makers to sell even a single supercomputer to a United States research laboratory or university -- despite building many of the world's fastest machines -- has remained a sore point for the Japanese. And they, in turn, have routinely been accused by American corporate executives and Government officials of maintaining their own market restrictions.
Now, the impending NCAR supercomputer award comes as high-technology trade frictions between the United States and Japan are again heating up. Cray Research recently, and quietly, urged the Clinton Administration to put new pressure on the Japanese in the wake of the company's loss of two bids in the Japanese Government market, according to the newsletter Inside U.S. Trade. The publication reported that of 18 contracts for Japanese supercomputers in the last year, only 4 were awarded to United States companies.
"I have to say it feels like it has become tougher to do business in the public institutions in Japan," said Robert Ewald, president and chief operating officer of Cray Research.
But both Mr. Ewald and his Japanese competitors said they saw no evidence that political issues had played a role in the decision-making process at NCAR up to this point.
"We're in the hunt," said Tom Miller, sales and marketing vice president for Fujitsu's American subsidiary. "We feel that if this in fact turns out to be a truly open procurement, it's a tremendous opportunity for us."
Despite trailing in the market for the world's fastest computers, the Japanese have inexorably closed in on the speed advantage of American companies like Cray, I.B.M., and Intel. Today, the world's fastest supercomputer, according to a measuring system maintained by Jack Dongarra at the University of Tennessee, is a supercomputer made by Fujitsu that was installed at the National Aerospace Laboratory in Japan in 1993.
Moreover, 9 of the top 20 spots on Mr. Dongarra's list of the world's 500 fastest computers are now held by either NEC or Fujitsu. Currently, massively parallel supercomputers made by the Intel Corporation occupy the No. 2 and No. 3 positions on the list.
Fujitsu is now the world leader in absolute speed because the company has designed the world's fastest single processor, capable of 2.2 billion mathematical calculations a second.
Measuring computer speed is a tricky proposition, however. Mr. Dongarra's numbers measure pure calculating speed, akin to measuring the performance of a dragster, designed to go down a race-car track in a straight line as quickly as possible. Some computer experts argue that true performance is better measured by a balanced set of factors, more like a Formula One racing car that can also go through turns quickly.
That would mean that despite trailing on pure speed, Cray may still be able to win the contest based on its software and other factors.
"I think that NCAR could safely go with Cray on the basis of the numbers alone," said C. Gordon Bell, a veteran computer designer.

HEADLINE: Haitians at Center of Montreal Election

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH 

DATELINE: MONTREAL, March 24

 BODY:
Gilles Solomcariotte, a 40-year-old textile worker who emigrated from Haiti two years ago, is waiting for a bus on gritty Papineau Street, in a working-class district of northeast Montreal, the site of a fiercely contested election for a seat in the House of Commons.
Among the wooden-frame row houses strewn with "for rent" and "for sale" signs, posters hang from lampposts every few hundred yards to urge support for Pierre S. Pettigrew, the new Minister of International Cooperation. The battle in the Papineau-St. Michel district is the most important of six to be decided on Monday. 
 Mr. Pettigrew, recruited by Prime Minister Jean Chretien as part of a strategy to give his Cabinet greater French-speaking strength, is fighting to represent a district with the largest concentration of Haitians.
While Mr. Solomcariotte paces in the bus shelter, Mr. Pettigrew is in another part of the city as the host of the President of Haiti, Rene Preval. In his first official trip abroad, after stops in the Dominican Republic and the United States, Mr. Preval is making a celebratory visit to Montreal's Haitian population of 60,000. About a fifth of them are in Papineau-St. Michel.
Ever since announcement of the election in January, the welfare of Haiti has assumed an overarching importance in Canadian foreign policy, a fact that has not displeased Mr. Preval, though it has led some of the Ottawa Government's political opponents to cry foul.
Mr. Pettigrew, for instance, has already announced that Canada will spend $3 million on two new aid projects in Haiti. The Chretien Government has also in effect rescued a United Nations peacekeeping mission in Haiti by sending 700 troops there, at a cost of $22 million over the next four months, to support a contingent of 1,200 international troops that is to replace a force led by the United States.
"These are political strategems that we well understand," Mr. Solomcariotte, the textile worker, said in French, eyes brightening, lips breaking into a grin. "The candidate needs votes."
Mr. Solomcariotte said he missed Mr. Preval when he toured the district Saturday afternoon, but would see him Saturday evening when the President was to be guest of honor at a celebration featuring 2,500 supporters, Haitian singers, dancers and comedians in traditional costume.
"For me," the Haitian worker emphasized, "this visit comes at exactly the right time. I am a federalist for Pettigrew."
The Chretien Government says it is a "coincidence" that the visit comes the weekend before the tight electoral contest, in which Mr. Pettigrew, 44, an alumnus of the University of Quebec at Trois Rivieres and Baliol College, Oxford, is being challenged chiefly by Daniel Turp, 42, a University of Montreal constitutional lawyer and political adviser to the Bloc Quebecois.
The Bloc is a grouping of members of Parliament from Quebec who want the province to achieve independence, which almost became a reality upon the separatists' narrow defeat in a referendum on Oct. 30.
A victory for the Bloc would be a serious blow to Mr. Chretien, who is a Quebecer himself but who has fought the separatists throughout his long political career and who is now desperately trying to keep Canada together.
Dismissing suggestions of a plot to sway the election, Mr. Chretien told reporters in Ottawa last week, "If the President decided to come this weekend, we would not tell him to go back home until after the election."
Alain Gagnon, a political scientist at McGill University, is among many who think the Prime Minister may be a little disingenuous.
"Canada and Quebec both want to be associated with improvement in Haiti," he said. "So Mr. Chretien has certainly encouraged Mr. Pettigrew, as minister responsible for international aid, to make this visit now. If we didn't have such a major Haitian community, Canada would be much more discreet and much less forthcoming in its support to Haiti."
Amid all the talk of coincidence, Foreign Affairs Minister Lloyd Axworthy said wryly, "It's amazing how these things work out."
Mr. Preval, 53, a trained agronomist who once operated a bakery in Port-au-Prince and had been close to the man he replaced, Jean-Bertrand Aristide, has voiced annoyance at the suggestions that he is being used in Canada's political games.
"The Canadian Government respects Haitian sovereignty," he said a little testily in Montreal on Saturday, "and I keep myself from mixing in Canadian political affairs."
Papineau-St. Michel has been hard hit by Montreal's lingering recession. Mr. Solomcariotte is far luckier than many of the residents, about a third of whom are jobless or collecting welfare. His wife also works, to make sure his two children stay in school.
"Aristide got some of his education here," he said. "Good schooling is terribly important."

HEADLINE: POLITICS: FOCUS ON JOBS;
House Debate Hits Home on Jobs Program

SERIES: AN AMERICAN PLACE: Workers and Training

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINERIP 

DATELINE: CANTON, Ohio, March 24

 BODY:
The Job Training Partnership, a Federally financed program to retrain dislocated workers, is widely respected here by Republicans and Democrats, business, labor and educational leaders.
Managers at local companies including the Timken Company, the Detroit Diesel Corporation, Park Farms and Morton Salt, praise the skills of the retrained workers. "Pleased? You bet," says David Smith, a research supervisor at Timken, the largest local employer. Last year he hired four men and women who had been retrained on computer-run milling and lathing machines. "They had been exposed to state-of-the-art machinery," he said. 
 At his inauguration last year, Gov. George Voinovich, a Republican, lauded Canton's "Chicken College," another of the job agency's programs, which trained a primarily minority, unemployed group of 18- to 21-year-olds for jobs processing chickens at Park Farms.
Both Ohio Senators, Mike DeWine, a Republican, and John Glenn, a Democrat, were part of a recent bipartisan 84-to-16 Senate vote to maintain current financing levels for job training, a measure supported by the Clinton Administration.
But so far, the more conservative Republican House leadership is not going along. The House leaders want to reduce money for job training by 30 percent, and eliminate some programs altogether, including one that provides 600,000 summer jobs for youth. They have put moderate House Republicans, like Ralph Regula, the local Congressman who has long supported such legislation, in a tight spot.
Mr. Regula is one of three dozen moderate Republican Congressmen being targeted for lobbying by groups like the National Association of Counties and the American Association of Community Colleges, which favor the higher financing level.
"I called his office," said Dr. John McGrath, president of Stark Technical College. The college helps run the computerized machine operator training program here in partnership with the Federal agency. "I know Ralph is a strong proponent of this kind of technical training," Dr. McGrath said. "Ralph Regula helped bring our college into existence, he's the father of our college."
"I did call his office," said Daniel Sciury, president of the Greater Canton A.F.L.-C.I.O. Council. "I have never heard Ralph once ever indicate anything but praise for this program."
But whether that will translate into a vote this time around is another question. Since Newt Gingrich became Speaker of the House, even 25-year Congressional veterans like Mr. Regula have had to toe the line. For his part, Mr. Regula says he is still making up his mind. "It's not an easy answer, 'Yes the Senate level of funding is better,' or 'Yes the House level,' " he said.
Stark County in northeastern Ohio is a good reflection of the nation when it comes to voting patterns and the economy. While unemployment here is several points below what it was during the last Presidential election, there is still much economic turbulence. Many workers' lives have been touched by downsizing and outsourcing, mergers and acquisitions, and while new jobs can be found here, they often do not pay as well as the jobs that were lost.
The experiences of Chris Suteu, 33, Linda Olinger, 41, and Lee Andrews, 32, all dislocated workers being retrained by the job agency here, are not unusual. All three were longtime workers for Controlled Power Corporation, a locally owned manufacturer of switch gear equipment for transit systems. They made $11 to $15 an hour and said that until 1989 it was a good place to work.
Then, Controlled Power was acquired by a large Chicago company, Henry Crown and Company. The workers say Crown ran the company into the ground and Dan Marchak, a vice president who has been with Controlled Power for 14 years, agrees. "I attribute it to this age of outside acquisitions and mergers in the 1980's," Mr. Marchak said. "They bought a company that they didn't understand."
By 1995, Controlled Power had gone from a high of 410 workers to 150 and was on the verge of closing. Mr. Andrews recalls the engineering department misreading blueprints and having workers build a switching system backward, losing two weeks of work. Ms. Olinger said: "Everything we did, we had to redo to meet quality standards. They had to pay tons of overtime."
In 1995, the original owner James Owens, repurchased Controlled Power. "We had a meeting," Mr. Andrews said, "and Mr. Owens said Crown should have just let everyone stay at home and mail them their checks, they would have lost less money that way." There was no union, and by last fall, many top paid workers were let go, including Mr. Suteu, Ms. Olinger and Mr. Andrews.
The Controlled Power vice president, Mr. Marchak, said that to compete, "we have to get into less skilled, lower wage jobs." (Crown officials did not respond to an interview request.)
After being laid off from his $15-an-hour industrial painting job, Mr. Suteu says he could not find anything for half that wage. He, Ms. Olinger and Mr. Andrews are among 20 dislocated workers now being retrained as computerized machine operators in an eight-hour-a-day, five-day-a-week, five-month program created by the Job Training Partnership.
The idea came from the council of local businesses that advises the Federal agency here. Through the years the council has been headed by managers from the biggest local companies, including Timken, Hoover and Diebold. They have not been able to find enough operators qualified to run computerized lathing and milling machine and so the Job Training agency created the intensive course in cooperation with Stark Technical College, which provides the state-of-the art equipment and classroom space.
More than 100 people have applied for each class. For the first class last year, 20 were enrolled, 18 completed the course and 16 got jobs at an average wage of $8.18 per hour; in the second class, 17 enrolled, 14 completed and 13 were placed at $7.46 an hour on average. "You have to be obsessed to pass this," Ms. Olinger said. "It's demanding -- we started with six weeks of remedial math."
Job Training has created similar programs for garbage and recycling truck drivers (10 of 14 placed in the first class at an $8-an-hour average) and chicken processors (at $7 to $8 an hour) at Park Farms. Workers trained by the jobs agency have a retention rate three times higher at Park Farms than those hired off the street.
In an interview on Thursday, Congressman Regula, who began his working life as a teacher and principal, agreed that the Job Training program for dislocated workers was effective here, but carefully paired any positive comments with cautions. "I think Stark County has done an exceptionally good job," he said, then added, "I'm not sure that is the case of job training everywhere." Asked about the summer job program for youth, he said, "I suspect it's done well in Stark County," then added "but in a lot of cities, it's just buying peace." He said he was "supportive" of the higher budgeting level for job training in the Senate, but added that he agreed with the House leadership's emphasis on balancing the budget and finding offsetting cuts for any "addbacks."
There are some here like Mr. Sciury, the labor leader, who criticize Mr. Regula for "being in lockstep with Newt." They say he and his fellow moderates are being trampled by the freshman Republicans. Last week, after the Senate voted for the extra job training money, several of those freshman Republicans marched into the office of Dick Armey, the majority leader, and demanded that the House hold the spending line.
But there are others who believe that moderates like Mr. Regula, a gentleman farmer who gets elected by large majorities without taking PAC money, whose views are at the heart of Ohio Republicanism, may have something up their sleeves on this one.
That scenario goes like this: The reason the Senate Republicans got so enthusiastic about job training was that their majority leader, Bob Dole, was hurt in the primaries by Patrick J. Buchanan's hammering on worker and job issues and Mr. Dole does not want a repeat of that against President Clinton in the fall. They point out that Mr. Gingrich has promised to defer to Senator Dole to help his bid for the White House. They predict that when the House and Senate versions of the job training bills are hammered out in conference next week, it will be the conservative Republican freshmen who come out squirming, not the moderates.
Mr. Regula hinted as much. "The press has tended to treat the House freshmen as a monolithic group," he said, "but that may get a lot less so as the election gets closer."
"A lot of freshmen," he added, "may discover they have good Job Training Partnerships in their districts."
 
An American Place
 Throughout the Presidential election year, articles in this series will examine Canton, Ohio, and surrounding Stark County, a political bellwether for decades.

HEADLINE: Benjamin Franklin Bills Ready to Become Hot Item

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 24

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve will release new $100 bills with off-center likenesses of Benjamin Franklin on Monday, and, based on past experience, most of them will soon be abroad.
The bills are technologically advanced to combat increasingly sophisticated counterfeiters, but the United States Treasury Department said it would not immediately replace the existing $100 bills. They will be replaced as they wear out, so it could take several years to replace them all. 
 The new bills will be available only on a limited basis at first, but they will be in wide use by next month at financial capitals around the world. New bills worth about $80 billion have been printed, which represents about one-third of all $100 bills in use.
Currently, the total amount of American currency outstanding is $380 billion, which would be almost $4,000, on average, for every household in the United States. But studies show that Americans hold far less cash than that per household.
Where has the money gone? To countries like Russia, Mexico and Saudi Arabia, where it forms the underpinnings of underground economies.
Some American currency is used abroad for transactions, both legal and illegal. But foreigners also hoard $100 bills because they worry about the value of their local currency.
Almost two-thirds of the currency in circulation here and abroad, measured in terms of value, is in $100 bills. That has not always been the case. Twenty-five years ago, $100 bills represented only one-fifth of the value of all currency, according to Federal Reserve data.
Counterfeiters in the Middle East have turned out exceptionally high-quality $100 bills in recent years, prompting the newly designed bill. The United States Secret Service came across a new, far more sophisticated fake note in Lebanon about six years ago. It was dubbed the Superdollar. About $10 million worth of the counterfeit bills have been confiscated, although officials do not know the extent of the problem.
In the United States, domestic counterfeiting has been made easier and cheaper as a result of new personal computer technology. Because of these counterfeiting successes, there are plans to redesign other bills.
This is the first time since 1929 that the United States has significantly changed the design of its currency. The new $100 bills incorporate a variety of small changes intended to thwart counterfeiters. For that reason, the Treasury Department, citing security concerns, has refused to disclose all of the changes. But it gave one example, saying that the words "United States of America" are printed in tiny letters on Benjamin Franklin's coat.
More American currency held abroad seems to be winding up in more official channels.
In the last year, foreign central banks have increased their holdings of United States Treasury notes by 25 percent, to $524 billion from $414 billion, according to data from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. This means that foreigners are increasingly exchanging dollars for those nations' local currencies. The American dollars wind up in those countries' central banks, which then use them to buy United States notes, said Martin Mayer, a guest scholar at the Brookings Institution, who is completing a book on banking.
Mr. Mayer also said that the Federal Reserve branch in Los Angeles had recently built new vaults to hold all the cash that has been brought back into this country as a result of the Latin American drug trade, which is often transacted with $100 bills.

HEADLINE: CHINA IS OFFERING HIGH-LEVEL TALKS TO TAIWAN LEADER

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 24

 BODY:
In a gesture of conciliation to President Lee Teng-hui after his resounding election victory in Taiwan, China called today for a meeting between Mr. Lee and its own President, Jiang Zemin, and for opening direct air, shipping and mail links across the Taiwan Strait.
"The door is open," said Shen Guofang, a Foreign Ministry spokesman. "The obstacles today lie with the Taiwan authorities." 
 In Taipei, Prime Minister Lien Chan responded by saying Taiwan's leaders wanted to explore both a "peace agreement" and a long-term policy of "detente" with China.
Whether the upbeat remarks signaled a turning point in China's struggle with Taiwan, or simply an optimistic rewording of each side's still-divergent positions on Taiwan's future, will only become clear in the coming weeks. Beijing has raised the possibility of a top-level meeting before, though the two sides' leaders have never met.
Yet today's comments appeared to reflect a willingness by leaders in both countries to reduce the chance of military conflict, which has hovered ominously in recent weeks. On a day when each side was watching the other carefully, it suddenly seemed conceivable that Beijing and Taipei could resume the discussions about expanding civilian ties. The talks were suspended nearly a year ago, and new talks seemed impossible just a few days ago.
Beijing has been raining insults on Mr. Lee for weeks, casting his efforts to raise Taiwan's international profile as strivings for independence. It has called him, among other epithets, a two-faced autocrat and a sponsor of organized crime. But today Beijing cut the invective.
Neither Mr. Shen, who was quoted by a Beijing-controlled newspaper in Hong Kong, nor a commentary by the official New China News Agency criticized Mr. Lee. Instead, they tacitly accepted his victory, which was also reported today in several Chinese Government-controlled newspapers.
There was no mention of a third round of the war games that Beijing has recently carried out near Taiwan in an explicit attempt to intimidate its voters and that were scheduled to end on Monday.
Mr. Lee had hinted that after the election he would make a visit that could surprise everyone -- to a world capital. It was not clear if he referred to Beijing, or to Washington, or to somewhere else.
A meeting with Mr. Jiang, should it ever materialize, would mark a greater policy change for Taiwan than for China. Beijing has long encouraged closer official contacts with Taiwan, though few mainlanders are allowed to visit there. Taiwan limits official contacts, but hundreds of thousands of Taiwan's residents visit China each year.
Today's comments by officials of China and Taiwan, while decidedly friendly in tone, offered no substantive change in either side's positions.
Mr. Shen warned pointedly that China would not drop its option of invading Taiwan should the island's authorities move toward greater independence from mainland China, and away from the concept of "one China." Both the Communist and Nationalist Governments hew to that concept, even though they have lived apart as rivals since their civil war ended in 1949 and the Nationalists took refuge on Taiwan.
Whether tensions now ease, Mr. Shen said, will hinge on whether Taiwan's authorities pursue or reject a policy of independence. Beijing will not be satisfied with conciliatory statements, he said, but only with conciliatory acts.
Although he did not request specific actions, Chinese leaders have been infuriated by Mr. Lee's attempts to secure a seat for Taiwan in the United Nations and by his visit to the United States last year. A promise not to do either again would certainly be on China's list.
In Taiwan, Prime Minister Lien, who was Mr. Lee's running mate to become Vice President, did not raise any specific proposals either and took a cautiously optimistic approach toward China's offer.
"On the question of a peace agreement, we are interested in seriously thinking about it," Mr. Lien said in Taipei. "A lot of preparations need to be done for that.
"We should pursue a policy of detente. I am basically optimistic, but I think it will take time."
Mr. Shen renewed a proposal made by President Jiang in 1995 that urged Taiwan to lift its ban on direct trade, air and shipping ties across the Taiwan Strait, as part of China's efforts to increase Taiwan's contact with the mainland.
"We have never had a positive reaction from the Taiwan side," Mr. Shen said.
In the same way that he blamed the recent tension between the mainland and Taiwan squarely on Taipei, Mr. Shen added that the strain in Chinese-American relations was entirely the fault of Washington.
Two American aircraft carriers, dispatched to the western Pacific near Taiwan, have already provoked objections from Chinese officials that they represented meddling in China's internal affairs. The Americans maintain that they are free to move in international waters.
Mr. Shen urged Washington to take a "a more stable, more wise policy" toward China and said its recent actions were interpreted by Taiwan as a sign that the United States supports "separatist" activities on the island.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who returned to Washington late Saturday from Europe, had no immediate reaction to the prospect of improved relations between China and Taiwan. Administration officials said they were watching to see if China carried out additional military exercises near Taiwan.
On Friday, the Administration called off the visit of China's Defense Minister, saying it was "not appropriate in the current climate" between Beijing and Washington. The Clinton Administration has criticized China's human rights record, its sale of nuclear-related technology to Pakistan and the pirating of American movies, software and music, as well as the war games.
But Administration officials said Mr. Christopher still plans to meet with China's Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, on April 21 in The Hague.
A New China News Agency report issued late tonight put a positive spin on the election, declaring that the low vote tally for Taiwan's pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party showed that China's efforts to stop the "Taiwan independence movement" had succeeded.
"Almost all Taiwan people now focus their attention on whether the winners of the election will try to develop relations across the Taiwan Strait," the agency said. "Taiwan residents share the view that the only way out for Taiwan is to develop relations across the Taiwan Strait."
The report quoted business people, journalists and academics from Taiwan as saying that Mr. Lee, whom China has accused of changing his mind too often, should "cease to be self-willed or make self-contradictory remarks."
"They maintain that the first thing the newly elected Taiwan leaders must do is to further cross-strait relations," it said.
Mr. Shen said the election would not change China's position that Taiwan is simply part of China and that Taiwan's leader was equivalent to the leader of one of China's 30 provinces.
He added that China's "one country two systems" formula, devised for Hong Kong -- whose capitalist economy China has promised to leave intact after it resumes sovereignty next year -- is appropriate for Taiwan as well.
"It is the most realistic and the most feasible way to realize peaceful reunification," Mr. Shen said.

As General Motors reopens its assembly plants after a 17-day brake-factory strike, the bad news for the company, its shareholders and the American economy is that the lost weeks of production may never be made up.

Going Abroad Gets Rougher
After a decade of relentless global expansion, MTV is finally learning that American pop culture has its limits as an export. Rival music-video channels have sprouted from Brazil to Hong Kong. Simply by showcasing local artists performing in their native languages, these MTV clones have been able to cut into the MTV audience. Television. [D7.]
 
Beef-Free McDonald's Menu
McDonald's said it had stopped selling hamburgers in its 660 restaurants in Britain, after the Government's announcement last week that beef infected by "mad cow" disease might be linked to Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease, a rare and deadly brain disease among humans. British consumers and retailers are boycotting the beef, and 15 nations have banned its import. [A4.]

Days after Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield received New York State approval to establish a for-profit subsidiary, legislative and consumer groups raised the issue of a payback for the public. SECTION: Section D; Page 2; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1007 words

HEADLINE: Market Place;
G.M. has begun telling analysts it can't offset lost production.

BYLINE: By Keith Bradsher 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
AS the General Motors Corporation struggles to reopen its assembly plants after a 17-day brake-factory strike, the bad news for the company, for its shareholders and for the American economy is that much of the lost weeks of production may never be made up. And that disrupts G.M.'s planning for the third quarter, when it will shut many plants as it prepares to introduce many new models, its most ambitious retooling in years.
G.M. had built up unusually large inventories over the winter, anticipating limited production in the third quarter. But now a large chunk of that inventory is being sold and could be hard to replace. 
 G.M. officials have quietly begun telling Wall Street analysts that they cannot increase production enough during the rest of this year to offset the estimated 240,000 cars and trucks that should have been built over the last three weeks and were not because of the strike, which ended on Friday.
By early Saturday afternoon, a rainbow sea of workers' cars and trucks surrounded the yellow brick walls of the main brake factory in Dayton, Ohio. A steady plume of steam rose from the southern end of the four-block-long building as brake production moved into high gear. G.M. officials said they hoped to reopen all assembly plants by Thursday. But with the exception of a few car plants that build unpopular models, G.M. will have trouble making up for lost production.
"I spoke to the company at length about this on Friday, and they said they'd be lucky to get 50 percent of it back," said Jack V. Kirnan, an auto analyst at Salomon Brothers. Mr. Kirnan estimated that G.M.'s first-quarter profits after taxes would be $850 million lower than previously expected.
That would reduce earnings per share by $1.15, leaving G.M. with only 90 cents to $1 a share in profits for the quarter, Mr. Kirnan said. Only 40 percent of the loss can be made up in later quarters this year, he predicted. Nonetheless, he is maintaining a "strong hold" rating on the stock so long as the American economy remains strong.
Some auto industry experts are gloomier. Scott F. Merlis, an independent analyst in Westport, Conn., predicted that the G.M. would be unable to recoup any of its losses in later quarters. He put those losses slightly lower than Mr. Kirnan, estimating that after-tax earnings would be $780 million lower in the first quarter because of the strike, or $1.04 per share. The pretax loss to G.M. is around $1.2 billion, he said.
Should G.M. not catch up on lost production, it would be bad news for the American economy. Economists estimate that the strike trimmed $5 billion to $7 billion from economic output in the first quarter, shaving three-tenths of 1 percent from the annualized growth rate in gross domestic product. But economists have been uncertain how much of the lost output would be recovered in the second quarter through extra production at G.M.
G.M. officials may be talking to auto analysts, but they have been much less willing to commit themselves in public to figures on their plans to recoup lost production. Tom Klipstine, a company spokesman, said yesterday that the company's first signal of those plans was likely to come on April 1, when G.M. plans to release its production schedule for the month.
G.M.'s pessimism with the analysts about recovering lost production is the latest indication that the strike hurt the world's largest auto maker financially. What remains unclear is whether G.M. will recoup these losses in national negotiations this summer with the United Automobile Workers, which was also bloodied by the strike. The brake-plant strike might also benefit G.M. if it discourages the U.A.W. from calling other local strikes before the national negotiations
Shares in G.M. held up fairly well during the strike. The stock closed at $52.25 on March 4, the day before the strike began, and closed at $53.375 on Friday, up $1.125 for the length of the strike.
Mr. Kirnan said the apparently improving American economy helped the stock, because the auto industry is strongly cyclical and produces large profits during times of prosperity. Investors have also applauded the auto maker's willingness to stand up to the U.A.W. and the workers in Dayton, who earn an average of $69,000 a year by putting in six- and seven-day weeks.
The strike in Dayton ended with a compromise that made no changes in G.M.'s overall ability to farm out the production of auto parts to nonunion companies. But the company agreed to hire at least 417 workers, most of them over the next two years and slightly more than the number of workers expected to retire or leave the factory for various reasons over that period.
Union locals at assembly plants in Lordstown, Ohio; Janesville, Wis., and Oklahoma City have been preparing for strikes, auto industry experts said. The clearest signal of whether the U.A.W. has been frightened by G.M.'s tough stance in Dayton will be whether strikes flare elsewhere in the next several months.
While the U.A.W. has not released any precise figures, the Dayton strike appears to have cost it about $1.2 million in strike benefits for 3,000 workers there. But if the strike had gone on much longer, it could have cost the union as much as $36 million a week.
The reason for the potentially higher cost is that G.M. had taken legal steps to block unemployment benefits for U.A.W. workers laid off elsewhere because of the strike in Dayton. In the days before the strike was settled, G.M.'s action put tremendous pressure on the U.A.W. to begin paying strike benefits to more than 100,000 laid-off union members. While union members are supposed to refund these strike benefits if they eventually receive unemployment benefits, many union workers have not done so in the past.
An unsuccessful strike last year against Caterpillar Inc. has depleted the union's strike fund, which now has no more than $700 million, union officials say. Whether that will affect U.A.W. strategy remains a key question for G.M. and its shareholders.
