HEADLINE: POLITICS: FACING THE ECONOMY;
Recycled Ideas Echo Forbes and Buchanan

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
Steve Forbes might be out of the race and Patrick J. Buchanan relegated to the sidelines, but some of their economic ideas, reformulated or toned down, live on in the campaigns of Senator Bob Dole and President Clinton.
Just last week in Wisconsin, Mr. Dole volunteered that "Steve Forbes had a good idea" when he proposed the 17 percent flat tax, a plan the Senate majority leader was bashing a month ago for its failure to preserve deductions for home mortgages, charitable contributions and state and local income taxes. 
 And President Clinton has lately refined his economic pitch to reflect some of the anxieties tapped into by Mr. Buchanan, including calls for corporate responsibility and tougher enforcement of trade agreements.
Some of Mr. Buchanan's and Mr. Forbes's more improbable ideas are dying a quick death. No one is repeating Mr. Buchanan's calls for big tariffs on Asian imports or for a huge wall to keep out Mexicans. But to listen to the talk out of Dole and Clinton headquarters about flat taxes, trade and economic growth is to hear familiar echoes.
Mr. Dole is now talking about a flat tax, something his aides hint he would have announced sooner if Mr. Forbes had not grabbed the issue first. No one in Mr. Dole's camp wanted to get too specific because keeping popular deductions would mean a tax rate far above the 17 percent that Mr. Forbes proposed.
"You're not likely to be hearing any numbers," warned one Dole adviser, who insisted on anonymity.
And when Mr. Dole mentions Mr. Buchanan these days, he usually acknowledges Mr. Buchanan's diagnosis of economic ills, even while stepping around his protectionist solutions. "Pat Buchanan has touched a nerve when it comes to people concerned about their jobs," Mr. Dole said recently, changing the subject before saying what to do about those concerns. His aides are trying to figure out how they might hit the same nerve themselves, without rejecting the North American Free Trade Agreement and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, two free-trade accords Mr. Dole backed.
The Dole camp, acknowledging that their candidate was something less than a font of original economic thinking during the primaries, is unapologetic about borrowing liberally from former rivals. "If we are skillful about it," said Vin Weber, the co-chairman of Mr. Dole's campaign, "some of the economic growth message of Forbes becomes the essence of the appeal to the distressed workers who went to Buchanan. But the fact is that we are just at the beginning of developing a package that addresses the concerns of those 'at risk' working families."
Of course, Mr. Clinton is angling for those same voters. He has begun sampling a campaign-speech brew that is one part economic growth, one part tax breaks for the middle class, and -- as the Democratic pollster Stanley Greenberg called it recently -- one part "aggressive free trade, which sells very differently than just free trade."
The growth part of Mr. Clinton's agenda is hardly new, but it closely parallels Mr. Forbes's insistence that the American economy can grow far faster than a crawl-along 2.3 percent a year that the White House and Congress forecast as an average for the next seven years.
A month ago, as Mr. Forbes's campaign was peaking, Mr. Clinton used the renomination of Alan Greenspan as chairman of the Federal Reserve to question whether the traditional assumptions about how fast the economy can grow are too conservative. "There are a lot of people," he said, "including Republican executives in the manufacturing sector," who believe that far higher growth rates are possible without inflation.
One Cabinet member noted recently that Mr. Forbes "showed that you can go a long way with an optimistic economic message, and it plays right into our pitch about how the economy has created 8.4 million jobs since we came to office, and how we now lead the world in key industries."
The argument inside the White House, however, has focused on how much to temper that optimism with an acknowledgment that the growth has been very uneven, widening the divide between the rich and the middle class. So without dwelling on the growing division, Mr. Clinton is using events like the release of the 1997 Federal budget last week to portray himself anew as the advocate of the middle class, pressing for a $500 tax deduction for every child under the age of 13 and a $10,000 deduction for college tuition.
The political key, White House officials said, is the education deduction, which has strong support in the polls and allows Mr. Clinton to make the case that the Government should help America invest in future workers just as it currently helps companies buy new factory equipment.
But the biggest challenge for the Administration, which pushed through Nafta and gave birth to the World Trade Organization, is to make the case that foreign trade benefits American workers. While the Buchanan campaign has exploited the widespread perception that the United States has been played for a sucker by many of its trading partners, Mr. Clinton is openly putting a foot in both camps, talking about "trade that is both free and fair."
The phrase is the work of Mr. Clinton's former campaign chief, Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative. Mr. Kantor says free trade sells only if trading partners are visibly pushed into opening markets. After three years of facing off against Japan, he is going after Mexico, Canada and China.
"If you hear the debate you would think there are only two choices," Mr. Clinton said in New Orleans last week: wall America off from countries "that pay people wages we couldn't live on," or naively press ahead with "pure open trade in which our markets are open to others, and we hope that they'll open their markets to us."
Instead, he is talking weekly now about "truly open, two-way trade," code words for the argument that the United States should keep its markets open only to trading partners who reciprocate. That seems partly intended to head off Mr. Dole, who has argued that the United States has all the right trade agreements, it just needs to enforce them. But Mr. Dole himself, notes Robert B. Zoellick, the former Under Secretary of State in the Bush Administration, "has been a free-trader all of his life, and there is a lot of risk if he tries to run away from his record."
Mr. Kantor is going to extraordinary lengths to inoculate Mr. Clinton against complaints that the Administration has, in Mr. Buchanan's oft-repeated phrase, "sacrificed American workers on the altar of free trade."
In early January, the Administration outraged Mexico by declining to open the border, despite the trade agreement, to increased Mexican trucking. The Administration cited safety problems and drug smuggling aboard the trucks, but clearly there was also some concern about the image of the border being thrown open in the vital states of Texas and California. Mr. Kantor is also challenging Canada over trade restrictions and is battling a World Trade Organization ruling that would require changes in the Clean Air Act.
"You only build a constituency for free trade if you show you will stand up at every chance for American workers," Mr. Kantor said recently. "So that's what we're going to do."

HEADLINE: Proposed Cuts to College Aid Protested as Hardship for Poor Students

BYLINE: By EMILY M. BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
The poor college student is romanticized in popular culture as a young person leading a sort of bohemian life style: wearing vintage clothing and living off campus, waiting tables or selling books between classes, struggling to remain in school and, eventually, reach the middle class.
But in reality, at the City University of New York, many poor college students are older, shouldering the responsibilities of a job and family as well as homework and grades. They are often laid-off workers or welfare parents studying to find a good job, also struggling to remain in school and, eventually, reach the middle class. 
 Take Linda C. Carberry, a nursing student at the College of Staten Island, who works as a building superintendent in Brooklyn so she and her two daughters will not need to pay rent. Or Leonard Zeiger, an English major at Kingsborough Community College in Brooklyn, who already owes almost $10,000 in student loans and rotates his credit cards to buy food and other necessities. Or Juan Gonzalez Hernandez, a student in human services at La Guardia Community College who sometimes begs for money to pay his train fare to Queens from Red Hook, Brooklyn.
These students and thousands more are struggling even though they receive financial aid. But college aid may be cut sharply under a proposal by Gov. George E. Pataki.
About 90,000 students in the City and State University of New York systems receive money from the state's Tuition Assistance Program to cover tuition, as well as money from the Federal Government called Pell grants, which are distributed based on need and intended to be used for college-related expenses.
Under the Governor's proposal, half of the Federal aid a student received would instead be applied to tuition, and the state would provide the difference. So students at CUNY would still receive enough aid to cover the tuition of $3,200 a year at four-year colleges, $2,500 at community colleges. But the Federal money available for extra costs including fees, books and transportation would be reduced by half.
The state would give SUNY and CUNY $10 million each to use as they choose to help students facing cuts in aid, but that would clearly not match the $51 million they estimate students would lose under the proposal.
Students and college administrators are lobbying state legislators to ease the proposed cuts. The heads of the higher education committees in both the Assembly and the Senate have said they want to restore at least some of the money cut from the Tuition Assistance Program.
But given the uncertainty surrounding the state budget this year, some college administrators are worried that even if the money is restored, it will not come in time to help students and their families. Chancellor W. Ann Reynolds of the City University and Chancellor Thomas A. Bartlett of the State University have sent a joint letter to legislative leaders asking them to make a commitment to TAP.
"If the state budget is not adopted by April 1," the letter read, "we strongly urge that an agreement be reached and announced as soon as possible on TAP restorations so that potential applicants can be informed and plan accordingly for college."
The Governor's proposed cuts are part of a larger effort by his administration to streamline government and lower taxes to encourage economic growth in the state. Administration officials have said New York will still have the most generous financial aid program in the country.
But the proposed cuts are toughest on the state's poorest students, since those who qualify for more Federal money will have more to cut. They will affect students at SUNY and CUNY, young people trying to improve their lot through education, or older people who have lost jobs and are looking for education and re-training.
Many of those poor students attend the City University of New York, where half the 200,000 students come from households with income under $22,000. About one-tenth receive some form of welfare. Two-thirds work at least part time. CUNY officials estimate that the proposed cuts in state aid will affect 57,800 of their students, who will lose $654 to $1,029 a year.
For many students, the cuts will mean following one of three options: borrowing more money, taking on new jobs and going to school part time, or dropping out altogether. "I can't live the way I live anymore," Ms. Carberry said. "I want my kids to get a good education, and I can't give it to them unless I finish school."
Members of the Pataki administration say they do not believe students will drop out if the cuts are made, because tuition will still be covered. Students can manage other expenses that Federal money has covered by budgeting their money better, the officials say. "I know I used to buy used books or borrow books from a friend of mine versus buying new books," one official said.
Ms. Carberry's budget is too tight to stretch much further. As a superintendent living rent free in her building in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, she scrubs hallways and answers complaints. She and her daughters, Kate, 15, and Tara, 12, also get food stamps.
Ms. Carberry, 42, is enrolled in the selective nursing program at the College of Staten Island and does not have time to take another job. She is about halfway through the program and hopes to take her nursing exams in another year.
Ms. Carberry pays for college with TAP and Pell money and has about $600 left over each semester for other expenses. Books cost about $100 each semester. Transportation on the three buses it takes to get to school costs $9 a day. She usually takes a sandwich from home but buys a soda.
She views college as a way to find a job and stop depending on food stamps. "Most of the people in my program and other programs are striving for something," she said. "They don't feel like they're taking something because they're going to be giving back. If I didn't go to school, I'd still be poor and getting assistance."
Juan Gonzalez Hernandez also hopes college will launch him out of Red Hook. Sometimes he has to stand on a corner in his neighborhood, asking for train fare to get to La Guardia Community College in Long Island City, Queens.
TAP and Pell pay Mr. Hernandez's tuition and leave about $250 a semester to buy books, pay for transportation, buy food and cover other expenses. He also works part time for a recycling program on campus.
He is loud in his anger at the proposed cuts and helped to organize a recent protest march with a university-wide group called Student Liberation Action Movement, or SLAM! "Students at CUNY are not educated about what's being done to them," he said. "If they were, we would have already had a riot."
Mr. Hernandez grew up in the Red Hook projects, dropped out of John Jay High School and was in and out of jail. But he finished high school in a special program and enrolled at La Guardia three years ago.
"I'm one of those numbers that wasn't supposed to make it," he said. "I am the first generation to ever go to college in my family. And if it wasn't for financial aid, I wouldn't be in school at all."
Mr. Hernandez is trying to avoid going into debt so he does not take out student loans. He is already applying for grants and scholarships in case his financial aid is cut.
Leonard Zeiger, on the other hand, relies heavily on debt, not only student loans but also credit cards, to finance his education at Kingsborough Community College in Brooklyn.
Mr. Zeiger has lived on his own since he was 18. Now, at 23, he hopes to transfer next year to a four-year college so he can become an English teacher. He maintains a 4.0 average and runs one of the student councils on campus.
More than $200 of the $900 he receives each year from Pell goes to supplement his tuition assistance. The room he rents in the shadow of the Cyclone in Coney Island, Brooklyn, costs $200 a month. Transportation to and from the campus in Manhattan Beach costs $3 a day, four days a week during the 12-week semester.
A separate $250 from the College Discovery/SEEK program pays for Mr. Zeiger's books each semester. If that is not enough, he uses more Pell money to pay the book bill.
Mr. Zeiger works as much as he can, during a two-month winter break and summer vacation. In a good year, he makes $3,000. And this year he has taken out a $3,500 loan, bringing his total student-loan debt close to $10,000.
But none of that is enough. "I start the semester with a healthy bank account and by the end I usually owe money on my credit cards," he said. "Honestly, if it wasn't for this wonderful benefit of credit cards, I wouldn't be surviving."

HEADLINE: Metro Digest

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
A Crisis for Smaller Cities
A fiscal crisis, like the one that racked New York City in the 1970's, has gripped the state's smaller cities. With alarming frequency, cities like Utica, Rome, Schenectady and Niagara Falls have found themselves staggering under the crush of budget deficits. The crisis, simply, reflects the fact that the cost of providing municipal services has risen as rapidly as revenue from taxes and state and Federal aid has fallen. More broadly, it reflects the gnawing decline of the state's urban cores. And that, say the cities' advocates, threatens to erode the state's economic viability. [Page A1.]
Seeking a Share of the Riches
 Days after Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield received New York State approval to establish a for-profit subsidiary, legislative and consumer watchdog groups raised the question of a lucrative public payoff as part of the package. [A1.]
Cardinal Opposes Execution
John Cardinal O'Connor, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, voiced his deep personal opposition to capital punishment, warning that it has tended to single out certain groups and offers a deceptively simple approach to wider problems. Although the Cardinal has spoken out against capital punishment before, the timing and audience of his sermon gave his remarks a special resonance. The homily was delivered before hundreds of police officers who attended a special annual Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral. [B1.]
Battle Brews Over a Park
With the exception of a patch of struggling grass, little is blossoming at Hunters Point Community Park in Long Island City. The park is a virtual wonderland of concrete. Although the park has won awards -- from the Concrete Industry Board and the American Institute of Architects -- neighbors say the park satisfies everybody but the people who are supposed to use it. [B1.]
Nostalgia for Death and Taxes
Looking ahead to Campaign 2000, and remembering a time when salable issues and satisfying slogans were easier to find. Metro Matters by Joyce Purnick. [B1.]
Bratton's Job Hunt Is Official
Mayor Giuliani said that William J. Bratton will step down as New York City's Police Commissioner as soon as he finds the right job. Responding to months of speculation about Mr. Bratton's future in the administration, the Mayor said that Mr. Bratton has advised him that he plans to leave. [B1.]
Burglar Assaults a Priest
A burglar burst into a Franciscan monastery in Brooklyn and, when he found nothing to steal, he smashed stained-glass windows, hurled lamps, desks and picture frames and beat a 76-year-old priest bloody before fleeing empty-handed. What the burglar had found was not a church wealthy in gold, silver or ready cash, but a place rich in art, culture and history, the heart of what was once Brooklyn's thriving Lithuanian refugee population. [B3.]
Finally, the Warmth of the Sun
Yesterday was a day that finally felt like spring: sunny, comfortable, inviting. Only a meteorological curmudgeon would have realized that it was not the warmest day of the year. Does anyone remember that the temperature climbed past 50 four times in January, nine times in February and seven times this month? Yesterday was a day when spring was more than just a far-off promise. [B3.]
Lobbying for Tuition Assistance
At the City University of New York, many poor college students are struggling even though they receive financial aid. They are older students who are shouldering the responsibilities of a job and family as well as homework and grades. But college aid may be cut sharply under a proposal by Governor Pataki. Students and college administrators are lobbying state legislators to ease the proposed cuts. The heads of the higher education committees in both the Assembly and the Senate have said they want to restore at least some of the money cut from the Tuition Assistance Program. [B6.]
2 Bronx Youths Shot Dead
Two teen-agers were killed and a third was critically wounded when an argument between two men in a Bronx apartment building erupted in gunfire, the police said. Neighbors said the graffiti-strewn building in the Bedford Park section had long been known as a crack house, but neighbors and relatives of the victims also said that they were not known as drug dealers or criminals, and said that the youths did not spend time in the building. [B2.]

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Chile Says Its Spraying Has Suppressed Medfly

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile

 BODY:
Chile has declared victory over the Mediterranean fruit fly in a persistent, 30-year battle that included such tough tactics as spraying pesticides over heavily populated areas and confiscating all organic material entering the country.
The Agriculture Ministry said its latest round of inspections at the end of 1995 showed that all regions of Chile except one in the extreme north were free of the Medfly, one of the world's most dreaded agricultural pests, which lays eggs in fruit and vegetables and causes them to rot. 
 Chilean agricultural officials said that eradication of the Medfly would allow the country to start exporting apples, grapes, avocados, kiwis and other fruit to Asian markets where it is currently banned or subject to strict fumigation and quarantines.
With the pestilence eliminated, the officials estimated that Chile's agricultural exports, currently worth $1 billion annually, could increase by $500 million a year by the end of the decade.
"By freeing ourselves of this plague, our country has overcome a major barrier to our fruit exports," Agriculture Minister Emiliano Ortega told local news organizations. "We've opened up China to our apples and kiwis."
The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization's field office in Santiago verified Chile's victory, saying that the country "had done an excellent job" in combating the Medfly and was "in good shape" to start exporting fruits and vegetables to countries free of the pest, notably Japan and South Korea.
However, several agricultural experts cautioned that the pest was known to reappear after months of absence and said that to maintain control, Chile must continue its strict campaign of eradication or face a new outbreak.
Chile's victory over the Medfly contrasts with the situation in California. Faced with threats of quarantines from several Asian countries, the state is still struggling to control the pest after a 20-year campaign that has cost upward of $300 million.
California state officials and growers said the main reason the Medfly thrived in their state was the arrival of infected fruit and vegetables, typically in the luggage of travelers.
State agriculture officials regularly confiscate fruit from passengers arriving at Los Angeles International Airport, but their random inspection system is lax next to Chile's.
James R. Carey, an entomology professor at the University of California at Davis, said that California could not eradicate the Medfly because of public opposition to aerial spraying of malathion and other insecticides and the size and complexity of the California landscape.
"California is just a hog heaven for Medflies," Mr. Carey said. "Los Angeles is a mosaic of 2,500 backyards per square mile with lots of fruit trees that Medflies come into contact with at different times of the year." The professor said he doubted that Chile had completely eradicated the Medfly but that Chile had made more progress than California because it had not informed its people about the use of insecticides.
Indeed, while Chilean environmental groups have criticized aerial spraying of pesticides over heavily populated areas as a potential health threat, the Government has largely ignored their complaints and continued such fumigations, saying they are necessary to control the Medfly.
"These emergency fumigations are not justified because the health of the people should come first and the economy second," said Maria Isabel Manzur, an investigator for the National Committee for the Defense of Flora and Fauna, a well-known environmental organization. "These sprayings violate human rights because they are fumigating people."
Further, Chile is perhaps the only country in the world where the baggage of every arriving airline passenger is checked for organic material that could contain insects, parasites or viruses harmful to the country's agricultural industry. Chile seizes more than 1,300 pounds of organic material at its airports each week, including all leftover food from arriving aircraft.
In its $50 million battle against the Medfly, Chile has used border controls and introduced sterile fruit flies. Chile has also conducted an educational campaign, distributing handouts and posters asking Chileans not to bring fruit into the country from abroad and to report any sign of the pest.
Leopoldo Sanchez Grunert, national director for the Agricultural Ministry's livestock and agricultural service, said that the Chilean public had been very responsive to the campaign and provided information on the spread of the fly.
"I think the public realized just how important it was to Chile to eradicate this pest," Mr. Sanchez said. "Everyone stands to benefit from this success."
Agriculture is vital to Chile's $44 billion economy, employing 400,000 of the country's 13 million people. More than 200 agricultural products can serve as host for the Medfly, including oranges, grapefruit, avocados, strawberries, peaches, plums, nectarines, table and wine grapes and dates.
In its battle against the Medfly, Chile benefited greatly from its geographic isolation. Chile's borders are framed by the Pacific Ocean, the Andean Mountain region, a vast desert, and the South Pole, making it difficult for the Medfly to proliferate.
While the Medfly first appeared in South America in 1901, it did not reach Chile until 1962, where it was detected in the northern border city of Arica. The fly spread as far south to the capital Santiago within three years and threatened to contaminate all of Chile's fruit crop.
But agricultural officials undertook what was perhaps the most determined of all fumigations: they sprayed the entire city of Santiago.

HEADLINE: Home Resales Surge 6.5% In Rush to Beat Rising Rates

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 25

 BODY:
Fears of rising mortgage rates spurred a surprising increase in sales of existing homes last month despite severe winter weather, the National Association of Realtors said today.
Sales of existing homes climbed 6.5 percent, to an annual rate of 3.96 million, seasonally adjusted. That followed a revised January decline of 3.9 percent. 
 February was the first monthly rise since October.
The rebound not only was contrary to expectations but also demonstrated the resilience of the housing sector, which recorded stronger rates of home building as well as sales last month.
But analysts cautioned that the industry was unlikely to keep February's pace for long because of rising inventories of new and used homes on the market and costlier mortgages.
"Higher mortgage rates to some degree may spur people to buy now in anticipation of rates being even higher," said Paul Kasriel, an economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. But "we may have seen the last of the positive effects of lower mortgage rates," he added. "A lot of people will be priced out of the market."
The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said average rates for a 30-year mortgage rose to 7.08 percent in February from 7.03 percent in January. That was still below the rate in February 1995, when 30-year loans averaged 8.77 percent.
More homes were sold in every region of the country in February than was the case in January, when a blizzard lashed the East Coast and much of the country suffered bitter cold.
Art Godi, president of the realtors association, said February's relatively brisk sales pace -- the strongest since a four-million-a-year rate in November last year -- was a "pleasant surprise."
Sales of existing homes in February were a strong 12.5 percent above the rate a year earlier, when they were running at 3.52 million a year.
Regionally, the strongest rise in business was in the West -- including California -- where sales increased 11 percent during February to an annual rate of 910,000. In the South, the country's largest sales region, sales rose 9.4 percent, to 1.51 million a year.
There were smaller monthly gains during February of 3.6 percent in the Northeast to 580,000 a year and in the Midwest, a 1.1 percent rise from January to 960,000 a year.
While sales were up, the median sales price for used homes fell in February to $113,900 from $114,800. The median represents a midway point, with half the homes selling above that price and half selling below it.

HEADLINE: Agua Prieta Journal;
Border Patrol vs. 'Illegals': Now, the Desert War

BYLINE: By SAM DILLON 

DATELINE: AGUA PRIETA, Mexico, March 21

 BODY:
Raul Gutierrez had put in much of a day's work by the time he sat down for lunch in the Yolanda Cafe near the international border station here, so he ordered a T-bone steak.
And since his mother was not around, Raul, who is 14, seized the steak in his hands and gnawed the meat right off the bone. Then he wiped his fingers with a tortilla, peeled a $20 bill from a wad of cash to pay the bill and rode his bike back to work along the tattered cyclone fence dividing Agua Prieta from Douglas, Ariz. 
 Thousands of Mexicans hoping to enter the United States are streaming into this watering hole in the Sonoran desert every week, jamming hotels and sidewalks, and Raul is cashing in on his knowledge of the local topography by leading groups through the fence and along back alleys and drainage ditches 10 blocks north into downtown Douglas. At $20 a head, he earned $280 before lunch on this day, but business has been so lucrative recently that he found this take disappointing.
"I had five more clients, but another boy took them away," Raul said.
Raul works in a cottage industry that has blossomed here in recent months as United States crackdowns south of San Diego and El Paso have made Agua Prieta one of the most popular crossing points for illegal immigrants to the United States.
So many migrants poured across here in January and February that the Border Patrol detained nearly 35,000 people, more than six times as many as in the same period last year. Along the whole border from Texas to California, 146,000 illegal crossers were detained during January and February, up by 24 percent from 1995.
No one can say for sure that the increase in detentions reflects more than the recent addition of hundreds of new Border Patrol agents. But many demographers believe that Mexico's economic crisis, combined with strong American job growth, is persuading more Mexicans to travel illegally into the United States.
Robert Bach, director of policy research at the Immigration and Naturalization Service, sees the thousands of Mexicans streaming into Agua Prieta as a triumph for Washington's get-tough policies. "We're restructuring the flow, squeezing people into Arizona, and that's favorable terrain for us," Mr. Bach said. The difficulty of crossing the Arizona desert has forced most migrants to hire smugglers to get across, driving up costs and discouraging others from making the trip, he said.
Douglas Massey, a University of Pennsylvania demographer, said there was no evidence yet that the northward flow had slowed. "But if the I.N.S. puts enough resources into it, maybe they can raise the probability of apprehension high enough to persuade people not to try," he said.
And so Agua Prieta is the new immigration battleground. Time was when the only news here was when a pack of wild dogs would move into town and start howling. And the Border Patrol used to be a sleepy outfit. When George Lopez, second in command of the local border station, was first assigned to Douglas about 15 years ago, there were just two agents.
Today Mr. Lopez commands 127 officers equipped with ground sensors, tower-mounted cameras, night-vision scopes and helicopters, but the Douglas station still seems overwhelmed at times. At least a dozen smuggling organizations are operating here, and many migrants are detouring hundreds of miles to cross at Agua Prieta, Mr. Lopez said.
Thirteen young men from Baja California, for instance, who had crossed illegally for several years at Tijuana on their way to jobs in Naperville, Ill., crossed through Agua Prieta this week. One of the men, Gerardo Cordero, a 28-year-old dishwasher who returned to Mexico to see his family at Christmas, said the group hired a smuggler after a woman at the Agua Prieta bus terminal offered them a package deal: the migrants would be spirited north into Douglas, ferried to Phoenix, and driven on to Chicago in the back of a rental van. The price, Mr. Cordero said, was $800 a head.
The group's first crossing attempt ended in frustration last week, when Border Patrol agents chased them into a cul-de-sac near the Douglas airport, detaining and expelling all 13 back to Mexico.
But two days later, the 13 were assigned a new guide: Raul Gutierrez. His mission, he said, was to get them to the McClain's Hotel in Douglas, a popular migrant way station, where a van would be waiting for them. Because he is a minor, Raul does not worry about criminal prosecution, though he said he had been detained many times in Douglas. Once, he said, a Border Patrol agent got one handcuff on him before he broke free and sprinted back to Mexico.
"I paid a Mexican policeman 20 pesos to unlock the cuff," Raul said.
The sun was setting, and at the Hotel Yolanda two blocks south of the border, Raul's 13 clients were stuffing their belongings into plastic bags and pulling on sweat shirts and high-top sneakers. Minutes later, they were at the fence along the border, where Raul was staring at a Border Patrol jeep moving along a line of warehouses on the United States side. Raul positioned the 13 men near a hole in the fence underneath a tower supporting one of the Border Patrol's powerful video cameras, making surveillance difficult.
"Let's go!" he said, and the men ducked through the fence and raced north past the warehouses. Minutes later, however, they came huffing back, scooting through the fence just as a Border Patrol van roared into a defensive position opposite them.
"I told you to stay together," Raul yelled at the men, most of whom were twice his age. "Now keep down and wait." Minutes passed, an I.N.S. helicopter clattered overhead, peering downward with a searchlight, and the Border Patrol van eventually moved off.
Then Raul ordered a new advance. The migrants and their teen-age guide sprinted past a line of buildings and disappeared into the cool desert air.

HEADLINE: Problems Schools Can't Solve

BYLINE: By Stephen O'Connor; Stephen O'Connor is the author of the forthcoming "Will My Name Be Shouted Out? Reaching Inner City Children Through the Power of Writing."

 BODY:
One of my students wrote a short story in which he recounted how he watched as his father was shot and killed inside their apartment building. Another student was neglected so badly that at age 7 she lost all her hair from malnutrition; at 14, she still had to wear diapers to school. Yet another student was walking to the grocery store with her best friend when gang members started firing at one another; her best friend was killed. And just the other day, a 9-year-old boy in one of my classes wrote:
"I am afraid I might die before I'm 11 . . .
 I hate myself because I'm dumb. 
 I like guns because I'm bad and ugly as the guns."
I have taught creative writing for eight years in New York City and San Francisco public schools, and these are only a few of the scores of stories that I could tell about my students. The stories are especially horrifying because they are so common.
Virtually every teacher in the United States can tell similar tales about abused children who come to school too depressed or angry to learn, who disrupt lessons, get into fights with classmates or simply spend their days with their heads on their desks.
President Clinton, several business leaders and most of our nation's governors are meeting today and tomorrow for the Second National Education Summit, in Palisades, N.Y. But social problems are not on their agenda; higher curriculum standards and technology are.
For the past decade and a half, our leaders have primarily chosen to treat the education crisis as if it was a simple matter of inadequate standards and mind-numbing bureaucracy.
This is safe politics. Nobody can deny that less red tape and more stringent and precise standards would help students and teachers alike, and perhaps have the additional benefit of saving money. What is wrong with such initiatives is that they completely fail to address the most severe problems in our schools.
The single factor that most frustrates any teacher in reaching his or her goals is the relentless intrusion of social problems into the classroom. Teachers, no matter how talented or dedicated, cannot combat poverty, broken or single parent families, violence, AIDS, homelessness, child abuse and racism.
The public schools offer perhaps the clearest picture of our nation's economic and social health. President Clinton and other leaders are often heard worrying about the poor performance of American students, especially compared to students in other industrialized countries. But they must remember that this poor performance is and always has been partly a symptom of our neglect of the many social crises that afflict our nation.
No amount of tinkering with curriculum will enable schools to combat these problems on their own. Unless our leaders develop the resolve to deal realistically with them, American students -- and American business -- will continue to lose ground to foreign competition. Higher standards and a computer in every classroom are important, but they won't begin to address the crisis in our schools or our nation.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Seeking Indigent-Care Plan, Hospitals Send Trenton Bill

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, March 25

 BODY:
Seeking to put pressure on the state to come up with a plan to pay for hospital care for the poor, the heads of several New Jersey hospitals today left a $96 million bill on Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's desk and vowed to begin doing business with only those companies providing health insurance for their employees.
Since Jan. 1, Governor Whitman and the State Legislature have been unable to agree on a new financing plan to repay 84 acute-care hospitals for the estimated $384 million in charity care that they provide each year. 
 The state has missed two payments since the beginning of the year, and some hospital officials say they have been forced to delay payments to vendors and draw up contingency plans that include laying off hospital workers and closing wards.
"I know of no requirement that restaurants are required to feed the hungry," said Sister Jane Frances Brady, the president of St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center in Paterson. "I know of no requirement that Macy's is required to clothe the naked or that builders build housing. But the hospitals are required to provide any kind of care to all comers, and we feel that it is an impossible situation."
At the urging of the New Jersey Hospital Association, which represents most of the state's private hospitals, Sister Brady and other hospital presidents said they would begin to review contracts with their vendors and seek to do business only with companies providing health insurance for their employees.
Dr. Jonathan M. Metsch, the president of the Jersey City Medical Center, said he had asked hospital lawyers to help determine what contracts could be terminated with vendors who do not offer health insurance.
To put more pressure on Governor Whitman and lawmakers to find a solution, the hospital association said it would file a lawsuit within 30 days if the $96 million bill -- which includes the cost of charity care through March 31 and interest -- remained unpaid. "The state requires hospitals by law to provide a service, and they haven't paid for it," said Gary Carter, the president of the hospital association.
Becky Taylor, a spokesman for Governor Whitman, said the Governor's proposals have been unable to win legislative approval. "We are unable to do it unilaterally," she said.
The State Legislature has rejected numerous proposals, including increasing the cigarette tax and taking money from the state's unemployment insurance fund. Both organized labor and businesses object to continuing to take money out of the fund. The state has used $1.6 billion from the fund to pay for charity care for the last three years and promised to find alternatives. Robert A. DeSando, a spokesman for Jack Collins, Speaker of the Assembly, said lawmakers were working on a plan that would be able to win approval in both houses and the Governor's signature. The Senate President, Donald T. DiFrancesco, declined to comment.

HEADLINE: Supreme Court Roundup;
Justices to Review Effort to Make English Official Language

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
Turning the constitutional spotlight on the growing number of state laws declaring English to be the official language, the Supreme Court today agreed to review an Arizona effort to require public employees to conduct government business only in English.
At the same time, the Court indicated doubt about whether it would actually rule on the merits of the case, in which two lower Federal courts found that the English-only amendment to Arizona's Constitution violated the First Amendment right of public employees to speak the language of their choice. 
 The state itself is not defending the amendment, which was narrowly adopted in a voter referendum in 1988. Since the Federal District Court in Phoenix struck down the amendment in 1990, the case has been carried forward by the private group that sponsored the referendum, Arizonans for Official English. Rose Mofford, Arizona's Governor at the time, opposed the amendment and refused to appeal the district court's ruling. In accepting the appeal today, the Justices asked for briefs on the question of whether the private group had standing to defend the law.
The Court's unusual order raised the prospect that a case that had been seen as an important test case for the English-only movement might instead produce a ruling on the ability of private citizens' groups to appear in court to defend laws that state officials choose not to defend.
With state ballots showing voter initiatives on subjects from gay rights to lawyers' fees to affirmative action, the question of who has standing to defend the measures if they become law is significant in itself.
Twenty-one states have recently acted to make English the official language, with most provisions being essentially symbolic. Arizona's constitutional amendment, which was approved by 50.5 percent of the voters, is one of the more sweeping, and it was challenged shortly after adoption by a bilingual state employee, Maria-Kelley F. Yniquez, who processed medical malpractice claims. Ms. Yniquez spoke Spanish and drafted documents in Spanish when dealing with Spanish-speaking Arizonans.
When the amendment, known as Article 28, took effect, Ms. Yniquez stopped speaking Spanish on the job and filed a lawsuit. She later left her state job, and the Court's order today also suggested that her interest in the case may now be moot.
In a 6-to-5 ruling last October, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit found that the amendment placed an unconstitutional burden on the free-speech rights not only of the public employees, but also of the people they served. The amendment "obstructs the free flow of information and adversely affects the rights of many private persons by requiring the incomprehensible to replace the intelligible," Judge Stephen Reinhardt wrote for the majority.
In the dissenting opinion, Judge Alex Kozinski said the majority was ignoring the principle that "government employees have no personal stake in what they say in the course of employment because that speech is the government's, not theirs." The majority's approach, Judge Kozinski said, would give "bureaucrats the right to turn every policy disagreement into a Federal lawsuit."
The appeal, Arizonans for Official English v. Arizona, No. 95-974, which comes from an earlier stage of the case, argues that the First Amendment implications of Article 28 are minimal because the choice of what language to use is an aspect of conduct, not speech. The Ninth Circuit majority had rejected a similar argument.
"Speech in any language is still speech, and the decision to speak in another language is a decision involving speech alone," Judge Reinhardt said.
There were also these developments at the Court today:
 
Endangered Species
The Court agreed to decide whether people can sue the Federal Government under the Endangered Species Act to argue not that an endangered species is being inadequately protected -- as is nearly always the allegation in such lawsuits -- but that it is being overprotected.
There is a "citizen suit" provision of the Endangered Species Act that permits "any person" to file a lawsuit charging that Federal officials failed to carry out the law properly.
In this case, a group of ranchers and Oregon irrigation districts sued to set aside a finding by the Fish and Wildlife Service that more water must be kept in reservoirs of the Kalmath Irrigation Project in Oregon to protect the environment of two endangered fish, the Lost River sucker and the shortnose sucker. The plaintiffs argued this would unnecessarily hurt the economy by decreasing water for irrigation.
The Federal District Court in Eugene, Ore., in a decision upheld last year by the Ninth Circuit, dismissed the lawsuit on the ground that the citizen suit provision did not apply to suits seeking to lower rather than increase the level of environmental protection.
The ranchers and irrigation districts "seek only a greater share of the water and do not contend that compliance with the Act will improve the fish's lot," Judge Reinhardt said in his opinion for the appeals court. Rather than serving the purpose of the law, "they claim a competing interest," he said of the plaintiffs.
In their appeal, Bennett v. Plenert, No. 95-813, the plaintiffs argue that the Ninth Circuit has misinterpreted the intent of Congress to make citizen suits available to "any person" rather than only to "one apparently favored group."
 
Punitive Damages
The Court agreed to decide whether punitive damages awarded in a personal injury suit are taxable.
The Internal Revenue Code excludes from its otherwise sweeping definition of gross income any damages received "on account of personal injuries or sickness."
The lower Federal courts, as well as the Internal Revenue Service itself, have interpreted this provision inconsistently in various contexts. The Supreme Court has ruled in two recent cases that the provision cannot be used to exclude from taxable income the money received from successful suits for employment discrimination.
In the new case, O'Gilvie v. United States, No. 95-966, is an appeal by the husband and children of a woman who died of toxic shock syndrome in 1983. The family won a $10 million punitive-damage award in a products liability suit against International Playtex, Inc., the manufacturer of the tampons the woman, Betty O'Gilvie, had used.
The family members reported the award as personal income, paid taxes and filed a claim for a refund on the ground that the money should have been excluded as damages received "on account of personal injuries." They lost in the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit, in Denver, which joined four other appeals courts in finding that punitive damages were not excludable from taxable income.

HEADLINE: Curbing Central America's Generals

 BODY:
Since the cold war ended, the small countries of Central America have been trying to recover from an era of military dictatorship. Guatemala, home of Central America's most brutal military -- installed with the help of a C.I.A.-backed coup in 1954 -- is having the hardest time. A succession of presidents have tried, with small success, to bring the soldiers under control.
Guatemala's new President, Alvaro Arzu, inaugurated in January, has acted to diminish the power of the corrupt military. He has removed some of the worst human rights abusers, including 11 generals and several colonels, among them Col. Julio Alpirez, who is said to have been involved in the killings of Michael DeVine, an American innkeeper, and Efrain Bamaca Velasquez, the husband of an American lawyer. 
 Honduras was never directly involved in the kinds of guerrilla conflicts that battered civilian life in Guatemala and El Salvador. But Honduras became a staging ground for American operations in the region. Its military gained inordinate power during this period and brutally suppressed dissent. Hundreds of people "disappeared," victims of elite army units whose leaders were trained by the C.I.A.
Now Honduras's elected civilian Government has taken some courageous steps, including the prosecution of military men responsible for the worst abuses during the 80's. President Carlos Reina has abolished the draft, separated the civilian police from the military and rejected the military high command's choice of defense minister.
In El Salvador, the process of reining in the military is a qualified success, helped by a large United Nations presence in the early days of peace between the guerrillas and the Government.
The United States could do more in all these countries to encourage the establishment of civilian authority. Programs that give the military a role in economic development projects, especially in places like Guatemala, are questionable investments. Commercial arms sales to these countries also need to be reconsidered. In fiscal 1995, the United States licensed $22 million in arms sales to Guatemala, a country already awash in weaponry. Similar amounts were licensed to El Salvador and Honduras.
The United States has a long, ignoble history of supporting repressive military leaders in Central America. For a change, it would be nice if Washington helped the vulnerable civilian leaders who are trying to bring the generals under control.

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE UNIONS;
Labor Movement Endorses the President

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 25

 BODY:
The nation's labor movement has set aside its anger over President Clinton's trade policy and endorsed him today for re-election. Just 2 of the 78 unions in the A.F.L.-C.I.O. -- the teamsters and the longshoremen's union in San Francisco -- dissented, saying they wanted more time to consider their action.
The labor federation, under new leadership for the first time in 16 years and bursting with the symbols of change and newly found solidarity, also unanimously approved the assessment of special dues to provide $25 million of a $35 million fund to promote the union agenda during this election year in an effort to rout the Republican majorities in Congress. 
 Speaking of those lawmakers, the federation's president, John J. Sweeney, told about 500 exuberant delegates at a special convention here: "They want to get off on the cheap. We're going to take our jobs back. We're going to take the Congress back, and we're going to take our country back."
John N. Sturdivant, president of the American Federation of Government Employees, shouted to the delegates, "We intend to be in their faces and on their cases."
In the past, unions have sometimes complained about the caution of the Clinton Administration on some issues, including raising the minimum wage and protecting the jobs of striking workers. In addition, they were furious about its support of the North American Free Trade Agreement, which Congress approved in late 1993. But today Vice President Al Gore, who addressed the meeting after the votes, was unequivocal in backing every important item on the unions' agenda.
To chants, cheers and the strains of folk songs, Mr. Gore pumped his fists in the air, gave a bear hug to the federation's secretary-treasurer, Richard L. Trumka, and thanked the unions for their support. He told them, "One group with a conscience connected to working families can overpower hundreds or thousands of interests working against the interests of working families."
Republicans were quick to criticize the federation's political endorsement. "Bill Clinton has been tight with Washington union bosses for some time," said Cheri Jacobus, spokeswoman for Republicans on the House Committee on Economic and Educational Opportunities. 'And they're eager to use $35 million to put liberals back in Congress."
Ms. Jacobus noted that in the 1992 Presidential election, 40 percent of union members voted Republican -- suggesting a division between union officers and the rank and file. But today, the federation released a poll by Peter D. Hart Research Associates showing an upswing in support for the Administration.
Interviews with 829 union members and retirees from March 12 to 14 showed that 67 percent would vote for Mr. Clinton in a head-to-head election against Senator Bob Dole, the likely Republican nominee. That figure was up from 54 percent in April last year and 60 percent last November.
Mr. Sweeney was elected president of the 13.1-million-member federation last October after leading a coup against the leadership of Lane Kirkland, and the federation considered the gathering here an important statement of new energy. It was the first special convention in the 41 years since the A.F.L. merged with the C.I.O., and it was also the first vote to raise money to support the labor agenda in national elections.
But the tone of the meeting was at least as noteworthy because of a sense that the long decline in membership is over and that workers are rallying to unions as the wages of average workers continue to fall.
And as speaker after speaker stepped to the microphones to endorse the Democratic ticket as well as the additional dues -- 15 cents a month per member for a year -- it was clear that the face of the federation's leadership was changing from middle-aged white men to women, blacks, Hispanic Americans and young workers.
"The truth of the matter is, we're all in lockstep," said Gerald W. McEntee, president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees.
George Becker, president of the 481,000-member United Steelworkers of America shouted that President Clinton "showed us there really is a difference between Republicans and Democrats."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Advance in Light Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose in light volume yesterday ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy meeting today. Economic fundamentals were unchanged and trading was confined to technical factors and short-covering by speculators.
Sales of existing homes rose in February more than was expected, according to a report yesterday from the National Association of Realtors, but by and large the market ignored the news, since traders had expected some kind of rebound. The Federal Reserve Open Market Committee meets today to discuss monetary policy, but few market participants expect the Fed to ease its policy. 
 By late yesterday, the Treasury's 30-year bond was up 26/32 of a percentage point, to a price of 92 19/32 . The yield -- which moves in the opposite direction from price -- fell to 6.57 percent, from 6.64 percent on Friday.
Traders said that another factor giving prices a short-term boost was the likelihood that the Treasury's supply of new securities would tighten a bit. In fact, last evening the Treasury Department did postpone this week's auctions of $30.25 billion of two-year and five-year note sales because Congress has failed to lift the debt ceiling. The Treasury did not say what it was planning to do about plans to sell $18.75 billion of one-year bills on Thursday.
Carroll J. Delaney, director of research at Stires, O'Donnell & Company, said that although a variety of economic reports were due out this week, the focus of the market would likely remain on today's Fed meeting.
Yesterday's lone economic release was February's existing-home sales report. It showed a rise in sales to 3.96 million units at an annual rate from 3.72 million units in January. Analysts said it was noteworthy that unsold inventory increased despite the increase in sales.
Mr. Delaney said the fixed-income markets would continue to be dogged by conflicting economic crosscurrents. "In such an environment," he said, "especially confronted by new supply, the odds favor lower prices in the short term" and higher yields. He added, "Although we may not see it this week, we still think it's possible for yield levels of 6 percent for a 2-year note and near 7 percent for 30-year bonds to be reached, before a significant rebound develops."
Scott Bleier, vice president of market strategy at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, agreed there was confusion in the market with regard to the economy and what it meant to bonds.
"There are a couple of reasons for that," he said. "The numbers coming from the Government, for one, are unreliable and skewed because of the Government shutdowns and the harsh winter that affected business activity. We not clear yet on how strong or weak the economy is."
Mr. Bleier also noted a number of currents affecting interest rates, including commodity prices "that may or may not be perceived as inflationary." But, he continued, "since they are regarded as harbingers of inflation the market does become concerned; while oil prices and real estate prices to date have been stable, they are two of the largest inflators in the economy."
He added: "The Fed needs to see a clearer picture with unskewed numbers, and must see a trend. I think the economy is still lackluster at best even with all the skewed data."
Consumer prices, producer prices and employment numbers remain the most important focus of attention as investors wait for a clearer trend to appear without the seasonal anomalies and weather-related prices. Mr. Bleier expects the yield on the long bond to remain between 6.25 percent and 6.75 percent.
At the regular weekly bill auction of new three- and six-month paper, the average rate for a three-month maturity fell three basis points and a six-month issue fell nine basis points, to 4.99 percent and 4.97 percent, respectively. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Analysts said that retail demand was decent for the six-month issue, but below average for the three-month bills.
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of new three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: POLITICS: ON THE TRAIL;
Focusing On Issues To Shape The Future

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: SPOKANE, Wash., March 25

 BODY:
For a last campaign swing through two Western states today, Patrick J. Buchanan chartered an airplane to travel in style as he delivered another version of his list of demands on the Republican Party.
But the plane was mostly empty, leaving Mr. Buchanan's dwindling campaign caravan looking like one of the "lost tribes" he keeps saying the Republican Party needs to bring home. 
 And on the eve of the primaries here and in California, where polls suggest that Mr. Buchanan will fare poorly, the questions and answers at news conferences today had less to do with the campaign at hand than with his recurring threat to bolt the party.
"I am not coming to this convention in San Diego to walk out," Mr. Buchanan said this morning at a briefing in San Diego in the building where the Republican National Convention will be held in August. "But we are not ruling anything out."
Mr. Buchanan said that after conferring with top advisers at his headquarters in McLean, Va., on Thursday about a possible independent bid, he would begin writing an outline of his vision for the party, which he called his "McLean Manifesto." But he said he would not start a third party campaign before the Republican convention, and might not do so at all.
Mr. Buchanan, who later held a news conference in Sacramento, Calif., before flying to a Spokane rally tonight, has begun traveling to journalists, because few journalists are traveling with him. He was accompanied today by more flight attendants -- three -- than newspaper reporters.
Including network crews, the disheveled journalists following Mr. Buchanan outnumber the crisply dressed secret services officers narrowly, by 11 to 9. Counting campaign staff members and candidate, 25 of 90 airplane seats were filled today.
Mr. Buchanan is still developing his list of desired positions for the Republican Party. In San Diego today, he named three main demands: that the party remain anti-abortion; that it address the economic anxieties of working- and middle-class people, and that it aggressively oppose illegal immigration.
But in Sacramento, he emphasized that those were not the only issues destined for the McLean Manifesto. "I have in mind a variety of issues that will be addressed in this in much more specificity and depth than you can do right here at a press conference," Mr. Buchanan said.
Even on a subject close to his heart, trade, Mr. Buchanan said today that he remained uncertain what to ask for. "I have not formulated exactly anything on that," he said in San Diego.
Mr. Buchanan said he intended to express a broad vision in the manifesto for Republicans caught up in "an arid economics that knows the price of everything and the value of nothing."
"If this party doesn't find a heart and soul to go along with its economic ideas," he said, "then it's not going to have a future in this country."
Mr. Buchanan said: "You know, we've denounced welfare queens over the recent years, and we've got to start talking as well about these corporate butchers, and some of these leveraged buyout folks."
While he is still working out his economic positions, Mr. Buchanan has lost none of his trademark specificity on social issues. In Sacramento, he was asked what he thought of a marriage of homosexuals conducted today by San Francisco's Mayor.
"That's a phony wedding," he said. "I think that's a mockery of traditional marriage. It's a manifestation of societal decline when political leaders stand up and lend their prestige and, if you will, give a secular benediction to that kind of travesty."

HEADLINE: Ford Shifts Leadership at Lincoln-Mercury Unit

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., March 25

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company announced today that James G. O'Connor, executive director of export operations, had been selected to try to reverse the sagging sales of Lincoln and Mercury cars.
Mr. O'Connor replaces Keith G. Magee, who was general manager of the Lincoln-Mercury division for two years. Mr. Magee will head Ford's European sales efforts. The changes are effective immediately. 
Although Ford, like many auto makers in Europe, is struggling against the weak economy, some analysts see Mr. Magee's transfer as a vote of confidence. Many of the auto maker's top echelon, including the chief executive, Alex Trotman, did tours in Europe.
Sales of Mercurys, which include the Tracer and Sable, fell about 7 percent last year, while Lincolns, including the Continental and Mark VIII, fell about 16 percent.
Ford is trying to reposition its cars in the marketplace and will be introducing the Mercury Mountaineer sport utility vehicle this fall and Lincoln Navigator sport utility vehicle in 1997.
"Mercury's role in the marketplace needs a little more definition, while Lincoln has long-run potential, but right now is struggling," said Michael Schmall, director of automotive forecasting for J. D. Power & Associates. "With the right product, Lincoln could do extremely well."
The division has been criticized for missing the mark with its new vehicles, as well as for relying too much on sales to rental companies.
Lincoln-Mercury has lost market share to the General Motors Corporation, which is also trying to reposition its brands, as well as to Japanese auto makers. Lincoln-Mercury controls 3.7 percent of the auto market in the United States, down from 4.2 percent last year, according to the Autodata Corporation.
Mr. O'Connor will be succeeded by Richard N. Beattie, former executive director of rental and leasing operations. James F. Gwaltney, executive director of strategic planning and external affairs for the financial services group, will succeed Mr. Beattie.
Donald Cook, who was in charge of Ford's European marketing and sales, will return to the United States to a new position as head of customer loyalty, communication and training.

LENGTH: 1559 words

HEADLINE: It's a New Season For the Economy;
Some of Winter's Worries Linger But Growth Is on the Rebound

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Beverly B. Miller, president of a company that manufactures packaging equipment, first noticed the change in late February. Calls to her sales force surged unexpectedly, and one large customer, Hallmark Cards Inc., increased its orders for the automated machinery that packages the cards and party favors it makes.
But Ms. Miller, the president of Miller/Bevco Inc., in Kansas City, Mo., is hardly getting her hopes up for a booming year. The way she sees it, customers are loosening their purse strings only slowly and reluctantly. "Many companies were taking a wait-and-see attitude, and now they are taking less of a wait-and-see attitude," she said. "Demand has backed up, and they have to do something." 
 After stumbling in December and January, the American economy is bouncing back -- not strongly, but enough to be noticeable. Fears of a recession, evident in February, have faded. All but a handful of prominent forecasters expect this Presidential election year to be one of growth.
The growth that is emerging, however, is turning out to be too mild to give President Clinton any assurance that he can run successfully on economic growth alone. The recent signs of revival are probably strong enough, however, to keep the Federal Reserve from pushing down interest rates at its policy meeting today.
As for business executives like Ms. Miller, they say that a recession has probably been averted, but they are not yet breaking out the champagne. Stephen R. Hardis, chairman of the Eaton Corporation in Cleveland, for example, finds small comfort in the rising backlog of orders for the truck transmissions and axles that his company makes.
"I don't think the economy has a clear-cut direction yet," Mr. Hardis said. "You can say it isn't falling, which was what people were worried about. We always thought 1996 would be a year that would be flat or a little up, and it seems to be a little up."
The signs of revival, however lacking in vigor, show up in the almost daily release of new statistics. Retail sales are marginally stronger. Home construction has picked up. Job creation is more robust. Rising stock prices are increasing the wealth and the buying power of millions of people. And inventories of unsold goods are beginning to dwindle, which should make merchants increasingly willing to order and restock.
 The problem is that for nearly every ray of sunshine in the economic data, there is a troubling shadow. Home construction starts, for example, jumped in February to well above last fall's level, but permits to break ground for more construction in the months ahead have not risen. Auto and truck sales, another major source of economic growth, are also rebounding from a winter dip, but auto manufacturers are offering more discounts and incentives to maintain sales.
Capital spending on machinery, computers, trucks and buildings -- the tools needed to run a business -- was an important component of economic growth in 1994 and early 1995, and still is. But while this spending once rose briskly, the outlays are rising more modestly today. Similarly, while retail sales have risen gradually, so have personal bankruptcy filings and the level of consumer installment credit as a percentage of disposable income -- two indicators that Americans may be pressed for cash.
"All these factors are producing a high degree of uncertainty about the future direction of the economy," said Lewis Alexander, chief economist at the Commerce Department.
Jerrold Abell, the business manager of the Rogers Corporation in Rogers, Conn., a manufacturer of materials used in electronic circuitry, says he is certainly getting mixed signals. "Competition is very fierce right now," Mr. Abell said. "Our customers are postponing orders, not quite certain what will happen."
Motorola is a Rogers customer, purchasing material for the circuitry that goes into telephone beepers. "Motorola's orders aren't dropping off," Mr. Abell said, "but they are not increasing at the rate we thought they would."
Such hanging back inevitably is reflected in the forecasts of what will happen in the seven months to Election Day. Even the most optimistic forecasters do not expect gross domestic product -- the value of all that the nation produces in goods and services in a given year -- to grow by more than 2.3 percent this year, compared with 2.7 percent in 1992. That was the year that Bill Clinton wrested the Presidency from George Bush, promising to reinvigorate his rival's sluggish economy.
Senator Bob Dole, who has locked up the Republican nomination, has not yet tried to exploit this political irony. But Senator Connie Mack of Florida, the Republican chairman of the Joint Economic Committee, is beginning to. "As the candidate in 1992, Mr. Clinton portrayed the economy as the weakest in 50 years," the Senator said, "and now he is talking about a weaker economy in 1996 as the strongest in three decades."
Administration officials are already developing a pre-emptive defense against such attacks. They are arguing that whatever its shortcomings, today's economy is of far higher "quality" than in the last year of Mr. Bush's term. The unemployment rate, for example, is 5.5 percent, compared with 7.4 percent in 1992, "which means that if you get downsized, you are able to get another job more quickly," said Joseph E. Stiglitz, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers.
The two election years are indeed different. In 1992, the nation was still shaking off the effects of a nine-month recession that had ended in the spring of 1991. Economic growth normally spurts in the first year after a recession, but most of the statistics available at the time suggested that the economy was still in the doldrums. Not only was the unemployment rate significantly higher, but the work force had shrunk during the recession, and by Election Day the number of Americans holding jobs was no greater than it had been when Mr. Bush took office in 1989 -- a setback that Mr. Clinton exploited by promising to create eight million jobs during his first term in office.
And that did happen. Still, whatever positive spin Mr. Clinton tries to put on this job growth, the economy is turning out to be distinctly weaker in the second half of his Administration than in the first half. In 1995, G.D.P. growth fell to just 1.3 percent, from an annualized rate of 3.5 percent for the period from the summer of 1993 through all of 1994.
The decline came largely in response to rising interest rates for mortgages, cars, home-equity loans and the like. Rates had been raised by the Federal Reserve out of concern that an overheated economy would push up the inflation rate.
With the economy weakening, the Fed changed course last July, and has been lowering rates slightly over the last eight months. But growth has remained sluggish in the first quarter of 1996, which ends Sunday, held back in part by winter storms, which depressed construction and discouraged shopping, and by a strike at a General Motors parts plant.
The ripple effect from the strike almost halted production at the giant auto manufacturer. Economists at the Federal Reserve have calculated that as much as three-tenths of a percentage point could be shaved off the growth rate in the first quarter as a result of the auto and truck production lost during the strike, which ended late last week. By most estimates, that would reduce the G.D.P. growth in the first quarter to an annual rate of only 1 percent.
This lost three-tenths will almost certainly be restored in the second quarter, as production recovers its old level, most economists say. But even so, growth in all of 1996 is not likely to exceed 2.2 percent. Fifty prominent forecasters surveyed monthly by Blue Chip Economic Indicators, a newsletter, are predicting 1996 growth of about 2 percent, or a bit higher.
The Administration does not challenge this estimate, and neither do most economists.
"I doubt that home construction and motor vehicles, which are very important in driving the economy, can get much better than they are right now," said Edward E. Yardeni, chief economist at C. J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell Inc. "You would really have to see much stronger consumer demand and greater demand for our exports to raise the growth rate significantly."
A few forecasters see a recession ahead. They would blame the Federal Reserve for failing to lower interest rates more quickly and the Clinton Administration for cutting back Government spending too precipitously, thus depriving the economy of the stimulus that such spending produces. "The President may have precipitated a recession," said Erich Heinemann, chief economist of Heinemann Economic Research. "That would be ironic."
At the other extreme, some economists on Wall Street, also in the minority, see in the latest statistics the beginnings of inflationary economic growth. They are urging the Fed to delay further cuts in interest rates.
The majority of economists fall in the middle, sharing the view of Peter L. Bernstein, an economic consultant. "The odds of a recession have gone way down, to practically zero, in recent weeks," he said. "We are going to have growth, perhaps a surprising amount. That is my gut feeling, but no one can really know how much. There are still too many unknowns."
