HEADLINE: After Life of Notoriety and Pain, Son Tries to Solve His Mother's Murder

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD 

DATELINE: CLEVELAND, March 23

 BODY:
He slept right through it, that terrible night more than 40 years ago when his mother, Marilyn Sheppard, was bludgeoned to death in her bedroom.
Sam Reese Sheppard was only 7 years old when his uncle woke him the next morning and hustled him downstairs, past the policeman standing outside the blood-spattered room where his mother lay dead. It was July 4, 1954, and his father, Dr. Sam Sheppard, was in the Cuyahoga County Jail in Cleveland, about to become the defendant in a murder case that transfixed the nation. 
 Although Dr. Sheppard said he had been overpowered by a "bushy-haired" intruder that night, he was convicted of second-degree murder and sent to prison for life. Twelve years later the Supreme Court declared the trial had been a "carnival" in which reporters and television cameras trampled on his rights, and ordered a retrial at which, , with a young lawyer named F. Lee Bailey at his side, Dr. Sheppard was acquitted. Over the decades, the Sheppard drama never went away, inspiring the television series and movie "The Fugitive." But nobody was ever brought to justice for the murder and many in Cleveland still think Dr. Sheppard did it.
Now, Sam Reese Sheppard, 48 years old, believes that with the latest forensic methods, newly revealed evidence and a fresh suspect, he can finally solve the mystery.
And the Cuyahoga County prosecutor's office, which had fought for Dr. Sheppard's conviction, now thinks his son may be right -- but may never be able to prove it.
Under a court order obtained by Mr. Sheppard, the prosecutor's office earlier this month took a blood sample from Richard Eberling, the Sheppard's window washer, who is in prison for the 1989 murder of an elderly woman. Tuesday, also under the court order, the county coroner's office is to give the prosecutor and an attorney for Sam Reese Sheppard an inventory of evidence it holds on Mrs. Sheppard's killing.
Among the items Sam Reese Sheppard hopes the coroner's office still has are scrapings from under his mother's fingernails, hairs from the murder scene, a piece of a rocking chair from her bedroom, and several wood chips with blood on them, taken from stairs in the house.
None of the blood was tested at the time, so it is not known whether it was Mrs. Sheppard's or her killer's.
Together with a spot of blood from a wood chip that Dr. Sheppard managed to retrieve from the coroner's office before his own death in 1970, Sam Reese Sheppard hopes these slivers of evidence can provide enough material to conduct DNA tests that will prove Mr. Eberling was the real killer.
Carmen Marino, the first assistant county prosecutor, said, "I don't think Sam Sheppard killed his wife. There should have been more of an investigation at the time."
But now, so many years later, with many of the principals in the case dead and the files of both the Cleveland police and the county prosecutor missing, it may be impossible to finally settle the mystery. "It seems far-fetched to me now that Sam did it," Mr. Marino said. "But I don't know that there will be enough evidence to declare him innocent or convict anyone else."
The outcome of the new investigation is critical to Sam Reese Sheppard, an unemployed dental hygienist from Oakland, Calif.
"The murder destroyed my family," he said in a telephone interview.
Not only was his mother beaten to death with 35 blows, but his father drank heavily after being freed and died of liver disease, and two of his grandparents, distraught over the slaying, shot themselves to death.
Out of fear of publicity, Sam Reese Sheppard lived for years like "The Fugitive," not revealing his past.
But since 1989, Mr. Sheppard, has worked with a writer, Cynthia L. Cooper -- with whom he has published "Mockery of Justice; The True Story of the Sheppard Murder Case" (Northeastern University Press,1995) -- and private investigators to reverse the verdict of fate. Under an Ohio law, he is suing the state for wrongfully imprisoning his father for 10 years.
To win, Mr. Sheppard must first get a local judge to declare his father innocent and then he can seek damages in state court. Under the law, Mr. Sheppard could win $25,000 plus interest for each of the 10 years his father was incarcerated. And he might be able to claim the financial losses his father suffered from losing his practice as a prominent osteopathic surgeon. The total could run to more than $1 million.
But Mr. Marino is skeptical that Mr. Sheppard will prevail. First there is the issue of whether Sam Reese Sheppard has legal standing to sue. The Ohio law on wrongful imprisonment was designed simply as "conscience money" to be paid to the victim, Mr. Marino said, not to his descendants. Then there is also the question of how long the statute of limitations lasts.
Terry Gilbert, Mr. Sheppard's lawyer in Cleveland, acknowledges that the effort to win any actual monetary settlement may be protracted because the legal issues are unusual. But, Mr. Gilbert said, "We are thankful we have gotten this far, with even the prosecutor now believing Dr. Sheppard is innocent."
Mr. Eberling, now a 65-year-old state prison inmate confined to a wheelchair, denied through his lawyer that he murdered Mrs. Sheppard. "This is much ado about nothing," said David Doughten, Mr. Eberling's attorney. "Richard is the last living suspect, and in America this is how it is done," Mr. Doughten said. "With due respect to O.J. Simpson, Sam Sheppard is the holy grail of crime detection, and there is always going to be somebody coming up with a new theory."
In the original case, according to the vague version Dr. Sheppard gave to the police, he had fallen asleep on a day bed downstairs in the family's Dutch Colonial house on a bluff above Lake Erie. He awoke to his wife's screaming, "Sam, Sam." He ran upstairs, he said, and was attacked from behind and knocked unconscious.
When he came to, there was blood everywhere and his wife lay with no pulse, her pajamas pulled below her knees and above her breasts. Hearing a noise, he ran outside down some steps to the lake, where he got a brief glimpse of a tall man with a large head before being overpowered again.
Dr. Sheppard's story seemed suspicious. There were no signs of forced entry, the police said. And Dr. Sheppard was a poor witness, denying that he and his wife had any marital problems. But the police soon found Susan Hayes, a lab technician who recounted having sex with the doctor in his Jaguar.
But Sam Reese Sheppard and Ms. Cooper have now found that the police withheld vital evidence. Henry Dombrowski, a police officer, discovered pry marks on the basement door, and there was a trail of more than 30 blood spots from the bedroom down to the cellar. Two of Mrs. Sheppard's teeth were broken outwards, suggesting that she bit her assailant and that the blood trail was left by the killer. Dr. Sheppard had no cuts.
Mr. Eberling first came under suspicion as early as 1959 when he was arrested for burglary and a ring belonging to Mrs. Sheppard was found in his house. He told the police that he had been working at the Sheppard home two days before the murder and had cut himself, bleeding all over the house. He had a prominent scar on his left wrist.
In 1989 Mr. Eberling was convicted of murdering Ethel May Durdin, a 90 year-old for whom he had worked as a caretaker, and forging her will, which left him most of her $750,000 estate. A few years earlier, her sister, who had not liked Mr. Eberling, was found beaten to death in her bed, much like Mrs. Sheppard. That murder has never been solved.
Since he has been imprisoned, Mr. Eberling has made a number of tantalizing statements to Mr. Sheppard and Ms. Cooper. "Sam, yes, I do know the entire story," he wrote in one letter. Another time he drew an accurate diagram of the interior of the Sheppard's house.
Based on information obtained by Ms. Cooper, Mr. Sheppard believes Mr. Eberling was a troubled man who "was jealous of our family as the ideal family he didn't have."
Mr. Sheppard hopes DNA testing will confirm his hunch.
While denying the murder, Mr. Eberling has written: "The Sheppard answer is in front of the entire world. Nobody bothered to look."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 2103 words

HEADLINE: Tucson H.M.O.'s May Offer Model for Medicare's Future

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: TUCSON, Ariz.

 BODY:
"Partners for Seniors has expanded its pharmacy benefit!" a newspaper ad proclaims to Tucson's big retirement community. "Enjoy free health club benefits," promises Intergroup of Arizona. "Do you know," touts FHP Health Care, "how your health plan stacks up against FHP's? You tell us. $0 plan premium. $0 deductibles."
Tucson's health maintenance organizations offer free hospital stays, free annual physical exams, free X-rays, free mammograms, free laboratory tests, $26 eyeglasses, $5 and $10 doctors' appointments, free rides to get to them and this year's newest offering: $7 for a three-month supply of any of 300 prescription drugs. 
 The juices of unbridled competition are bubbling in Tucson's medical community. Lured by the payments the Government gives for medical care for each Medicare patient, four private H.M.O.'s are vying for the business of the elderly and stirring a stampede from the conventional Medicare system by offering new services, lower prices and more preventive care. This is not charity, they say. By keeping people healthier, the companies say, they hold down costs and fatten their profits.
In response to the companies' appeals, 42 percent of the people 65 and older in Tucson's Pima County, or six times the national average, have fled the standard, more costly Medicare program to enroll in the programs for the elderly offered by the four competing H.M.O.'s: Partners Health Plan, Intergroup, FHP and Cigna Health Care of Arizona. In only a few other cities so far, including Riverside, Calif., San Diego and Portland, Ore., have such organizations captured more than 40 percent of the Medicare-aged population.
For lawmakers, the health organizations' success in enrolling the elderly makes Tucson a test case for ways to cut fat from the health care system and curb the rise in Medicare spending. While both Democrats and Republicans support greater use of H.M.O.'s, they differ on how to achieve that goal. Last year, the Republicans proposed financial incentives for the elderly to leave their traditional plans; President Clinton halted the proposal, calling it coercive.
The rush of the elderly into H.M.O.'s in Tucson runs counter to the more common image of H.M.O.'s as ferocious cost-cutters that employers hire to provide health care for their workers. In programs for the elderly, the patient, not an employer, is the customer.
The environment is so competitive here for the business of the elderly that H.M.O.'s are behaving like banks giving away toasters. Customers who do not see enough to like can stick with conventional Medicare, which serves most of the nation's elderly.
"It's been sort of a price war in Tucson," said Chris Herstam, director of the Arizona Department of Insurance in Phoenix, which oversees the financial condition of the H.M.O.'s. "And that's great for consumers."
But Stewart Grabel, ombudsman for the Pima County Council, calls the H.M.O.'s a mixed blessing. "So far, the H.M.O.'s' emphasis has been on cutting costs," he said. "There are serious quality-of-care issues that we see in terms of discharges from hospitals and nursing homes, in terms of getting things approved that would be readily approved under traditional Medicare and in terms of rights of appeal."
Such advocates for the aging accuse these H.M.O.'s of the same shortcomings that have been ascribed to many of those serving younger people: reducing services to the sickest and having a cost-cutting mentality that obstructs access to specialists, delays surgical operations and shoves patients out of hospitals prematurely.
 
Lower Costs, Less Red Tape
But Government analyses also show that only 1.2 percent of the organizations' patients in Arizona quit the plans each month to return to conventional, fee-for-service Medicare. And in a state poll for the Arizona Hospital and Health Care Organization last November, the Gallup Organization found that the elderly in H.M.O. programs were more satisfied than health care consumers in all other types of programs, including fee-for-service Medicare, employer-financed H.M.O.'s and employer-financed insurance programs that permit workers an unrestricted choice of doctors.
Herman and Catherine Manus, who retired here from Queens in 1979 after bringing up four children, report that FHP has provided generally satisfactory care, though they have had complaints.
In the last five years, Mr. Manus, 85, has had surgery to his hip, both knees and his prostate. Mrs. Manus, 74, has had a hysterectomy, angioplasty to clear out her arteries and two hernia operations; now she has another hernia.
In the middle of these medical problems, FHP assigned the Manuses a new primary-care doctor, the gatekeeper that H.M.O.'s use to supervise patients and control costs.
"I had sharp pains in my side," Mrs. Manus said, "so I went to see her. She told me it was bursitis. My daughter, who's a nurse in New York, said, 'Mom, get rid of her.' " So the Manuses complained, and FHP let them select a new doctor. "He tells me what it was," she said. "A hernia."
It was a small price, Mrs. Manus said, for all the money they have saved. "We can't believe we don't have to pay anything," she said. "Except for the fee to see the doctor. That was $10 a visit; now it's $5. And we don't get all the paper work."
Like the Manuses, many of Tucson's elderly are swayed by the simple arithmetic of joining H.M.O.'s., and by the prospect of being liberated from Government forms, insurance forms and other assorted paper work. Under standard, fee-for-service Medicare, an individual pays $716 for each hospital admission, pays for all medications and pays a $46.10 monthly premium to cover 80 percent of the cost of physician and outpatient services. Many also buy insurance costing $200 or $300 a month to cover the charges that Medicare does not.
 
H.M.O.'s Reaping Medicare Profits
H.M.O.'s finance their services through grants from the Federal Health Care Financing Administration. It pays them 95 percent of what it would typically pay to care for a beneficiary.
The grants are based on local health care costs; in Tucson, H.M.O.'s get $438.58 per month per patient. That income and the money saved through tight cost controls are expected to leave the organizations room enough to offer cheap prescriptions and many additional services, like free physical exams, while still making a profit. The companies say profits range from 2 to 5 percent in Arizona.
The success of the H.M.O.'s here is built upon the state's early start in managed care, particularly its unique approach to Medicaid, the Federally financed health care program for the poor. The Medicaid program has given Arizona experience in dealing with managed care, and it has given the state's H.M.O.'s experience in dealing with clusters of patients.
Fourteen years ago, the state got a waiver from Federal regulations and began requiring all Medicaid beneficiaries to join an H.M.O. Arizona now invites H.M.O.'s to bid for the business every three years, and the state tries to insure competent care by attaching high priorities to the accessibility of care centers and the quality of their service.
Numerous studies of the state program say the result has been to keep Medicaid costs lower in Arizona than in most states and to provide better care. Many other states have now established Medicaid managed-care programs, but no others have reached Arizona's level of patient coverage, which is close to 100 percent.
Now Tucson's experience with H.M.O.'s for the elderly is offering policymakers insights into how to curb the growth in Medicare spending so its trust fund does not run dry early in the next century, as many economists predict.
In their 1996 budget proposal to keep Medicare afloat, Republicans in Congress have proposed a $270 billion reduction in projected spending through 2002 for Medicare, which cost $175 billion last year. They would do that by reducing the growth in spending to 6 percent a year from 10 percent. President Clinton favors a smaller cut, $89 billion.
The H.M.O.'s here argue that there is plenty of room for cuts that would still leave them with adequate profits. "That's nothing, $270 billion," said Dr. Bill Buchsbaum, vice president of medical affairs for Partners Health Plan.
But no one can yet claim that H.M.O.'s would make a dent in Federal spending for Medicare, however much they might save their patients. "The way the Medicare-H.M.O. program is currently constructed, we're not saving any money," said Bruce C. Vladeck, head of the Health Care Financing Administration, which oversees Medicare.
The reason, Mr. Vladeck said, is that the H.M.O.'s appear to be subtly attracting the youngest and healthiest among the elderly, who can be served for less than 95 percent of the average cost for Medicare patients. That gives them enough left over to offer services that conventional Medicare cannot match, Mr. Vladeck said.
The H.M.O.'s deny that. "I've never seen any analysis to support that," said Thomas Lescault, vice president for government programs at Intergroup.
The health agency's statistics are inconclusive as to whether the H.M.O.'s are serving a healthier population than Medicare as a whole. They show that 9 percent of the H.M.O. patients are 85 or older, compared with 10 percent of those in conventional fee-for-service programs. But the data also show that 24 percent of the H.M.O. patients are in the presumably healthier group of 65- to 69-year-olds -- a lower proportion than the 26 percent in that group on the fee-for-service rolls.
Other analyses show that H.M.O.'s can drive down all Medicare spending, as fee-for-service physicians keep their fees down to compete with the companies. And while many physicians here work exclusively for H.M.O.'s, many others work on contract for H.M.O.'s while also taking fee-for-service clients. In many cases, they adopt cost-saving H.M.O. practices, leading to what economists call a spillover effect.
 
Study Predicts More Savings
In a study last September for the industry's trade group, the Group Health Association of America, Jack Rogers, chief health economist at the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse, reported that a 10 percentage-point increase in the proportion of the elderly using H.M.O.'s would spill over to reduce the Government's fee-for-service Medicare spending by 2.8 to 7.6 percent.
And if H.M.O.'s nationwide raised their enrollment of Medicare patients, now 7 percent, to 40 percent, or close to the Tucson level, the study said, all Medicare spending would drop by 21 percent, just about enough to achieve the Republicans' projected reduction of $270 billion.
Despite the free services that H.M.O.'s offer in Tucson, the issue of choice discourages many retirees from signing on.
"That's the primary thing," said Nancy Menth, 78, a widow and former high school English and French teacher who has osteoporosis. "I don't want to be restricted to the doctors in the H.M.O."
But the appeal of fee-for-service care is evaporating as the influence of the H.M.O.'s becomes pervasive here.
"The doctor I go to happens to also be an H.M.O. doctor," Mrs. Menth said. "Even though I have freedom of choice, his backlog of people interferes with accessibility. The volume of the whole thing -- it's just about impossible to get in on a phone line."
State Senator Ann Day of Tucson, chairwoman of the Senate Health Committee, is leading an effort in Phoenix to tighten regulatory control of H.M.O.'s by requiring them to disclose more information. "I think it's a fairly young industry and still evolving," she said. "It seems to be evolving more toward the cost-cutting end."
Walker W. Wilson, 86, an FHP enrollee who worked until a year or two ago as a carpenter refurbishing mobile homes, has few complaints.
Around Christmas, he recalled at a recent appointment, he started having trouble breathing. On Jan. 3, he went to see Dr. Thomas Eyler, who has a contract to serve FHP patients. Dr. Eyler listened to his chest. "He said, 'There's something there I haven't heard before,' " Mr. Wilson said. Dr. Eyler found that he had pneumonia and something else. The doctor dispatched him that day to a cardiologist, and the cardiologist immediately put him into the hospital.
"The cardiologist said with that heart valve the way it was, he'd be gone in six months," said Alice Wilson, 81, Mr. Wilson's wife of 62 years. Mr. Wilson had the aortic valve replaced with a pig's valve and was in the hospital for three weeks. "To this day," she said, "we've never gotten a bill."

HEADLINE: In Bosnia, Securing a Peaceful Future Now Depends on Roads, Refugees and Elections

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, March 22

 BODY:
"You want to see my graph of the future?" asks Carl Bildt, the former Prime Minister of Sweden who is in charge of carrying out all provisions of the peace agreement in Bosnia and Herzegovina except for the work of the 60,000 NATO peacekeepers who keep the belligerents apart.
His graph is a time line, five arrows beginning with NATO's arrival last Dec. 14 and pointing toward a huge question mark for the period after NATO is to leave at the end of this year. 
 The future is a shaky one, compared with the vision painted in the Dayton accords -- that of a peaceful Bosnia with ethnically integrated cities, awash in international donations to rebuild what war had torn down, a country equipped to conduct the free elections vital to its survival.
"The popular perception is that after the elections, we go home because it's all over," said Mr. Bildt.
But on the civilian side, work has barely begun on the hardest tasks -- organizing elections, rebuilding shattered homes, roads and power lines, and overseeing the return of 2.2 million refugees. And unless there are signs of success soon, Mr. Bildt and others warned of the danger of resumed fighting after the NATO force leaves, a prospect that would make all the billions of dollars spent on the operation money down the drain.
"We need money," Mr. Bildt said. "We don't have the money. The election is not funded. Refugee returns are not funded. There are an estimated 3 million uncleared land mines scattered all across the country. More than 60 percent of all housing units are damaged, and 18 percent are destroyed.
"All of these problems will take many years and a lot of money to solve, and I don't see where it's coming from," he said.
The World Bank and other international agencies estimated last year that $5.1 billion in foreign aid would be needed during the next three to four years to get a recovery started, $1.8 billion of it this year alone.
But, according to Mr. Bildt, donor countries have actually contributed only about $358 million of the $550 million they have pledged, including $84.9 million for "quick impact" relief from the United States and $45 million from the World Bank for emergency recovery projects.
Even the $1.8-billion goal for this year does not include the cost of getting refugees to begin returning to their home towns, or of housing them. And it seems a small sum compared with the devastation of the country's roads and bridges and the money needed to get moving again a national economy that is flat on its back.
NATO officials and critics in the United States blame some problems on what they see as Mr. Bildt's slowness off the mark. But European officials, particularly in France, say that the Americans gutted his job of any real authority by excluding him from the NATO command, to avoid repeating the civilian-military disagreements that had paralyzed United Nations forces during the war.
Yet even as he insists that securing lasting peace will take years of effort, and probably a residual NATO military presence beyond the projected pullout date, Mr. Bildt, 46, says that he intends to leave his post of civilian High Representative in Bosnia at the end of the year.
He has not looked for an apartment here, but instead has a $165-a-night room at the Hotel Bosnia. His operation, of about 50 people, is squeezed into a single bullet-pocked office floor in downtown Sarajevo.
"I see this as a one-year thing," he said. "The local authorities have to take their own responsibilities."
What happens then depends on whether other countries are prepared to put as much time, effort and resources into encouraging the former belligerents into getting together as NATO has put into keeping the cease-fire alive.
So far, it does not seem that they are.
"I think the military side is going to be okay," Adm. Leighton W. Smith Jr., the American commander of the NATO force, told reporters recently. "But if the civilian side goes belly-up, the possibility of peace in here diminishes dramatically."
Local authorities on all sides of the conflict have complied with the military provisions but brazenly ignored many of the civilian ones, with no effective sanctions from Mr. Bildt or Admiral Smith.
Bosnian Serb authorities coerced tens of thousands of Serbs in Sarajevo and its suburbs into leaving when their neighborhoods were turned over to the Bosnian Government in recent weeks. The Government did little to persuade them to stay.
Mr. Bildt criticized the factions after the fact, but could not effectively bash Bosnian Serb and Muslim heads together in time to stop the exodus.
NATO forces chased down and arrested only a handful of arsonists, arguing that maintaining civil order was a civilian police responsibility, but the international police force as yet has in place less than half the 1,721 officers provided for in the peace accords.
Instead of the ethnic mix of residents protected and policed by forces carefully composed to reflect the ethnic breakdown of the original population of neighborhoods, Sarajevo is largely a Muslim city now, with little prospect that Serbian refugees will return soon.
Police of all sides have brazenly violated the peace agreement by keeping checkpoints on roads that members of all Bosnian nationalities are supposed to be able to travel freely. Muslims and Croats, supposedly members of one federation recognized in the peace agreement, have clashed openly in Mostar, and many Croats in western Bosnia consider that a part of Croatia.
A new high-level conference of donors is scheduled to take place in Brussels from April 12 to 13, with a goal of raising $1.2 to $1.3 billion for reconstruction this year.
[Foreign ministers of five countries closely monitoring compliance with the peace agreements have threatened to cancel the conference unless all sides release prisoners still held in violation of the peace accords.]
Hasan Muratovic, the Bosnian Prime Minister, told a group of prospective donors here last week that just the physical destruction done by the war would cost $80 billion to repair, with $16 billion in foreign aid needed to get private money flowing.
"You might be prepared to ask: Why the world?" he said. "Because nothing had been done to prevent this hell, to which you are all now witnesses, from happening. Therefore we believe that the world has an obligation to help us."
Mr. Muratovic is a Muslim, and his remarks make it doubtful that he was referring to the need to help repair the devastation in Serbian-controlled areas. But in any case, according to an American official at the conference, the statement had the effect of alienating many of those in his audience.
NATO forces have done some repair work to the infrastructure despite their American commanders' fear of "mission creep."
American military engineers and Hungarian contractors will complete a bridge to Croatian territory over the Sava River near Brcko by the end of this month, and German Army engineering units were repairing blown-up bridges on the road between Sarajevo and Tuzla.
But Sarajevo is still a national capital without a civilian airport.
Less than six months from the elections prescribed by the peace agreement, which are expected to take place around Sept. 1, the pre-war census list that is to be used for voter registration has not yet been found, according to officials here.
"The peace agreement provides for refugees to have the right to vote for candidates in the districts they lived in before the war, but they are scattered all over Europe," one of Mr. Bildt's aides said. "The lists will have to be distributed to them and they have to register to vote either there or in other districts. All of this work hasn't even been started, and it will all have to be completed very soon."
Nor has funding yet been provided for the hundreds or even thousands of international monitors needed to insure a fair election.
The elections are to establish a national parliament divided among members of Bosnia's three main ethnic groups, a rotating national presidency, and separate parliaments for the Croat-Muslim federation and the Bosnian Serb republic within Bosnia. But to many diplomats here, it is beginning to look as if real power will be held by nationalists determined to keep Muslims, Croats and Serbs living separately.
"If things keep going the way they are," one international civil servant warned, "it will be impossible for refugees to return to areas not controlled by their own ethnic group."
All these problems -- displaced people, demobilized soldiers with no jobs, and simmering political tensions -- could mean a return to limited war next year if the NATO peacekeepers all leave before civilian part of the accord takes hold, Mr. Bildt and other officials warn.
Of particular concern is the north of Bosnia near Brcko, where a territorial dispute between the federation and the Bosnian Serbs has yet to be mediated.
"The military bit's gone fine, but the civilian and reconstruction bit isn't going fine, largely because the federation is in trouble and the political guys on both sides cannot agree to sit down and come up with a tri-entity solution," said Lieut. Gen. Sir Michael J. D. Walker, the British deputy of Admiral Smith who commands NATO ground forces here.
"If that isn't going to be the case, it is a widely held view that one solution might have to be some sort of follow-on force," he said, but NATO has not even begun to consider one.
Making peace among themselves is primarily a task of the parties, Mr. Bildt tells them during the frequent meetings between them that he presides over. But the level of mistrust is still so great that NATO peacekeepers had to escort Bosnian Serb delegates into Sarajevo when they last met here on March 16.
A day earlier, Mr. Bildt got a taste of the mistrust himself when he went for a stroll in the Sarajevo district of Grbavica just before it was turned over to the Government.
Blond and over six feet tall, he was recognized instantly.
"Look at this identity card," said a man who had come from Serbia, handing it to Mr. Bildt at a Bosnian Serb police checkpoint. The man had been told that the Government probably would not let him cross the street into their territory. "Can I visit my relatives on the other side with this card?" he asked.
"Yes," Mr. Bildt answered.
"Who will guarantee it?" the man pressed.
"That's a good question," was all Mr. Bildt could answer.

HEADLINE: STUDY CRITICIZES FEDERAL RESERVE AS LAX MANAGER

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 25

 BODY:
In a rare independent examination of the Federal Reserve's operations, a Congressional report issued today criticized management by the secretive central bank of its own finances, suggesting that it could spend less and return billions of dollars to the Treasury.
The report by the General Accounting Office was released by two Democratic Senators a day before the Senate Banking Committee is to take up nomination of the Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, to a third term. While it contains no direct criticism of Mr. Greenspan and does not address the monetary policy pursued by the Federal Reserve under his leadership, the report provides an unusually detailed look inside an institution with enormous power and, critics contend, insufficient accountability. 
 The report found that the central bank's spending rose from 1988 to 1994, the period it studied, at a higher rate than overall Federal Government spending. It said the Federal Reserve did not always seek fully competitive bids for services it buys.
The report also said that the Federal Reserve, which operates with no oversight of its internal finances, had accumulated, with little justification, a $3.7 billion contingency fund out of money that would otherwise have been returned to the Treasury, with $1.6 billion of the fund put aside since 1988, the year Mr. Greenspan became chairman. Each year, the Federal Reserve returns $16 billion to $24 billion in profits from its own operations.
More broadly, the report -- a draft that is expected to become final within a few months -- questioned whether the Federal Reserve was being managed properly to prepare it for a rapidly changing financial world.
The report seems likely to raise eyebrows among political leaders, from President Clinton down, who have heard Mr. Greenspan lecture repeatedly on the need to make painful choices to reduce the Federal budget deficit, and among ordinary citizens, whose mortgage rates, credit card bills and savings accounts are all influenced by the central bank.
There has long been a tug-of-war between members of Congress who want greater oversight of the Federal Reserve, and the central bank, which jealously guards its independence as a bulwark against political meddling in the sensitive area of interest rate policy. Although the G.A.O. has undertaken smaller studies of the Federal Reserve's operations, this one, which took two years, was its most comprehensive.
The Federal Reserve's policy- making body, the Federal Open Market Committee, is also to meet on Tuesday. The committee is not expected to change interest rates, given recent data suggesting that the economy is growing at a faster pace than at the end of last year.
A spokesman for the Federal Reserve, Joseph R. Coyne, said the central bank had been given a copy of the report for formal comment, and would have no public statement until it had drafted its reply.
The Federal Reserve does not receive any Congressional appropriation but instead finances itself through interest earned on Treasury securities and fees charged to the financial services industry. It returns to the Treasury each year the difference between its revenues and its expenditures.
Specifically, the report made these points:
*From 1988 to 1994, operating expenses for the Federal Reserve Board and the 12 Federal Reserve Banks around the country increased 50 percent, to $2 billion, twice the rate of inflation and nearly three times the rate of growth in overall Federal discretionary spending. (The rate of growth in Federal Reserve expenditures for the period was about the same as for Federal spending when the effects of declining military spending were factored out.)
*Contracting and procurement practices at some of the Reserve Banks "favored certain sources over others, despite systemwide guidance that prohibits this," the report said. "Such practices raise questions about conflicts of interest and favoritism and whether the system is receiving the most favorable prices." The report provided few details.
*The size of the staff rose 4 percent from 1988 to 1994, to 25,745, but total compensation costs rose 53 percent in the same period, to more than $1.3 billion. Much of the increase was in benefits, which vary among the Reserve Banks but "are generous compared to those of Federal financial regulatory agencies with similar personnel requirements," the report said. During the six-year period, benefit costs in the Federal Reserve rose 91 percent for each employee, while the increase for Federal Government employees generally was 62 percent.
*The $3.7 billion contingency fund kept by the Federal Reserve, which has grown sharply in recent years, "could safely be reduced or returned to the Treasury," the report said. "Although the surplus account is intended to absorb possible losses, the Federal Reserve has recorded substantial net profits for 79 consecutive years," the report said. "Even though the likelihood of the system's incurring losses exceeding its revenues appears remote, the total surplus increased 79 percent in the 1988-1994 period."
* The Federal Reserve and Congress should consider a number of changes, including possible mergers of the 12 Federal Reserve banks and their 25 branches.
While the most visible role of the Federal Reserve is setting monetary policy, it has a host of other responsibilities, including banking regulation, that have grown ever more complex. The report said the largest increase in personnel came in bank supervision and regulation.
The report noted that the Federal Reserve paid to the Treasury $16 billion to $24 billion a year in profits in each of the six years studied. Most of the profits come from interest paid by the Government on Treasury securities held by the Reserve Banks as collateral, with some coming from fees charged by the Federal Reserve for check clearing and other functions.
It also said that the central bank had begun to show that it could work to address its problems. But it made clear that the G.A.O. believed the problems were serious.
"With the current budgetary climate, the Federal Reserve could do more to increase its cost-consciousness and insure that it is operating as efficiently as possible in its day-to-day operations," the report said.
Urging the Federal Reserve to undertake a broad re-examination of its mission and structure, the report said: "The need for such a re-examination is underscored by a number of major legislative, technological and marketplace developments that could profoundly affect the nature, size and distribution of the Federal Reserve's activities and resources."
The question of Federal Reserve secrecy and accountability have long been debated outside the institution, and increasingly within it. Senators Harry Reid of Nevada and Byron L. Dorgan of North Dakota, who asked the G.A.O. to do the report and released it today, have sought unsuccessfully for years to pry more information from the central bank and to interest their Congressional colleagues in legislation to create more oversight without impinging on its power to set monetary policy.
"This is the kind of thing that goes on behind closed doors that taxpayers ought to know about," Mr. Dorgan said.
The central bank has always jealously guarded its independence, fearing outside pressure to manipulate interest rates. Still, some insiders, notably Alan S. Blinder, who resigned recently as vice chairman, have argued for greater openness, at least in disclosing the reasoning behind monetary policy decisions.

HEADLINE: Benefits Fund Could Grow In the Market, Panel Advises

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 25

 BODY:
Members of a Federal advisory panel told Congress today that a portion of Social Security payroll taxes should be invested in the stock market, and several senators expressed cautious support for the idea.
The proposal, which represents a radical change in Social Security policy, survived its first test on Capitol Hill without criticism from any member of Congress or any of the experts on pension policy who testified before a Senate subcommittee. 
 Details of the proposal have not been worked out, and Congress is not expected to take action this year.
Still, lawmakers were clearly intrigued with the possibility that Social Security could earn a higher rate of return by investing some of its trust fund assets in common stocks and mutual funds. Since creation of the Social Security program in 1935, the money obtained from payroll taxes and not immediately needed for benefits has been invested in Government securities.
Members of the advisory panel said stocks had outperformed bonds over long periods. The return on Government securities, while relatively low, is guaranteed. The panel acknowledged that stock investments would entail a slight increase in risk for Social Security, but said the risk was manageable.
After hearing from 3 of the 13 members of the panel, the Advisory Council on Social Security, Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana, said: "There is agreement that the trust fund could be invested in equities. The question is, Who controls those investments?"
The hearing today was held by the Finance Subcommittee on Social Security and Family Policy, headed by Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming. The council, appointed in June 1994 by Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, includes business executives, union leaders and pension experts chosen to represent self-employed workers and consumers in general.
Some council members said that Social Security payroll taxes should be kept in one big pool, and that a portion should be invested by Federal officials or their agents in a broad selection of stocks intended to mirror the overall performance of the market. Other council members want to create an investment account for each person covered by Social Security. Workers could then decide for themselves how the money should be invested, though the Government would still provide some basic Social Security benefits.
Edith U. Fierst, a member of the advisory panel, testified: "All members of the advisory council favor private investments. That's a very significant change. The difference among us is whether investments in equities should be made by individual workers or by the trust fund."
Mrs. Fierst said she believed that the money should be invested by the trust fund because many workers had no experience in the stock market and could not make sophisticated investment decisions. In addition, she said, private investment options would be more vulnerable to scandals and swindles than the current Social Security system.
Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said he was surprised and pleased that council members, though divided on details, were "unified in support of the principle that some portion of the retirement system should go into private investment."
"I represent New York City," the home of many stockbrokers, investment advisers and mutual funds, said Mr. Moynihan, a longtime student of Social Security. Mr. Moynihan said he was not shocked, but delighted and surprised by the broad support for the recommendations among council members.
Senator Breaux said, "If we can encourage investment in equities, it's a good idea, but we also want maximum protection" for Social Security beneficiaries.
The Social Security trust fund now takes in more money in taxes and interest than it pays out in benefits. But Federal officials say the program will not be able to pay all the benefits earned by members of the baby-boom generation because, under the latest estimates, outlays will exceed income starting in 2020, and the trust fund will be depleted in 2030.
Mr. Simpson said: "A yawning chasm is not far down the road. The sooner we address this problem, the less painful the solution will be."
Mr. Moynihan said Congress could alleviate the problem by slowing the growth of Social Security benefits paid to 43 million people. He said the Government could reduce the annual cost-of-living adjustment in such benefits because the current formula overstated inflation.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Fed's Finances Criticized In Congressional Report
A Congressional report criticized the Federal Reserve's management of its finances, suggesting the central bank could spend less and return billions of dollars to taxpayers.
The report by the General Accounting Office cited in particular a $3.7 billion contingency fund the Fed has accumulated. It was released by two Democratic Senators a day before the Senate Banking Committee is to take up the nomination of the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, to a third term. He was not criticized in the report. [Page A1.]
 
Russia Drops Planned Tariff Rise,
Clearing the Way for an I.M.F. Loan
Russia dropped a plan for a sharp across-the-board increase in tariffs, clearing the way for a $10.2 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund, Western economists said. In another conciliatory move, Russia dropped its ban on American poultry imports, the Clinton Administration announced. [A1.]
 
Mad Cows Strain European Union
The European Union moved to ban British beef as unsafe, even as the British Government was telling consumers at home that no further steps were necessary to protect them from exposure to so-called mad cow disease. The consumer scare is destroying Britain's $6.5 billion beef industry, and the standoff is straining the 15-country European alliance. [A3.]
 
Rate Fears Increase Home Sales
Fears of rising mortgage rates resulted in an unexpected 6.5 percent increase in sales of existing homes last month, to an annual rate of 3.96 million, seasonally adjusted, the National Association of Realtors said. It was the first monthly rise since October. [D5.]
 
Stocks Mixed in Slow Trading
Stocks were mixed in slow trading. The Dow Jones industrials rose 7.22 points, to 5,643.86, but the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite fell 15.13 points, to 1,087.09. [D12.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities rose with the 30-year bond up 26/32 of a percentage point, to 92 19/32; its yield fell to 6.57 percent from 6.64 percent on Friday. [D19.]
 
Ford Selects Lincoln-Mercury Head
Ford Motor appointed James G. O'Connor, executive director of export operations, to try to reverse the sagging sales of its Lincoln and Mercury cars. He replaces Keith G. Magee, who will head Ford's European sales. [D4.]
 
Time to Sell Preferred Shares
Time Warner said that it planned to sell $1 billion in preferred shares with a 20-year maturity linked to its Time Warner Entertainment venture, and use the proceeds to ease its debt. [D4.]
 
N.A.S.D. Bans Frank Wolf
Frank N. Wolf, former president and owner of F. N. Wolf & Company, was ordered to repay $7.9 million to hundreds of investors because they were not warned that his firm sold them risky penny stocks. He was also banned from the industry and fined $250,000 by the National Association of Securities Dealers. [D10.]
 
Chile Declares Victory Over Medfly
Chile has declared victory over the Mediterranean fruit fly in a persistent, 30-year battle that included such tough tactics as spraying pesticides over heavily populated areas and confiscating all organic material entering the country. Chilean agricultural officials forecast that agricultural exports, currently $1 billion a year, could rise by $500 million a year by the end of the decade. [D6.]
 
Melville to Sell Kay-Bee Toys
The Melville Corporation agreed to sell its Kay-Bee Toys chain, the second-largest toy retailer after Toys "R" Us, to Consolidated Stores, a deep discounter, for $315 million. The sale of the 1,000-unit chain is expected to heat up competition among toy stores. [D9.]
 
Finalists for Magazine Ad Awards
Among the finalist agencies in the annual Magazine Publishers of America Kelly Awards competition for creative excellence in magazine advertising, Carmichael Lynch in Minneapolis and Wieden & Kennedy in Portland are tied for the lead. Each has five campaigns. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D11.]

HEADLINE: Russia Drops Big Tariff Increase, Clearing Way for an I.M.F. Loan

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 25

 BODY:
Russia has dropped a plan for a sharp across-the-board increase in import tariffs, clearing the way for a $10.2 billion loan from the International Monetary Fund, Western economists said tonight.
The election-year loan had been thrown into doubt earlier this month after Russia's Finance Minister, Vladimir G. Panskov, proposed a 20 percent increase in the tariffs, contradicting previous assurances to the I.M.F. 
 But a senior Western economist said tonight that Russia has now met almost all of the conditions and that the fund's staff has prepared a confidential analysis recommending that the loan go forward.
The fund's 24-member executive board is scheduled to take up the loan on Tuesday, and formal approval is now virtually assured.
The huge loan, which the United States has strongly supported, is linked to a comprehensive plan to proceed with market reforms and is expected to give President Boris N. Yeltsin an important election-year boost.
Mr. Yeltsin has been gaining ground in the polls against Gennadi A. Zyuganov, the Communist candidate. One of Mr. Yeltsin's selling points has been his ability to secure Western financial assistance.
Under a quickened schedule, an initial disbursement of $340 million could come as early as this month and more than $1 billion would be available before the elections in June.
That will provide Mr. Yeltsin with a badly needed infusion of money at a time when he is trying to win votes by making good on his promise to see that back wages are paid and social spending is increased.
On a related economic dispute, the Clinton Administration announced tonight that Russia has finally dropped its ban on American poultry imports. But negotiations on Moscow's decision to increase tariffs on those imports are just beginning.
The basic terms of the International Monetary Fund loan were set in February when Michel Camdessus, the fund's managing director, met with Russian officials. But only a week later, Mr. Panskov, the Finance Minister, proposed the average 20 percent increase in tariffs to raise revenue for increased social spending this year.
In another move that worried the West, Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin promised beleaguered farmers and ailing industries protectionist measures to help safeguard them from foreign competition.
That was a particular problem because Russia had promised the monetary fund that it would reduce the average import tariff by 1998. It also pledged that the average tariff would not increase before then.
The European Union sharply criticized Russia's talk of protectionism, a move that also worried the United States. The Clinton Administration was also distressed over the protectionist measures that blocked American exports of frozen chicken. In an effort to boost Mr. Yeltsin's standing with the voters, Mr. Clinton had endorsed the fund loan before negotiations were even complete.
But weeks of intensive consultations between the fund and Russian officials, as well as the I.M.F.'s explicit threat to withhold the loan, forced the Russians to modify their plans for the generally higher tariffs.
That does not mean that Russia's protectionist impulses have been completely checked.
According to Western economists, the average Russian tariff has still been increased 5 to 10 percent. But the monetary fund's staff says it does not believe that the politically important loan should be held up because of those increases.
Specifically, the fund's staff believes that Russia should be given more time to reduce the average tariff by, for example, lowering tariffs on equipment and machinery.
The I.M.F. itself has complicated Russia's task by insisting that quick steps be taken to impose modest tariffs on previously exempt goods. The fund urged action to encourage a more uniform system of tariffs.
Moreover, the fund's staff has concluded that Russia has made good on almost all of its other key promises. Moscow has eliminated the tax-exempt "stabilization fund" of Gazprom, the world's largest producer of natural gas. The fund insisted that such a step be taken to eliminate a huge tax loophole for a rich company with powerful friends in the Government, particularly Mr. Chernomyrdin.
At the behest of the monetary fund, Russia has moved to phase out export tariffs on oil and gas. The fund says those tariffs have produced artifically low energy prices in Russia, distorting investment decisions at home.
At the fund's suggestion, Russia is moving to introduce new excise taxes on electricity and fuel in order to make up the lost revenue from export tariffs.
Still, potential problems loom. In addition to the tariff issue, there is the problem of raising revenues, which have fallen drastically.
Russia's goal last year was to raise revenue to 12.5 percent of Russia's gross national product. Instead, revenue declined to 10 percent. It has since dropped further and is now running at a worrisome 8.5 percent of gross domestic product.
As a result, Russia's budget deficit has grown considerably, though it remains within limits set by the monetary fund.
To raise funds for the cash-strapped Government, tax loopholes favoring vested interests will have to be closed. Raising revenue is crucial because the Government needs money to ease the pain of transition to a free-market economy and reduce popular resistance to reforms.
Despite a new agreement to restore import licenses, the dispute between the United States and Russia over American chicken exports still persists.
Under the new agreement, Russians will begin issuing new import licenses for the more than $500 million a year in American poultry exports. In return, the Russians will be able to conduct spot checks of American poultry plants and a small sample of each American poultry shipment will be checked for bacteria and disease.
But American and Russian officials are still at odds over Russia's decision to increase tariffs on frozen poultry, which could effectively be doubled.

HEADLINE: Old Problems Surface Between China and Taiwan

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 26

 BODY:
With the dust-up between China and Taiwan settling down, their officials began grappling in public today with the obstacles that remain before the two sides can even begin talking about delivering mail to each other, much less about a meeting between their leaders.
Blunt comments by officials in China and Taiwan have demonstrated that despite the euphoria over receding military tensions in recent days, major differences remain. 
 Shen Guofang, a spokesman for China's Foreign Ministry, said flatly that Beijing would not consider reopening talks about establishing mail, air and shipping links until Taiwan's leaders stopped seeking a higher diplomatic profile around the world, which China interprets as moves toward independence.
In Taiwan, Premier Lien Chan stridently asked China to renounce its threat to use force to retake the island before sitting down for talks.
"I call on the Chinese Communist authorities to thoroughly abandon the flawed strategy of the possible use of force to resolve cross-strait problems," Mr. Lien said, speaking on state television. "When the two sides consider that the time is right, we are willing to hold talks aimed at a peace accord."
The remarks on each side, while keeping to previously set positions, were tougher in tone than the conciliatory gestures made immediately after Saturday's presidential election, which President Lee Teng-hui won decisively.
For years, China has urged the opening of direct air, shipping and mail links with Taiwan, where many residents have relatives on the mainland with whom contact had been broken off until tensions eased in the mid-1980's. Taiwan officials hesitated, but eventually agreed to a series of meetings on the topic, which were suspended last summer after President Lee's trip to the United States infuriated leaders in Beijing.
Chinese leaders have argued that greater contact with Taiwan will speed an eventual reunification on China's terms, even though the mainland restricts the flow of both information and ordinary citizens more than Taiwan does.
Since 1949, when Nationalist forces retreated to Taiwan, all travel, mail and trade -- each of which has grown sharply in the last five years -- has been through Hong Kong, the British colony that reverts to Chinese rule next year.
China has promised the same "one country, two systems" approach for both Hong Kong and Taiwan, theoretically allowing them to keep independent judiciaries and governments and capitalist economies. China plans to handle Hong Kong's foreign affairs and defense, but has said it would allow Taiwan to keep its own army.
Yet many doubt China's ability to keep from meddling, and just this week Beijing made final a decision to abolish Hong Kong's existing legislature on July 1, 1997. Chinese officials objected strongly to the way some members were chosen in Hong Kong last year -- though democratic elections.
A day after China announced the end of a third round of military exercises that it had conducted near Taiwan over the last three weeks, a Beijing-controlled newspaper in Hong Kong, Wen Wei Po, quoted Chinese military officers today as saying that they might hold another round.

HEADLINE: Business Consultant To Study Broadway

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS 

 BODY:
In hopes of bringing more original work to Broadway, New York City and a group representing theater producers, landlords and unions have hired a management consultant to look at how Broadway operates and explore the creation of a foundation to finance new plays and musicals.
The hiring of Bain & Company, of Boston, a consulting concern frequently called on to analyze troubled industries, is a first step in the establishment of what city and theater leaders said they hoped would be a long-term plan to stimulate Broadway. Part of that plan is the proposed creation of a Theater Trust, a permanent foundation that would award grants or perhaps make loans to producers and theaters. 
 The decision by the city and the Broadway Initiatives Working Group, a coalition formed two years ago to consider the future of Broadway, to participate in the study is in itself considered a breakthrough. For years, theater leaders have discussed the dearth of new productions on Broadway. But addressing it has been stymied by the age-old feuds among theater owners, producers and the craft unions.
"The reason for doing all this is that it's very clear that the No. 1 draw for the city is the Broadway theater and other live presentations," said John S. Dyson, Deputy Mayor for Economic Development. "Considering how many different interests there are, and the ancient and even slightly tedious disagreements among them, I think they're working very well together on this."
The city is providing half the money for the $100,000 study, with the rest coming from private donors, said Jack Goldstein, the coordinator of the working group and assistant to Ron Silver, president of Actors' Equity.
Analysts from Bain & Company, who began their research about three weeks ago, are examining financial documents from various Broadway productions and talking to people in the industry to develop a portrait of how Broadway does business. Their analysis is expected in about a month.
Increasingly, Broadway has been relinquishing its role as an incubator for new work, especially straight plays. While the so-called mega-musicals, the multimillion-dollar productions created by the likes of Cameron Mackintosh and Andrew Lloyd Webber, are thriving, the straight play, once a Broadway staple, has all but vanished. This season, for instance, only eight new plays will have opened on Broadway by the season's end on May 1. Broadway faces other problems, like competition from other forms of entertainment and rising costs. In those ways, it shares the concerns of larger industries in transition, like car manufacturing, airlines and steel, said Patrick F. Graham, director of Bain & Company.
"Broadway has many of the characteristics of a turbulent industry," he said. "The issue here before us is, is there a way for a trust to be established to help this group move forward and grow and prosper?" The Bain analysts have also been asked to recommend ways the trust fund itself could be financed.
"We have a desperate need for producers in the theater, and it is very hard for them to get money and find investors for new plays," said Arthur Laurents, the director and playwright. With the composer Stephen Sondheim, he has long been agitating for a concerted effort by Broadway to devote resources to developing plays.
The Broadway Initiatives Working Group was organized after the city decided to grant subsidies to the Walt Disney Company for its plans to rehabilitate the New Amsterdam Theater on 42d Street. The group -- comprised of Broadway's big three landlords; the League of American Theaters and Producers; the Dramatists Guild, and the unions representing actors, directors, stagehands and press agents -- came up with the notion of a trust fund, to be administered by a standing board. But the tricky question of where the money would come from has not been settled.
"There are two big challenges," said Jed Bernstein, executive director of the theater league. "How should the trust be structured and what should its objectives be, and secondly, how should it be funded?"
One proposal under consideration would be to use some of the revenue from the sale of air rights over Broadway theaters for the trust fund. Privately, however, theater executives say that all parties, including the unions, would have to contribute to the theater trust in order for the theater owners to give money to the fund.
Barbara B. Hauptman, executive director of the Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers, and a member of the working group, said the financing of the study itself was a reassuring sign that the city recognized Broadway's importance.
"The theater trust could be a catalyst for bringing back a creative environment to this area," she said. "We talk about the talent leaving us. If that creative environment could be rejuvenated around here, that wouldn't be an issue any more."

HEADLINE: Conference Board Survey Shows Dip in Consumer Confidence

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Consumer confidence was little changed in March following a sharp rise in February, an important index showed, amid indications that the economy is gaining steam.
The Conference Board, a private research group in New York, said yesterday that its index of consumer confidence was 97.7 for March, slightly less than February's revised reading of 98.0 but much more than the 88.4 it hit in January. Analysts had expected the index to be unchanged or slightly higher. 
 "We did not give back any of the bounce we saw in February," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "It suggests the economy is holding up fine."
As the index was released at midmorning, Federal Reserve officials were meeting in Washington to set interest-rate policy. They decided later in the day to leave rates unchanged.
The Fed had been easing rates to stimulate the economy, since lower rates translate into cheaper borrowing costs that tend to increase investment, hiring and economic activity over all. Recent data, though, have suggested that the economy is already strengthening.
Three weeks ago, a report that the economy created 705,000 jobs in February caught economists and others by surprise. Since then, signs of strength in the housing market have also suggested improvement.
The consumer confidence index is based on a monthly survey of 5,000 households in the United States.
Results of the survey suggested that despite the recent data, consumers remain somewhat concerned about job prospects. In March, 26.5 percent of respondents said jobs were hard to get, compared with 23.4 percent the month before.
"The improvement in employment conditions reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics for February has not been translated into a less apprehensive outlook about jobs," Edgar R. Fiedler, the economic counselor at the Conference Board, said.
That, however, contrasts with another measure in which those surveyed rated business conditions as good. That figure rose to 23.5 percent, from 22.3 percent in February.
The confidence index produced by the Conference Board is considered an important barometer of consumers' willingness to borrow and spend, which accounts for the bulk of economic activity in the United States.
Its results for March, which fell somewhat below the level a year earlier of 100.2, provided little reason to believe any major change in consumer behavior was in the offing.
"There's no buying binge," Mr. Roach said, "but there's certainly no collapse of consumer demand."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
German's Hint of a Rate Cut, And Fed's Refusal, Spurs Dollar

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar edged higher against the German mark and the Japanese yen yesterday after the head of Germany's central bank hinted at interest-rate cuts there while the Federal Reserve left rates unchanged in the United States.
Since interest-rate cuts make a country's assets and currency less attractive to investors, the combination of German and American developments helped the dollar move up against the mark, which was followed upward by the yen. 
 Comments from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, helped bolster the dollar. Testifying before a Senate panel considering his renomination for a third term, Mr. Greenspan said that the economy appeared to be running at a "reasonably good clip."
Tom O'Malley, a senior foreign exchange analyst for Technical Data in Boston, remarked that "comments from two central bank chiefs should be taken in a supportive fashion for the U.S. currency."
In New York trading last yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.4785 marks, up from 1.4781 marks on Monday. The dollar rose to 106.47 yen, from 106.16 yen.
Market participants had expected the Fed not to lower rates, given recent economic data hinting at some economic growth.
Analysts said the market also reacted to remarks by Hans Tietmeyer, the president of the Bundesbank, that the dollar was likely to strengthen at the same time the German money supply was slowing. Strong growth in the German money supply earlier had dampened expectations for a rate cut because of fear that such a move would stir inflationary pressure.
"There are a host of reasons for interest-rate cuts, none of which escapes Tietmeyer," said David Gilmore, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics.
Bolstering that view yesterday were comments by the German Economics Minister, Gunter Rexrodt, who said that the country's gross domestic product was flat in the first quarter of 1996. In last year's fourth quarter, output decreased by five-tenths of 1 percent from the previous quarter.
The Bundesbank's policy-making committee meets tomorrow, and the currency market is not anticipating a rate cut that soon. "But it is clear that German rates will come lower some time in the near future," Mr. O'Malley of Technical Data said.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Drought Sends Wheat Prices Up; April Gold Climbs to $400.50

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Wheat futures soared yesterday amid concern that a five-month drought affecting winter wheat fields was unlikely to ease soon.
Gold prices also gained. April gold rose $1.50, to $400.50 an ounce on the New York Mercantile Exchange's Comex division -- its highest price since March 1 -- amid signs that the economy may be strong enough to generate stronger inflation. 
 The rally lifted the Commodity Research Bureau index 0.22 point, to 252.66, its highest since July 25, 1988.
United States home resales surged by 6.5 percent in February, their first rise since October. And a recent jump in commodity prices is a traditional early warning of a rising inflation rate, traders said.
"Investor focus has settled on inflation again," Daniel McEvoy, trader at Credit Suisse in New York, said. "Concerns are creeping back that inflation will rise."
As for wheat, the National Weather Service predicted below-normal rainfall for the major wheat-growing states in its latest extended forecast.
"We are going to continue to see tight markets," Brian Doyle, president of the King Milling Company in Lowell, Mich., said, even after this year's harvest, which begins in May and lasts through July.
Agricultural officials in Kansas rated 43 percent of wheat fields in poor to very poor shape. In Oklahoma, 60 percent of wheat fields are in poor or very poor shape, while 66 percent of Texas fields are in such condition, state officials said. Those states produced 21 percent of last year's wheat crop.
Hard red winter wheat, the variety grown in the Plains, for May delivery surged 14.75 cents, to $5.19 a bushel at the Kansas City Board of Trade.
"The crop is waiting for a drink of water, and we are running out of time," said Joe Christopher, a trader with the Linnco Futures Group at the Kansas City Board of Trade.
Gasoline retreated from Monday's four-year high after a 13 percent rally in prices in the last two weeks that was based on speculation that refinery inventories were too low to meet a seasonal surge in demand. April unleaded gasoline fell 0.75 cent, to 66.25 cents a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Hold Steady

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in thin trading yesterday, as the Federal Reserve held its monetary policy meeting without changing short-term interest rates.
The Fed's decision had little impact on the bond market, as it had long been expected, especially after a surprisingly strong employment report earlier this month crushed any remaining hopes that rates would be lowered yesterday. Indeed, some market participants expect the central bank will refrain from lowering rates at its next policy-making meeting, on May 21, unless it has evidence that the economy is as weak as it appeared at the beginning of the year. 
 "There was no data today which would have caused a fundamental shift in market psychology," said P. Christopher Leary, senior vice president and portfolio manager of SunAmerica Asset Management.
Bond prices were held down in part by speculation that the Labor Department would revise upward the surprisingly strong February payroll number when the agency reports on March employment on April 5. More than 700,000 jobs were added to the nation's payrolls in February, and the number prompted sharp selloffs in the bond and stock markets on March 8. Some traders speculated yesterday that the number could be revised to as high as one million new jobs.
Still, prices largely held on to their gains of the last few days. The price of the 30-year bond settled unchanged yesterday at 92 17/32, leaving its yield also unchanged, at 6.57 percent.
"I think over all the rally we've seen over the past week or so represents a corrective bounce after a 12-point decline in the long Treasury bond futures contract," Mr. Leary said. "What we've seen over the last couple of days was exaggerated volatility based on the lack of liquidity, with small trades making big moves."
"Part of the rally," he said, "really has been anchored by the better performance of the short end of the market, which has rallied on the lack of supply with the postponement of the two-year and five-year auctions this week. However, this can be quickly reversed once the auctions are announced or if we do not get a coupon pass by the Fed, which has been widely expected for sometime this week." A coupon pass occurs when the Fed adds money to the banking system by becoming a buyer of various Treasury issues.
The market had little reaction to a report showing consumer confidence in March slightly lower than it was in February. The Conference Board, a private research group in New York, said its index of consumer confidence was 97.7 for March, compared with February's revised reading of 98.0
"Rather than the current trend of confidence showing improvement, it is merely maintaining last year's levels," said Bruce Steinberg, manager of Macroeconomics at Merrill Lynch, "and given weak income growth and high indebtedness, we look for confidence to gradually fall during the first half of 1996."
In the municipal market, the Puerto Rico Highway and Transportation Authority sold $1.08 billion of tax-exempt securities yesterday through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
The Puerto Rico agency had originally planned to sell the bonds two weeks ago, but a surge in rates -- and borrowing costs -- that followed the March 8 release of the February employment report prompted the sale to be postponed.
Municipal bond yields, as measured by the Bond Buyer index of 40 municipal issues, were at 5.90 percent, or 17 basis points lower than the recent high of 6.07 on March 18. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The Puerto Rico offering consists of $886.4 million in bonds to raise new money and $193.3 million in refunding bonds.
Underwriters initially priced the new money portion of the deal to yield a maximum 6.05 percent for an uninsured bond due in 2026, with yields on uninsured serial bonds ranging from 4.1 percent for one due in 1997 to 6 percent for one due in 2018. These uninsured bonds are rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's.
For the $193.3 million insured portion of the financing, the maximum yield is 5.675 percent, with the yield on the serials ranging from 4 percent in 1996 to 5.60 percent in 2015.
