HEADLINE: Personal Health;
Bullying: who picks on whom, and why?

SERIES: First of two articles on bullying in childhood.

BYLINE: By Jane E. Brody 

 BODY:
A SMALL group of young teen-age boys decided it was "fun" to turn a quiet classmate into a human plaything. They forced him to give them money, swallow weeds, drink milk mixed with detergent and allow himself to be led around on a leash.
A 10-year-old girl was bribed into doing homework and running errands for a classmate who told her she would not be allowed into "the club" unless she complied. 
 A third-grade boy woke up three school days in a row with a stomachache and refused to go to school after three fifth-grade boys surrounded him, taunted him, smeared him with animal excrement and then called him names.
The stories of bullies and their victims have a familiar ring to almost everyone. Most people have seen bullies in action and, in fact, most children are victimized by bullies at least once. According to Dr. Carla Garrity, a child psychologist in Denver with a special interest in bullies, "approximately 10 percent of all children attending school are afraid through much of the school day." Some of these children avoid lunch, recess and playtime out of fear that they will be humiliated or picked on by bullies, she said.
However, few people in authority respond to bullying with the appropriate degree of concern or with an appreciation for its potentially serious consequences for both the bully and his or her victims. Nor do most parents, teachers or school authorities know how best to put a stop to this destructive behavior.
 
The Making of a Bully
Myths abound about why some children become bullies and others victims. Contrary to popular belief, bullies are not inwardly anxious, insecure children with a desperate need to boost themselves up by making others afraid of them. Rather, when tested, bullies tend to score high in self-esteem. Nor are most bullies academic failures or loners without friends. Rather, studies have shown that bullies learn their aggressive, intimidating tactics from others, especially from parents or caretakers who rely on severe and often capricious physical discipline to get their way.
"Bullies are not born that way," said Dr. Leonard Eron, a research psychologist at the University of Michigan who has been studying aggressive behavior in children for decades."They learn that being aggressive and physically coercive is a way to get other people to do what they want and to increase their status and self-esteem. They learn this long before school age, from television as well as from parents. They see cartoon characters using physical force to acquire things, vent their frustrations and get their way, and they think the damage isn't permanent. The cartoon characters blow up and then come back."
Dr. John Lochman, a psychologist who studies aggression in children at Duke University, agrees that bullies "come to believe that aggressive behavior will work for them" and says "bullies place a high value on being in control and dominating others."
"Bullying is a way to make a child feel important," Dr. Lochman said.
 
A Bleak Future
Bullying often does not stop in childhood. Bullies are at greatly increased risk of becoming first, juvenile delinquents and later, criminals. Dr. Dan Olweus, a psychologist at the University of Bergen in Norway, followed thousands of boys from grade school to adulthood. He found that 65 percent of the boys identified as bullies in the second grade had felony convictions by 24.
As Dr. Garrity put it, "If nobody helps these children, they get worse and worse."
In an article in the current issue of Contemporary Pediatrics, Dr. Garrity and Dr. Mitchell A. Baris, a psychologist in Boulder, summarized Dr. Olweus's findings: "Bullies are at risk for conduct disorder and delinquency in adolescence, and for serious antisocial and criminal behavior in adulthood. Most remain bullies throughout their lives, enjoying their power and the control over others that their behavior evokes. They often drop out of school, have difficulty holding jobs and fail to sustain close, intimate relationships."
Dr. Eron has followed bullies in the Chicago area for 22 years, has found finding that they achieve less academically, socially, economically and occupationally than their nonbullying peers of comparable intelligence. He said, "They have more arrests for felonies and more convictions for serious crimes, are more abusive toward their spouses and are more likely to have highly aggressive kids."
 
Who Becomes a Victim?
Dr. Olweus's research also showed that most victims of bullies do not have external characteristics that set them apart. Children who were overweight, wore glasses or spoke with an accent were not more likely to be victimized than other children. Rather, it was mainly psychosocial characteristics that set them apart.
Victims tend to be anxious, insecure and lacking in social skills, Dr. Olweus found. These "passive victims" are often emotionally vulnerable and physically weak , easy targets who do not fight back.
A second, less common type of victim is the restless, irritable child who teases and provokes others. These "provocative victims" do fight back when attacked, but are not adept enough to win. Many are thought to have attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder, with poor impulse control.
Dr. Olweus's long-term studies showed that, as with bullies, the propensity to remain a victim is relatively stable over time unless something is done to help the child develop new ways of thinking and behaving. Although systematic long-term studies of victims have not been done, Dr. Garrity and Dr. Baris wrote that their counseling experience indicates that "victims of bullying suffer from low self-esteem, fear and anxiety, disrupted academic performance, lack of interest in school, a lack of trust and difficulty in establishing and sustaining friendships."
Dr. Garrity reports that girls are as likely as boys to be the victims of bullies, but the way girls are bullied tends to differ. Boys are primarily bullied by other boys who use swift and effective physical aggression, like tripping victims in the lunch line, shutting them up in lockers or elbowing them in the stomach as they pass in the hall.
Girls may be bullied by girls, boys or both, and the methods used are less physical, primarily social alienation and intimidation. A girl might be teased about her appearance or clothing or be made the target of malicious gossip. She may be the victim of extortion, for example, promised membership in a group if she participates in a cruel or humiliating prank. Or she may find intimidating notes.
 
Next : Changing bullies and victims in school and at home.

HEADLINE: Prosperity In New Chile Nourishes Drug Trade

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile

 BODY:
For the last decade, Chile has served as the model for economic growth and stability in Latin America, after opening its doors to foreign investment and shifting from military dictatorship to democracy.
But like a rising star with a dirty little secret, this enterprising country of 13 million people, nestled on a narrow strip of land between the Andean Mountains and the Pacific Ocean, has also become a major center for drug trafficking and money laundering. 
 Because of Chile's proximity to cocaine producing countries and miles of unprotected borders, it has become an important transit route for drugs from neighboring Bolivia and Peru to the United States, Europe and Asia, according to a report issued this month by the United States State Department.
The report found that Chile's open and thriving economy and its bank secrecy laws have made it an easy place to launder drug money and that drug use within Chile is rising sharply, especially among the upper classes and young people and in the workplace.
Stepped-up drug enforcement efforts in Columbia, Peru and Bolivia, including the shooting down of drug cartel planes by the military, have forced drug barons to establish new transit routes through the southern part of Latin America, namely Chile, State Department officials said.
"There have been incidents of substantial money flows that cannot be accounted for," said a State Department official who spoke on condition that he not be identified. "I'm talking about large bank deposits from companies that do not appear to have the means to generate that type of cash."
Drug experts said domestic drug consumption was also rising.
"We are like the United States in the 1980's in terms of our drug consumption," said Maria Pia Guzman, manager of Paz Ciudadana, a nongovernmental drug organization. "New freedom and new wealth as well as a breakdown in social norms are contributors to the problem."
Chile was the first Latin American country to undertake market economic reforms, including privitizing most state enterprises, eliminating tariffs and opening its markets to foreign investment.
A result has been 12 years of uninterrupted growth at an average of 7 percent, and record low inflation and unemployment that have positioned Chile to become the next member of the North American free-trade bloc.
Responding to the findings of the State Department report, Chilean Undersecretary of the Interior Belisario Velasco said simply, "In Chile, money has been and is laundered."
But Pablo Lagos Puccio, a lawyer for the National Committee for the Control of Drugs, a Government agency, said it would be a mistake to conclude that Chile is becoming a major world center for drug trafficking and money laundering.
"We are a country that is growing and changing very rapidly, and we acknowledge that there is a drug- and money-laundering problem here as there is throughout the world," Mr. Lagos said. "But we are taking the necessary steps to deal with these problems."
State Department officials said that while the Chilean Government has taken steps to address the drug problem, including increased enforcement and a new narcotics law that makes laundering of drug money illegal and obliges banks to report suspicious deposits to authorities, more work still needs to be done, especially to close loopholes in the new law.
"We believe that the Chileans are very sincere in trying to address this problem," a senior State Department official said. Referring to the North American Free Trade Agreement, he added, "They understand that if they are next on the list to be admitted to Nafta, they have to deal very strongly with drugs."
Last year, police drug seizures increased by 100 percent in Chile to 760 pounds of refined cocaine, 2.5 metric tons of cocaine base and 95.9 metric tons of marijuana, law enforcement officials said.
Most of the cocaine enters Chile on the backs of Indian runners who pass through its northern border with Bolivia in the town of Arica. From there it is carried by car to southern Chile for refining and then shipped abroad from Chile's thousands of miles of border and coastline.
The Government's anti-drug efforts suffered a major setback last year when President Eduardo Frei freed Angel Vargas Parga, a drug dealer who was convicted in 1989 for helping to smuggle half a ton of cocaine into Chile. Mr. Frei said he ordered Mr. Vargas's release because he showed good conduct in jail.
But the fact that Mr. Vargas has relatives who are officials in Mr. Frei's Christian Democratic Party brought widespread criticism of his pardon at a time when the Government was launching a nationwide campaign against drug use.

HEADLINE: $10.2 Billion Loan To Russia Approved

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund said today that it had approved a $10.2 billion loan for Russia. The move is expected to be helpful to President Boris N. Yeltsin in the presidential election in June.
The three-year loan is the fund's second biggest, after a $17.8 billion credit granted to Mexico last year. It is designed to help Russia along the road from Communism to capitalism. 
 To qualify for the loan, Russia agreed to far-reaching changes in its economy, including cuts in its budget deficit and more liberal trade policies. On Monday, Russia dropped plans for a sharp across-the-board increase in import tariffs. The plan for the tariffs had threatened the approval of the loan.
The credit is a vote of confidence in Mr. Yeltsin and his economic policies. He has been lagging well behind Gennadi A. Zyuganov, the Communist candidate, in opinion polls 12 weeks before the election.
The United States Treasury Secretary, Robert E. Rubin, said today that he welcomed the fund's decision and said that the loan should help Russia as long as it vigorously carried out the promised reforms.
An initial disbursement of $340 million of the loan could come as early as this month, and as much as $1 billion could come by the time of the Russian presidential election.
The money will help Mr. Yeltsin carry through on commitments to increase social spending and to pay back wages, both of which will be helpful to him in winning votes.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
A state agency takes charge of the commercial redevelopment of a Massachusetts military base.

BYLINE: By Susan Diesenhouse 

DATELINE: AYER, Mass.

 BODY:
A NEWLY formed Massachusetts state agency is moving forward with its first major project, a $1.5 billion redevelopment of half of the Fort Devens Military Reservation, which spans four towns 35 miles northwest of Boston.
The Army base is being transformed into a mixed-use industrial park with as much as 8.4 million square feet of space. The project, the Devens Commerce Center, has already signed its first major commercial tenant, the Gillette Company, to a long-term lease. 
 A 410,000-square-foot warehouse and distribution center, with 200,000 square feet of expansion space available, will be built expressly for Gillette, which is based in Boston. Site preparation is already under way. Gillette will be consolidating operations currently in the Massachusetts towns of Andover, Wilmington and Lynnfield.
The new agency, the Massachusetts Development Finance Agency, plans to take title to 4,480 acres, about half the total area of the 79-year-old Army base. Negotiations on the terms of the purchase have not been completed, but the agency will begin managing the property soon, even if the sale terms have not been concluded, agency officials said. The Army will retain the land that is not sold to the agency.
The agency, in addition to being the landowner, will become the lead developer, local governing authority and a major source of financing for the Devens redevelopment -- the first time that a single agency has assumed all these roles. The executive director is Michael P. Hogan, formerly the Mayor of Marlborough.
A redevelopment plan for the property was approved in 1994 by the four towns through which the base runs: Ayer, Shirley, Lancaster and Harvard. The agency will sell or lease existing buildings and land for the development of offices, light industrial use, research and development space, community recreational areas, retail stores and housing.
The agency will have the authority to assess taxes or fees; issue tax-exempt bonds; extend loans from a $150 million fund; sell or lease property and issue all permits. It also has the responsibility to provide for the public safety and deliver services like utilities, snow and trash removal, and schools, if residential development occurs.
The Massachusetts Development Finance Agency was formed to enable the state to be more active in commercial and industrial development projects. It was created through the affiliation of a state financing agency, the Massachusetts Industrial Finance Agency, with a land development agency, the Massachusetts Government Land Bank, which was set up in the 1970's to convert old military bases to civilian use.
A former deputy director of the Industrial Finance Agency, Theodore S. Chandler, said the new agency "brings a phenomenal new dynamic to the development process." In the past, one agency had control over land and development while the other had the financial resources. To have both land and capital accessible through one source makes it possible to do large-scale development projects, he said.
If the four towns had independently reclaimed the land they ceded to the Federal Government in 1917, they would not have had the technical or financial resources to develop it, said Stephen M. Slarsky, a selectman in the town of Ayer. "It's necessary to have a larger body to drive the process," he said. The town has 7,000 residents.
Over all, Mr. Hogan, the executive director of the project, said, it will cost about $1.5 billion to upgrade and install basic services like roads and pipes; renovate two million square feet of space in 70 commercial buildings and 280 houses that had been officers' quarters, and build about 6.5 million square feet of new commercial space.
The state and Federal governments will provide about half the financing and private developers are expected to arrange about $750 million worth, Mr. Hogan said.
Since last autumn, the state has offered low prices to entice the first developers and tenants. Taxes have been cut to 35 cents a square foot from 40 cents. Rents including taxes are $2.30 to $8 a square foot, and land has been sold for $20,000 an acre, about half price, Mr. Hogan said.
This year, 1.2 million square feet of construction, valued at about $127 million, is scheduled to begin.
Two Federal projects are already under construction: a $75 million, 400,000-square-foot prison hospital and a $20 million, 176,000-square-foot residential job training institute.
Last week, old buildings were demolished on the 25-acre site of the $18 million Gillette warehouse. The developer, the Campanelli Companies of Braintree, will close on the land by the end of May and start construction then.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Calls the Fed 'Extraordinarily Well Run'

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
Responding to a Congressional report that was critical of the Federal Reserve's management of its finances, Alan Greenspan today defended his record as chairman of the central bank at a Senate hearing on his nomination to a third term, calling the Federal Reserve "an extraordinarily well-run organization."
On a day in which the Federal Reserve's monetary policy committee decided to leave interest rates unchanged, Mr. Greenspan also gave a relatively upbeat though brief assessment of the economy, saying it was operating at a "reasonably good clip" with unemployment "lower than it's been at any time in the recent past." 
And Mr. Greenspan, a strong advocate of making inflation the Federal Reserve's overriding concern, heard President Clinton's nominees to two vacant Federal Reserve seats say that while price stability would be their top priority, they would also focus on jobs and economic growth. President Clinton and many other Democrats have questioned whether the Federal Reserve, by fighting inflation so aggressively in recent years, has kept the economy from growing at its full capacity.
Mr. Greenspan and the two other nominees to the seven-member Federal Reserve Board, Alice M. Rivlin, the White House budget director, and Laurence B. Meyer, a prominent economist at Washington University in St. Louis, were all praised by Republicans and Democrats alike on the committee, and seemed assured of confirmation.
But Mr. Greenspan, who is normally treated with considerable deference when he appears before Congress, came in for sharper-than-usual questioning about the Congressional report on the Federal Reserve, which was compiled over the last two years by the nonpartisan General Accounting Office and issued Monday by two Democratic Senators, Byron L. Dorgan of North Dakota and Harry Reid of Nevada.
The Senators have both sought ways to require more accountability from the Federal Reserve, which at its founding in 1913 was granted the freedom to operate with no direct oversight from Congress as a means of insuring its independence in setting interest-rate policy. Although Mr. Dorgan acknowledged he was critical of monetary policy under Mr. Greenspan, both Senators said their intention in releasing the draft report one day before Mr. Greenspan's confirmation hearing was to promote debate on how better to monitor the nonmonetary policy aspects of the Federal Reserve's activities.
The report said that the Federal Reserve had not kept sufficiently tight control over its expenses, which grew at twice the rate of inflation from 1988 to 1994. It questioned the need for a $3.7 billion contingency fund amassed by the Federal Reserve. And it urged the Federal Reserve to undertake a sweeping re-examination of its structure and mission.
While strongly opposing any attempt to restrict the Federal Reserve's independence in monetary policy, Mr. Greenspan said the Federal Reserve, like any organization, could learn things from outside evaluations, and that the G.A.O. report had some valuable suggestions.
But he said the overall tone of the report, in portraying the Federal Reserve as lax in imposing budget discipline, was wrong. The Federal Reserve does not receive appropriations from Congress. Instead, it finances its operations itself with the interest it receives on Treasury securities held by the 12 Federal Reserve Banks and with the fees it charges banks. It sets its own budgets and returns to the Treasury each year the difference between its revenues and its expenses, an amount typically in the range of $20 billion.
"My experience with the Federal Reserve in a little over eight years has led me to conclude that this is an extraordinarily well-run organization," Mr. Greenspan said.
The G.A.O. report "has a number of useful things and indeed I commend them for some of their insights," Mr. Greenspan said. "Nonetheless, the general thrust of the report that somehow the Federal Reserve has been profligate in the use of taxpayer funds, I find wholly contrary to the facts."
Mr. Greenspan said much of the rise in personnel costs, for example, resulted from a shift in the composition of the Federal Reserve's work force. The Federal Reserve's employees, he said, had turned during the period from traditional tasks like check clearing to regulating an ever-more complex financial world during a period that included the savings and loan crisis, rapid consolidation among banks and an increase in the interdependence in the global economy.
"Unless we are extremely scrupulous in our budget activities, there is nobody beyond us to protect the taxpayer," Mr. Greenspan said. "As a consequence of that, certainly since I've been there and from what I can judge with my predecessors as well, we have been extraordinarily concerned about what our budgets look like. I have been working very hard to restrain the budget, as all of my colleagues have."
A separate report by the G.A.O. of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas also found weaknesses in the bank's accounting procedures. Representative Henry B. Gonzalez of Texas, the ranking Democrat on the House Banking Committee, said he was seeking hearings on the Federal Reserve's operations.
Mr. Greenspan testified after a meeting of the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee. The committee's decision not to change interest rates had been widely expected after a spate of data suggesting that the economy, while hardly robust, was growing at a sufficient rate that it did not currently need the stimulus of lower interest rates. The committee is to meet again on May 21.
At today's Senate hearing, the primary topic of debate after the Congressional report was the extent to which the Federal Reserve should concentrate on defeating inflation rather than giving equal weight to its other mandated tasks of promoting full employment and maximum sustainable growth.
"The single most important thing in the long run is protecting the value of the dollar, price stability, containing inflation," Mr. Meyer said. But he added that he did not view his duties as a Federal Reserve governor ending there.
"I care deeply about whether or not this economy is at full employment," he said.
Ms. Rivlin was less outspoken on the subject, but suggested that inflation was part of a mix of factors to be considered in setting short-term interest rates.
"The goal of economic policy, of monetary policy, fiscal policy, all other kinds of policy, should be the maximum sustainable rate of growth in the economy," she said. "There are several things that could make growth unsustainable. One of them, obviously, is inflation."

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1472 words

HEADLINE: With Plenty of Jobs, Nebraska Goes to Lengths to Lure Skilled Labor

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: OMAHA, Neb.

 BODY:
Laurianne Kobzeff squealed with delight as dollar bills and discount coupons swirled around her in the plexiglass booth known as the "Money Machine." Before her 14-second stint ended she had scooped up $32 as a job bonus, breaking two nails in the frenzy.
It was all in a day's work because Ms. Kobzeff, a telemarketer from California, decided that her work would be in Nebraska, a state whose record employment levels have added a new dimension, and appeal, to the notion of migrant labor. 
 Actually, Nebraska's annual unemployment rate has been the lowest in the nation for the last three years, a result of flat population growth that has left the number of Nebraskans hovering around 1.3 million since World War II and a robust economy in which industries like telemarketing, food and data processing are expanding. Last year, an average of 2.3 percent of adult Nebraskans were jobless, less than half the national average of 5.5 percent.
Such stratospheric levels of gainful employment have left employee-starved businesses here fighting over workers the way most companies fight over customers.
Their targets are skilled laborers from out of state and youths at home who are new to the job market.
Their recruitment techniques are varied, sometimes novel: CD-ROMs and Internet Web sites proclaiming the attractions of life in Nebraska and in Omaha, its largest city; toll-free job-lines through which potential workers can dictate job applications, and bounties paid to anyone who brings 'em back alive. Then there is the flying Omaha job booth, which roams the nation, following news of major corporate layoffs in an effort to scoop up the newly unemployed and redeploy them here.
"I came out here because the job market was good, unemployment was low," said Ms. Kobzeff, 31, pulling dollar bills from under her fuschia sweater. It did not hurt to have half a dozen telemarketing companies offering lucrative employment packages and benefits.
To an extent Nebraska, and indeed, the entire Midwestern Plains region, which has a chronically low jobless rate, is living through the sequel to the farm crisis of the early 1980's. When family farms failed, people abandoned the region. With the economy growing again, Nebraska is finding itself short-handed.
"For plants, employees are the fuel," said Ernest Goss, who moved from Georgia to teach economics at Creighton University, a private college here. "We've depopulated the rural areas. Now, we are out of fuel."
Replenishing the supply has been difficult. Many of the state's young people have left for climes warmer than Nebraska and cities bigger than Omaha. In the late 1980's, net migration deprived the state of 5 percent of its residents in their 20's, about 10,000 people, according to the University of Nebraska's Center for Public Affairs Research.
Nebraska only recently started to reverse these trends. Over the last five years, the state's population increased 3.7 percent.
But still, too few Laurianne Kobzeffs are abandoning the nation's coasts for its center. In Nebraska, wages are higher while living costs and crime rates are lower than the national averages. But modern American migrants are holding out for beaches, mountains and big-city cultural attractions.
Recruiting employees "is a struggle for all of us in Omaha," said Rodger Jensen, personnel director for Miss Kobzeff's employer, Oriental Trading Company.
The weather -- brutal, according to the National Weather Service in Omaha, which logged 46 snow days and 8 days with sub-zero temperatures last year -- has not helped. The average temperature for December, January and February over the last 30 years was 24 degrees, the Weather Service said.
"It's easy to get people to move from North to South," said Peggy Noll, vice president of the Noll employment agency here, but the reverse is hard.
Help wanted advertising has increased 59 percent since 1993 at The Omaha World-Herald, the largest selling newspaper. "Three years ago, you could go to work for Wendy's for $5 an hour," said Dale Harris, the classified advertising manager. "Now you get $7 to $8 an hour, plus some incentives."
With the Money Machine passe after a year, Mr. Jensen plans to fill $6.50-an-hour positions at his catalogue company by setting up mobile booths at local shopping centers to recruit workers.
Advertising on television for employees is only a first step for Nebraska Furniture Mart, a mammoth housewares mall that employs 1,100 people. The company begs for workers through billboards, banners, credit card bills, sales slips and posters placed in churches.
When the mart has a major furniture sale, customers are channeled past job booths staffed with interviewers. A job-line (402-255-MART) allows job hunters to tap a list of openings, then dictate their applications.
"For people jumping ship, we want to make it as convenient to fill out an application as possible," said Ruth McCully, the company's promotions coordinator.
Furniture Mart and other companies are even turning employees into headhunters, paying cash bonuses for each referral hired. For more competitive professions, like systems analyst, companies pay hiring bonuses as high as $5,000.
"Raiding companies will offer 50 percent raises if you go work for them," said Jan Isom, information systems recruiting manager for Noll. "Then, the employers come back with counteroffers: more money, new job titles, bonuses, free parking, an extra week of vacation."
Half the 3,000 local companies polled last December by the Greater Omaha Chamber of Commerce said they planned to increase employment through 1997. The labor market here is expected to tighten, pushing up the average Nebraskan's income $1,000 a year through 1997, Mr. Goss, the economist said.
In the last five years, salaries for carpenters, plumbers and electricians have increased by 5 percent a year, hitting the national average last year of $40,000. This spring, labor shortages are stretching construction times by one-third.
Another of the state's attractions is the cost of living, about 8 percent below the national average. "When I moved here from New Jersey, the housing market seemed like a candy store," Ms. Isom said. A decade ago, she said, she traded a three-bedroom house in New Jersey for a four-bedroom house in Omaha for roughly the same price, $200,000.
To lure workers, Bob Bell, president of the local chamber of commerce, talks of "mining California" and "ambulance chasing" after company layoffs in New York.
Mounted at job fairs, the traveling "Omaha" booth offers company information, a CD-ROM on the delights of Omaha, free tickets to Omaha arts events and copies of The Sunday World-Herald's help wanted section. CareerLink, a Web site offers information about technical jobs in Omaha.
For executives moving here, the chamber offers a package of free tickets to Omaha's symphony, ballet, opera and playhouse.
To keep young Nebraskans here, companies work with high schools to match training with job needs. Aiming at college students, the Labor Availability Council, a business group, holds a job fair during the Christmas holidays.
Every year, the council identifies 12 top performing high school seniors. Once in college, these young Nebraskans are flown to Omaha free of charge for a weekend of wining and dining with local executives.
While some Americans snub Nebraska as "Cornville," the term does not seem to have been translated into Spanish. Last year, the Immigration and Naturalization Service arrested 704 illegal aliens in Nebraska -- double the number of the year before. Many of the illegal Mexicans seek work in the low-wage, nonunion beef packing plants that have opened in the state's interior in recent years.
In many of the nation's cities, the state unemployment office can be an abused building, frequented by lines of sullen people facing equally sullen bureaucrats. In Omaha, a visitor is greeted by wall-to-wall carpeting, hushed tones, and an invitation to talk in a semi-private cubicle with a job placement adviser.
Nebraska pays a maximum of $184 a week for an unemployment claim -- the 45th lowest level in the nation. A proposal to raise the maximum to $261 by the end of 1998, provoked The World-Herald last week to warn: "Too much too soon."
Judging by interviews on a recent morning, most of Omaha's unemployed see the center as a free employment agency. "I'll have a job in a month," John Falck, a 42-year-old computer hardware worker predicted confidently as he left the center.
Shelly Sullivan, a 27-year-old home care helper, was working at two jobs. But she stopped by the office to see if she could land a better paying one.
Asked if it was hard to find work, this Nebraska native laughed. "If someone doesn't have a job in Omaha," she said, "they don't want one."

HEADLINE: The Master Builder of Malaysia;
He Thrives With a Little Help From His Friends

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia

 BODY:
It isn't often that across-the-board rejection by swaggering American and European investment banks warms a developer's heart. But Francis Yeoh Sock Ping acts as if it is the best thing that has ever happened.
Refusing to capitulate to the foreign bankers' terms for financing his 1,200-megawatt power project, Mr. Yeoh (pronounced YEOW) instead found a way to borrow the $1.1 billion through Malaysian institutions. As a result, he said, he saved the project money and provided power for 25 percent less. 
 "You should use resources from your own country," Mr. Yeoh said. "The net result is better for the people."
Such self-reliance, shot through with a strong dose of nationalism, is a hallmark of Mr. Yeoh, who heads one of Malaysia's largest project-development conglomerates, the YTL Corporation. With interests in power projects, property development, manufacturing and hotels and resorts, the company, named for Yeoh Tiong Lay, Mr. Yeoh's father, is at the heart of Malaysia's economic boom.
In his climb to the top ranks of Malaysia's corporate giants, Mr. Yeoh has weathered restrictive government policies, cold shoulders from global banks and the threat of guerrilla war and has earned a reputation as an innovative and risk-defying tycoon. Despite being an ethnic Chinese Christian in a predominantly Muslim, Malay chauvinist state, he has managed to thrive. Indeed, like virtually every successful corporate heavyweight here, he is a familiar presence in the halls of political power, and is an intimate of Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad.
That symbiosis of political power and entrepreneurial energy is a phenomenon that has spread through much of Southeast Asia and helps explain the region's economic dynamism. While acknowledging the potential for corruption, some analysts say that such alliances of mutual advantage are well suited to Asia's authoritarian tradition.
Governments in the area rarely live up to the human-rights ideals espoused by the United States and Europe, but they embrace Western-style capitalism with passion.
Indeed, many Southeast Asian politicians view the success of their business proteges as the key to holding power. In Indonesia, for example, the Suharto family's involvement in government contracts and concessions is blamed for increasing the cost of goods and services and delaying projects. Meantime, the relationship between the Indonesian military and the country's leading ethnic Chinese businessmen has benefited both parties, giving the generals access to capital and the capitalists protection against the threat of anti-Chinese violence.
Jim Rohwer, the chief economist at CS First Boston in Hong Kong, said that while cronyism flourishes throughout much of Southeast Asia, "it is very hard to take the position it has held these countries back." He added, "If it doesn't go too far, it can act as a lubricant for the economy."
Mr. Yeoh, though worth more than $2 billion, is more of a foothill next to some of Malaysia's Everests of tycoons. Robert Kuok's vast holdings in Malaysia and across Asia -- hotels, newspapers, real estate, commodity trading, plantations, wood processing -- had their roots in a small grocery store begun by his father, an immigrant from China's Fujian province. Today, he is one of the globe's wealthiest men.
Likewise, Quek Leng Chan, head of a vast conglomerate including steel, motorcycle manufacturing and banking, comes from a family that migrated from Fujian to Singapore and Malaysia in the 1920's.
Nevertheless, the growth of Mr. Yeoh's business empire shows how fast even the lowliest entrepreneurs can rise if they learn how to pull the right levers. YTL originated as a small construction company started by his grandfather, who fled to Malaysia from China as the flames of World War II were dying down.
The founder's son, Yeoh Tiong Lay, wrangled the first significant contracts for the tiny company in 1955 to build ammunition depots and garrisons for the British colonial army. Two years later, when Malaysia gained independence, YTL continued building army compounds while expanding into other areas.
When anti-Chinese riots swept Malaysia in 1969, the elder Mr. Yeoh kept a low profile and kept building even as the Government enacted laws to grant special economic and social benefits to the native Malays.
"My grandfather came here and was willing to stick with it," said Mr. Yeoh, 42. "We rode the storm until we became what we are today."
Slouched in a brass-studded, burgundy leather chair and wearing a crisp gray suit, Mr. Yeoh presents a sartorial vision of conservatism. But he waves aside suggestions that favoritism is corrupting him or Malaysia's economic performance.
"In Malaysia, businessmen and Government work hand in hand, and it seems to smack of crony capitalism," he said. But in reality, he said, "the Government must choose performance, people who have a good track record." As for excluding big foreign companies from some big Malaysian construction projects, he said, in some cases the Government has no choice because against such deep-pocketed competition, "Malaysians would never have a chance to do it themselves."
Perhaps no other project solidified Mr. Yeoh's position as the building and financing of two power plants in the towns of Paka and Pasir Gudang on the Malay Peninsula. Two years ago, with Malaysia facing serious power shortages, the Government turned to the private sector for a solution. But, as in much of the privatization process here, there was no bidding. The first two licenses were handed to Mr. Yeoh's company, an act of favoritism that angered some critics of the Government.
His defenders point out that Mr. Yeoh completed the power stations, both of which began operating late last year, seven months ahead of schedule. "It's a very well-run company," said Lucy Chuah, the deputy head of research at TA Securities here. "Francis will tell you he'll be the next G.E." Of course, she added, "People see he's very well connected to Mahathir," the Prime Minister.
Getting the power permits was no guarantee that YTL could find financing for the $1.1 billion project, designed to supply 15 percent of the country's power needs. First, Mr. Yeoh turned to international partners and bankers. It was sobering.
"They would not give any loan beyond 10 years because of Malaysia's political risk. This was 1993. Can you imagine? I have a wall in front of me. I want a 15-year loan, and I get stopped at 10. It's a nonstarter from day one. So that didn't work. And thank God for that."
Though local capital markets had never entered the complex arena of project finance, Mr. Yeoh persuaded the state-run Employee Provident Fund, a social security savings fund, to lend the entire amount for 15 years at 10 percent, a substantially lower interest rate than the banks had proposed. His main negotiating weapon with fund managers was an agreement he had wrung from the state power utility to buy nearly three-quarters of YTL's power, whether or not the utility needed it.
Because of the lower interest rates, Mr. Yeoh said that he could produce power at 6 cents a kilowatt- hour, 2 cents less than projects elsewhere in Southeast Asia.
YTL's bottom line shows the results of Mr. Yeoh's negotiating skills. Profits for the fiscal year ended June 30 were more than 160 percent above those of a year earlier, rising to 273.5 million ringgit, or $112 million under exchange rates at the time, from 104 million ringgit, or $40 million, a year earlier. Sales in 1995 were 1.03 billion ringgit, or nearly $421 million. The Kuala Lumpur stock exchange, on which YTL was listed in 1985, values the company at $2.3 billion, of which the Yeoh family controls 49 percent.
In recent years, as Malaysia's economy has boomed, YTL has prospered by winning a steady stream of government contracts, ranging from a low-cost housing and commercial development in Ipoh and a million-ton cement plant in BukitSagu to a luxury condominium project in Johor and one of Asia's grandest resorts, in Pangkor Laut.
"There's no real tendering on key projects," an economist for a foreign bank said. "Mahathir sits on a committee for key projects. If he thinks you can deliver, he gives it to you."
Having established YTL's links to power, Mr. Yeoh, as managing director, has widened the company's reach, recently expanding into exclusive resorts. He began a super-luxury train service from Singapore to Bangkok -- the Eastern and Orient Express -- which trundles at a leisurely pace up the peninsula.
Now, he is scouting investment opportunities in Cambodia. That nation may be hurtling away from democracy, with press freedom stifled, the justice system in shambles and fire-fights flaring between Government troops and Khmer Rouge rebels, but Mr. Yeoh actually thinks things are looking up.
"How much worse can it get than the killing fields?" he asks.
Mr. Yeoh especially sees the tourism potential in the Angkor Wat ruins, which date from the 10th century and spread over nearly 70 square miles.
Last October, he won a 99-year lease from the Cambodian Government to develop 2,700 acres near the most spectacular complex of the Angkor temples. There, in the drowsy town of Siem Reap, he will invest $80 million of his own money.
"This is a phenomenal site," he said. "This is not the artificial castles of Disneyland. It's a U.N. world heritage site. I can bring all the great hotels and create a beautiful archeo-econological tourism product. No gambling. No go-go dancing. If I can do that, and it's a challenge, the world will come."

HEADLINE: Oil and Technology Stocks Lead Modest Rise in Market

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
The stock market rose broadly yesterday, helped by a recovery in technology issues and a surge in oil shares.
The gains came on a day when Federal Reserve policy makers left short-term interest rates unchanged, as expected. 
 "The Federal Open Market Committee came through exactly as expected," said Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall/21st Advisers. "It was a day of marking time."
The Dow Jones industrial average increased 26.74 points, to 5,670.60. The advance was led by I.B.M., which gained 2, to 110 3/4, after falling 5 1/2 on Monday. Increases in the shares of Exxon, Chevron and other oil companies also drove the Dow, as investors bet that a recent rise in the price of crude oil would lift the companies' earnings.
Among the broader market gauges, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks advanced 2.93 points, to 652.97, and the Nasdaq composite index gained 1.26 points, to 1,088.35.
Advances narrowly outnumbered declines, 1,235 to 1,116, on the New York Stock Exchange. The volume on the Big Board rose to 404.3 million shares, from 337.1 million shares on Monday.
With yesterday's activity, the total value of issues traded this year on the Big Board has exceeded $1 trillion -- the earliest that this mark has been topped in any year. The $1 trillion level was reached 32 trading days later last year.
The shares of many computer and software companies recovered from declines that had followed an article in The Wall Street Journal on Monday that raised concerns that corporate demand for their products was weakening. Intel rose 1 15/64, to 56 1/8, and Microsoft gained 2 7/8, to 102 3/4.
Among the rising oil stocks, Exxon advanced 2 3/8, to 86; Chevron rose 1 1/4, to 57 1/8, and ARCO increased 2 1/2, to 118 3/4. Triton Energy, which announced a major oil discovery in Colombia, climbed 8 1/4, to 59 3/4.
Drug stocks rose amid speculation that Glaxo Wellcome would merge with Pfizer. The American depository receipts of Glaxo rose 5/8, to 25 1/2, while Pfizer gained 1, to 68 3/4. Each A.D.R. of Glaxo represents two shares of the company, which is based in Britain. Other gainers included Warner-Lambert, up 1 3/8, to 105 5/8, and Merck, up 1 5/8, to 64 1/8.
The shares of gold companies also moved upward, in keeping with the advance in the price of the metal. Barrick closed at 31 1/2, up 1 1/4; Placer Dome closed at 29 3/8, up 1, and Newmont Mining closed at 59 3/4, up 2 5/8. The Standard & Poor's gold index jumped 2.93 points, to 652.97.
But retail stocks dropped after the Mitsubishi/Schroder Wertheim sales report was released, showing that volume at stores open at least a year declined 1 percent last week. J. C. Penney closed at 49 3/8, down 1 5/8; Nordstrom closed at 45 7/8, down 2 5/8; May Department Stores closed at 48 1/8, down 1 5/8, and Mercantile Stores closed at 61 1/4, down 1.
The shares of computer networking companies also turned lower, after Compaq Computer introduced a line of computer networking equipment. Bay Networks dropped 4 1/2, to 28 1/2; Newbridge Networks slid 5/8, to 49 1/2, and Cabletron Systems fell 1 3/8, to 66 1/2.
Lund International, which warned that its revenue in the most recent quarter would be lower than expected, declined 1 5/8, to 11 7/8. And Progress Software, which said that earnings in the first quarter would not meet Wall Street expectations, fell 5 1/16, to 14 15/16.

HEADLINE: Wireless Bidder Drops His Push

 BODY:
John Dolan, who bid more than $900 million in the Federal Government's auction for new wireless communications licenses, dropped out of the competition yesterday, saying the bidding had gone too high.
Mr. Dolan, the nephew of Charles F. Dolan, the cable television billionaire, said he had been outbid by Nextwave Communications for a license to serve the New York area. Nextwave bid $994 million.
Mr. Dolan had been the most surprising figure in an auction in which prices offered for wireless telephone licenses soared far higher than industry executives had seen before. He had focused virtually his entire effort on New York, bidding $936 million and fending off rivals.
Mr. Dolan also generated controversy. Nextwave, which is based in San Diego, asserted that his company, North Coast Mobile Communications Inc. of Huntington, L.I., was a possible front for his uncle's company, the Cablevision Systems Corporation of Woodbury, L.I. 
 In a statement announcing his decision, Mr. Dolan said, "After counseling with Charles Dolan and other financial sources, we have concluded that the bidding had reached a level of speculative excess which we could not economically support."

HEADLINE: In a U.N. Success Story, Guatemalan Abuses Fall

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: FINCA LOS CERROS, Guatemala

 BODY:
One afternoon not long ago, dozens of farm workers faced off against a platoon of military policemen in the cool coffee groves of this mountainside plantation in a tense labor dispute.
The police never fired their rifles. United Nations human rights observers arrived in the midst of the showdown and persuaded the police to leave and the coffee pickers to lay down their machetes. Unlike many similar confrontations in Guatemala in the last three decades, the episode ended without killing. 
 Worldwide, the prestige of the United Nations as a peacemaker is at an ebb. It is practically broke and fighting to recover from costly failures in Bosnia and Somalia. In the United States, many conservatives are calling for ending support of an organization that they say is spendthrift and ineffective.
But in Guatemala the United Nations has made a big difference, becoming the catalyst for a new tolerance for political dissent and protest about human rights violations. For the first time in a 34-year conflict in which more than 100,000 people have been killed, the United Nations is providing a neutral place where Guatemalans can go to recount the abuses they have suffered.
United Nations negotiators in two-year-old peace talks here have also been coaxing the Government and guerrillas toward a final armistice. [In a reflection of the optimism both sides feel about progress in the talks, the rebels on March 20 declared a temporary cease-fire, which the Government joined the next day.]
At the same time, the presence of United Nations observers in faraway corners like this coffee farm in western Guatemala has defused explosive situations and averted violence by the security forces.
The United Nations was called into Guatemala in November 1994 to monitor compliance with a partial peace accord in which the two sides committed themselves to improving respect for human rights. The United Nations mission here costs $20 million a year and has a staff of 416, including 50 police advisers, from 39 countries.
The United Nations is succeeding in Guatemala because it has not tried to do too much. It has not tried to impose peace or serve as a shadow government, as it did in Somalia. And in contrast to its role in Bosnia, it came to Guatemala with no peacekeeping troops at a moment when the people had shown they were ready for a change from war.
Over time, more and more Guatemalans have come to consider the United Nations office a sort of haven where they can report rights violations and even personal problems like neighborhood feuds. According to a Feb. 24 report, the mission received nearly 3,000 complaints between August and December 1995. The people found in the simple United Nations waiting rooms range from journalists threatened because of their reports to Indian farmers who need their stories translated into Spanish.
The violations are summarized in blunt quarterly reports that speak loudly in a country where many military commanders still regard the pursuit of human rights as an enemy act.
The United Nations has said the army is harboring car-theft and kidnapping gangs in its barracks, something Guatemalans knew but were terrified to say. Emboldened by the United Nations reports, the Guatemalan press has begun to investigate military corruption.
"We made it possible to say inside Guatemala what everyone was saying outside Guatemala," said Cecilia Olmos, a Chilean who heads the United Nations operations in Quetzaltenango, a western city.
Rodrigo Asturias, the commander of one rebel faction, said in an interview in Mexico City: "Three years ago, human rights was a subversive topic -- you could be killed for mentioning it. The United Nations turned it into a priority topic on the national agenda."
After the United Nations criticized the army for dragooning young men into its ranks at gunpoint off streets and buses, forced conscription stopped. In response to United Nations demands, the guerrillas ceased bombing bridges and the electrical grid.
United Nations officials regularly communicate with and often see military commanders on both sides, a change from years when Guatemalans were slain by Government forces simply on the suspicion that they had contact with the rebels. Ms. Olmos, while teaching human rights classes to army cadets, has traveled to the secret mountain stronghold of Mr. Asturias's guerrilla forces.
Political killings have decreased since the mission arrived. But gross abuses still occur, and the United Nations has no power to punish the offenders. United Nations officials acknowledge that most abuses in their reports have not been investigated or prosecuted by Guatemalan authorities.
"Impunity is the swamp that swallows everything in this country," said the head of the United Nations mission, Leonardo Franco of Argentina. "We have created a large opening for expression. But we haven't had an effect yet in the daily lives of the victims."
Last Oct. 5 a massacre took place that could have put the mission's effectiveness into doubt. Eleven Indian peasants were gunned down by soldiers in a refugee resettlement camp called Xaman in the rain forest in central Guatemala.
Instead, the killings showed how the United Nations could be useful. The army immediately asserted that the Indians were armed and had attacked first. But within two hours, while the bodies were still strewn about the camp, United Nations observers reached Xaman.
"At first the people were stunned and couldn't say anything," said Goran Fejic, an exiled Bosnian who is the United Nations official in charge of the region where the massacre took place. "We stayed and waited."
But the United Nations observers determined that the villagers had no weapons. They airlifted the wounded to a hospital in Guatemala City, where they talked to the press the same day, breaking the usual silence that surrounds such incidents.
On Oct. 10 the United Nations issued a report debunking the military version. The Defense Minister, Gen. Mario Enriquez, resigned.
Conflicts like the one at Finca Los Cerros remain difficult for the United Nations. The plantation changed hands several years ago and a new absentee landowner is seeking to drive 80 coffee pickers and their families off the farm. But they were born on the plantation and worked all their lives here. They came to the brink of violence out of frustration after local judicial authorities consistently favored the landowner.
"We have a deep feeling that we don't want to leave," said Julio Cesar Archila Miranda, the secretary general of a union the coffee pickers tried to form.
The United Nations has no mandate to intervene in land struggles. But its officials could respond to calls from both the police and the farm workers to come to the scene of a clash on Feb. 13. In a sign that the United Nations has persuaded Guatemalans of its neutral protection, the farm manager -- the man most hated by the laborers -- wrapped himself for several hours around a United Nations observer, Kenneth Ward, an American, to shield himself from attack by the peasants while the United Nations officials were calming things down.
United Nations officials also organized negotiations in the capital to resolve the issue. And Nelida Augier, the United Nations observer from Argentina who handled the case, did not back down in response to pressure by local officials. "This problem just shows how justice works faster here for economic powers than for workers," she said.
But the ultimate test for the United Nations is whether it can bring a long overdue peace. The talks wandered, then gained new momentum when President Alvaro Arzu Irigoyen took office in January. In February he became the first President to meet with rebel leaders since the fighting began.
"We couldn't have kept it alive among Guatemalans," Mr. Asturias said. "Without the persistence of the United Nations the peace process would have been impossible."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Greenspan Defends Fed As Its Efficiency Is Assailed
Alan Greenspan defended the Federal Reserve against criticism of the management of its finances by the General Accounting Office of Congress. At a hearing on his nomination to a third term as chairman, he called the Fed "an extraordinarily well-run organization." On a day that the Fed's policy committee decided to leave interest rates unchanged, Mr. Greenspan also gave a relatively upbeat if brief assessment of the economy, saying it was operating at a "reasonably good clip."
Mr. Greenspan and the two other nominees to the board, Alice M. Rivlin and Laurence B. Meyer, were praised by Republicans and Democrats. [Page D4.]
 
Dole Blocks Higher Minimum Pay
Senator Bob Dole blocked a Democratic effort to vote on raising the minimum wage, to $5.15 an hour from $4.25. Senator Edward M. Kennedy has been promising to offer the wage increase as an amendment to some bill for several weeks, and got his chance. Mr. Dole, the apparent Republican nominee for President, said a raise would cost many young people their jobs. [A1.]
 
$3 Trillion in Mutual Funds
 For the first time, the value of mutual funds has exceeded $3 trillion, a trade group said. But the headlong rush by investors into stock funds seems to be slowing, if only a bit. After two record-breaking months, during which investors poured $50.8 billion into stock funds, some fund managers say the flows have ebbed in March. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [D8.]
 
Consumer Confidence Is Steady
Consumer confidence was generally steady in March after a sharp rise in February, the Conference Board reported. One economist said: "We did not give back any of the bounce we saw in February. It suggests the economy is holding up fine." [D4.]
 
Chrysler Sues Class-Action Lawyers
Chrysler entered suits against lawyers in Seattle and St. Louis, saying they had filed frivolous class-action lawsuits. [A14.]
 
Change Stirs Cellular Industry
Cellular phone companies are coming off another year of soaring revenues, but changes are in the air, as shown by Sprint's success in Washington. In just three months, it lined up 60,000 customers for a new type of wireless services. Sprint offers free features, including caller ID and voice mail. [D2.]
 
Technology Stocks Improve
Stocks rose, helped by something of an improvement in technology issues and a surge in oil shares. The Dow Jones industrial average increased 26.74 points, to 5,670.60, led by I.B.M., which gained 2, and Exxon, which rose 2 3/8. [D8.]
 
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in thin trading as the Federal Reserve's policy committee met without changing interest rates. [D18.]
 
Hilton Expands Guest Plan
The Hilton Hotels' frequent-guest program allows travelers to exchange hotel points for airline miles and miles for points, and to transfer mileage from one airline program to another. And now it has become even more flexible, adding Trans World Airlines and Midwest Express to its roster of partners. Business Travel. [D5.]
 
Tobacco Lobby Fights New York City
The tobacco and restaurant lobbies are again active in Albany, pushing for a weaker statewide smoking law that would override New York City's strict limits on smoking in restaurants. [B6.]
 
John Hancock's New Pitch
John Hancock, after a decade of offering what was described as "real answers" for "real life," will now tackle a real challenge: persuading consumers to sign their own John Hancocks to fewer credit-card receipts and more investment contracts. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [D7.]
 
Wheat Futures Soar
Wheat futures soared amid concern that a five-month drought affecting winter wheat fields was unlikely to ease soon. [D15.]

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE HOMETOWN;
With Dole Rising, His Hometown Looks Ahead

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: RUSSELL, Kan., March 26

 BODY:
For Bob Dole, it is a point of pride that he has not used his influence in Washington to bring home the bacon.
"That speaks well for me," Senator Dole said yesterday as he flew here for a brief visit to his hometown, on the eve of a California primary victory that would give him the Republican Presidential nomination. "I don't deal in pork. I represent Kansas." 
 This town of 4,800 can attest to that. Aside from the farm subsidies that all such areas receive, Washington largesse is as nonexistent here as it is bountiful in, say, West Virginia, where just about every major highway and many Government buildings are named for the man often called the Senate's King of Pork, Robert C. Byrd.
Here, apart from the multitude of promotional signs for Mr. Dole's candidacy, and a landmark grain elevator that has his name painted on the side, the only official nod to him is a small, two-block lane that the City Council renamed Bob Dole Drive last year -- and not because he provided any money for it. It runs by the V.F.W. hall, which raised cash in cigar boxes a half-century ago for Mr. Dole's medical care when he returned wounded from World War II. Mr. Dole does not even maintain an office here.
But now, with Russell's favorite son the inevitable Republican nominee for President, many people here are hoping that his prominence, not to mention his election in November, will spark the economy in this 19th Century town whose population peaked at 6,700 in the mid-1950's.
Russell is already talking about a Dole Presidential library, a complex that could provide for Russell the kind of economic miracle that the Dwight D. Eisenhower library provided for Abilene, 110 miles to the east, one of the biggest tourist draws in the state.
A library might seem like an odd tribute to Mr. Dole, who frequently notes that he was never much of a student. Talking the other day about his best friend in childhood, Phil Ruppenthall, who died many years ago, Mr. Dole said, "I think he read every book in the Russell Library. And I watched him."
But a hometown library is now de rigueur for modern American Presidents, and people here, most of whom revere Mr. Dole and do not see how President Clinton could possibly beat him, are starting to count the benefits.
"There would be one more Presidential library in the state of Kansas, and tourism would jump," said Daron Woelk, who helps run his family's jewelry store on Main Street. Mr. Woelk, 31, is an exception to the rule in Russell, where most young people leave to find work. He said that of the 92 students who graduated with him from Russell High School in 1983, only a third still lived here.
The three biggest employers in Russell are the governmental: the school district (with 270 people), the county government and the county hospital. The biggest private employer, King of the Road, which makes recreational vehicles, employs about 119 people.
Eugene Davidson, a chiropractor and chairman of the local Republican Party, suggested that having a Presidential library might set off a chain reaction, not only bringing in tourists but also prompting other businesses to notice the quality of the labor force here.
"People will sit up and look at the example we have in Bob Dole," he said. "We have a good work ethic, and if we're paid a dollar, we'll earn that dollar."
Russell's biggest selling points are the same ones that Mr. Dole touts about himself in his Presidential campaign -- basic values of honesty and decency and self-reliance, said Russell Townsley, 76, the former publisher of The Russell Daily News and Russell Record. Still, it is hard to compete with states that boast of water and mountains.
But with a Presidential library, he suggested, Russell could compete with Abilene. A couple of years ago, Russell Stover, the candy maker, which has no relation to the town, relocated in Abiline after considering Russell.
Simply being the home of a leading Presidential candidate has started to pay off, with tourists already dropping in off the two major roadways that intersect here, Interstate 70 and U.S. 281, which is a main route between Canada and Mexico.
"The most popular site is his home," said Susan NeuPoth Cadoret, director of the Russell Area Chamber of Commerce. "But you can't go in," she added. "It is his private residence and is not open to the public."
This is the one-story red-brick home at 1035 North Maple Street. Still attached to the garage is the homemade systemof pulleys and four rusting window weights, that Mr. Dole used a half-century ago to regain his strength as he recovered from his war wounds. The tiny house where he was born in 1923 was torn down several years ago after he rejected a offer of $17,000 for it.
With visions of a Presidential library already dancing in the heads of local business owners, the town elders are talking about research trips to Abilene, to Independence, Mo., home of former President Harry Truman, and to Hope, Ark., home of President Clinton.
"In our minds we're looking at them, and they may start doing some physical visits," said Ms. Cadoret. "You prepare for it. How did they handle it? What points do you like, which ones don't you like as far as how they deal with tourists and public attractions?"
Everett Dumler, 76, the former manager of the chamber, said he was hoping for a library but did not want to jinx Mr. Dole's campaign by talking about it too early. "And," he added, "we haven't picked out a site yet because someone would buy up the land."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A grain elevator on the main street is one of the few structures bearing the name of Senator Bob Dole in Russell, Kan., his hometown. Since most here do not see how he can lose in November, they are already talking about the economic lift a Dole Presidential Library would give the area. (Charlie Riedel for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Fiscal Watchdog Bites Capital Master

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 26

 BODY:
He challenged residents to mow their lawns and clean their alleys, business leaders to create more jobs. He implored the District of Columbia Council to protect his summer jobs program, Congress to pass the District's 1996 appropriation bill.
In his first State of the City address since regaining office in 1994, Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. deliveredan impassioned plea on Monday night that the nation's capital be protected from financial, physical and spiritual ruin. 
 But today, the head of the city's financial control board said in an interview that there was one crucial figure who was not doing his part to help the city recover: Mr. Barry.
"I saw promises and the reiteration of promises, but I don't see a display of any means of achieving them," Andrew F. Brimmer, the economist appointed by President Clinton last year to lead the District into financial stability, said in an interview today, referring to newspaper accounts of Mr. Barry's speech, which Mr. Brimmer did not attend. "Even when the Mayor makes substantial commitments, I don't see any determination to stick with them."
The speech was Mr. Barry's most wide-ranging assessment of the city since its financial ills became apparent. He hammered away at two themes, calling for more public service by citizens and less "District bashing" by critics. He also strived to convince listeners that even with the city's appropriation stalled in Congress, many of the steps to return the city to sound financial footing, including the cutting of thousands of government jobs, were well under way at his direction.
"Let me report," he said, "that this government has not just been standing around, waiting for a financial ambulance or cash transfusion. We have worked every day to meet our challenges with whatever resources, skills, friends or ingenuity we could find."
He also took pride in pointing out that the District had reduced spending this year by a record $151 million.
But Mr. Brimmer, whose board has authority over all fiscal matters and who has frequently expressed such concerns, said he was not yet convinced that Mr. Barry was earnest in his efforts to reach a balanced budget by 1999, as required by the law that created the five-member board. Mr. Brimmer said he felt that Mr. Barry, whose political success has largely been built upon job creation, was using the board "as a foil" to preserve his base by passing blame for tough decisions, like cutting jobs.
"I'm not optimistic," Mr. Brimmer said. "Some of my colleagues are more optimistic than I am. They believe there has been a major sea change in the Mayor's behavior. I do not see that sea change."
Mr. Brimmer cited several recent examples of actions by Mr. Barry that leave him unconvinced. One involved Mr. Barry's veto of a measure passed by the City Council that would have forced the school system to cut 1,500 jobs. Mr. Barry had previously supported the cuts but changed his mind under pressure from teacher unions and the National Education Association.
"That is the latest illustration of the Mayor's ambivalence," Mr. Brimmer said. "The lack of commitment to achieve these goals, I find that very troublesome."
Mr. Brimmer also cited Mr. Barry's comments to students from the University of the District of Columbia who blocked a major street for 14 hours, protesting a perceived cut in the school's budget.
Anthony Williams, city's chief financial officer who was appointed by Mr. Barry but is answerable only to the control board, notified all city agencies that had overspent their budgets, including the university, that 10 percent of their current appropriation would be held up until he was certain they would not overspend again.
In addressing the students, Mr. Barry told them to blame Mr. Williams, not school officials, for any cuts.
"That disappointed me," Mr. Brimmer said.
Beyond those incidents, Mr. Brimmer cited a variety of other issues that he said worried him, including Mr. Barry's proposed budget for 1997 that estimates an increase in overspending by $102 million, after a $54 million increase this year. Adding the carry-over debt of $335 million from Mr. Barry's predecessor, Sharon Pratt Kelly, the new increase would leave the city with overall debt of $544 million by next year.
Mr. Brimmer said the city's indebtedness had grown to such an enormous problem that he almost daily encountered city contractors who plead with him to help them get their money.
"My voice mail at home is clogged with calls from contractors and vendors, telling me their difficulties with the city," he said, adding:.
"I can't accommodate any of them. I refer them to the chief financial officer. That's all I can do."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Andrew Brimmer, head of the fiscal control board for the District of Columbia, says he is not impressed by the Mayor's calls for change. (David Scull/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POLITICS: THE OVERVIEW;
California Voting Leaves Dole Claiming G.O.P. Nomination

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 26

 BODY:
Declaring that "we are now just one election away from restoring America's leadership," Senator Bob Dole today capped two dozen straight Republican primary victories with a triumph in California, the largest state of all, surveys of voters at the polls show.
"I am so confident that I am going to declare right now that I am the Republican nominee," Mr. Dole said flatly, repeating his now familiar ritual of a Tuesday night victory party in a Washington hotel ballroom. He proclaimed that he now had amassed enough delegates to propel him to the nomination. 
 With 24 percent of the vote tallied in California, the Kansas Senator had drawn 67 percent, crushing Patrick J. Buchanan by more than a 3-1 margin. Alan Keyes, a radio talk-show host, was well behind Mr. Buchanan. Mr. Dole also glided to resounding victories in primaries in Nevada and Washington. In Nevada, with all of the vote counted, the publisher Steve Forbes led Mr. Buchanan, 19 percent to 15 percent.
While Mr. Dole's victory was never in doubt, the apparently wide margins today reinforced the Senator's base in the state with by far the largest delegate prize, as well as the largest cache of electoral votes: 54. It is a state that White House officials say the President must carry to win re-election.
"The battle for the Republican nomination is over," Mr. Dole said. "And the battle for America's future is beginning tonight."
About 50 friends and family members were celebrating tonight in Mr. Dole's hometown of Russell, Kan. His daughter, Robin, addressed the group by speaker phone, saying, "I've never been so proud of my father."
By contrast, Mr. Buchanan looked downcast at a rally tonight in Costa Mesa, Calif., in Orange County. "We all have to concede a certain reality tonight," he said. "There is no doubt about it that Senator Dole is going to go over the top in terms of the delegate count." The crowd, about 250 people, started booing, but Mr. Buchanan continued: "He will be the Republican nominee, and we have to congratulate him on his victory."
But Mr. Buchanan repeated his pledge to press forward until the Republican National Convention in San Diego in August.
Mr. Dole's apparent victory led Haley Barbour, the Republican national chairman, to end months of neutrality and officially put the party apparatus behind the Senator. "As of today, the Republican National Committee will treat Senator Dole as our party's nominee," Mr. Barbour said in an interview. "We have up until now not taken sides because the nomination is determined by millions of Republican primary voters around the country."
The Dole campaign is nearly out of money, and the Republican Party plans to help the campaign endure the months before the party convention in August by paying for generic advertising and other costs.
Mr. Barbour also insisted that despite President Clinton's edge in polls here, the party would not abandon California in the fall, as did President George Bush's campaign four years ago. "The Bush campaign's decision to write off California was inexplicable and indefensible," he said. "The effect was that in 1992, we won fewer Congressional seats, fewer legislative seats and probably cost ourselves a United States Senate seat."
By prevailing in this winner-take-all state with 165 delegates -- "the big enchilada" -- Mr. Dole, the 72-year-old majority leader, was expected to move easily across the threshold of 996 needed for the nomination. Some news organizations had declared Mr. Dole the victor after last week's primaries in the Midwest.
But Mr. Dole waited until tonight to proclaim victory, in part because campaign officials wanted to generate whatever suspense they could in a primary process that has struck many Republicans as pointless since it became clear weeks ago that Mr. Dole would win.
Even though Mr. Dole celebrated tonight, he was preparing for trouble ahead. He made one last effort today to discourage Ross Perot not to stage a bid in November through his third-party organization, the Reform Party. "I would hope Ross Perot -- and I know him quite well -- understands that we are the reform party," Mr. Dole told reporters in Washington. "The Republican Party is the reform party."
The survey of voters leaving the polls today showed other worries for Mr. Dole. A third of the voters say they expect Mr. Dole to lose to Mr. Clinton in November. And most voters were not satisfied with the Republican field; more than half indicated that they would have liked to see someone else run.
In addition, many California Republicans are divided on controversial issues that could be important here in the general election. Almost three-fifths of the Republicans polled today favor doing away with affirmative-action programs entirely. Three in 10 would like to see those programs changed, and only one-eighth favor the idea of leaving affirmative action programs as they are now.
Republican voters in this state are also split on immigration. About half say that the United States should continue to welcome some immigrants. Four in 10 say the country cannot afford any new immigrants. Immigration ranked as a more important issue to Republicans in California than in other states. While almost 20 percent of Republicans here cited it as the issue that mattered most in their voting today, in many other states the issue was only cited by 4 or 5 percent of the voters.
Men and women in California have widely divergent views on the issue. Three-fifths of male voters endorse a policy of welcoming new immigrants, while more than half of the female voters say the country cannot afford new immigration.
Republican voters were also divided on trade. Almost half view foreign trade as beneficial to California. But nearly 4 in 10 consider it harmful.
As in other states, economic issues mattered most to the Republicans who voted today. The economy and jobs, taxes or the deficit were cited by more than half as the issue most affecting their vote. Half of the California voters say the standard of living for the average person will fall in the next 10 years, while almost as many say they expect it to rise.
Weighing in on Mr. Dole's quest for a running mate, more than half of the Republican voters say they would prefer Gen. Colin L. Powell, Gov. Pete Wilson of California or Dan Lungren, the state's Attorney General, but each drew the support of only one-sixth of the Republican voters. Republicans in the state are also split over whether the No. 2 spot on the ticket should go to a candidate who supports or opposes abortion.
The big news here this week was the Academy Awards, not the Presidential primary. Even Governor Wilson conceded that the voting today did not mean much. "I don't think it will have much bearing on what I expect to be a very hotly fought contest in California that will conclude with Bob Dole the victor," Mr. Wilson said in an interview.
The voting here marked the official end of a extraordinary year for Mr. Dole. A year ago, he viewed Senator Phil Gramm of Texas as his most formidable rival. But the road to the nomination has been far more complicated than that: Mr. Dole survived a possible bid by General Powell. Then he had to contend with Mr. Gramm, Mr. Buchanan and former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, only to be faced by the most unexpected contender of all, Mr. Forbes, who showered the airwaves in important states with attack commercials about Mr. Dole.
Yet the Senator managed to turn things around quickly. Beginning with the South Carolina primary on March 2 and going into today's voting, Mr. Dole won 21 primaries.
Before the polls closed today, Mr. Buchanan told reporters that if Mr. Dole were to offer him the Vice Presidential slot, he would consider it "to unite all the disparate forces."
Mr. Barbour said he would not call on Mr. Buchanan to withdraw. Asked if he had plans to press Mr. Buchanan privately, he said, "Not that I want to announce in a newspaper."
