LENGTH: 1543 words

HEADLINE: ON THE SET WITH/The 'Seinfeld' Steinbrenner;
The Head Yankee, Deconstructed

BYLINE: By IRA BERKOW 

DATELINE: STUDIO CITY, Calif.

 BODY:
YANKEES fans may not always find George Steinbrenner a bundle of laughs, but a hefty slice of America does. For the last two years, a character in the guise of the Yankees' principal owner has emerged as one of the funnier aspects of "Seinfeld," the hit sitcom.
While the real George Steinbrenner -- known as The Boss to his minions and to tabloid headline writers -- spends most of his time barking orders from various command posts around the country, the "Seinfeld" Steinbrenner can usually be found behind a big desk in his imperial office in Yankee Stadium. He always sits with his back to a camera on the set on Stage Nine in the CBS Studio Center lot here, and neither the face nor the profile of the Top Banana is ever seen by viewers. 
 There is only his broad back, a large, graying head and the occasional manic flinging of arms and hands, like a man drowning. His speech pattern is arresting -- a kind of tyrant staccato. As observed in a recent run-through for the show to be aired April 25, The Boss describes to an underling, George Costanza, his lunch routine.
Costanza: "So tomorrow, Mr. Steinbrenner, I was thinking how 'bout we try some corned beef."
Steinbrenner: "Corned beef? Ah, it's a little fatty don't you think?"
Costanza: "I love it. I could have it every day."
Steinbrenner: "No, we'll stick with the calzone."
Costanza: "It's just that a little variety might be nice."
Steinbrenner: "Nope. I find something I like, I stick with it. From 1973 to 1982 I ate the exact same lunch every day: turkey chili in a bowl made out of bread. Bread bowl, George. You'd eat the chili, then you'd eat the bowl. Nothing more satisfying than looking down after lunch and just seeing a table."
Who is this Steinbrenner? It may come as no surprise to baseball followers to learn that the "Seinfeld" version has a dual personality: two people must play him simultaneously.
Steinbrenner, the body, doesn't speak; he merely flails. Sitting a few feet behind him, in a slightly elevated director's chair and out of camera range, is the prattling voice itself, contained in the slender body of Larry David, the show's 47-year-old executive producer, co-creator, writer, onetime stand-up comic and passionate, lifelong Yankees fan.
"I grew up in Sheepshead Bay in Brooklyn, and I've always loved the Yankees," said David as he moved among the actors and camera crew on the set of the show recently. "It was a kid's fantasy that if you couldn't play center field for the Yankees -- and I was a huge Mickey Mantle fan -- well, maybe you could work for them in some capacity." And when the George Costanza character, who is based on David and played by Jason Alexander, needed a job after being unemployed for two years, David hit upon the Yankees. "It's a chaotic place and I thought George would fit in perfectly," he said.
So the comic possibilities were inherent there. But for David, so is the pain. "Being a Yankees fan with Steinbrenner as the owner is so frustrating," he said. "I was the kind of fan who even followed the minor leaguers in the system! I knew all the players coming up. But when Steinbrenner became the owner, they usually didn't come up. He traded them. Nobody would make it to the team.
"And then when he'd have good players like Rijo and Drabek and Buhner, he'd trade them! And the free agents he'd get -- the Dave LaPoint types -- were usually disasters. You just knew you could run the team better than he did."
Viewer response has been enthusiastic since Steinbrenner's first appearance on the show. The Yankees even report that George Costanza gets fan mail delivered to Yankee Stadium.
While the "Seinfeld" Steinbrenner may be impetuous, irascible and despotic, he can also be generous and warmhearted in his impetuous, irascible and despotic style.
The voice was inspired by Steinbrenner himself. "I don't know the man," David said, "but from seeing him interviewed on television and seeing his quotes in newspaper stories, I came up with this version of the way he speaks, the going on and on on subjects, and going from one topic to another almost without stopping for a breath."
Jerry Seinfeld, leaning against the couch in his apartment on the set, said: "Larry wanted to get an actor to say the lines on the show, but when I heard his interpretation, I said: 'This is great. It's funny. You read the lines.' And the guy who plays him now? Excellent. He has a very gifted back of the head. I guess all that is needed to play George Steinbrenner is the back half."
Seinfeld and David had called Steinbrenner to ask permission to use his name and the Yankees for their show. "At first he was confused," Seinfeld said. "He thought that the George character played by Jason was supposed to be him. I told him, no, that we'd had that character in the show for five years. But he gave us the permission, and I think it's a credit to him. A lot of people take themselves so seriously that they have refused to allow us to portray them on the show."
One of the show's writers, Jeff Schaffer, said that the Steinbrenner character is Every Boss. "He can fire you on a whim," he said. "And this one is the Renaissance man of mindless things."
Another writer, Alec Berg, said: "Actually, the less we know about Steinbrenner the better. We can do or say just about anything to caricature him."
What does Steinbrenner's body have to say for itself? And by the way, whose body is it?
When the head of Steinbrenner the Body turns around, the broad face of one Lee Baer, an actor, is revealed.
And where did he come from?
"From central casting," Baer said. Of course. Where else would you expect George Steinbrenner to come from?
"I got a call that they were looking for a Steinbrenner look-alike," Baer said. "I don't know anything about George Steinbrenner other than that he owned the Yankees. I don't follow baseball. I don't really follow sports. I like old cars."
Baer is a large man, 59, and there the relative similarity with The Boss ends.
He speaks with all the animation one expects from an undertaker, not the perfervid Steinbrenner. "I used to do a little stand-up comedy," he said. "Deadpan. Dry humor."
Actually, Baer is a relatively new Steinbrenner. Another extra had done it, and when he couldn't make it for a show, Baer was brought in.
"We liked his mannerisms, like the crazy way of pointing in the air," David said, giving a loony impersonation, "and decided to keep him."
But it is David who delivers such Steinbrenner lines as the one to George Costanza when he shows up after being presumed dead and finds out he didn't get the promotion he expected. "Well, once you were dead," Steinbrenner says, "we couldn't just sit on our hands. We had to move."
Or when Costanza tries to get his secretary a raise and tells Steinbrenner that she supports an entire family, including a sick mother, and that she can't afford to go out to lunch so she goes to a nearby school cafeteria and pretends to be a teacher. Steinbrenner commiserates. "You know," he says as he reaches for a ringing phone, "she'd be better off making a sandwich and bringing it in."
On a show last December, Steinbrenner said: "Sure, I like a cupcake every now and then, like everybody else. You know I like it when they have a little cream on the inside. It's a surprise. That's good. Plus the chocolate ones are good, too. Sometimes I just can't even make up my mind. A lot of times I'll mix the two together, make a vanilla fudge. . . ."
Speaking by telephone from his office in the Yankees' spring training complex in Tampa, Fla., the real George Michael Steinbrenner 3d said: "Sweets are one of my weaknesses -- I can't deny it. I like chocolate, I like doughnuts. My favorite doughnuts are the glazed from Krispy Kreme. I'm a freak for glazed doughnuts. And I like the jelly ones from Dunkin' Donuts, too. People around here know I like them, and when I make a talk or an appearance at some place, someone usually brings over a box of a dozen doughnuts for me."
Steinbrenner said he had seen only a couple of "Seinfeld" shows. "They're very good, very funny, very well written," he said. "It's amazing how popular the show is. And my grandchildren love it. My oldest is 9 years old, and he thinks being on that show is the greatest thing I've ever accomplished in my life. The writers are terrific. I'm impressed with the detail, even down to the names in the Yankees' parking lot. I was prepared not to like the show, but I came away laughing my head off."
"Hey, if you can't laugh at yourself, you're in bad shape," he continued. "We need more laughs today. I go to too many funerals and not enough birthday parties.
"And yes, I've come to be called The Boss. Nobody loves The Boss, especially a hard-nosed Boss. I am a tough boss, no question about it, but I don't demand anything from the people who work for me that I don't demand from myself. Maybe that comes across on the show, too.
"My favorite episode on the show? That was the funeral scene where I go to the home of a grieving family and the father sees me and he's hardly concerned that his son is no longer with us. He hollers at me, 'How could you trade Buhner?' "
Steinbrenner laughed. "It was sick," he said, "but hilarious."

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Capitalism's Future, Seismic If Not Apocalyptic

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT 

 BODY:

THE FUTURE OF CAPITALISM
How Today's Economic Forces Shape Tomorrow's World
By Lester C. Thurow
385 pages. William Morrow & Company. $25.
Be brave! Lester C. Thurow exhorts the reader at the end of his engrossing new book, "The Future of Capitalism: How Today's Economic Forces Shape Tomorrow's World." Imagine yourself Columbus on a voyage into the economic future, and sail with "similar persistence and willingness to attempt the unknown." 
 The trouble is, by this point Mr. Thurow has made you feel so sick about the future that you dare not even get out of bed, let alone set out to sea. The very ground is dangerous, he has argued, extending his geographical metaphor. Beneath the surface, five tectonic plates are relentlessly shifting, so that at any moment new conditions could arise to send us the way of dinosaurs.
The first of these crustal plates is "the end of Communism," with the attendant loss of a focusing threat to the non-Communist world, as well as the liberation of new sources of raw materials and an educated low-wage work force. Capitalism has no more rivals. The second plate Mr. Thurow calls "a technological shift to an era dominated by man-made brainpower industries," where geography and natural resources no longer matter so much and human skills are the "only source of long-run sustainable competitive advantage."
The third of Mr. Thurow's mighty plates he describes as "a demography never before seen," in which the world's population is growing in size, moving from poor countries to rich ones and getting older. This last shift has produced "a very large group of elderly, relatively affluent people, most of whom do not work, and who are dependent upon government social welfare payments for much of their income."
The fourth plate is "a global economy," meaning that countries have splintered, regional trading blocs have grown, the world's economies have become ever more interconnected and "a substantial disconnect" has arisen "between global business firms with a world view and national governments that focus on the welfare of 'their' voters." And the fifth plate is "an era where there is no dominant economic, political or military power," with a result that no country will be strong enough to coordinate economies or impose trading rules.
As if these subterranean forces weren't earth-shaking enough, what Mr. Thurow perceives as "remaking the economic surface of earth" is also imposing. A combination of a "skill-intensive shift in technology" and the tendency in a global economy of wages to equalize is producing greater unemployment in the leading industrial nations, driving down the real wages of nonsupervisory labor and giving rise to surging inequality.
Leaders in Europe and the United States are damagingly preoccupied with the "extinct volcano" of inflation, he insists. And a major fault line dominates global trade, "with Japanese trade surpluses on one side and American trade deficits on the other side."
This fissure is widened, he says, by the trade surpluses with America accumulated by the successful Pacific Rim countries (Hong Kong, Singapore, Taiwan and Korea), which they use to pay for their even bigger trade deficit with Japan. Mr. Thurow writes: "When conditions have existed for a long period of time and nothing has happened, humans, being human, begin to believe that it is possible to defy economic gravity forever. People begin to act as if the United States can run a trade deficit forever and the patterns of trade they now see can go on forever."
But they can't, he maintains. "At some point the United States will lose its ability to finance its trade deficit." And "when the end comes, the economic pain in Japan, the United States and the rest of the world will be extreme." For this country, a flight from the dollar will occur, and Americans will have to work much harder to achieve a dramatically lower standard of living.
Can all these hazards possibly be avoided? Mr. Thurow seems to doubt it. To do so would require change, something that human beings don't like to do unless they have to. Japan is too closed-minded, he writes. Europe is too fragmented. As for the United States: without the threat of Communism the country lacks the motivation to transcend itself, because the nature of pure capitalism is such that its short-term need to maximize consumption contravenes its long-term need to invest in research and development, in education and in other vital public projects.
Does Mr. Thurow offer any hope? He suggests that Americans develop "a builder's mentality" and compete with the Japanese and Europeans to develop "the best intercity high-speed rail network in the world," as well as "the most skilled and best-educated labor force." But such a suggestion seems a little feeble in the face of his blockbusting geological metaphors.
Those metaphors serve him well overall to make a highly abstract subject seem concrete and dramatic. But they eventually take on a counterproductive life of their own. At the end of his book he tries to cheer us up by comparing social change to "waves hitting rocky cliffs on the Maine coast." His point is that while the rocks of present conditions prevail in the short run, in the long run the waves of social change will pound the rocks into "bits of sand."
But he has just spent some 300 pages walking the reader over a terrifying continent. When you finally reach the coast, you are much too drained of hope to plunge into any waters of social change. You feel more like that pounded rock. As for sailing into the economic future with Columbus: no way. He's surely going to fall off the world.

HEADLINE: Sports of the Times;
Misery Has Company Among the Final Four

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

 BODY:
THERE is something wrong with a man who can't enjoy a free extended weekend in East Rutherford, N.J.
Yet Rick Pitino wants no distractions, Richard Williams prefers no questions and Jim Boeheim is accepting no congratulations. 
 I wish these guys would lighten up already. They are college basketball coaches, not Middle East statesmen trying to preserve a fragile peace accord. They have high-paying jobs and appear to be in no danger of being downsized. Life for them could be much worse. They could be spending this week in New York.
Actually, there ought to be some kind of humility amendment to N.C.A.A. bylaws, requiring every power-broker coach to dance in the National Invitation Tournament once every few years. Then they would not have to worry about the national sports media that will infest the Meadowlands this weekend.
Having spent last weekend at the Southeast Regional, I have to say that if I had a dollar for every time a coach sneered and told some poor schnook with a notepad that he knew nothing about basketball, I'd have a down payment on scalping tickets to Saturday's semifinals.
At the N.I.T. on Tuesday night, the coaches were in much better moods, genuinely grateful to be playing in half-empty, circus-smelling Madison Square Garden for a championship that would earn them a modicum of prestige and a negligible cash prize of roughly $150,000.
"How happy are we to be playing in the N.I.T.?" said Phil Martelli, the St. Joseph's coach whose team will play Nebraska for the title tonight. "We would've been willing to play outdoors."
That is in sharp contrast with three of the Final Four coaches, who would prefer that this year's championship be settled in secrecy.
Kentucky's Pitino, asked last weekend to name the one thing he would change about the tournament, didn't say that he thought the players should receive spending money from the millions of dollars in television revenue, or that the schools should be allowed to fly parents in to watch their children play. After careful consideration, he said there were too many reporters covering the games. Sorry. Wrong answer. Let's try social science for $80.
Mississippi State's Williams, meanwhile, was crabbing his way through the most triumphant weekend of his career. Why didn't we know more about him and his upstart team? What exactly did we mean that his shooting guard has an unconventional hitch in his jump shot? What did it say that the official Final Four caps had Mississippi printed on the back and not Mississippi St.?
Williams had a chip on the shoulder the size of a bowling ball, much like Syracuse's Boeheim, who believes all-Americans over the age of 12 sit around 365 nights a year picking apart his matchup zone.
If he thinks he has it so bad, he should call up Brian Mahoney and find out what the recently discharged St. John's coach will be doing next season. Or go to the Garden tonight and introduce himself to Jimmy Williams, a 48-year-old Nebraska assistant who has been waiting for a quarter of a century for a head coaching job.
Williams spent 15 years at the University of Minnesota, where he made various head coaches look good by reeling in gems such as Ray Williams, Mychal Thompson and Kevin McHale. He discovered Dave Winfield playing in college intramurals.
"It's still a goal of mine to be a head coach," he said. But he is an African-American and the historical percentages say his chances are not good.
At the University of Illinois last week, another popular black assistant and crack recruiter, Jimmy Collins, was passed over for Lou Henson's vacated position. The job went to Florida's Lon Kruger instead. Florida has hired 30-year-old Billy Donovan, a Pitino protege. Who would be surprised if Uncle Rick put in a call, the way he did to help John Calipari land at Massachusetts, Pitino's alma mater?
Sometimes the coaching fraternity reminds you of a closed union shop, its members as delusional with conceit as some of the players they churn out.
My friend Stanton of Westchester maintains there is only one way to stop this runaway inflation of coaching egos: ban game coaching. If basketball is part of the "student-athlete" curriculum, he asks, then why are they allowed to be coached in what amounts to their exams?
Remove the coaches from the sidelines, and that will stop the endless television posturing for endorsement riches. No one would know or care who they were.
Maybe that would make Jim Boeheim happy.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The much-maligned Syracuse coach, Jim Boeheim, is bringing the Orangemen back to the Final Four for the first time since 1987. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: U.S. Imposes Strict Controls on Chemical Exports to Colombia

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

 BODY:
In a strategy intended to cripple the manufacture of Colombian cocaine, the United States is imposing stringent new controls on chemicals exported to Colombia by American companies that could be used to refine the illegal drug.
The controls, which are to be announced in the Federal Register today, were instituted by the Drug Enforcement Administration, after it could not vouch for the disposition of 6,000 metric tons of solvents and related chemicals sold annually by American companies to Colombia. 
 The counternarcotics agency reported that American sales of such solvents had jumped 57 percent since 1990, prompting officials to suspect that some Colombian drug cartels had been using some, if not most, of the chemicals to extract cocaine's crystalline powder from raw coca leaves and paste, often in clandestine jungle laboratories.
The chemicals listed include M.E.K. (methyl ethyl ketone), acetone, toluene potassium permanganate and ethyl ether, which all have legitimate industrial uses but are also used in cocaine processing.
Starting today, an American company exporting the listed chemicals to Colombia must notify the Drug Enforcement Administration in writing at least 15 days in advance. Until now, the notification could be made as late as the date of shipment.
Potentially more important, the exporter must show that the chemicals will have a legitimate use in Colombia, a demonstration that involves identifying the company receiving the chemicals and its officers.
"I think this really will change the situation radically," said Gene R. Haislip, a deputy administrator of the drug agency who heads its office of diversion control in Washington. "This is about as strong a step as we can take here to make sure our chemicals don't get to the traffickers."
The new controls on chemical exports follow the exclusion of Colombia from an annual list of drug-producing or transit nations that are trying to stem the flow of narcotics. Preident Clinton issued the list on March 1.
Colombia's decertification disqualifies it from most American economic assistance.
Law-enforcement officials, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the new controls had been adopted because of fears that rampant corruption within the Colombian Government had tainted its National Directorate of Dangerous Drugs, which has licensed and controlled chemical imports. Its top officials trusted by Washington have been transferred or assigned to other duties, an American official said.
As a rule, it takes 12 kilos of solvents to process 1 kilo of cocaine. Under this formula, the 6,000 metric tons of American solvents imported by Colombia are sufficient to produce up to 500 metric tons of cocaine.
Mr. Haislip said that the Drug Enforcement Administration had briefed American companies about the new controls and that "we've had a pretty good response from them." Two of the largest companies, Pecten, a Shell subsidiary, and Exxon Chemical, had been very cooperative, he said.
"Although the new regulations involve additional work for our employees, we fully support the D.E.A.'s efforts," said Kitty Borah, a spokeswoman for Shell Oil Company and its subsidiaries.
Colombian drug cartels could seek suppliers in Europe and Latin America. But Mr. Haislip said European countries were cooperating to prevent the diversion of chemicals, and Brazil passed legislation a year ago controlling the shipment of solvents to Colombia.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Higher in Quiet Trading On Hope of a German Rate Cut

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar moved slightly higher in quiet trading yesterday on heightened expectations of an interest rate cut in Germany.
Remarks by a German monetary official yesterday bolstered other recent comments suggesting that the Bundesbank would consider cutting rates when it meets today. 
 "At least it made it closer to a 50-50 proposition," Dave Glowacki, a senior trader at the NBD Bank in Detroit, said of the officials' statements.
The prospect of lower rates often prompts selling of a currency because they reduce the value of investments denominated in that currency.
There were no firm trends in yen trading as many Japanese traders took a break from the market during the last few days of that country's fiscal year, which ends Sunday.
In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar rose to 1.4845 German marks from 1.4785 marks on Tuesday. The dollar was quoted at 106.55 Japanese yen, up from 106.47 yen.
Hans-Jurgen Krupp, the head of a regional central bank in Hamburg, was quoted in a magazine report yesterday as saying there were good reasons to cut rates in Germany.
Mr. Krupp said a report last week showing a surge in money supply should not bar a cut in rates
Hopes for lower rates had dimmed on the money supply report. With more money in the financial system, a rate cut would add to the supply and risk inflation. But inflation appears under control and other economic signs suggest there is room for the Bundesbank to stage at least one more rate cut, economists say.
The dollar also benefited slightly from weakness in the British pound, which fell as the European Union banned British beef exports worldwide Tuesday to contain "mad cow" disease.
The pound fell to $1.5200 from $1.5225.

HEADLINE: Orders in Transportation Fell Sharply Last Month

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27

 BODY:
The United States economy gained strength last month even though a midwinter lull in aircraft purchases caused factory orders to fall by the largest percentage in 10 months, the Commerce Department reported today.
While overall orders dropped 2.5 percent in February -- as demand for passenger jets weakened -- analysts pointed to a seven-tenths of 1 percent increase in orders excluding transportation equipment as a sign that a spring rebound for the economy was likely. 
 The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, sounded a similar note in renomination testimony before Congress today. "The current economic expansion seems to have exhibited staying power," he said to the House Budget Committee.
The Commerce Department's report showed that demand rose for industrial machinery and primary metals in February. And unfilled orders for durable goods, a gauge of pent-up demand, increased two-tenths of 1 percent, the sixth monthly increase.
The drop in aviation orders appeared to be short-lived, said Raymond Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J.
The Boeing Company, for example, said last week that it was increasing production of its 737, 757 and wide-body 747 commercial jets next year, expecting a surge in orders. "In recent months aircraft orders have been very strong," Mr. Stone said. "You took five steps forward and last month one step back."
In his testimony, the second of two days, Mr. Greenspan said that businesses had nearly finished whittling down their supplies of unsold goods. "Much, but perhaps not all, of the needed inventory correction already has been accomplished," he said.
Some analysts, though, said the economy was hardly out of the woods. Leonard Katz, who manages $300 million at the Fixed Income Management Group in Garden City, L.I., pointed to an increase in consumer-loan delinquencies and to continuing corporate job cuts, like one today in which the Northrop Grumman Corporation said it would eliminate 2,100 jobs by the end of the year.
"Everything points to a slow-growth economy," Mr. Katz said. "There is a possibility of recession."
Before the Commerce Department report, analysts had expected a three-tenths of 1 percent decline in durable-goods orders for February, according to a Bloomberg survey.
Economists caution against reading too much into any single monthly durable-goods report. Orders tend to be volatile from month to month because of the erratic pattern of orders for commercial jets and military hardware.
Not counting military hardware, orders decreased 1.3 percent last month, the largest loss since July 1995, the Commerce Department said.
Among major industries, transportation orders fell 11.6 percent in February, the biggest drop since last October; electrical-equipment orders fell 1.1 percent, and military capital-goods orders dropped 26.5 percent.
But orders for industrial equipment rose 2.8 percent; primary-metals orders were up five-tenths of 1 percent, and capital-goods orders excluding aircraft increased 3.7 percent.
Shipments of durable goods, a gauge of current demand, rose 1.3 percent, the third gain in four months.
The release of the report comes a day after a meeting of the Federal Reserve's policy committee, which chose not to lower interest rates after other recent economic indicators showed strength in housing and labor markets, including a big gain of jobs in February.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Show A Sharp Decline in Price

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply yesterday, after comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and a report on durable goods suggested that mounting econonic growth could stave off further cuts in interest rates.
"The market showed its true colors," said Doug Burtnick, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston. "People were waiting for an opportunity to sell, and they chose Wednesday to do it."
The price of the 30-year bond fell 1 8/32 yesterday, to 91 8/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 6.68 percent, from 6.57 percent on Tuesday. The yield is at its highest since March 19, when it was 6.71 percent. Bondholders lost about $12.50 for every $1,000 invested.
Bond prices were pressured early on after the Commerce Department reported that orders for durable goods -- products from washing machines to aircraft -- fell 2.5 percent, the largest drop since April 1995. While the main number would ordinarilly have encouraged the market, the report also showed that the drop was largely a result of sharp declines in aircraft and military orders -- categories noted for month-to- month volatility.
Bond prices managed to bounce back off their lows only to weaken again after Mr. Greenspan, speaking before the House Budget Committee, said that "the current economic expansion seems to have exhibited staying power." Mr. Greenspan also said that a period of slow real wage growth might be coming to an end.
Traders said Mr. Greenspan's comments poured cold water on hopes that Fed policy makers will lower short-term interest rates when they next meet, on May 21.
A slump in the Treasury futures market also pressured prices. In addition, hedge fund selling of some intermediate and long maturities added volatility to the day's decline.
"It was very much a futures-led market, with the cash market thin," said Louis Brein, a financial analyst at Finacor Vendome Inc., a brokerage firm in Chicago. "A lot of people tried to buy the market earlier, but gave up later in the day, and it appears that it snowballed at the close of futures trading."
As the market looks for further clues to the direction of the economy and of interest rates Mr. Brein noted that "a Fed that cuts rates at a time when the market is unsure of the level at which the economy is operating leads to uncertainty, which in turns lead to liquidation."
"Every time the Fed eases, it lifts the lift of a Pandora's box just a little more and tempts letting inflation slip out." Mr. Brein said. "Therefore, unless a rate cut simply reaffirms something about the economy that bond traders were already sure of, a rate cut risks a market selloff. It is better to anticipate a rate cut based on economic conditions than it is to actually get one."
The Treasury announced yesterday that it had postponed its sale of new one-year bills that was planned for today, saying that if Congresss passed a debt ceiling extension, the sale of the bills would probably take place next Tuesday. A two-year note auction that had been scheduled for Tuesday and five-year note sale scheduled for yesterday had already been postponed.

HEADLINE: Clinton Urges State Action on Education

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: PALISADES, N.Y., March 27

 BODY:
President Clinton urged the nation's governors today to enforce their push for rigorous classroom standards with state competency tests, saying there should be "no more social promotions, no more free passes" for students.
At an education conference of governors and business leaders, Mr. Clinton cited as a model his home state of Arkansas, where as governor he made education issues a priority. Under his stewardship, Arkansas began requiring students to pass a minimum performance test in eighth grade to be promoted into high school. 
 If a state enacts "meaningful standards that you have confidence in," Mr. Clinton said, "you shouldn't be afraid to find out" if the students are learning and performing up to the standard. "And you shouldn't be deterred by people saying this is cruel, this is unfair or whatever they say," the President added. "The worst thing you can do is send people all the way through school with a diploma they can't read."
Several hours after Mr. Clinton spoke the governors wound up their two-day meeting with corporate leaders and education experts by issuing a policy statement committing themselves to developing "internationally competitive academic standards" in their states and the tests to assess whether they were working.
The leaders of some of the nation's most powerful corporations also agreed to work to improve public education, to emphasize student scholastic records in their hiring and to consider academic standards when making decisions on business sites.
Some of the governors seemed less than delighted with the President's scene-stealing appearance at a conference at which many of them emphasized the local -- not Federal -- nature of education policy.
"President Clinton is a supporter of the status quo in public education," said Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania, a Republican. "He thinks things are fine, and all you need to do is test a few folks. He's coming to tell this group something we've been talking about not just for the past two days but for a couple of years. That's hardly revolutionary, hardly leadership, hardly ahead of the curve."
And Governor Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, another Republican, characterized the President's speech as simply a "good summation of what we've been discussing for the past day."
Mr. Clinton's speech here was another in a series of exhortations he has made at appearances in which he has tried to use the bully pulpit of the Presidency since the Republican sweep of Congress in 1994. He has spelled out his vision for the nation without proposing action that could be defeated by a hostile Congress.
The speeches have also allowed the President to move into the Republican arena of cultural issues and position himself as a social moderate in this election year. He has particularly focused on issues affecting children, calling for school uniforms, anti-drug efforts, a battle against teen-age smoking and curbs on violence in children's television. His strong stand today against unjustified promotions to higher grades was another part of that effort.
The "education summit" held in the cloistered confines of an International Business Machines conference center came seven years after President Bush summoned the nation's governors to Charlottesville, Va., for a similar meeting. There, officials outlined broad national goals for schools and set in motion federally financed efforts to create voluntary national guidelines in core subject areas.
At that time Mr. Clinton, then a governor who played a major role in the summit, praised its recommendations, saying, "This is the first time in the history of this country that we have ever thought enough of education and ever understood its significance to our economic future enough to commit ourselves to national performance goals."
But his comments today were an indication of how the political climate has changed, as he made only passing references to a Federal role in education. Mr. Clinton acknowledged that the effort to draw up national standards for schools had been, "I think it's fair to say, less than successful."
And he singled out history and English standards as efforts that "did not succeed." The recently released English standards have come under wide criticism as imprecise, and the national history standard was repudiated by the Senate last year by a vote of 99 to 1.
Mr. Clinton echoed the governors' contentions that setting standards in education should be up to the states. "I accept your premise," he said.
"We can only do better with tougher standards and better assessment, and you should set the standards."
The President cautioned that while states should establish their own standards and their own testing system "being promoted ought to mean more or less the same thing in Pasadena, Calif., that it does in Palisades, N.N."
Mr. Clinton also called for governors to put in place a system that "rewards and inspires and demands higher standards of teachers."
Mr. Clinton called for more "charter schools," under which educators and parents get charters to create and manage innovative public schools that only remain open if they do a good job. And sounding much like Rudolph W. Giuliani, the Republican Mayor of New York City, he said administrative costs in the nation's school systems should be cut. "If it is true that New York City spends $8,000 a student on education, but only $44 goes to books and other classroom materials that's a disgrace," he said. "That's wrong."

HEADLINE: California Homes Are Selling Again

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: PERRIS, Calif., March 27

 BODY:
Beth Combee could hardly contain her excitement. After worrying about their jobs during the recent recession, she and her husband just received unexpected promotions and took a step she said they had only dreamed of during the years of economic uncertainty: they bought a handsome $104,000 house in a new development here known as May Ranch, 60 miles east of Los Angeles, in Riverside County.
"It's going to be empty for a while," said Mrs. Combee, 25, a supervisor in a pharmaceutical plant, as she explained that they would be moving from a one-bedroom mobile home to a three-bedroom house but would not be buying a lot of furniture right away. "We were thinking about this for about four years, but we just weren't sure about our jobs or that we could finance it until now." 
 The Combees are harbingers of an important economic development in Southern California. The housing market plunged into deep distress when California's economy first stalled in 1990, and it has been the last major industry in the state to begin to recover.
But finally, economists say, housing sales and construction are showing signs of a solid rebound, one of the strongest pieces of evidence that California's incipient recovery is slowly turning into a sustained expansion -- particularly in Southern California.
Moreover, the signs indicate that California's growth is likely to exceed the national recovery over the next few years in critical areas like job and income gains.
"This year looks like the transition to real sustainable growth," said Tom K. Lieser, associate director of the economic-forecasting project at the University of California at Los Angeles. "Until now, housing had been a real enigma to us. But the problem was that the uncertainty had been high. Every segment of the public had some anxiety. That's why the new signs in the housing area are so important."
U.C.L.A. is projecting employment growth in California this year of 3 percent, compared with 1.3 percent nationwide, and 2.8 percent next year, higher than an expected national increase in jobs of 1.5 percent.
Jeffrey Meyers, head of a real estate consulting business in Orange County, south of Los Angeles, added: "Just 90 days into the year, you don't want to hold your breath, but this appears to be a strong recovery. Builders are telling us this is the strongest they've seen the market in six years, and some of the figures prove it."
Existing-home sales rose 24.7 percent in February from the year earlier, according to the California Association of Realtors. In Los Angeles County, the median sales price of a single-family home fell 4 percent from the year earlier, to $170,210. But in Orange County, it rose 5.3 percent, to $212,130.
"These are the best sales we've seen since 1988," said Roland Osgood, a senior executive of the Kaufman & Broad Home Corporation of Los Angeles, the developer of the May Ranch project, where the Combees had bought their home. "It's continuing. More jobs are being created in this area than we expected."
Kaufman & Broad's sales in what is known in this region as the Inland Empire -- Riverside and San Bernadino Counties -- are expected to rise to 11,000 units this year, from 8,800 last year. And Mr. Osgood said sales in Orange and Los Angeles Counties were expected to rise to about 9,000 homes this year, from 7,200 last year. Those homes are in the $180,000-to-$250,000 range.
Donna Cox, the senior sales agent at May Ranch, said the project had buyers for 22 of the 27 homes that had been put on the market since the opening on Feb. 3. She added that one of the more important shifts was that more of the customers, because they had better jobs, now qualified for mortgages. Two years ago, she said, nearly half the deals fell through at another Kaufman & Broad development where she worked because the customers could not get credit.
The improvement is evident, too, in northern Los Angeles County, as well, another area hard hit by the recession. Thomas L. Lee, chief executive of Newhall Land and Farming Company, one of the largest landowners and home builders in the Santa Clarita Valley, said his company's sales of new homes had risen 39 percent so far this year from 1995 and that prices were moving upward for the first time in six years.
"This has been a long recession -- I mean, we've been in this thing for a good five years," Mr. Lee said. "There have been a lot of people who postponed decisions. Now there's a lot of pent-up demand."
Housing sales and housing starts remain well below those in the peak years of the late 1980's, when booming economic growth was still built into the California dream. And the experts say that the current rebound, while strong, is unlikely to bring the housing industry back to those levels.
But the recovery is being built on a new California economy, one less dependent on manufacturing and more on service industries, like entertainment. And there is now significantly less inflation, which had given an artificial boost to housing.
"Before, inflation covered up a lot of mistakes," said Bruce Karatz, Kaufman & Broad's chairman. "The industry is now operating well without that inflation. We're a better company today than we were seven years ago."
Even sales of luxury homes are starting to show some life. Joe W. Stemmer, an independent builder in Palm Springs, said he had built 8 houses last year, and expects to increase that to 10 this year. Those are 3,000-square-foot homes that will cost $350,000 and more.
The sales are "not like it was before," he said, "but this is an improvement. "Things are moving."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The rich are getting richer, etc., and it's likely to remain that way.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
THE rich are getting richer, the poor, poorer and the middle class is barely hanging on. But not to worry: it's not nearly as bad as the numbers look.
That has long been the word from Republican conservatives, who view the current handwringing over inequality of income as a distraction from the issue of getting the economy into higher gear. That view is likely to be embraced in the Presidential campaign by Bob Dole, if only because he cannot afford to alienate the "growth is everything" wing of his party. But new research is making the rationale for neglecting inequality harder to sustain. 
 Lynn Karoly, an economist with the Rand Corporation, has found that the trend toward inequality appears to have accelerated in the 1990's, dashing hopes that the 1980's were an aberration. Moshe Buchinsky and Jennifer Hunt of Yale University tested the premise that the prospect of moving up the income ladder has offset widening disparities in earnings and found it wanting. For while mobility does soften the blow, the probability of changing economic class was actually lower in 1990 than in 1980.
Ms. Karoly, writing in the current issue of the Oxford Review of Economic Policy, slices and dices income trends between 1973 and 1993 in every imaginable way. As has been widely reported, average family income adjusted for inflation fell by 11 percent across the two decades. But since the average family size also fell, there was actually a modest gain in the average living standard.
At the same time, however, the gap between the top and bottom widened sharply. An American at the 10th percentile of the economic pecking order suffered a 21 percent decline in income, while an American in the 90th percentile enjoyed a 22 percent gain.
These numbers won't surprise the economically literate. What may shock, though, are the data for the last few years, which have only recently become available. Average (50th percentile) and poor (10th percentile) individuals both lost ground during the 1990 recession and never gained it back in the recovery. Again using the poverty line as the benchmark, the average American was 8 percent worse off in 1993 than in 1989 while the poor were 14 percent worse off.
Such snapshots of the income distribution offer no clear sense of who is poor and for how long. For example, "we don't worry about college students who are voluntarily poor," explains Rebecca Blank, an economist at Northwestern University.
What one really would like to know is the distribution of long-term incomes, which factor out the brief ups and downs as workers change jobs, recover from illness, raise children and so forth. And even that statistic would be an imperfect measure of economic welfare. Many Americans, it is safe to say, would trade a guarantee of a modest income for substantial opportunity to strike it rich through personal initiative.
That's where the research Mr. Buchinsky and Ms. Hunt, just published by the National Bureau of Economic Research in Cambridge, fits in. They extend the time horizon for measuring wage income from one year to four and found, as expected, that inequality is reduced by as much as 26 percent.
But the story does not end there. Real mobility might be defined as the prospects of changing economic class -- in this case, arbitrarily but plausibly represented by the chance of moving from one-fifth of the income distribution to another in any given year. And here, the two researchers offer little comfort to the champions of capitalism in the era of downsizing.
In 1980, they calculate, a high school graduate with six years of work experience had a 17 percent chance of jumping to another fifth of the wage distribution. An elementary school graduate with six years' experience had a 17 percent chance of changing economic class. In 1990 a high school graduate with six years' experience had just a 10 percent chance of moving, while a high school dropout's probability of changing class fell to just 11 percent.
Taken separately, the trends in inequality and mobility are distressing; together, they are kindling for social conflagration. Is there any hope that the labor market will reverse course on its own?
In the 1980's, notes Orley Ashenfelter, an economist at Princeton University, there was hope that the widening wage gap would spur college enrollment and reduce the wage premium paid to college graduates. But enrollment rates have been slow to respond, and other factors driving the wedge in the income distribution -- technology, international trade, formation of single-parent families -- march on.
"There's little doubt," said Gary Burtless, an economist at the Brookings Institution: "Permanent inequality is going up."

HEADLINE: New Custody Rules Complicate the Task of Judges

BYLINE: By JAN HOFFMAN 

 BODY:
To a divorced parent with custody of the children -- usually the mother -- moving to a new area often promised a fresh start with a new spouse, a new job, or with old friends and family. But to the parent with visitation rights, usually the father, such a move augured a kind of parenting death by deprivation. And it was up to the judge to decide: should she stay or should she go?
These relocation cases are among the most difficult Solomonic calls a judge has to make, said Lewis R. Friedman, a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan. "Whatever the judge decides is a disaster," he said. "There are no good results, and no one comes out ahead." 
 On Tuesday, the Court of Appeals, New York's highest court, made the judge's task in these cases even more difficult. The court struck down a narrowly defined test that placed a heavy burden on the relocating spouse to justify the move and instead told judges to reach whatever conclusion would best serve the interests of the children, not the parents. Simply put, the court told judges that from now on, they had to use common sense.
"This is more difficult, from a judge's point of view," said Justice Friedman, "The old rule was easy to follow; the new rule is, 'Do the best you can.' "
Judges who preside over domestic cases, whether in Family Court or State Supreme Court, have almost unlimited authority to shape the lives of a family in distress. That prospect unnerves lawyers and divorcing parents, particularly those who perceive themselves to be on the losing end. The earlier test for coming up with relocation decisions, developed in the 1980's, was an attempt both to acknowledge the importance of a noncustodial father's impact on his children's lives, and to clip a judge's power to make those decisions without direction.
Now, the court has essentially returned to judges an extraordinary amount of discretion by giving them a range of factors to consider in arriving at that amorphous phrase, "the best interests of the child." Such factors may include whether the parent requesting or opposing the move is doing so in good faith; the child's relationship with each parent; the potential for the parent without custody to maintain contact with the child after the move; the impact of the move on the child's relationship with extended family members on both sides, and the hostility between the parents.
"Children are not chattel," wrote Judge Vito J. Titone, "and custody and visitation decisions should be made with a view toward what best serves their interests, not what would reward or penalize a purportedly 'innocent' or 'blameworthy' parent."
The Court of Appeals said that it was returning such discretion to judges because the old rule created mechanical solutions that ignored the volatile details of individual cases.
Under the old rule -- among the most restrictive in the nation and a beacon of the fathers' rights movement -- a parent without custody had to demonstrate that the other parent's anticipated move would interfere meaningfully with visitation. If a judge agreed, then the move could only go forward if the parent demonstrated "exceptional circumstances."
New York appellate courts were stringent in their view of such explanations. The mother had to show that she was taking a job in a new area because of economic "necessity," not merely to better her condition. A remarriage alone did not suffice. And she couldn't just move to a new state hoping to meet a new man or find a new job.
And if she persisted with her desire to move, the courts said she certainly could do so, but she would have to give up custody of the children to their father.
The hurdle was so high that lawyers often advised clients to either forgo the move or to give up custody. One judge said that lawyers often used the threat of the guidelines as a club to broker new support agreements: the husband might offer not to contest the move in exchange for the wife accepting lower child support payments and alimony.
Not surprisingly, the new rule has prompted howls of anguish from fathers without custody like Andrew S. Kenward, 44, a White Plains accountant who tried to prevent his ex-wife from moving 130 miles away to Pittsfield, Mass., with their 9-year-old son. Mr. Kenward, whose case was one of two that were considered and rejected by the Court of Appeals, predicted that the new guidelines would be a boon to lawyers and mental health experts, and harmful to fathers and children.
"If a mother decides she wants to pick up and leave, that should be her problem," said Mr. Kenward, who added that until his former wife's move, he had 12 overnight visits each month with his son. "The court says that the children's rights are the most important thing to look at, but their reasoning is specious and false. They're really saying that women's rights should prevail over the best interests of the children and, it goes without saying, fathers."
But Kathleen Donelli, a White Plains lawyer who represented Mr. Kenward's ex-wife, Jacqueline Browner, said the decision should not be read as endorsing the traditional view of custody disputes that a mother should always triumph.
"More and more fathers are gaining custody of their children," Ms. Donelli said, pointing to a 1993 Court of Appeals decision that blocked a father with custody from moving to New Jersey with his new wife to ease their commute to their jobs. "Now there is less of a burden for a custodial parent to gain permission to relocate," she added.
Joan L. Ellenbogen, a Manhattan matrimonial lawyer, says that her advice to clients who want to relocate will change as a result of the ruling. "I'll tell them, 'You still have to have a damn good reason for moving, but it's worth going to court over it,' " she said.
Noting the opacity of the guidelines, she said that predicting outcomes for her clients would be very difficult. "It all depends on which judge you get," she added.
In fact lawyers and judges said yesterday that the ruling would be an invitation for many divorced parents who would have otherwise not tried to move to now request hearings. "And there may be judges who would have wanted to give permission to a move and felt constrained until now," said Myrna Felder, a Manhattan matrimonial lawyer.
Although some judges said they felt uneasy about the additional burden of decision making placed on them by the new rule, they emphasized that the philosophy embedded in the old rule remains. "I think parents still have to be cautioned to understand that a child's best interest is served by having the love and attention of both parents," said Justice Jacqueline W. Silbermann, a State Supreme Court justice who hears divorce cases in Manhattan.
And Judge Michael Gage, the administrative judge of the city's family courts, said that the decision is a return to the mainstream of thinking about children in family disputes. The best interests of the child inquiry, she noted, is the direction that New York judges must take in assessing challenges over adoption, custody and foster care.
"Once you have to make a best-interests finding, your ruling becomes very specific to the case," Judge Gage said. "In family law, that's the way it should be."

HEADLINE: Sports Agency Suggested to Handle Yankees

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
As the Yankees get ready to decide where to play when their Yankee Stadium lease expires in 2002, New York State is contemplating the creation of a sports authority that might give it an edge on its chief rival, the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority.
New York State's top economic official has suggested the establishment of such an authority to finance stadium renovations or the construction of a new ball park. 
 By April 9, a study paid for by the state, New York City and the Yankees is expected to determine which is the best site among four being considered: Yankee Stadium, Manhattan's West Side, and two other Bronx locations, Van Cortlandt Park and Pelham Bay Park.
Creating an authority to pay for the stadium through bond issues means that state and local governments do not have to finance the project directly. Often, an authority ceases to exist once financing is complete, unless it becomes the equivalent of a state agency, like the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, or New Jersey's sports authority, which runs Giants Stadium, the Continental Arena, the Meadowlands Race Track and the Atlantic City Convention Center.
How the state and city propose to finance a stadium is not the Yankees' primary interest, since the team is not putting up any money for construction.
The chief goal of George M. Steinbrenner 3d, the team's principal owner, is to increase revenues sharply wherever the team is based after the 2002 season.
"I don't know if it's an enormous economic advantage to create an authority," said Charles A. Gargano, the state's Commissioner for Economic Development. "Technically, it's still a state and city debt. But it identifies it as a political need and might get people more excited."
Howard J. Rubenstein, a spokesman for Mr. Steinbrenner, said, "We haven't evaluated the sports authority idea."
To reduce the amount the state and city would have to finance, Mr. Gargano is looking to raise money by the advance sale of luxury suites and club seats, personal seat licenses and the rights to name the stadium.
Former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo -- who proposed in 1993 that a West Side stadium be built over the Pennsylvania rail yards -- said that proposing a sports authority represented a positive step.
"Their intent is to do anything to make this happen," Mr. Cuomo said. "If you believe the Yankees should stay, it's a good sign."
Discussing the practicality of creating a sports authority, the former Governor added: "Theoretically and practically, the state can borrow the money. But politically, when you present your budget, you don't have to say, 'I borrowed $800 million for a stadium. The authority did.' It's off-budget."
He added that he believed the stadium study would identify the West Side location, south of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, as the best one. Community opposition is expected, but Mr. Cuomo said he expected that it could be overcome.
Three years ago, the cost of building a stadium on the West Side, along with an adjacent garage, was placed at $307 million, plus $223 million to erect concrete platforms over the Long Island Rail Road storage yards.
Mr. Gargano said the cost of renovating Yankee Stadium, and adding garages, highway ramps and a bridge across the Harlem River, would come to $745 million. But Mr. Steinbrenner has rejected 13 stadium renovation plans.
New Jersey's Sports and Exposition Authority is said to have a stadium plan in place for attracting the Yankees. But Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has said the state will await Mr. Steinbrenner's decision and not raid New York for the team. She has also said the state will not use taxpayer money to pay for a new stadium.

Treasury Prices Fall On Strengthening Economy
Treasury bond prices fell sharply on comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and a report on durable goods that both suggested that mounting economic growth could stave off further cuts in interest rates. Traders took the chance to sell, and the price of the 30-year bond dropped 1 8/32, to 91 8/32. Its yield rose to 6.68 percent, from 6.57 percent on Tuesday. [Page D20.]
Bond prices were pressured after the Commerce Department reported that orders for durable goods fell 2.5 percent, the largest drop since April 1995. [D2.]
 
Stocks also fell sharply following the slump in the bond market. But technology issues bucked the selloff. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 43.71 points, to 5,626.88. But the Nasdaq index rose 5.53 points, to 1,093.88. [D10.]
 
Japan Air Dispute Is Settled
The U.S. and Japan settled a dispute on air cargo service, erasing one dispute that threatened to mar next month's summit meeting between President Clinton and Japan's Prime Minister. [D6.]
 
California Sees Housing Rebound
California's housing market is showing signs of a solid rebound, providing one of the strongest pieces of evidence that the state's incipient recovery is turning into a sustained expansion, particularly in Southern California. [D5.]
 
Strong Profits at Morgan Stanley
Morgan Stanley Group said its first-quarter earnings rose sharply, well exceeding Wall Street's expectations. [D5.]
 
U.S. Investigating Moody's
The Justice Department is investigating the workings of the credit-rating industry that focuses on what some contend are anti-competitive practices by Moody's in its ratings of some debt securities. [D4.]
 
Ban on British Beef Exports
The European Commission imposed a ban on exports to any country of British beef and goods made of beef byproducts. [A1.]

TCI Loss Widens
Tele-Communications Inc. said its fourth-quarter loss widened to $79 million, reflecting higher operating expenses and a spinoff. [D8.]

Litton Offices Are Raided
Federal investigators raided the offices of Litton Industry looking for contract and pricing information. [D6.]
 
Bidding War by Inco
Inco's $3.35 billion bid for the Voisey's Bay mine in Labrador might be the beginning of a battle with Falconbridge. [D6.]
 
Drug Makers Under Scrutiny
The prices that drug companies charge community drugstores drew scrutiny from all three branches of government. [D5.]
 
Lower Prices for Tissues
Procter & Gamble is cutting the prices of its tissues, paper towels and bathroom tissue by at least 8 percent. [D6.]
 
Sony to Build Operating System
Sony plans to develop a software operating system, the software controlling computers, challenging American companies. [D6.]
 
A Health Risk From Chips?
Groups that investigate whether there is a link between chemicals used in chip-making and health problems of workers are looking into a case in East Fishkill, N.Y. [B1.]
 
PC Support, a Growing Field
The business of providing PC services, from maintenance to consulting, appears promising. Last year, the market for desktop computer services was $28 billion, and was forecast to grow 14 percent annually. But investors seem wary of some of the companies, giving them low price-to-earnings multiples. Market Place. [D10.]

Ciba, which makes the drug Ritalin to moderate hyperactivity in schoolchildren, has begun a campaign to curb its misuse. [A20.]

HEADLINE: Sensible Health Reform, for Now

 BODY:
The House is expected to vote today on two versions of health-care reform -- a sensible if limited Democratic bill and a harmful Republican version. The Democrats have also embraced a bipartisan bill now pending in the Senate that would make it easier for workers who lose their jobs to buy health coverage. That is of critical importance in this era of downsizing and job shifts. House Republicans have embraced these provisions but have added to their bill amendments that are not only bad health policy but could delay passage of any useful health-care reform this year.
The Senate bill, written by Nancy Kassebaum and Ted Kennedy, would require insurance companies to sell policies to workers who leave their jobs but have been continuously covered by their employers. The bill would also limit the length of time that insurers could refuse to cover an applicant's pre-existing medical problem and forbid insurers to drop chronically ill enrollees. 
 These modest measures, which were approved unanimously by the Senate Labor Committee, would give some peace of mind to workers who are dismissed or want to find better jobs. The bill is crafted so that enrollees will not be hit with steep premium hikes. Because most of its guarantees apply only to already insured workers, they would not encourage healthy individuals to drop coverage or subject insurers to waves of applications from chronically ill unemployed people.
House Republicans know that if they venture much beyond the Senate bill they will lose bipartisan support. Yet their bill would create tax-favored medical savings accounts, which would allow people who buy only catastrophic health policies to sequester funds to pay their ordinary medical bills. This is a bad idea that is almost certain to be rejected by the Senate. Medical savings accounts would appeal primarily to healthy people, because they would not need to tap most of the money in the tax-advantaged savings account. That would leave less healthy people to buy ordinary medical coverage at elevated prices.
The goal of health reform ought to be the opposite -- to standardize policies so that everyone buys the same basic package. That way health plans would be forced to compete by offering better treatment, rather than by tailoring coverage to attract only applicants unlikely to need treatment.
The House G.O.P. bill would provide unwarranted protection to doctors and hospitals from malpractice suits, depriving injured patients of full redress. It would also allow small employers to band together to buy coverage for their workers -- a good idea -- but would needlessly exempt these associations from state taxation. States that need to raise money to pay for care of the uninsured, for example, often resort to taxes on insurance premiums. If Congress puts more health plans out of reach of state tax authorities, it makes state reform of health care substantially harder.
The House G.O.P. bill would make it more difficult to find common ground with the Senate. If no bill passes, health care reform will get pushed off once again into the indefinite future. If the House Republicans are serious about protecting workers who lose or leave their jobs, they will vote for Kassebaum-Kennedy and nothing else.

HEADLINE: Justices Curb Federal Power To Subject States to Lawsuits

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 27

 BODY:
Escalating its profound and divisive debate over the relationship between the states and the Federal Government, the Supreme Court today bolstered state power by sharply curbing the authority of Congress to subject states to suits in Federal court.
The 5-to-4 ruling came in a case challenging the constitutionality of a 1988 law permitting Indian tribes to sue states in Federal court for failing to negotiate in good faith over the operation of gambling casinos on tribal land. In an opinion by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, the Court ruled today that this portion of the law, the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act, was an unconstitutional incursion on state sovereignty. 
 But the significance of today's decision extends far beyond the particular context of the case, raising questions about whether individuals can use the courts to force states to abide by a variety of Federal laws.
With respect to Indian gambling, the decision left unanswered many important questions, which the Justices may soon address in related cases awaiting Court action. But the paradoxical effect may be that even though an Indian tribe was nominally the loser in the case, it will now be easier for tribes to open casinos by getting authorization directly from the Interior Department rather than dealing with the states at all.
And at the broadest level, the decision made it stunningly clear that last term's ruling in United States v. Lopez that Congress lacked authority to ban possession of guns near schools was not an aberrant decision, as some thought then.
It is evident now that the Lopez decision was a signal that the current majority is in the process of revisiting some long-settled assumptions about the structure of the Federal Government and the constitutional allocation of authority between Washington and the states.
The lineup in the two cases was the same: Chief Justice Rehnquist wrote for the majority, joined by Justices Sandra Day O'Connor, Anthony M. Kennedy, Antonin Scalia, and Clarence Thomas, while dissenting votes were cast by Justices John Paul Stevens, David H. Souter, Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Stephen G. Breyer.
The subject of the case today was the 11th Amendment, which bars jurisdiction in the Federal courts to hear suits against a state by citizens of another state. An 1890 Supreme Court decision, Hans v. Louisiana, gave the amendment the broader interpretation of generally barring Federal court suits against states without their consent, whether by their own residents or residents of other states.
The significance of Hans v. Louisiana as a precedent had been watered down over the years, as the Court permitted suits against states in Federal court to enforce a variety of Federal laws, most recently, in a 1989 decision, the Federal Superfund environmental law. The Court today overruled that decision, Pennsylvania v. Union Gas, declaring that laws enacted by Congress in the exercise of its authority to regulate interstate commerce were not enforceable against states in Federal court.
Also overruled, by implication, was a series of recent decisions holding that the 11th Amendment required only that Congress make clear its intention to subject the states to suits in Federal court to enforce particular laws. If the Federal law was clear enough, these cases held, the states' 11th Amendment immunity would be abrogated. Chief Justice Rehnquist said today that although Congress had made its intention to subject the states to suit by Indian tribes "absolutely clear," the 11th Amendment barred the suits anyway.
The practical significance of the decision is far from clear. In a dissenting opinion, Justice Stevens cited Federal copyright, bankruptcy and antitrust laws as among those that would "have no remedy" for state violations, an assertion that Chief Justice Rehnquist disputed in his majority opinion.
The full scope of the ruling will have to be filled out in future cases. Some limits on the decision are clear. Suits may still be brought against states to enforce the right to equal protection guaranteed by the 14th Amendment, which Chief Justice Rehnquist noted was adopted "well after" the adoption of the 11th Amendment and which "operated to alter the pre-existing balance between state and Federal power."
Suits may also be brought by the Federal Government against states, and by individuals against state officials for injunctions to prohibit future illegal actions. The principal effect of the decision will be to limit suits to enforce rights granted by Congress within its authority under the Commerce Clause, which encompasses much of modern Federal regulation.
That was the area addressed in the Union Gas case in 1989, in which the Court held that a Federal court could order a state to pay environmental cleanup costs. In declaring today that the Union Gas precedent was overruled, Chief Justice Rehnquist said it was a "deeply fractured" ruling, unsupported by a majority opinion, that had "created confusion among the lower courts" and "deviated sharply from our established federalism jurisprudence.
Regardless of the immediate practical effects, the breadth of the debate was clear from the vigor of the language on both sides.
Justice Stevens and Justice Souter both filed dissenting opinions; Justice Souter's 92-page dissent (compared with 31 pages for the majority opinion) was also signed by Justices Ginsburg and Breyer.
Justice Stevens, disputing the Chief Justice's assertion that the Court was simply restoring a long-dominant view of federalism, called the decision a "sharp break with the past." He referred to "the shocking character of the majority's affront to a co-equal branch of our Government," meaning Congress, and said the decision was "profoundly misguided."
Justice Souter attacked the majority opinion on both broad theoretical grounds and specific legal analysis. He said the majority was endorsing and giving constitutional status to a notion of state sovereignty that was incompatible with the Federal Government that the Constitution had established.
He said the ratification of the Constitution "demonstrated that state governments were subject to a superior regime of law in a judicial system established, not by the state, but by the people through a specific delegation of their sovereign power to a national government that was paramount within its delegated sphere."
He added, "Given the framers' general concern with curbing abuses by state governments, it would be amazing if the scheme of delegated powers embodied in the Constitution had left the national government powerless to render the states judicially accountable for violations of Federal rights." Justice Souter said the Court was making the same mistake it made at "the nadir of its competence" early in this century, when it applied common-law concepts of property rights and contract to overrule Congressional economic regulation.
Chief Justice Rehnquist dismissed Justice Souter's opinion by saying it "disregards our case law in favor of a theory cobbled together from law review articles and its own version of historical events."
The decision, Seminole Tribe v. Florida, No. 94-12, upheld a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, in Atlanta. That court ruled in 1994 that the 11th Amendment barred a suit by the Seminole Tribe under the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act to force Florida to negotiate the terms of a tribal-state compact to open a casino on Seminole land.
The Indian gaming act set up a complex procedure under which a tribe, if frustrated by a state, can take its request to the Secretary of the Interior. Under the appeals court's analysis, that option remains now that tribes can no longer sue the states.
Gambling in reservation casinos is now a $4-billion a year business, with 200 tribes operating 126 casinos in 24 states. The decision today may enhance the prospects in Congress for an overall review of the situation.
Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, where the Atlantic City casinos are strongly opposed to gambling on Indian reservations, said today that Congress should hold hearings to assess the decision and "must enact comprehensive reform to redefine the playing field."
It is quite possible the Court has not yet said its final word on the Indian gaming act. The Justices will act soon on a challenge to the law brought by Oklahoma, which is attacking not only the lawsuit provision the Court struck down today but the ultimate authority of the Federal Government under the 10th Amendment to require unwilling states to accept tribal casinos. That further question was not before the Court today. The Court has not yet agreed to hear the Oklahoma case, Oklahoma v. Ponca Tribe, No. 94-1029, but today's majority may not be able to resist the opportunity. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: New Jobless Claims Surge, but Strike is Cited

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 28

 BODY:
The number of new claims for jobless benefits surged by 43,000 last week to the highest level in nearly four years, lifted by applications from workers affected by the General Motors Corporation strike, which has been settled.
The Labor Department said today that new applications for unemployment insurance totaled a seasonally adjusted 429,000, up from 386,000 in the week ended March 16 and the highest since July 25, 1992. 
 Many analysts had expected an increase of just 11,000.
A Labor Department spokeswoman attributed the increase in part to the 17-day strike at two G.M. brake-parts plants, but was unable to say to what extent. The 34,000 increase in the week ended March 16 was also attributed in part to the strike, which idled about 175,000 workers.
The four-week moving average of new weekly jobless claims increased by 17,750, to 382,500, the highest since Feb. 10, 1996.
