HEADLINE: On Stage, and Off

BYLINE: By Peter Marks 

 BODY:

Love, Valour, Deja Vu
The phone call immediately got Joe Mantello's attention. It was from an actor he knew who had attended a production of "Love! Valour! Compassion!," in Boca Raton, Fla. "I think you might want to look into seeing this," the actor said.
Mr. Mantello, who directed the Tony-winning production of "Love! Valour!" at the Walter Kerr Theater, hopped on a plane. Sitting in the audience at the Caldwell Theater Company in Boca Raton, he felt a sense of deja vu. "It was a 90 to 95 percent replication of the staging that we had done," he asserted. "If you squinted, you actually felt that you were in the Walter Kerr." 
 In the script, Mr. Mantello says, Terrence McNally provides the barest of stage directions. At Caldwell, he says, everything from the staging of the opening tableau to the deployment of props was identical to Mr. Mantello's. On Broadway, a doll house sat on a green mound onstage as the audience entered. At Caldwell, he noted in a four-page letter outlining similarities, "Doll house sits alone on green mound as audience enters."
Enter the lawyers. Ronald Shechtman, lawyer for the Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers, wrote to Michael Hall, Caldwell's artistic director (and director of the production, which runs through Sunday), demanding that Mr. Hall "cease and desist any further unauthorized use of Mr. Mantello's work" until an acknowledgment was made of the direction's origin and licensing arrangements negotiated.
William McCarthy, development director and lawyer for the 20-year-old nonprofit Caldwell, declined to address Mr. Mantello's claims, but added that Caldwell is "in discussions" with the directors' union. "We are optimistic we will be able to resolve this situation," he said.
A director's work is a gray area in copyright law. Lawyers familiar with intellectual property law say copyrighted work must be in some recorded form; dance notation, for example, is a method of copyrighting choreography. Barbara Hauptman, the union's executive director, says the union is becoming more aggressive. Recently, she said, Gerald Gutierrez won a settlement with a theater in Illinois involving his direction of "The Most Happy Fella" on Broadway.
 
 
 
So Much for the Heartland
 "State Fair," the Rodgers and Hammerstein musical about life at the Iowa State Fair, opened Wednesday to mixed-to-negative reviews. There was more bad news: the show's tour was a total financial failure.
In a March 13 letter to the tour's investors, the show's chief producers, Philip Langner and Robert Franz of the Theater Guild, reported that the six-month pre-Broadway tour lost its entire investment, $2.25 million. While the show made money in big cities like San Francisco and Los Angeles, they wrote, it lost money in all of the smaller cities it played.
 
 
 
Detective and King
 God for Harry, England and the Delacorte: Andre Braugher, who plays the dogged Det. Frank Pembleton on NBC's "Homicide: Life on the Street," has the title role in the New York Shakespeare Festival production of "Henry V" in Central Park, beginning June 18.
"Henry V" will be the 31st play in the Shakespeare marathon's cycle of 36 productions. Clarifying an earlier report on the final marathon plays, the festival says they will be "Antony and Cleopatra," "Timon of Athens," "Henry VIII" and the three parts of "Henry VI" made into two.
 
 
 
Whither 'Floyd Collins'?
 You stage a musical for six and a half weeks off Broadway. Industry people show up in droves. Nonesuch Records makes the cast album. Many reviews are encouraging. What happens next?
That is what Adam Guettel is trying to determine. Mr. Guettel, grandson of Richard Rodgers and composer of "Floyd Collins," which closed on Sunday at Playwrights Horizons, says he is talking to regional theaters about productions of the musical. (Steppenwolf is among them.)
"We weren't surprised that it didn't get moved," Mr. Guettel said, voicing the eternal Off Broadway hope. "But we were disappointed."
Playwrights Horizons also had hopes for it beyond its scheduled run. Tim Sanford, the artistic director, says the musical is about faith, and "the climate is a bit cynical around here."
Mr. Guettel says the Playwrights production convinced him that he should try writing a musical again. "It was kind of a graduate school for me," he said.
 
 
 
Sam Shepard Blitz
 Atlanta may have the Olympics this year, but New York has Sam Shepard. His "Buried Child" comes to Broadway next month; the Signature Theater Company is doing an entire season of his work this fall. Second Stage is the newest venue, presenting "The Tooth of Crime" in partnership with Signature in September.
The 1972 play, set in the world of rock music, will have a reworked script by Mr. Shepard and a new score, by T-Bone Burnett, to replace one Mr. Shepard wrote.
In other twists in the theater world:
*Chubby Checker, of all people, gyrates into the cast of "Grease!" on April 29, replacing Al Jarreau as the Teen Angel.
*The playwrights Lynn Nottage, Tom Donaghy, Christopher Kyle, Doug Wright and Wendy MacLeod are the second group of recipients of Steven Spielberg's $10,000 Amblin Playwriting Commissions, awarded by Playwrights Horizons.
*"Sabina," Willy Holtzman's well-received drama about Sabina Spielrein, a patient and later colleague of Carl Jung, has been extended at Primary Stages on West 45th Street. It is directed by Melia Bensussen, and runs until April 21.
 
 
 
Slam the Door, Serve the Cocoa
 For months, Jennifer Smith has been one of the unsung heroes of "Victor/Victoria." Night after night, hunched over so far her face is hidden, she plays gnarled Madame Roget, who serves Julie Andrews cocoa at Chez Lui, a Paris nightclub.
It's a performance of economy and ingenuity. And just as important, it always gets a laugh. "All I can see is the floor," Ms. Smith said. "I'm always afraid of spilling something on Julie."
Ms. Smith, who became an actress after training as a dancer at Texas Tech, has a second strong turn as a hotel chambermaid in the farcical door-slamming scene in the second act.
They are the kind of moments actors in smaller parts dream of, and Ms. Smith is grateful for them. But she is, she says, under no illusions about how much attention she can reasonably expect. "It is not, after all, called 'Victor and Friends,' " she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Unsung hero: Jennifer Smith, who appears in the Broadway musical "Victor/Victoria." (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Making of an Anti

BYLINE: By A.M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
"The dictatorship of the Communist Party is maintained by recourse to every form of violence."
Leon Trotsky wrote that in 1924, when he was a leader of the Soviet party. He knew; he was a commander of party terrorism before and during the revolution until he became its victim, causing few to weep. 
 In the Soviet Union, and everywhere else a Communist party came to power, violence was the bedrock of its power. Now the Chinese Communist party stays in power through the unceasing use of violence against its people -- torture, imprisonment and slave labor. Outside its borders, it used the ultimate violence of military invasion to occupy Tibet and for the half-century since to massacre its people and civilization.
But as Chinese missiles were dropping off Taiwan -- the violence of international terrorism -- U.S. China specialists were heard urging a policy that has never worked against any dictatorship, Communist, Fascist, theological or military: persuasion unsupported by political, economic or military sanction.
"Rather than stigmatizing and sanctioning China, the United States should assist those on the mainland who are working to change things" was one example. Michel Oksenberg, a prominent academic on Asia, wrote that in Newsweek and identified those people -- "many" Chinese leaders now in power.
Let's state clearly what is rarely said and often covered up. Attitudes about dealing with dictatorships do not spring full-born from the problem of the moment. They germinate -- from personal background, political leanings, motivation, experience, and above all from beliefs about what is good or evil.
That is true of scholars, officials, businessmen and commentators like myself. None are acting simply as reporters, trying to convey data and present cool analysis. We are advocates for our visions of morality.
We believe one set of attitudes toward dictatorships to be moral and another evil. We do not often say so, possibly for fear of being considered appeasement-soft or warmonger-hard. Americans who advocate persuasion without penalty can speak for their values themselves.
Mine come from the belief that all dictatorships are based on violence and therefore dangerous and despicable. By instinct and experience I am not a non-Communist but an anti.
For me, the question becomes how can we use our economic and political pressure to weaken dictatorships. The corollary is that even if we cannot drastically weaken them, it is a sin to enrich or empower them, synonyms really. I will not buy anything made in China.
No dictatorship was ever wheedled out of violence. The Soviet Union collapsed because of internal rot, economic isolation, increasing American military power preventing expansion of the empire, and dissidents heard abroad, with the help of America's Lane Kirklands.
President Clinton did well in the crisis China manufactured out of fear of democracy on Taiwan -- although Beijing pointedly has not renounced future missile use. But the overall Clinton policy remains to exact no price for the indecencies inflicted on Chinese and Tibetans, and instead to encourage American businesses and officials to push trade with China, including its armed forces. The policy has failed, except to strengthen the dictatorship.
Short of war the U.S. cannot destroy the dictatorship; the Chinese people will do that. But the President can take steps that at least would not shamefully bolster it. Among them:
* Tying tariffs to proven elimination of torture and military action, against the people of China, Tibet and Taiwan.
* Prohibiting export of any U.S. product or technology that would strengthen China's armed forces.
* Eliminating credit or guaranteed U.S. loans for such suicidal trade. (During World War II Americans said sardonically that U.S. scrap iron sold to Japan was dropped on Pearl Harbor; with China it's gone high-tech.)
* Invoking against China the severest penalties available by law for selling nuclear-weapon material to Pakistan or any country.
Similar steps -- plus constancy -- helped end the Soviet dictatorship. They can bring closer the end of its Chinese successor. That goal is in the best interests of the people screaming in the torture cells, of America's security and its morality.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS -- Advertising;
Americans over 50 but under 65 may finally be getting some attention from Madison Avenue.

BYLINE: By Jon Nordheimer 

 BODY:
AMERICANS between the ages of 50 and 64 may finally be getting something their considerable spending power previously couldn't buy: a little respect from Madison Avenue.
Caught in relative demographic obscurity between their more famous Depression-era parents and the ubiquitous baby boomers, this graying but active generation has been largely ignored by advertisers or else lumped with the geriatric set. And many of them are annoyed at getting such short shrift. 
 "Ads on television directed at people my age are only about incontinence or constipation," grumbled Dick Samartin, a 62-year old former Boston investment counselor who lives in suburban Harvard, Mass. "And I am offended that someone trying to sell me a car shows commercials with kids racing around accompanied by a rock 'n' roll sound track."
Lately, though, there are indications Madison Avenue is belatedly recognizing Americans born in the Depression and war years as a distinct economic target, deserving the same attention other age groups get. And while it hasn't come up with a clearly defined message for them quite yet, it is at least wrestling with the problem.
"If you aim a television program for a younger audience, you still reach people in their 50's who are attracted to prime time shows," said Arnie Semsky, executive vice president and worldwide media director for BBDO New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group. "But the reverse doesn't hold true. Younger audiences won't watch programs aimed at older people."
That may be changing, however, Mr. Semsky and other advertising executives said, as the oldest of the boomers turn 50 and ally themselves with their slightly older peers in demanding more sophisticated adult entertainment. Mr. Semsky cited the recent success of films that cut across generations like "Apollo 13," "Sense and Sensibility" and "Grumpy Old Men."
For advertisers, the most compelling attribute of late-middle-agers is probably their pocketbooks. The 24.4 million American adults between 50 and 59 have the highest average discretionary income -- $21,357 -- of any age group ranked by decade, according to the United States Census Bureau. That is 9 percent more than people in their 40's take home, 27 percent more than those in their 30's earn and almost twice the $11,885 average after-tax pay of the under-30 youth market that advertisers lust after so publicly.
And they aren't afraid to spend it. For a cross-country road trip this year, Mr. Samartin and his second wife, Elaine, a landscape designer in her mid-50's, said they would pay cash for a new Chrysler Town & Country mini-van with a sticker price of $23,000. They also recently paid cash for a personal computer and software used in running Mrs. Samartin's business accounts, and they like to lavish gifts on Mr. Samartin's six grandchildren from a previous marriage.
In another sign of 50-to-64-year-olds' growing influence, the American Association of Retired People, a formidable lobbying group with 20.7 million members, is pushing advertisers to make a bigger effort to cater to that group's values and tastes.
Steve Alexander, vice publisher of Modern Maturity, the association's magazine, believes advertisers are clinging to outmoded stereotypes of middle-aged people. "They take this market for granted and don't realize how individuals have changed because of the tremendous social changes that have occurred in the past 30 years," Mr. Alexander said.
Indeed, a recent study commissioned by Modern Maturity showed that people in their 50's experience a far greater range of "life events" -- divorce, remarriage, starting families, switching jobs, providing for aging parents or adult children and the like -- than their parents did or other current generations do.
"These changes have market implications," said Cary Silvers, Modern Maturity's research director. They point to unusual turbulence at a stage of life that many advertisers falsely assumed was settled and predictable, he said, and thus they create untapped marketing opportunities.
"Advertisers lump this age group in with people in their 70's, which is a very short-sighted mistake," Mr. Silvers added.
A lot of Americans in their 50's lead lives more akin to Generation X's fast pace than to the over-the-hill image so often attached to them. Jack Mulroy, a 58-year old bachelor in Chicago who just lost a sales job at AT&T, for example, is using his severance pay to start a new career as a pre-retirement counselor.
"Starting over at this age should be scary but I find it very liberating," Mr. Mulroy said in a telephone interview before heading for a daily workout at his health club. "I don't consider myself old. I feel like I'm 35 or, at most, 40."
Or take Ron and Barbara Stutzman of Cape Cod, Mass., both 59. Married for 40 years, they have taken in stride the disruptive "life events" that A.A.R.P. talks about. Mr. Stutzman lost his job as vice president of human resources at a Boston company before taking on a similar job at another concern. But that didn't stop the couple from spending money; they are currently building a four-bedroom, four-and-a-half-bath house in Falmouth, the first step toward their dream of operating a bed-and-breakfast and antique shop, Mrs. Stutzman said.
"We are very much in a consuming mode with a long list of purchases we have to make of furnishings, rugs and whatever it takes to have a high-quality place," she said with a laugh. She said Cape Cod was filling up with couples 45 or older -- some in a second marriage -- who were opening shops, starting new careers or living in semiretirement, all with the means to travel or pursue new interests.
And taking in a divorced daughter and her child until the daughter could find a job and her own apartment didn't overwhelm them, either. "It has taken a lot of juggling to hold things together," Mrs. Stutzman said. "But we feel we have the energy and zest for life to keep things going."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
German Rates Left Unchanged And Dollar Falls Against Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the German mark after the Bundesbank left German interest rates unchanged.
Many currency traders had been betting that the central bank would cut short-term interest rates at its policy committee meeting yesterday. Several Bundesbank officials in recent weeks suggested that the central bank might have to reason to cut rates to help revive the flagging German economy.
Indeed, as recently as Wednesday, a Bundesbank official was quoted as saying there was room to cut rates despite a report this month of a growing money supply. The day before, the president of the Bundesbank, Hans Tietmeyer, said much the same. But the Bundesbank took no action yesterday. 
 "I guess it's kind of surprising given the comments by Tietmeyer and his boys over the last week or two," said Kevin Lawrie, a currency vice president at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
Lower German interest rates would diminish the return on mark-based investments, reducing demand for the currency.
In trading in New York late yesterday, the dollar fell to 1.4739 German marks from 1.4845 marks on Wednesday. The dollar was quoted at 106.15 Japanese yen, down from 106.55 yen. The British pound rose to $1.5252 from $1.5200.
Analysts speculated that Bundesbank officials were waiting for proof of moderation in growth of the money supply measure known as M-3.
"It is important for them to see an actual decline in the M-3 numbers printed rather than being postulated for them to actually come along with a rate cut," said Hillel Waxman, chief foreign exchange dealer at the Bank Leumi Trust Company.
But Lisa Finstrom, senior currency analyst at Smith Barney Inc., said that in addition to the money supply, there were other warning signs of inflation that might be delaying action by the Bundesbank.
She noted that Germany's public union called for a wage increase of 4.5 percent yesterday.
"That's too high by Bundesbank standards," Ms. Finstrom said. "The central bank wants to be a bit cautious in here."
Foreign exchange markets watch both inflation and interest rate trends because they affect the value of investments in a country and demand for that nation's currency.
In other trading, the dollar fell to 1.1887 Swiss francs, from 1.1975 Swiss francs and to 5.0263 French francs, from 5.0630 francs.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Show Decline For a 2d Day

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday for a second consecutive session, as market participants grew more pessimistic about the chances that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates again soon.
Other concerns weighed on the increasingly bearish market. Traders were bracing for new supply on expectations that Congress would increase the ceiling on the nation's debt. After the market closed, Congress approved such an extension, which means the Treasury can again begin to borrow. 
 Market participants were also positioning themselves ahead of the employment report for March, which is to be released on April 6, and for end-of-quarter volatility as money managers do some window- dressing on their portfolios.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond settled down 16/32 , to 9024/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.72 percent, from 6.68 percent on Wednesday.
Activity was light in the futures and cash markets, exaggerating price movements.
Bond prices started the session by getting a little bounce after the weekly report on initial unemployment claims. The number of claims rose by 43,000, to 429,000, for the week that ended last Saturday. The number, which was inflated by a strike against two General Motors brake plants and the subsequent temporary shutdowns of other plants, matched analysts' expectations.
Signs of economic weakness are often bullish for the bond market, because they indicate that inflation, which erodes the value of bonds, is likely to remain in check.
Prices received little support yesterday from the release of the Conference Board's help-wanted index, which measures the amount of job advertising in newspapers. The index fell to 82 points in February from 85 in January, but remains at a relatively high level, pointing to continued strength in the employment market.
Carl Palash, chief economist at MCM Moneywatch in New York, a market research and analysis concern, said he expected the market to remain on the defensive through next week.
"Looking further ahead, I think the underlying modest growth of the economy will eventually show through in the economic numbers," he said, which will indicate "a modest growth that keeps inflation in check."
But it may take a month or more before the economic data, which have been affected by severe winter weather and the G.M. strike, show such conditions, he said.
At the close of the futures market, prices were near the lows of the day. The June Treasury bond futures contract, which had traded as high as 11113/32 , closed at 11023/32 , or just off its low for the day of 11012/32 .
Mike Zentz, director of capital markets research at Pegasus, a unit of Thomson Research, said: "In only two sessions, bonds have gone from extremely overbought conditions to nearly oversold.
"However, they are not quite there yet, and besides, this is in line with the main trend, and there's a chance that bonds could stay oversold for a day or two."

HEADLINE: Slapp-Happy Companies

BYLINE: By George W. Pring and Penelope Canan; George W. Pring, a law professor at the University of Denver, and Penelope Canan, a sociology professor there, are the authors of "Slapps: Getting Sued for Speaking Out."

DATELINE: DENVER

 BODY:
Corporate America complains that lawsuits are crippling productivity. Chrysler is seeking sanctions against lawyers who have filed unsuccessful class-action suits alleging that the company put faulty brakes in cars. A California referendum that would have capped fees for lawyers who represent injury victims was narrowly defeated on Tuesday. Under industry pressure, the Senate passed a tort reform bill limiting damages in lawsuits involving faulty products.
One might almost believe that corporations are constant victims of lawsuits. But they are actually doing much of the suing. 
 More and more often, the companies' targets are neighborhood groups, environmentalists, consumer watchdogs, good-government groups, homeowners' associations and individuals. Their sin? Exercising their First Amendment right "to petition the Government" by speaking out at public hearings or contacting their elected representatives about corporate or government misdeeds.
Lawyers and judges call such suits Slapps, for "strategic lawsuits against public participation." A nationwide study we recently completed for the National Science Foundation found that there were virtually no such suits before 1970, but since then tens of thousands of Americans have been sued and untold thousands have been silenced by threats.
A company filing a suit will usually allege defamation, business interference or conspiracy. But these accusations are just the window dressing necessary to get court attention.
The most frequent Slapps are filed by real estate developers against neighborhood groups and residents who oppose giving them building permits. For instance, SRW Associates of Woodbury, L.I., filed an $11 million suit against 9 community groups and 16 individuals who testified against a proposed development at a public hearing. (The suit was dismissed.)
Corporations sue customers for filing complaints with government consumer protection offices. Businesses sue women's rights groups, civil rights organizations and unions for pointing out discrimination and workplace violations. "Eco-Slapps" are a risk for environmental groups that take on polluting companies, toxic dumps, loggers and even zoos. The Sierra Club has faced 10 such suits.
Perhaps most troubling, government agencies and employees are suing critics. In West Contra Costa, Calif., the sewer district filed a $42 million suit against a resident, Alan LaPointe, and 490 unidentified John Does for opposing its plans to build an incinerator.
The good news is that Slapps are losers; most are dismissed. But a judge's decision is often not the issue. Legal costs can devastate individuals and volunteer groups. As one executive who filed a suit told us, "There should be a price for speaking out against us."
Recognizing that public participation is essential to a democracy, 10 states, including New York, have passed laws against Slapps. New York requires a plaintiff to prove that the defendant acted with malice and "reckless disregard for the truth." If a judge rules that a case was brought for purposes of intimidation, the plaintiff can be forced to pay damages and the defendant's legal costs. But only Congress can protect everyone's rights; it should take up a similar Federal bill quickly.
For now, some companies and their lawyers are getting a taste of their own medicine. The legal profession's newest growth industry is "Slapp-backs" -- countersuits filed by Slapp victims for abuse of the courts and violation of First Amendment rights.

HEADLINE: Albany Abandons Budget and Agrees on Stopgap Spending

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 28

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders today abandoned their effort to pass a state budget on time because of the budget impasse in Washington. They agreed instead to a stopgap spending measure that would freeze state spending at current levels for four weeks while also allowing a previously approved tax cut to take effect on Monday.
The move insures that the budget will be late for a 12th consecutive year, an ignoble tradition in Albany that has undermined confidence in New York's fiscal policies and driven its bond rating to among the lowest of any state. The state's fiscal year begins on Monday. 
 The measure endorsed today would pay the state's bills under the old spending levels until April 30. But that could worsen the state's finances because the second stage of a cut in state income taxes that the Legislature passed last year at Mr. Pataki's urging is to begin on Monday, costing the state $1.7 billion in the next fiscal year.
In the budget he introduced last December, the Governor had called for deep reductions in state spending on Medicaid, welfare and other programs to help pay for the tax cut. But those plans are now on hold.
At a meeting today, Mr. Pataki told Republican and Democratic leaders of the Legislature that they should quickly come to terms on a new spending plan. He said four weeks should be enough time to wrap up the process.
"The goal is to have us have an orderly month, to continue to observe what is happening in Washington, to not raise anybody's anxiety or fears about state government," Mr. Pataki said.
Mr. Pataki has said repeatedly that despite the state's fiscal problems, he would not consider repealing the tax cut. Both Joseph L. Bruno, majority leader of the Republican-controlled State Senate, and Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Democrat who heads the Assembly, have concurred.
The state budget is in disarray mostly because Mr. Pataki based his original plan on changes that he expected the Federal Government would make in its rules for Medicaid and welfare spending. But President Clinton and Congress remain at odds over how to revamp those programs, and without the expected changes an additional $2 billion gap opens.
Nearly two weeks ago, Mr. Pataki presented modifications to his spending plan, contending that he had found new revenues that would patch most of that $2 billion hole, even if the Federal Government took no action.
But many legislators and fiscal monitors expressed skepticism about whether the Governor had really come up with that money, and today's announcement suggested that Mr. Pataki and the Legislature want more time to figure out how to piece together the state budget if a Federal budget is not passed soon.
In recent weeks, Mr. Pataki had publicly clung to the hope that he and the Legislature could agree on a budget by Monday. As it became clearer in recent days that it would not happen, he began lobbying for a stopgap measure that would last only two weeks.
But legislative leaders sought six or eight weeks, and today the two sides compromised on four weeks.
The stopgap measure this year is longer than those that the Legislature routinely passed in previous years when it missed the budget deadline. Last year, before the budget was finally passed in June, the Legislature approved a series of one-week appropriations to keep the state running.
The move today drew criticism from fiscal monitors, who said New York's leaders had rarely shown fiscal discipline. They said they were concerned that because the tax cut would take effect on Monday without any corresponding cuts to pay for it, the budget would be thrown further out of balance.
"This makes an already grim situation grimmer," said Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a group that studies government finances. "You are phasing in a tax cut without doing anything on the expenditure side. It's a duck. It's the easy way out."
Robert Kurtter, a vice president at Moody's Investors Service, which rates government bonds, noted that many other states that were also grappling with the fallout from the Federal stalemate had not delayed their budgets.
Mr. Kurtter, whose firm has given New York the second-lowest rating of any state, after Louisiana, also questioned why Mr. Pataki and the Legislature wanted a postponement when it did not appear that action in Washington was imminent.
"Delaying the budget process to wait for something that doesn't seem to be close to being worked out seems to be waiting for nothing," he said. "It makes one wonder why New York has to go through a ritual that every other state doesn't have to do."

HEADLINE: Immigration Bill Advances in the Senate

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 28

 BODY:
The Senate Judiciary Committee today approved legislation that would slightly increase the number of foreign-born relatives who can be brought into the country by American citizens and legal residents in the next decade. Most of the relatives would be wives and minor children.
The committee, voting 13 to 4, also adopted provisions favored by business leaders to protect American workers from losing their jobs to temporary skilled foreigners. But backers of organized labor, including the Clinton Administration, said the safeguards were insufficient. 
 The bill could "put hundreds if not thousands of skilled U.S. workers' jobs at risk," Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich said. Democrats vowed to offer amendments to protect American workers when the full Senate takes up the bill in April.
The panel's action came on the day that the Immigration and Naturalization Service announced that the number of legal immigrants had fallen by more than 20 percent during the last two years.
According to the immigration service, 720,461 legal immigrants were admitted in the fiscal year ending last October, down from the 904,292 in the 1993 fiscal year. The 20 percent decline is the largest two-year drop in legal immigration since the 1930's and is part of an overall trend in immigration during the last four years.
Supporters of legal immigration are sure to use these statistics as fresh evidence that efforts to curb legal immigration -- mainly to appease large border states whose social services are being taxed by new immigrants -- are unnecessary. These advocates say the rush to crack down on illegal immigrants has unfairly included attacks on an American tradition of legal immigration that reunites families and serves as a wellspring of economic innovation.
The House last week overwhelmingly approved an immigration bill that would impose tough new restrictions on illegal immigrants, but dropped most provisions dealing with legal immigrants.
The Senate Judiciary Committee this month decided to address legal and illegal immigration in separate bills. The panel's illegal-immigration bill resembles the House provisions. Since the House has few remaining provisions governing legal immigrants, the Senate bill approved today will become the main legislative vehicle this year for changes in legal-immigration law. The full Senate is to consider both bills during the week of April 15.
A coalition of liberal Democrats and conservative Republicans, supported by religious organizations and pro-immigration groups, today reversed proposals in the original Senate bill that would have cut legal immigration by over 30 percent after five years. Family immigration makes up most of this category.
Instead, the panel adopted, by a vote of 11 to 4, a different family-visa approach offered by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Senator Spencer Abraham, Republican of Michigan. That approach allows citizens to sponsor their spouses, minor children and parents. It is expected to allow about 250,000 people to immigrate a year.
The original Senate bill, written by Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, would have limited eligible parents to those people 65 or older who had a majority of their children living in the United States and who had health coverage.
The current bill would also allocate 175,000 family visas a year for citizens and legal residents to bring in other relatives. The provision would reserve at least 75,000 of the these visas for children of citizens. The remaining 100,000 family visas would then go to, in priority, the spouses and minor children of legal residents, the children of citizens, the children of legal residents and the siblings of citizens.
Finally, the bill provides an additional 75,000 visas a year for 10 years to help reduce the backlog of 1.1 million spouses and minor children of legal residents and a backlog of 1.6 million siblings of citizens.
As a result, the bill approved today would allow for 500,000 family visas a year for 10 years, compared with 480,000 allowed now, a 4 percent increase. The original Senate bill would have eliminated the adult children and siblings categories.

HEADLINE: FINAL FOUR;
States Put Aside Their Rivalry And Try a Little Cooperation

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
New York and New Jersey may raid each other for businesses, squabble over Port Authority resources, litigate over proprietorship of the Statue of Liberty and feud over the peculiar residency of the Jets and the Giants, two carpetbagging "New York" teams who play in East Rutherford.
The two states may even be preparing their armaments for the coming Battle of the Hudson: Which will be the future home of the New York Yankees? 
 But all you need know about the temporary bond between the states hosting the Final Four in New Jersey is that the logo for the three-game hoop-de-doo at the Continental Arena features Miss Liberty, which the United States Supreme Court ruled belongs to New York even if it stands 8,000 feet closer to New Jersey. Bruce Springsteen could have been the logo's symbol of New Jersey, but he probably would have charged a hefty fee. Lady Liberty is in the public domain.
"The statue captures the area more than anything," said Robert Mulcahy, president of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority and a member of the Meadowlands Organizing Committee. "And she is closer to us."
New Jersey and the Continental (ne Brendan Byrne) Arena became Final Four host-worthy to the National Collegiate Athletic Association once Madison Square Garden's commitments made it unavailable. "To take five or six days out of inventory would be tough," said Paul Munick, the Garden's vice president of athletics and family entertainment. And at this time of year, the Garden also has the circus.
Meanwhile, the Continental Arena had proved itself by hosting N.C.A.A. regionals -- eight East regionals, to be exact.
Still, New Jersey had to augment its relatively slim lodging resources by linking with the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau to get coordinated access to the city's nexus of hotel rooms, venues, airports and transportation.
"The nature of our venue is so different from other Final Four venues in Seattle or Charlotte," said Mulcahy. "If you fly into Seattle, you have one airport and one central downtown. We have no city, no downtown, no 1,000-room hotels. We had to overcome that and went to the visitors' bureau for help."
The bureau assembled lodging totaling 23,000 room-nights -- impossible in New Jersey -- and located venues for events like the Fan Jam, which is being held at the New York Coliseum. Cooperation like this last occurred for the 1994 World Cup (held locally at Giants Stadium), but rarely does.
Steve Morello, president of the bureau, said: "There are times we have to cooperate to meet the customers' needs. At those times, it's necessary to overcome our natural competitive desires."
For most of a week, oodles of money will be spent by visitors on food, lodging and souvenirs, and plenty more will be exchanged for scalped tickets for what Mulcahy hyperbolically calls "American's greatest sports event."
But to stage the Final Four, the committee is spending a modest $1.5 million on transportation ($200,000), hospitality ($500,000, mainly for a reception for 5,000 at the New York Hilton), decorations ($300,000), volunteer training and management ($150,000) and arena operations ($350,000). That money is raised by renting 10 luxury suites for $150,000 apiece for six hours of sport.
"But we could have sold another 20," Mulcahy said.
Just as the arena's regular suite-holders know they cannot sit in their boxes during the Final Four (unless they are one of the 10 that paid the extra $150,000), so advertisers know their signs will be plastered over with the event's logo and the names of the 64 teams that started in the men's tournament on March 14.
"The N.C.A.A. wants a uniform look," Mulcahy said. Any chance that arena advertising will conflict with the N.C.A.A.'s sponsors is thus eliminated. The arena will also lose its sponsored identity for the event with an N.C.A.A.-leased floor, without the airline's name, now laid and ready for dribbling.
Mulcahy insisted there were few surprises over the past seven years. But of course, there was the disappointment of not having the 300- to 400-room Meadowlands hotel that the recession scotched. And there were the 160 banners placed along local highways that recently flew away in 100-mile-an-hour gusts.

HEADLINE: U.S. Business Cutting Plans For Spending

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 28

 BODY:
American businesses plan to spend only slightly more this year than in 1995 on new buildings and equipment, marking a sharp slowdown in an important sector of the economy, a survey released today by the Commerce Department said.
Overall economic growth has depended heavily in the last several years on capital spending by business, and economists said that today's figures were more evidence that growth this year would be anemic. 
 The Commerce Department's Investment Plans Survey estimated that businesses would spend about 1.5 percent more this year on capital goods, which are primarily buildings, machinery and other equipment. If the estimate proves correct, it would be the lowest growth recorded in capital spending since the recession in 1991, and it would be a steep falloff from last year's growth rate of 8.1 percent.
"We've had a boom in plant and equipment spending in the past several years," said Paul L. Kasriel, the chief domestic economist at the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. "That has added a lot of capacity to the economy at the same time that demand has slowed down. As a result, businesses do not believe they need to add a lot of capacity."
The overall numbers masked broad differences in spending plans among different types of businesses.
Manufacturers, which account for 30.6 percent of the planned spending, said they expected to spend 7.2 percent more on plant and equipment this year than last year, with the durable goods sector up 10 percent this year.
Economists said the figures appeared to reflect in part the continued strength of export growth for manufactured goods, particularly such capital goods as machinery being bought by foreign companies.
Retailers and wholesalers, however, plan a cutback in spending of 4 percent, in what economists said was a sign of weak consumer spending and overbuilding of stores.
Growth in capital investment has far outstripped growth in consumer spending since the economy started rebounding in 1992, and while today's figures were not a surprise to economists, they served as the latest confirmation that the nation's output this year would expand, according to various projections, by well under 2 percent.
"We don't see a recession," Mr. Kasriel said, "but clearly one of the main engines of growth is shifting into a lower gear."
Some economists said the lower rate of investment growth came not just from corporate decisions about capacity, but from their growing concern about their bottom lines.
"Capital spending plans usually turn weak when profits start to get squeezed," said Edward Yardeni, an economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell/C.J. Lawrence in New York. "Profits should be down 5 to 10 percent this year, so it's not surprising that companies are cutting back plans for purchasing new plants and equipment."
The Commerce Department survey found that companies plan to spend $603.4 billion for capital goods this year, up from $594.5 billion last year and $549.9 billion in 1994. The dollar figures are not adjusted for inflation, meaning that the small percentage increase in planned expenditures this year could actually translate into a smaller quantity of plant and equipment being acquired than last year. The survey got responses from more than 20,000 companies, which were questioned in November about their capital spending for last year and their plans for this year.
"Businesses will continue to invest, especially in equipment, to increase the efficiency of their operations," Mr. Kasriel said. "They feel they can handle without much problem the anticipated order growth, but it's still an extremely competitive business environment and they feel the need to produce that given amount of goods at a lower price."

HEADLINE: Stocks Are Little Changed, With Dow Gaining by 3.97

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Stocks were little changed yesterday in quiet trading.
Analysts attributed the trendless market to uncertainty as to whether economic growth would be damaged by higher interest rates. As it did on Wednesday, when stocks fell sharply, the stock market took its cues from bonds, which slumped for a second day. 
 "There was continuing weakness in the bond market," said Edwin D. Walczak, chief investment officer of Vontobel U.S.A. "Higher yields for bonds are an increasing hurdle for stocks."
The Dow Jones industrial average, which at one point during the session declined more than 35 points, closed up 3.97 points, to 5,630.85. Among the broader indicators, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks inched up 0.03 point, to 648.94, and the Nasdaq composite index increased 0.95 point, to 1,094.83.
Declining issues on the New York Stock Exchange outnumbered advancers, 1,272 to 1,053. A total of 368.3 million shares changed hands on the Big Board, compared with 403 million shares on Wednesday and the three-month daily average of 420 million shares.
Auto stocks -- like many other economically sensitive, or cyclical, issues -- generally turned upward. General Motors climbed 3/4, to 54, and Ford Motor added 5/8, to 34 1/4. But Chrysler eased 1/8, to 62 3/8.
Chemical stocks were higher on projections of a better-than-expected economy. Du Pont closed at 82 1/4, up 1; Eastman Chemical closed at 73, up 1 3/4, and Rohm & Haas, which was upgraded by Merrill Lynch, closed at 68 5/8, up 2.
Traders also rotated into aluminum issues. Alcoa, the biggest gainer in the Dow, increased 1 1/2, to 64 3/8, and Reynolds Metals advanced 7/8, to 59 3/4.
Insurance stocks sold off in sympathy with bonds, as they traditionally do. Chubb dropped 7/8, to 94 1/4; American International lost 1/4, to 95 1/8, and Reliastar gave up 1/2, to 45 3/8.
Interest-sensitive utility stocks followed the same pattern. Allegheny Power closed at 30 1/4, down 1/8; Duke Power closed at 50 1/2, down 3/8, and Brooklyn Union closed at 26 3/4, down 1/8. The Dow Jones utility average sank 1.47 points, to 215.27.
Banking issues were also lower. Wells Fargo fell 1 5/8, to 255 3/8; Mellon declined 1/2, to 56, and Republic New York dropped 1/4, to 58 1/2.
Sybase was off 2 1/2, to 22 1/4, on a negative report from Montgomery Securities. Asarco fell 1, to 34 1/4, after warning that first-quarter earnings would be hurt by a drop in copper prices. And Uromed plummeted 2 3/4, to 11, after stating that it did not expect imminent Food and Drug Administration approval of one of its devices.
On the other hand, Bay Networks was up for another day, jumping 1/4, to 30 1/4, on rumors that it may be acquired by AT&T. Segue Software, an initial public offering, is at 21 1/2. And Zoom Telephonics rose 1 1/8, to 16 1/2, following its withdrawal of an offering of almost 1.7 million new common shares.

HEADLINE: Minimum Pay Bill Falls Short in Senate

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 28

 BODY:
Republican desertions from Bob Dole's leadership today put a clear majority of the Senate behind increasing the minimum wage, but the House voted twice against considering the issue.
Eight Republican Senators voted with all 47 Democrats to support ending debate on the wage question, which President Clinton and Congressional Democrats have labeled a major issue for this session of Congress. But Senator Dole, the majority leader and the presumptive Republican Presidential nominee, and 44 other Republicans voted against them. So supporters of the increase -- from $4.25 an hour to $5.15 -- fell short of the 60 votes their motion needed for passage. 
 Even if they had won those votes, the complex parliamentary situation would not have enabled them to bring the issue to a vote any time soon. But the 55 votes made it clear that the issue would continue to haunt Mr. Dole.
"We'll be back offering this, week after week, until we get it passed," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader.
Not all of the eight Republicans who voted with the Democrats on the procedural issue would necessarily vote to raise the hourly minimum wage. Spokesmen for several of them pleaded ignorance about why their bosses had voted with the Democrats.
But four, Senators Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon, James M. Jeffords of Vermont and Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania, made it clear that their votes meant they supported an increase. With 47 Democrats on board, that means the Senate could pass an increase if the issue came to a vote.
Mr. D'Amato issued a statement saying: "Working men and women are having trouble making ends meet. Those who are taking on minimum-wage jobs, by and large, are doing so to get by. We can do better. My vote sends a signal that we recognize the difficult economic situation that some Americans are facing with the Clinton crunch economic policies. We should raise their pay, cut their taxes and help them find jobs."
A spokesman for Senator Rick Santorum, Republican of Pennsylvania, said that he did not know why Mr. Santorum voted to end debate but that the Senator was opposed to raising the minimum wage. A spokesman for Senator Olympia J. Snowe, Republican of Maine, said she believed that the issue should be voted on, but had not decided how to vote.
Spokesmen for the two other Republicans, William S. Cohen of Maine and William V. Roth Jr. of Delaware, said they could not locate the Senators or say what their votes meant.
In the House, Democrats struggled to overcome the fact that the minority has almost no ability to force an issue onto the floor if the majority wants it shelved. But Democrats tried twice today to put the minimum-wage question up for a vote, as an amendment to a bill raising the limit on the Federal debt.
They lost 232 to 180, and then 228 to 192. On the second vote, seven Republicans, either moderates or conservatives facing tough races for re-election, voted with the Democrats. Five conservative Democrats voted with the Republicans.
Representative Bill Goodling of Pennsylvania, chairman of the Committee on Economic and Educational Opportunities, opposed any consideration of the issue. He promised hearings to examine why wages seemed stagnant.
"We'll look at the overall picture," Mr. Goodling said. But he added, "We will not be rushed to do something that will stagnate the economy even more."
Representative David E. Bonior of Michigan, the deputy Democratic leader, complained that the minimum wage, adjusted for inflation, was now at a 40-year low. Mr. Bonoir also said a low wage interfered with welfare reform because "you can't move from welfare to work if you don't make work pay."
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader, said, "We're going to bring it back and back and back and back until we finally prevail."
The debate in the Senate was explicitly focused on Mr. Dole, though he stayed off the floor. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, the Massachusetts Democrat who has led the Senate effort to raise the minimum wage, quoted statements Mr. Dole had made in favor of past increases.
Then Mr. Kennedy broadened his fire to include Speaker Newt Gingrich, saying: "Speaker Gingrich and Senator Dole make a remarkable couple. It's like Bonnie and Clyde writing the Republican platform. Newt Gingrich wants to repeal the ban on assault weapons, and Bob Dole wants to block any increase in the minimum wage."
Senator Frank H. Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, said, "The attack is on my leader and I resent that."
Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma, insisted that raising the minimum wage would cause employers to dismiss workers. He called the Democratic effort "nothing but a political act of appeasement, or trying to make the leaders of organized labor happy."

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Chairman, Train Conductor And 'Regular Guy';
Blues-Playing Union Man Leads Party in Connecticut

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON 

DATELINE: HARTFORD

 BODY:
Chris DePino concedes that he may not be the most typical Republican state chairman Connecticut has had: an Italian-American, Roman Catholic city-dweller who proudly shows off his union card from his job as a Metro-North train conductor.
At the Capitol here, where he is a legislator from New Haven, Mr. DePino talks with relish about the people he has met on the train, from immigrants on their way to housekeeping jobs to vice presidents on their way to Wall Street. He takes out the 48-note chromatic harmonica that he always carries, that he mastered over years of swing time between trains, and says that as much as he loves what he's doing, if Toots Thielemans offered to take him on tour, he would walk out right now. 
 "I try not to lose my focus," said Mr. DePino, who performs with jazz and blues bands at a New Haven club on weekends. "There's life, and then there's politics. I try not to turn it around."
But as he prepares for his party's biggest annual fund-raiser -- the Bush Dinner in May, named for former Senator Prescott Bush, and in 1996 honoring one son, Prescott Bush Jr., with the help of a second, George Bush -- Mr. DePino vows that the Republican future in Connecticut depends on regular guys like him.
"My goal is to break the perception that we're all rich people," said the 43-year-old Mr. DePino, whose 24 years' punching tickets on Metro-North have yet to earn him enough seniority to claim a summer vacation. "We've got to have the ability to grow as a party, and there's a huge bloc of conservative and moderate Democrats we're going after."
"They don't have to change their party," he said. "They just have to vote Republican. And their fingers won't fall off."
Those votes are needed to give Republicans control of the State House of Representatives, whose Democratic majority has blocked efforts by Gov. John G. Rowland, the first Republican elected governor here since 1970, to remake government.
Mr. Rowland, whose political base is Waterbury, a city that swooned over the Kennedys in the 60's and voted for Ronald Reagan in the 80's, has courted the state's largest city, Bridgeport, with offers of economic aid and by supporting an unsuccessful effort to authorize a casino there.
Now, in choosing Mr. DePino as party chairman, Mr. Rowland has elevated an exemplar of both the urban voters he is seeking and the new Republican politicians needed to attract them. Mr. DePino, who took over in January, has twice won election to the Connecticut House from a city where Democrats outnumber Republicans 11 to 1.
But can Mr. DePino, the son of a union welder and union seamstress who also happened to be Republicans, duplicate himself among the working people his party has wooed ever since Richard Nixon appealed to the "silent majority" in 1968?
Riding the New Haven Line for more than two decades, he has learned to appreciate the "literally thousands of very decent, genuine people" he has met. He has taught English to Central American immigrants, and been taught Spanish by them; he has played his harmonica over the public-address system on the Friday rush-hour train for executives on their way home to Southport and for strippers on their way to work in Bridgeport.
"The train is my center of gravity," Mr. DePino said. "When I change gears and get on the railroad, I get a rest."
And to win election from Morris Cove and Fair Haven Heights, his district in New Haven, Mr. DePino benefited not only from his reputation as an alderman and from intense door-to-door campaigning, but also from deep ethnic, religious and personal ties in the neighborhood where he grew up.
While the party plans a minority-outreach office to register black and Hispanic voters, Mr. DePino said, the largest group of potential supporters are people just like himself, in neighborhoods just like his.
"Italian-Americans alone are 20 percent of the population," Mr. DePino said, "and as a state we have the largest proportion of Catholics, about 42 percent. I'm not speaking in terms of religion; I'm speaking about political philosophy. The point is that Roman Catholics as a group stand for something. Their moral values stand for something. And when I look at the Republican Party, it's clear to me that it stands for their values."
Unlike the Democrats, he said, Republicans welcome conservative Catholics, whether they support abortion rights or oppose abortion. "I'm a pro-choice Republican," he said, "but if you're a pro-life Catholic, I have a home for you."
Republicans favor school vouchers that would enable poor minority children in cities to attend better schools, he said, and if the better school is a parochial school, so be it. In supporting school choice, he speaks from experience; he is a graduate of a Catholic high school, and his children attend parochial school.
"Besides," he said, "my bishop asked me to vote for it."
Robert M. Ward, a Republican State Representative from North Branford, said Mr. DePino's background was unique for a party chairman but "not greatly different from the base of our party."
"There are plenty of blue-collar Republicans in Connecticut," he said, "It's just not what people see or focus on."
Mr. Rowland echoed that view, saying: "If you go into Bridgeport or Waterbury or New Haven, if you go into a predominantly black or Hispanic area, and you talk about the death penalty or replacing welfare with workfare, or local empowerment, you'll get a more rousing response than you would in Simsbury.
"The problem is that a lot of people think that the people in cities must be liberals, and they're not. They're the ones who are living with crime and living with social problems, and most of them want to see these types of changes."
Democrats and labor leaders praise Mr. DePino, but they say they doubt that his working-guy background is going to shape the party, when Mr. DePino himself says that his job as chairman is to rally support for Mr. Rowland and his agenda.
"Before you get to the politics, you have to look at the individual, and Chris is first-rate," said Representative Thomas D. Ritter of Hartford, the Democratic Speaker of the House. "When the Governor told me that Chris was going to be party chairman, he said, "That means he can't vote with you any more,' and I said, 'As long as he doesn't vote with me any less, I'm happy.' "
"I hope that he is successful in moderating his party," Mr. Ritter continued, "but I'm not sure he's going to do it."
John Olsen, president of the state A.F.L.-C.I.O., whose state-employee affiliates have been attacked by Mr. Rowland over raises won in arbitration, said, "I agree; Chris has been someone who has been sensitive to labor."
"But this is all an illusion," Mr. Olsen said. "He has a Governor who has an agenda, and his approach is not one of reaching out to working people. No. 1 on his agenda is taking care of the business community. He believes in trickle down."
Mr. DePino acknowledges that his main job as chairman is "to support the big picture, and the big picture is the Governor." And he is enjoying the job.
"When I'm on the stage," he said, "I'm not a politician, I'm not party chairman, I'm just a musician, I'm me, and that's best for me. But there are some perks to being state party chairman: I get to talk to the Governor whenever I want."

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Padres' Small Step South Reflects Game's Growing Interest in Mexico

BYLINE: By Claire Smith 

 BODY:
When the Republicans gather in San Diego this summer to crown Bob Dole as their presidential candidate, they will also have to debate their stance on illegal immigration, including Patrick Buchanan's call for the building of a wall along the Mexican border.
Yet even as they consider that issue, the hometown Padres will be on the road to Monterrey to play the Mets, the first-ever regular-season series played south of the border. 
 The Padres weren't ordered to leave the country, nor do they have to give up their field at Jack Murphy Stadium to the G.O.P. Rather, the National League team chose to play the three games Aug. 16-18 in Monterrey, where sellout crowds of close to 30,000 are expected.
"It's a way of becoming more of a team with Mexican connections, not just for Mexicans but for Mexican-Americans," said Larry Lucchino, the chief executive officer of the Padres. "It's just a broader marketing base."
Still, the Padres' one small step in this direction reflects a larger, bolder step for the sport. For baseball's view of Mexico is the antithesis of the seal-the-border, shut-them-out fervor sweeping some quarters in America.
But baseball is offering the Mets-Padres series as an hors d'oeuvre for the global-minded. It is also holding an audition for a Mexican metropolis to be a candidate for a major league expansion team. For Monterrey and Mexico City have superseded Charlotte, Orlando, Vancouver and even the once-hot northern Virginia area in the eyes of those who want to see baseball grow to 32 teams before the end of this century.
"Yes, we want to see how the fans respond to those games," said John Harrington of the Boston Red Sox, the chairman of the baseball owners' expansion committee, which has doled out new franchises to Miami, Denver, Phoenix and Tampa-St. Petersburg in this decade alone. "I'll be curious myself. I might even go down there.
"I would say that the country itself is one of the most viable situations for us, because of Monterrey or Mexico City. You look at the population down there and the interest in the game, that's what makes it so viable."
The very notion that baseball is thinking of its future in Mexico shows how much the sport has changed. As recently as 1992, it balked at allowing Japanese interests to buy majority interest in the struggling Seattle Mariners.
In a highly criticized isolationist move, baseball introduced bylaws that to this day limit majority ownership in clubs to Americans and Canadians, rules that eliminate not only overseas investors but the only other nation in North America -- Mexico.
Times and financial interests have apparently gone a long way in eroding those xenophobic inclinations. After all, Mexico is full of major markets still untouched by any major league sports as Americans know them. And it is ensconced in a Latin American rim rich with its own baseball history.
Mexico has been home to a professional summer league since 1955. The league, which ranks in caliber with Class AAA in the United States, is already an independent partner in baseball's National Association of minor leagues and has produced, among others, Fernando Valenzuela and Teddy Higuera.
Baseball officials began thinking about Mexico more seriously when they received informal overtures from brokers and wealthy Mexican interests during the scramble for expansion franchises last spring that was won by Phoenix and Tampa-St. Petersburg.
Now, major league owners are aware that Mexico's economy almost melted down in the 1990's and that the collapse of the peso helped spur a wave of immigrants coming into America. "The economic and governmental situations may be such a handicap over the next 10 years that we may not be able to get there at this time," Harrington said. "We will have to look at that as part of our due diligence."
Still, this is one of the precious few caution flags thrown in this discussion.
"If you went just by the demographics, Mexico is on its own list and everyone else is on the next list, if you're talking A and B lists," said Harrington. "If you didn't have to consider the economic troubles and the governmental situation and well, if Mexico City were in the United States, they would have had a major league team a long time ago."
In North America, only New York City (16.3 million) has a larger metropolitan-area population than Mexico City's 15.5 million. Monterrey, located just southwest of Brownsville and Laredo in Texas, has a much smaller area population of two million, but it holds the heart and soul of the nation's baseball pulse.
"The people love baseball, especially in Monterrey," said Colorado Rockies third baseman Vinny Castilla, a Mexican who plays winter ball in his homeland. "In Mexico City, people play a lot of soccer, but Monterrey I think is the best place to get a major league team because of that love of baseball."
Baseball officials need little convincing. The sport already is in partnership with Mexico in many ways, according to Timothy Brosnan, the chief operating officer of Major League Baseball International Inc., the sport's economic expeditionary force.
"We've had a longstanding television partner, Televisa, the national network, that has carried up to three major league games a week live, and all the jewels for as long as I can remember," said Brosnan. "It's a fertile market, almost untapped, but we're poised to tap it."
Said Harrington: "We have two new teams starting up in 1998 and we're three to four years away from serious consideration to do it, again, until we get our economic situations settled. But Mexico's in there. I wouldn't want to get their hopes too high, but they have a lot going for them down there."

HEADLINE: 1995 Was Good for Companies, And Great for a Lot of C.E.O.'s

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
A preliminary survey of the compensation of chief executives at a number of America's largest corporations indicates that executive pay may have risen last year at the fastest rate since the mid-1980's, when pay for performance became the guiding principle for rewarding corporate chiefs.
The median salary and cash bonus rose nearly 15 percent in 1995, to more than $2 million, for chief executives at 76 of the largest 150 companies in a survey conducted by an expert on executive pay. That compares with median pay increases for chief executives at large corporations of 11 percent or less since 1988. 
 Add the value of other compensation, mostly in the form of options to buy company stock at special prices, and the median increase in total compensation rose 31 percent last year, to nearly $5 million. Swelled by sharply rising stock prices, this estimated increase was nearly double the rise in 1994 and triple the one in 1993 for those among the 76 executives in their jobs that long.
The increases in executive pay come against a backdrop of stagnation in the earnings of most Americans. The pay of chief executives of publicly traded companies, who number in the thousands, has been rising at an average annual rate of nearly 9 percent since 1990, according to Graef Crystal, the compensation expert who conducted the survey. But the wages and salaries of the nation's workers have never risen by more than 4 percent a year over the same period, the Labor Department reports. Lately the rise has been under 3 percent a year.
While raises for chief executives have for years outpaced what most other people get, the early returns for 1995 are especially significant at a time when some chief executives have been criticized for being rewarded with hefty pay increases for decisions that result in the layoff of thousands of employees.
"Their incentive pay encourages anything that increases the value of the company's stock, and in some cases that means downsizing," said Stephen F. O'Byrne, senior vice president of Stern Steward & Company, a consulting firm.
But many chief executives argue they are being rewarded for making critical decisions that play a big role in determining whether their companies will sink or swim in a highly competitive world. Their large increases in compensation reflect, they say, the valuable executive skills that have made corporate America more successful in recent years, and have enriched their stockholders as well as themselves.
"Most of the escalation in C.E.O. pay reflects healthy increases in profits and shareholder gains," said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers. "That should be applauded."
All this only adds fuel to the growing debate over the pay of chief executives. This is especially evident when chief executives receive big raises in years when their companies' performance lags, a phenomenon widely evident last year among the 76 surveyed.
Moreover, the spread between the pay of the typical worker and chief executive -- a 30-to-1 ratio in the 1960's and more than 100 to 1 today -- creates "an incredibly privileged class of people," said Richard Freeman, a Harvard labor economist. "These executives are hard-working, driven guys, and if you give them $1 million instead of $10 million, they are still going to be very motivated."
Some experts argue that judging a chief executive's performance is an inexact science at best.
"No one has been able to measure the value of a chief executive," said Nancy Rose, a management expert at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, who has been trying to do exactly that. "There are so many factors that go into a big corporation's performance, other than what the C.E.O does. But if you tie his pay to the stock and stock prices go up, then he gets the credit."
Each year, starting in late winter, corporations whose stock is publicly traded are required to file with the Securities and Exchange Commission a "proxy statement" that details the pay of each company's top executives. By midsummer, thousands of these reports will be on record and the early returns offer a strong flavor of what is ahead. The 31 percent jump in compensation may taper down to a smaller increase once all the proxy statements are in, including those from companies that are not as large, compensation experts said. But the early returns still suggest that 1995 was a record year. Not since the 1980's, when incentive pay -- mainly stock options -- became the major form of rewarding chief executives, has so large an increase been reported for a group of chief executives. The norm has been under 20 percent.
The 76 examined by Mr. Crystal all come from the nation's 150 largest companies, as measured by the value of their outstanding stock.
A handful of the 76 reports bear out the view of corporate consultants that the directors of major corporations are increasingly insisting on C.E.O. pay packages that more or less match measures of a company's performance. At Johnson & Johnson, for example, Ralph S. Larsen, the chairman, received $3.2 million in compensation last year. That was a rise of 25.8 percent from 1994, or roughly in line with the 21.5 percent compound annual return to shareholders over the last three years of his tenure. Shareholder return is measured by combining the change in a stock's price with the value of the dividends.
But that was not the case for most of the packages. Instead, many chief executives have received compensation increases that exceeded what they delivered for shareholders. For example, Donald V. Fites, chairman of Caterpillar, received a total package last year of $4.07 million, up 53 percent from the year before. The payoff to shareholders was notably less, an annualized return of 31.4 percent over the last three years and 8.8 percent last year.
A Caterpillar spokeswoman, while declining to comment, pointed to passages in the proxy statement that said Mr. Fites had met sales and profit goals, and had successfully managed the company during a long strike by the United Automobile Workers, settled last December.
Many compensation experts argue that executives often receive pay increases that are more generous than justified by a company's performance. The reason, they say, is because directors are constantly trying to make sure that their C.E.O.'s are paid enough to attract the best talent to the job. And when word comes of a big pay package for some newly hired executive, pressure builds to raise the pay of other corporate chieftains.
"You get a C.E.O. brought into a corporation to do a tough job and a big package is offered to get him," said Paula Todd, a principal at Towers Perrin, a consulting firm. "And all the other chief executives look at the package and say to their directors, 'I'm a C.E.O. and I'm doing a good job and I should get that pay, too.' And pay almost goes up for that reason. Chief executives don't want to fall in the C.E.O. pay scale."
The survey of 76 large corporations found that three-quarters of the pay increases last year were not in line with company performance as measured by the return to shareholders, according to Mr. Crystal, who compiled the 1995 pay data from the latest proxy reports. This was especially evident when stock performance and pay were compared for the 47 executives in the group who had been in their jobs at least three years.
The average stock price of the companies surveyed rose by a total of 13 percent in 1993 and 1994, and then surged in 1995, so that the rise for the three-year period reached 36 percent. The median value of the stock options, in turn, rose by 50 percent from 1993 through 1994 -- far more than the stock price or shareholder return -- and then took off in 1995, rising a total of 125 percent for the three years.
"The executives should have gotten fewer stock options in 1995, but that did not happen," Mr. Crystal said. "They said their stock went up and they were the geniuses who made it go up and, ergo, they should get more options."
Of the 76 executives, only five received less than $1 million last year in salary and cash bonus. But because of changes in tax laws and accounting procedures, more and more of the compensation of executives has been shifted to incentive pay, chiefly the stock options that permit an executive to buy his company's stock several years later, paying only the price of the stock when the option was awarded. If a stock is valued at $50 a share on the day an option is issued and at $75 three years later, then the C.E.O.'s reward is $25, multiplied by the number of options.
Given that stock prices have been rising with few interruptions since the mid-1970's and that the number of options often runs into the thousands, this procedure has paid off handsomely. But there is a risk that stock prices might drop. In order to value the options in the year they are issued, a complex formula is used that takes into account the various possibilities, including the risk that a stock might fall to a point where the option becomes worthless.
When stock prices rise sharply, as they did last year, then the current value of new stock options also rises. "Even if you issue no more options in 1995 than you did in 1994, compensation jumps sharply, and that is what happened last year," said James Woodrum, a pay expert at Hewitt Associates, a consulting firm.
The Gillette Company, the razor and toiletries manufacturer, exemplifies many of the complexities associated with executive pay. The company paid Alfred M. Zeien, its chairman and chief executive, $7 million last year, a rise of nearly 94 percent from the previous year's compensation. The package included a grant of 350,000 stock options, up from 100,000 the year before. Moreover, Gillette's share price rose last year by 50 percent, to $52.13.
One goal of the big pay package was to keep Mr. Zeien, who is 66, from retiring, Patricia Klarfeld, a company spokeswoman, said. Another was to prevent him from being lured away to another corporation, given his success at Gillette. During his five-year tenure, Gillette's earnings per share rose by 18 percent a year, and the return to shareholders increased a total of 253 percent.
Mr. Zeien's base pay -- salary and cash bonuses -- rose 209 percent in that period, to $2.4 million last year from $785,000 in 1990. He also received nearly 700,000 in stock options, and those he could cash in today would bring him upward of $15 million.
"Mr. Zeien has been a very, very successful chairman and chief executive," Ms. Klarfeld said, "and the board wanted to compensate him for his great skill."
