HEADLINE: Dijon Journal;
To Arms! Rebuilt Organ May Have German Accent

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: DIJON, France

 BODY:
Burgundy, with its matchless wines and architectural monuments, is the last place you might expect the French to be on the defensive about their culture.
There is little argument from Germans, Americans or anyone else who visits Dijon or nearby towns with names like Gevray-Chambertin, Fixin and Nuits-St.-Georges about the wine. 
 But the French can be touchy and defensive when they see a threat to their cultural heritage, and prone to unease about Germany, which they fear might swallow them up economically in a more closely united Europe.
That fear surfaced in the unlikely setting of the newly restored Gothic Cathedral of St. Benignus, whose historic 250-year-old pipe organ was rededicated this month in a weekend of celebrations after eight years of work. It was built, albeit in the French style of the time, by a German -- Karl Josef Riepp of Bavaria, who stayed in Burgundy and eventually made more money in the wine trade. But of his instruments, he said, "If better ones can be found in Europe, then my name is Jack."
A century later, French organ builders like Aristide Cavaille-Coll could claim superiority over the Germans. But today, French builders are losing contracts even at home to competition from the Netherlands and Germany.
So it was in 1988, when city and state authorities decided to restore Riepp's instrument, built in the French Baroque style, and awarded the contract to a contemporary German builder from Bavaria, Gerhard Schmid, instead of to a French company.
Now, $1.8 million worth of public money later, passions have exploded over the result, with champions of the French musical tradition crying cultural betrayal and showing how fragile European unity can be, even half a century after World War II, once national pride is threatened.
"This is an organ that was classified as a national historical monument, and we had builders in France who were perfectly capable of restoring it," said Michel Chapuis, an organ virtuoso who specializes in French Baroque music but angrily called off plans to play at the rededication in protest at the way the project turned out.
"Mr. Schmid has not restored the Riepp organ at all," he said. "He has turned it into a modern Schmid instrument."
Maurice Clerc, the cathedral organist at the center of the storm, is incensed by the criticism. Mr. Chapuis, he pointed out, was the recording secretary of the state commission that oversaw the restoration project.
"What we're seeing is sour grapes by people who had plenty of time to pay close attention to what was going on but didn't, and now want to find somebody else to blame for being surprised at the result," he said.
On March 8, 2,000 people, many of them German-speakers drawn to Burgundy by the controversy, filled the church and enthusiastically applauded Mr. Clerc's two-hour dedication recital, an eclectic mix of works by French composers, Bach and Lizst.
Mr. Schmid, a bespectacled 71-year-old Bavarian, spent the previous night tuning many of the organ's 7,000 pipes and recovered before the dedication in a sleeping bag tucked up in the loft behind the towering organ case. Rubbing his eyes, he seemed baffled by all the fuss.
"I can't really respond to the criticism," he said. "The organ has just spoken for itself, and maybe after a while it will calm people down."
"Usually," he allowed, "behind the criticism there's a desire that some other organ builder should have gotten the job. I don't wish any of them any ill, but I'm glad the work is finished and I don't see any reason to redo any of it."
Mr. Chapuis thinks otherwise, particularly about the organ's trumpet, clarion and bombarde stops, which have a sonority in French Baroque instruments that he and some other French organists listening on that Friday night thought had been submerged by something more German-sounding in Mr. Schmid's renovation.
"He will have to do a few more months of work on them at his own expense," said Patrick Arnould, the regional curator of historical monuments.
The Professional Organ Builders Group, a French trade organization, warned that national honor was at stake.
"We consider that what has gone on in Dijon is an insult to French builders, to good craftsmanship and to our patrimony," the group said, criticizing the state authorities for letting Mr. Schmid overrun the initial contract by 45 percent and condemning him for lengthening many of Riepp's pipes with a different metal than the original's.
"The Riepp organ was altered considerably seven times after he finished it in 1745," Mr. Clerc retorted. "It was electrified 20 years ago, and we found fewer than 2,000 pipes dating from the 18th century when we dismantled the organ in 1988. We're at the end of the 20th century, and Gerhard Schmid has given us an organ that can play music from all periods, not just French Baroque music of the 18th century."
Mr. Chapuis recently dedicated a new organ modeled after a lost 18th-century instrument by the French Baroque builder Francois-Henri Clicquot, in the former royal chapel at Versailles.
"Bernard Cattiaux and Jean-Loup Boisseau, the builders who did that work, showed that it is possible to be faithful to 18th-century French ideals if you take the trouble to understand them," he said. "Mr. Schmid understood nothing."
Riepp, who had trouble getting his French Baroque-style organ accepted by the church authorities who commissioned it in the 1740's, might have sympathized. By the time he died in Dijon in 1775, he was as well known for the vintages he grew in Vosne-Romanee and Gevray-Chambertin as for the organs he built.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gerhard Schmid, a Bavarian, tunes the 250-year-old instrument he restored in Dijon, France. Some French organ experts are unhappy, with one charging he has turned the organ "into a modern Schmid instrument." (Agence France-Presse for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Texas Joins Other States In Suing Tobacco Industry

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
Texas yesterday became the seventh state and the largest yet to sue the tobacco industry, seeking an end to advertising the state says is aimed at children, as well as more than $4 billion in compensation for Medicaid spending on tobacco-related illnesses since 1980.
In a shift in tactics from the states that filed earlier, Texas sued in Federal rather than state court and is basing its claims in part on Federal racketeering, conspiracy and fraud statutes designed for use against organized crime syndicates. The suit also alleges that the defendants violated Federal and state antitrust laws and state public nuisance laws. 
 "The tobacco industry has violated the law for so long and in so many ways it has become standard operating procedure," said Dan Morales, the Texas Attorney General. "History will record the modern-day tobacco industry along side the worst of civilization's evil empires."
The defendants include Philip Morris Companies Inc., the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation, the Lorillard Tobacco Company and the Liggett Group Inc. Also named were the American Tobacco Company, which has been acquired by Brown & Williamson, B.A.T. Industries P.L.C., which is Brown & Williamson's British parent, and the United States Tobacco Company, the leading maker of snuff and chewing tobacco. The remaining defendants are the Tobacco Institute and the Council for Tobacco Research USA Inc., two industry-financed organizations, and Hill & Knowlton Inc., the industry's longtime public relations adviser.
"The Attorney General's legal theories have no support under state or federal law," said Philip Morris, the industry leader, in a written statement issued at its New York headquarters. "Every industry in Texas is now on notice that it may be the target of a politically motivated lawsuit."
Brown & Williamson, which is based in Louisville, Ky., accused Mr. Morales of trying to "retroactively change the rules" governing the sale of a legal product.
The decision to file the suit in the Federal court in Texarkana, Tex., reflects tactical considerations as well as the use of the Federal statute. Judge David Folsom, the only judge in the court, is relatively new and has a lighter caseload than state judges do. Texas hopes that will lead to faster pretrial preparations and a trial within 18 months.
Lawyers familiar with tobacco litigation say the effort to invoke the Federal Racketeer-Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, or RICO, faces an uphill battle. A Federal judge in San Diego threw out a suit based on the act and filed against the industry in 1994 on behalf of addicted smokers, ruling that their personal injuries were not covered by the statute. Texas will argue that its claim for economic losses can be distinguished from that case.
"Beyond that, there's more evidence emerging," said Laurence Tribe, a Harvard University professor working with Texas on its case. "With every added whistle-blower coming forward, there's more evidence of conspiracy to prevent the development of safe products."
Tobacco companies deny that they have squelched product safety research or shared information on product development. They also deny the state's charge that their advertising is directed at children.
Investors shook off their tendency of recent weeks to drive tobacco stocks lower with each potentially negative piece of news. Philip Morris shares actually rose $.75 to close at $88.375.
Texas's suit adds a twist to the political cross-currents in the tobacco wars, in which Democrats have been leading the attacks and Republicans repeatedly taking stands as defenders of the industry. At both the state and national level, Democrats have been accusing the Republicans of being influenced by the tobacco companies' hefty campaign contributions
In Texas though, Gov. George W. Bush, a Republican, has described the strategy of suing the industry as "interesting" and the decision whether to do so as one for his Democratic Attorney General. That is a stark contrast to Mississippi, where a fellow Republican, Gov. Kirk Fordice, has gone to court to challenge the authority of Michael Moore, a Democratic Attorney General, to pursue a similar suit. Moreover, Bob Bullock, a Democrat who is Texas's Lieutenant Governor, has said he is an addicted smoker who wants to be a witness against the companies.
"This issue is breaking through," said Representative Martin T. Meehan, Democrat of Massachusetts, an outspoken advocate of tougher regulation and criminal prosecution of the tobacco companies. "There is going to be enough political pressure to hold these companies culpable to reach both parties."
Besides Texas and Mississippi, the states suing the industry are Florida, Louisiana, Massachusetts, Minnesota and West Virginia. A half-dozen other states are considering similar actions, lawyers involved in the litigation say. In every case, the suits are being managed by private lawyers working on a contingency-fee basis, thus minimizing the upfront costs to the states.
Texas has not yet decided whether to join a proposed settlement that Florida, Massachusetts, Mississippi and West Virginia reached early this month with Liggett, the smallest of the cigarette makers.

HEADLINE: A Safer Way to Dredge New York Harbor

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I agree that we need secure containment sites for the contaminated dredge spoils that need to be dredged out of New York Harbor (editorial, March 24). But "deep holes capped by tons of clean sand" are not always secure containment sites.
Twenty thousand signers have joined me in opposing that approach. A better approach, urged by prominent environmental scientists, would be to use sand-capped pits in Newark Bay that would not contaminate the marine life in Lower Bay borrow pits off Staten and Coney Islands that is critical to waterfront businesses and commercial and retail fish operations. 
 Our coalition supports the restoration of shipping activity in New York City and the reopening of the Brooklyn port. In the 1960's, container shipping activity was shifted to New Jersey, costing New York thousands of jobs.
Given new technology, the harbor dredging and disposal operation could be performed without risking our health, the marine environment, coastal integrity, our recreational pursuits and other economic interests.
 
DANIEL L. FELDMAN
Albany, March 27, 1996
 
Chmn., Assembly Subcommittee
on Waterfront Development

HEADLINE: Product Liability Bill

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Contrary to your March 21 editorial and recent news articles, under the product liability bill since passed by the Senate and the House, people who are injured by defective products would still be able to collect damages for their economic losses ("lost wages, medical expenses and damaged property") and for non-economic injuries like "pain and suffering," loss of consortium and emotional distress. 
 The bill limits punitive damages only to the greater of two times all damages (economic and non-economic) or $250,000 for each claim filed. If a judge determines that the amount of the punitive damage is not adequate to punish the defendant, he or she can award more punitive damages up to what the jury awarded. The only exception to that punitive damages rule would be a case in which the defendant is a person whose net worth is less than $500,000 or a small business or organization with fewer than 25 employees. In these cases, punitive damages cannot exceed $250,000 in a single award.
 
(Senator) JOE LIEBERMAN
(Senator) JAY ROCKEFELLER
Washington, March 29, 1996

HEADLINE: FILM FESTIVAL REVIEW;
Noble and Self-Sacrificing, A Long-Distance Mother

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
If one were being facetious, Josephine Perera, the subject of Nilita Vachani's documentary film "When Mother Comes Home for Christmas," could be described as a Sri Lankan answer to Mildred Pierce. A widowed mother of three, who selflessly dedicates herself to making a better life for her ungrateful brood, Josephine is one of thousands of Sri Lankan women who have left their country to earn high salaries (by Sri Lankan standards) as domestics elsewhere.
The money they send home is so vital to the tottering economy that the Government gives instruction in modern housekeeping. The film visits a class in which aspiring domestics are taught everything from microwave cookery to the use of condoms. 
 The film begins in Athens, where Josephine works for an affluent Greek family with two young children. Almost every cent of the $500 a month Josephine earns is sent home. As the movie shows, her salary goes a long way in Sri Lanka. Josephine has bought a touring bus for her eldest son and has kept her youngest son in boarding school. Although she regularly writes letters to her grown-up daughter, they are not answered.
"When Mother Comes Home for Christmas" follows Josephine as she makes her first visit home in eight years and discovers to her chagrin that no amount of long-distance love and material help can assuage her children's bitterness. Her lonely, isolated daughter is rushing into a hasty marriage that will have no financial footing except what Josephine can provide. Her youngest son has been caught stealing and is earning poor grades at an austere boarding school that he hates. Although her bus-driver son seems to be making a go of it, it will be years before his vehicle will be paid off.
In the movie, which is being shown at the Museum of Modern of Art tomorrow and Monday at 6 P.M. as part of the New Directors/New Films series, Josephine emerges as a noble, self-sacrificing woman who hasn't lost her zest for life, although at moments she breaks into tears and wonders how long she can continue to be a workhorse. Adding to the pathos are her memories of a wretched marriage to an abusive husband.
"When Mother Comes Home for Christmas" presents an intriguing portrait of Sri Lankan society, but it is one of the cruder films in the New Directors series. Messily structured, with several unnecessary tangents and a voice narration than can be confusing, it offers a jumble of vignettes that never quite jell.
 
WHEN MOTHER COMES HOME FOR CHRISTMAS
 
Directed, produced and edited by Nilita Vachani; written in English and Sinhalese, with English subtitles; director of photography, Vangelis Kalambakas; music by Ross Daly. At the Roy and Niuta Titus Theater, Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, Manhattan, as part of the New Directors/New Films series of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art. Running time: 109 minutes. This film is not rated.

HEADLINE: In Cuba, A Musician As Outsider And Idol

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: HAVANA, March 29

 BODY:
Carlos Varela is one of Cuba's most popular singers and songwriters, yet it is almost impossible to find his records on sale in stores here. Many radio stations simply refuse to play his music, and he hardly ever appears on television. But when he walks down the street, Cubans of all ages stop him to talk about the meaning of his songs.
Paradox, in fact, seems to be the concept that best defines the career of this 32-year-old guitarist and bandleader. More by circumstance than choice, Mr. Varela has become a figure both idolized and marginalized in Cuba. He has also found that the Cuban exile establishment, which normally embraces everything that is frowned upon here, also regards him with suspicion. 
 These are not easy times for Cuban musicians and artists who are seeking an independent path. Just as Mr. Varela's latest record, "Como los Peces," on the Ariola label, was being released in the United States last year, the Ministry of Culture here was moving to shut down the private recording studio and management company of Pablo Milanes, one of Mr. Varela's mentors and probably the country's most prominent singer and songwriter.
"What is important for me is to be able to think, to read, to write, to create, to compose," Mr. Varela, a slight, bearded figure who is as energetic offstage as on, said in an interview here. "All I want to do is write songs that reflect how my generation of Cubans lives: our dreams, likes and dislikes and what it means to be living in Cuba at this moment."
Mr. Varela's first brush with notoriety came after he wrote "William Tell," a retelling of the Swiss legend that finds the son battling to take the place of his father the archer and resenting the older man's stubborn unwillingness to step aside. The ballad became an anthem for young Cubans chafing under the ideological rigidity imposed by a socialist state.
" 'William Tell' was a song that I wrote practically in 10 minutes," Mr. Varela said. He introduced it in 1989, just as the Soviet bloc was collapsing and doubts about Cuba's future were increasing. "There was a kind of catharsis," he said, "but I never could have imagined the dimensions it would have."
Among Cubans here and abroad, "William Tell" has been widely interpreted as an allegory about Fidel Castro's insistence on remaining in power and his resistance to political and economic reforms. Mr. Varela, however, will neither endorse nor reject that reading.
"I'm not going to tell you that I wrote it solely for that, because that would not be correct," he said. "To say that William Tell is one person, or to say the lyrics have only one meaning or another, would be to underestimate the song. Yes, 'William Tell' was written on the basis of something one lives through on a daily basis here. But in reality, I must confess to you that I wrote the song thinking of father and son, of the conflict of generations."
Since then, Mr. Varela has cemented his reputation, and fed the apprehensions of Cuba's old guard, with a series of equally bold compositions. On his 1992 record, "Monedas al Aire" (Qbadisc QB-9010), he addressed the collapse of the Soviet bloc in "Now That the Maps Are Changing Color"; expressed disgust for propaganda and indoctrination in "Like They Did to Me," and documented the erosion of Socialist ideals in "Wall."
That penchant for politically sensitive themes means that program directors at most state-controlled radio and television stations are reluctant to play Mr. Varela's music. But he has discovered that there are fewer impediments to live performances, including those at the prestigious Karl Marx Theater here, where he draws a full house whenever he is allowed to play. And like the Grateful Dead, he has grown accustomed to seeing audiences tape his songs so they can be copied and passed around to other fans.
"If I introduce five new songs today," he said, "in a concert a month from now, five thousand people will be singing along in unison, without these songs having been played even once on radio or television."
Despite his image here as an artist at odds with the system, Mr. Varela finds his relationship with the Cuban exile world to be as ambiguous and uneasy as that with the Cuban state. To be accepted by the Miami exile establishment, musicians, actors, painters and writers are expected to defect to the United States, then show up at a radio station for a ritual denunciation of Fidel Castro and any former colleague who chooses to remain here.
Mr. Varela, however, refuses to take that step, which would also enable him to gain access to the American market. "I don't question where you want to live, so don't you mess with me," he said. "I want to continue making my music, which is a music that is not easy to make in my country. I'm not an artist who has been given privileges by the system. Nevertheless, I want to continue returning here, and I believe I have that right, don't I?"
Under pressure from Cuban-American exile groups in Miami who thought otherwise, the all-music cable network MTV Latino in 1994 withdrew from its rotation a video of the song "Robinson," in which Mr. Varela likens the isolation of Robinson Crusoe on his island to Cubans on theirs. But that has been only one of Mr. Varela's problems in reaching young Hispanic listeners in the United States.
"In Cuba, there are people at the radio stations that won't play my music, and in Miami there are people who aren't willing to accept that my music is being played there," he said. "So the question becomes, 'Where do they want me to go and live?' "
Over the last decade, Mr. Varela has recorded and toured regularly in Latin America and Europe, winning a loyal following there. But the American embargo on travel to Cuba and trade with it makes it virtually impossible for him and other Cuban musicians to perform or record in the United States, which in turn makes it difficult to promote his records, commercial though they may be, in the American market.
"We're caught in the middle," said an executive at the Miami headquarters of Mr. Varela's American record company, BMG Records, a branch of the German conglomerate Bertelsmann. "I can't take people down to Havana for a showcase, and he can't come up here. It's very controversial with him right now."
In musical terms, Mr. Varela does not conform to stereotypes either. He and his six-man electric band have a vocabulary that includes not only traditional mainstays of Cuban music like salsa and cha-cha-cha, but also modern rock-and-roll and international pop, which often comes as a surprise to foreign audiences that encounter him for the first time.
"It always makes me laugh when I go to Spain, and they say to me, 'But you have so many connections with Bob Dylan, Bruce Springsteen and Paul Simon,' " he said. "Well, why shouldn't I? I'm from a generation that in addition to living with Cuban music has grown up with the best of American music, so it all seems perfectly coherent to me."
It was hardly surprising, then, that Mr. Varela said he not only would be interested in recording and performing in the United States, but also fully expects to do so before his career ends. "This situation is absurd and foolish, and it has to end some day," he said.
"I'm not directly identified with any political party or position, nor do I want to be," he continued. "What I want is for my songs to be like scissors that cut the strings that have made us puppets for so many years, inside Cuba and out. To me, all of us Cubans have the right to defend each other, everywhere, and I believe that many, many young people inside Cuba and out think just as I do."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Carlos Varela, a Cuban singer whose records are nearly impossible to find.

HEADLINE: New-Home Sales Drop 1.3% As Midwest Cold Hurts Buying

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 29

 BODY:
New-home sales slid nationally in February for the first time in four months, as unusually cold weather in the Midwest disrupted buying.
Sales improved in the Northeast, South and West, but a 24 percent plunge in the Midwest pulled down overall sales of single-family homes by 1.3 percent, to an annual rate of 700,000, seasonally adjusted, the Commerce Department said today. 
 "If we had had better weather in the Midwest, we would have had a better overall number," Eileen Neely, an economist with the Federal National Mortgage Corporation, said.
Still, said Stan Duobinis, an economist with the National Association of Home Builders, "700,000 is a surprisingly strong number compared with what we've seen for the last two years." He attributed the figure to buyers who were taking advantage of relatively low mortgage rates.
Earlier this week, the National Association of Realtors reported that home resales surged a surprisingly strong 6.5 percent in February and also attributed the gain to low rates.
The rates, however, began inching up during the month. Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages, which hovered around 7 percent before starting to rise, averaged 7.69 percent this week.
Ms. Neely said the higher rates could mean that the January-February sales levels would be the highest of 1996.
The Mortgage Bankers Association has already reported declines in home-loan applications for three consecutive weeks, Ms. Neely said. That will lead to declining sales in the coming months, she said.
The February decline was the first since October, when sales fell 1.6 percent. The new report showed that sales in January were stronger than previously thought, totaling 709,000 at an annual rate rather than the 693,000 originally estimated.
As a result, sales during the first two months of this year were 19.1 percent higher than during the corresponding period of 1995.
The report also said the estimate of new houses for sale at the end of February was 368,000, seasonally adjusted. That would supply six months' sales at the current rate, the smallest reserve since a backlog of the same size last August.
The inventory level "should allow housing starts to stay at a higher level than otherwise would be the case," Ms. Neely said. Because of the higher mortgage rates, "there will be a decline, but not to the degree some people had thought."
The median price of a new home was $134,900, meaning that half of the homes cost more and half less.
Sales in the Midwest plunged to an annual rate of 117,000, lowest since 106,000 a year earlier. In the Northeast, sales jumped 23 percent, to a 58,000 rate, after plunging 42 percent during the blizzards of January.
Sales rose 8.7 percent in the West, to a 213,000 rate, and in the South, up six-tenths of a percent, to 313,000.

HEADLINE: Bonds End the First Quarter on Upbeat Note

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The bond market ended the first quarter yesterday on a positive note, as buyers emerged and prices rose.
Bonds were bolstered by reports on manufacturing and housing that suggested the economy was expanding slow enough to keep inflation from accelerating. The data appeared to keep the door ajar for another cut in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve this spring. On Tuesday, Fed policy makers left interest rates unchanged. Their next meeting is scheduled for May 21. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond gained 19/32 , to 9111/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.67 percent, from 6.72 percent on Thursday. A week ago, the yield was 6.64 percent.
A report by the Chicago Purchasing Managers Association showed growth but with modest price pressures. The purchasing managers' index rose to 47.3 in March from 44.9 in February. While the index number was higher than expected, the report also showed that manufacturers were paying lower prices, as the prices-paid component showed sluggishness as it slipped to 46.8 from 49.1. The Chicago purchasing managers' report is seen by the market as a precursor to the report by the National Association of Purchasing Management, which is to be released on Monday.
In other data, the Commerce Department said sales of new homes fell 1.3 percent in February, to 700,000 annualized units from 709,000 in January. And traders said the University of Michigan's March survey pointed to an improvement in consumer sentiment, showing little difference from the preliminary results of the survey earlier this month. The university's surveys are released only to subscribers.
Stuart G. Hoffman, chief economist at the PNC Bank Corporation in Pittsburgh, noted that the bond market seesawed within a narrow price range this week, ignoring most economic reports.
"The February new-home sales edged lower, but all three winter months have seen solid home sales in response to falling mortgage rates," Mr. Hoffman said. "The spring home-buying season, however, will be weaker in response to the recent rise in mortgage rates."
But next week, he said, the market's attention will be focused on several important economic reports, including the purchasing managers' report and the Labor Department's March employment report on Friday.
"The bond market is searching for clarity in these numbers," Mr. Hoffman said. "Unfortunately the G.M. strike will make this data as clear as mud. In response the bond market may spend another week continuing to trade within a narrow band."
In addition to these reports, the market is also bracing for another round of new supply, which was largely absent in March. After Congress raised the nation's debt limit on Thursday night, the Treasury plans to return to the market in the next two weeks.
In addition to its regular weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills, the Treasury plans to sell new one-year bills on Tuesday and two-year notes on April 8 and five-year notes on April 9. In when-issued trading, the two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 5.75 percent and the five-year notes at a price to yield 6.09 percent. The Treasury will also sell nine-day cash management bills on Monday.

HEADLINE: Jan. 31 Rate Cut Unanimous at Fed

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 29

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers, confronted with signs of a slowing economy, were unanimous in lowering a key lending rate at their Jan. 31 meeting, minutes of the session disclosed today.
The Federal Open Market Committee voted 10 to 0 to trim the target for the Federal funds rate -- the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans -- to 5.25 percent from 5.5 percent at the meeting. 
 The full Fed board also voted 5 to 0 that day to lower the more symbolic discount rate -- the rate the Fed charges for loans to commercial banks -- by a quarter-point, to 5 percent. January's actions followed a similar quarter-point reduction in the Federal funds rate on Dec. 19.
"Although a pickup to an acceptable rate of expansion was seen as the most likely course for the economy in coming quarters, the risks of a shortfall in growth were believed to be significant," the minutes said. Some members suggested an even larger rate cut could have been warranted, "but they preferred a cautious approach," according to the minutes.
At their most recent meeting on Tuesday, the policy makers took no action on interest rates.
The minutes from Jan. 31 also showed that the Fed policy makers did not expect the decision to lower the Federal funds rate would undo their effort to prevent consumer prices from accelerating.

HEADLINE: For $125 Million Cash, City Cedes Budget Control

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
In exchange for an immediate cash infusion of $125 million from the Municipal Assistance Corporation to close this year's budget gap, the Giuliani administration has accepted the corporation's demand to cut projected city spending by $125 million for each of the next four fiscal years, according to details of the agreement made public yesterday.
The agreement represents the first time since the fiscal crisis of the 1970's that the city has agreed to let a state agency set its spending limits. 
 Administration officials defended the arrangement as a sound deal that would help the city solve its immediate budget problem while not necessarily binding it to any spending priorities. They said that if the city's actual spending strayed from the figures set out by the agreement, the city need only to repay the $125 million.
City Council leaders lashed out at the Giuliani administration for entering into what they characterized as a secret agreement that essentially would cede ultimate control over the city's budget to a state agency.
Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone demanded that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani rescind the agreement, which still must be formally approved by the corporation's board. He harshly criticized the arrangement because the spending limits are based on the Mayor's January financial plan, a document that traditionally is extremely tentative and is filled with budgetary assumptions that do not materialize or are significantly altered by the time a budget is adopted in June.
Later-year spending ceilings delineated by the corporation are based on preliminary budget figures for the years 1997 through 2000 that were proposed by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani in January. Those future-year budgets are highly tentative.
"This is purporting to write in stone our priorities for the next four years," Mr. Vallone said. "You might as well close shop and let Big M.A.C. and the Financial Control Board take over. Well, we're not prepared to cede our job to anyone else at the moment." Mr. Vallone asked the Mayor to rescind the agreement today, but the Mayor has not responded.
The Municipal Assistance Corporation, which has four members appointed by the Mayor and five by the Governor, was created to sell bonds to keep the city's finances afloat during the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's. The corporation pays off those bonds by tapping the city's sales tax revenues.
The Financial Control Board mentioned by Mr. Vallone was set up in 1975 to actually rein in city spending, but it officially gave up that power in 1986, when the city was in an economic boom. State law requires it, however, to continue to monitor the city's finances until 2008.
The Manhattan Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, also strongly opposed the deal, calling it "an abomination" because "it ties the hands of the City Council, abrogates the City Charter and the public's role in the budget process and further erodes basic services in the city."
The Mayor insisted that the agreement with the Municipal Assistance Corporation would not actually force the city to meet specific spending totals in the next four years. He said the agreement was no different in principle from the one the city and the corporation agreed to two years ago when the agency gave the city $200 million to finance severance packages that ultimately persuaded about 14,000 workers to leave the city payroll.
But while the previous agreement required the city to reduce its work force over a given period of time, it did not set specific spending limits. The current deal would set an overall spending total for all agencies that are completely under the city's control. Agencies such as the Board of Education and the Health and Hospitals Corporation, which rely heavily on state and Federal financing, would not be included.
The Mayor also said that he was perfectly comfortable committing to an additional $125 million cut in overall spending because he had already asked city agencies to come up with $200 million in savings for the next year.
"It's easy for me to agree to it because I know we're going to do a lot more downsizing than $125 million," Mr. Giuliani said.
Edward V. Regan, chairman of the corporation and a former state Comptroller, would not comment on the specifics of the agreement. He said, however, that he had already discussed it with the other members of the corporation and expected its formal ratification soon.
Officials of the State Financial Control Board would not comment on the agreement, but the city's two other fiscal monitors, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall and City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, both said they believed the deal was technically and legally sound.
Still, Leah C. Johnson, a spokeswoman for Mr. Hevesi, said Mr. Vallone had raised "significant charter issues" regarding the Council's role in the budget process that should be addressed.
Mr. McCall also said it was unfortunate that the administration did not try to resolve the Council's concerns before signing off on the agreement. He added, however, that he did not believe the agreement would place the city under outside financial control, as Mr. Vallone charged.
"We don't read it that way, because there's a way out of it," Mr. McCall said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone, right, and Councilman Herbert E. Berman held a news conference yesterday to discuss the city's budget deal with the Municipal Assistance Corporation. Mr. Vallone urged the Mayor to rescind the agreement, saying it would cede control over city finances to the state. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Toyota Sets A Buyback Of Its Stock

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 29

 BODY:
In a highly unusual move, the Toyota Motor Corporation said today that it would spend up to $1 billion to buy back its own stock.
Toyota's stock buyback appears to indicate that Japanese companies are beginning to pay more attention to their shareholders. 
 Buybacks, which are often used in the United States to raise a company's stock price, have been virtually unheard of in Japan, where shareholders are more docile. Securities analysts have long said that one of the competitive strengths of Japanese companies is that they can focus on long-term goals and use their cash to expand their businesses, without having to worry about share prices or short-term earnings.
Indeed, just a few months ago Japanese auto companies were relieved that they were not in the same situation as the Chrysler Corporation, which wanted to save its cash for its business but was being pressured by the billionaire Kirk Kerkorian to use it to reward shareholders.
But now, things are slowly changing in Japan, in part because a sour economy and low interest rates have forced institutional investors here to seek higher returns on their stock holdings. "It's becoming increasingly important to be aware of shareholders," said Saul Rubin, an analyst at SBC Warburg Japan Ltd.
In November, in an effort to bolster the stock market, Tokyo suspended for three years a tax that had strongly discouraged stock buybacks. Before the suspension, all shareholders of a company that did buy back some stock would be taxed on the ground that with fewer shares circulating the value of the remaining shares had risen.
Since the change in the law, a handful of companies including the Sumitomo Corporation, Asahi Breweries, the Tonen Corporation and Amway Japan have announced stock buybacks. With Toyota, one of Japan's largest manufacturers, now giving the concept respectability, the movement could accelerate, though no one expects it to turn into a rush.
"Everyone is just testing the waters at the moment," said Kathy Matsui, vice president and chief strategist in Japan for Goldman, Sachs & Company.
Toyota said it would buy back up to 100 billion yen of its stock, with details to be decided in May and shareholder approval sought in June. At today's closing price, that would represent 42.37 million shares, or about 1.1 percent of the company's 3.74 billion shares outstanding.
Toyota's announcement was made after the close of trading on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The company's stock fell 10 yen, to 2,360, on a day when the Nikkei index of 225 issues climbed 111.03 points.
Although a Toyota spokesman said the move was intended to benefit shareholders, the auto maker did not appear to be responding to any particular shareholder pressure.
Rather, Toyota apparently felt obliged to set an example. That is because its chairman, Shoichiro Toyoda, is also the chairman of Keidanren, a business lobbying organization that has been urging stock buybacks to bolster the market.
Toyota can well afford it. The parent company had 1 trillion yen, or about $10 billion, in cash as of the end of September, its latest reporting period. It also owned $4 billion in marketable securities.
Stock in many Japanese companies is largely held by friendly affiliated companies -- banks, suppliers or customers, or other members of the keiretsu, or industrial group. Such shares are held to cement the relationship and ward off takeovers and are therefore not easily sold.
In Toyota's case, 93.2 percent of the shares are held by such long-term investors, leaving only 6.8 percent floating in the market, said Peter Boardman, an auto industry analyst at UBS Securities in Tokyo.
The result is that while American companies are said to be run for the shareholders, Japanese companies are managed for the employees. The return on equity in Japanese companies is less than 3 percent compared with 23 to 25 percent in the United States, according to Ms. Matsui.
But now, Japanese companies are feeling pressure to raise stock prices or dividends. Some of that pressure is coming from foreign investors, who now own about 10 percent of the stocks compared with about 4 percent in 1989, Ms. Matsui said.
Even domestic institutional investors are starting to seek higher returns on stock holdings.
Still, a survey conducted by the Life Insurance Association of Japan a few months ago found 70 percent of companies saying they had no interest in buying back their stock.

HEADLINE: January Gap In U.S. Trade Grew Sharply

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 29

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit widened sharply in January to nearly $10.3 billion, reversing its performance of late last year, when the Clinton Administration boasted that its policies contributed to a drastic improvement in American competitiveness, Commerce Department figures showed today.
The surprisingly big trade gap -- the amount by which imports of goods and services exceeded exports -- was marked by record purchases from abroad and an almost equal drop in sales to foreigners. 
 Analysts said the figures suggested that in the months ahead, trade would provide scant support for the economy because exports would do little to create jobs.
While the January figures represent an aberration to some degree, Michael P. Niemira, an economist at the Mitsubishi Bank in New York, observed that export growth had been slowing for nearly a year. This, he said, suggested that with the disappearance of the temporary factors, the trade gap would settle in a range of $8 billion to $9 billion, compared with just under $7 billion in the final two months of 1995.
"The trend is toward a slower pace of exports," Mr. Niemira said, citing a growth rate now halved from the 20 percent or so that prevailed early last spring.
And Joel L. Naroff, chief economist for First Union National Bank in Philadelphia, said, "Forecasts that an improving trade deficit would be a significant factor in causing the economy to grow at a more sustainable 2 percent to 2.5 percent pace in 1996 may have to be revised." For the final quarter of last year, the economy grew at an annual pace of just under 1 percent.
Analysts and securities markets took the trade data in stride, apparently recognizing that special factors had magnified the $3.3 billion January surge in the deficit. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 43.71 points, though the sharpest drop was concentrated in late trading -- long after the 8:30 A.M. trade report.
The main factors in the sharp January rise were said to be severe weather, a jump in the price of oil and the lingering effects of a strike at the Boeing Company, analysts said. Some also speculated that the partial shutdown of the Federal Government may have delayed the permits needed for certain high-technology exports.
"It looks like exports were kept down pretty good while imports kept on coming," said Robert A. Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities International in New York.
He said the biggest factor was the blizzard, which had slowed or halted shipments in the Northeast, and flooding in other parts of the country that had crippled transportation.
Nonetheless, it seemed likely that a widening trade deficit could become more than the province of Patrick J. Buchanan, who based much of his effort to win the Republican Presidential nomination on the Clinton Administration's trade policies, which he said had cost American jobs and held down incomes. Among other things, President Clinton supported ratification of the North American Free Trade Agreement and other market-opening measures.
In January, exports of civilian aircraft plunged to $445 million, not seasonally adjusted, the lowest level in 18 years. The drop reflected the Boeing strike, which ended in December.
Over all, exports declined 2.2 percent in January, to $66.6 billion, with telecommunications equipment combining with aircraft to account for more than 85 percent of the drop from December's export record.
Meanwhile, imports climbed 2.4 percent, the bulk of it because of a higher bill for foreign oil and for automotive goods. Oil cost the nation 12.5 percent more than it had in December, reflecting a modest rise in volume, to an average 7.43 million barrels a day, and a 59-cent surge in price, to $16.45 a barrel.
The result was the biggest deficit since $11 billion in July.
The report showed that the nation's surplus in trade of advanced- technology products shrank, to $558 million in January from a 1995 peak of $2.4 billion in December.
Tabulated by trading partner, a $66 million surplus with Western Europe was transformed in January to a $935 million deficit, while the deficit widened sharply with the Pacific Rim. The deficit with Japan, which has been on the wane, rose 9.3 percent, to $3.8 billion, while that with China rebounded 39.3 percent, to $2.7 billion.
"The situation with China is becoming more and more critical," Mr. Naroff said.
With Canada, the deficit was unchanged at $2 billion, while the deficit with Mexico rose 23.2 percent, to $1.3 billion. The figures for countries and regions are not adjusted for recurring seasonal variation.

HEADLINE: Young Voters, Diverse and Disillusioned, Are Unpredictable in '96 Race

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
Their first memories of politics are of the Reagan era. They only glimpsed the end of the cold war. And they have no unifying experience like the anti-Vietnam movement of the 1960's.
They are often irritated when lumped together as faceless members of Generation X because they are a diverse group of executives, factory workers, students, welfare recipients and volunteers. 
 But as this generation of 18- to 29-year-olds strives to establish its turf in a society where baby boomers set the agenda, one thing clearly defines them, political strategists say: Their numbers are large and their political allegiances fluid, making them unpredictable in the Presidential election next November.
"My biggest concern is that I'm still a college student struggling financially," Kevin Rogers, 23, of Hot Springs, Ark., said. "What jobs are going to be there when I graduate?"
"The past two elections, I've voted Republican," said Mr. Rogers, who has taken a year off from college to work. "This election, I don't know what I'm going to do."
Referring to Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the presumptive Republican nominee who is 72 and, if elected, would be the oldest President ever to assume the office, Mr. Rogers said: "There is something about him that seems Presidential -- he follows foreign policy issues like trade and world peace. But he doesn't address enough issues at home."
Richard Thau, executive director of Third Millennium, a nonprofit, nonpartisan Generation X advocacy group, said it would be difficult to predict how millions of young voters like Mr. Rogers would vote. But Mr. Thau asserted that "young voters are as important demographically as California is geographically."
Even as political analysts, and candidates, recognize the force of this group of voters, a major registration drive is under way. The campaign is designed to draw young voters into the political process and continue a development that began in 1992 when, after years of poor turnouts, the percentage of voters between the ages of 18 and 29 rose.
In the 1992 Presidential election, young voters made up 22 percent of the electorate, compared with 20 percent in 1988, according to polls of voters after they had cast their ballots. The 1988 poll was conducted by The New York Times and CBS News, and the 1992 poll was conducted by the major television networks.
In the 1984 and 1988 Presidential elections, most young people voted Republican, according to exit polls conducted by The Times and CBS News. But in 1992, 44 percent of young voters chose Bill Clinton, while 34 percent supported George Bush and 22 percent backed Ross Perot, the exit polls found.
This year political experts are unwilling to predict what direction the young vote will take. "Neither candidate has come close to either appealing to the generation or addressing the issues facing it during the 21st century," Mr. Thau said, referring to President Clinton and Senator Dole.
David Anderson, 25, the tour manager of an MTV bus campaign that is crisscrossing the country to promote voter registration, called young voters "independent, undecided and wary about their future" and said, "They're wondering whether this year's candidates will really keep the promises they make."
Indeed, what was clear from dozens of interviews in Arkansas, Tennessee and Texas with college students, white- and blue-collar workers and young people on welfare was that young voters are increasingly dissatisfied, disillusioned and frustrated with the political system.
Conservative on economic issues and liberal-leaning on social issues like health care and abortion, young voters want lower taxes and less interference from the Federal Government at state levels, but they also talk about the need for a higher minimum wage and for Federal spending on education, and they are concerned about protecting the environment and finding better jobs. According to New York Times/CBS News polls, 33 percent consider themselves independent, 30 percent say they are Republican, and 28 percent Democratic.
Many of those interviewed said their identification with a political party would be driven by the personal appeal of a Presidential candidate and by specific issues.
"They are completely steeped in the new information environment," said Michael Delli Carpini, professor of political science at Barnard College, who specializes in American politics, the youth vote and the media. "They are more pragmatic, more cynical, more sophisticated. I think they are a vote that can move in different directions, depending on different appeals."
As a mark of the importance of these voters, a major effort is being made to register them -- the most extensive effort since the 26th Amendment, which lowered the voting age to 18, was ratified in 1971.
This year's Presidential election will be the first under the motor-voter law, which allows potential voters to register when they get a driver's license and in certain government offices. More than 11 million people were registered to vote in 1995 under this law, according to statistics from Human SERVE, a national voter registration organization. The group believes that a large number of these voters are under 29 because most people applying for drivers' licenses are young.
Youth Vote '96, a national coalition of youth organizations based in Washington, says its goal is to get 12 million young people to the polls this year, about 50 percent of the eligible young voters.
The MTV bus, covered with graffiti quotes ranging from Aristotle to Madonna, is stopping in cities, shopping malls and campuses to register young voters, answer questions, hand out voter guides and conduct surveys. In 1992, MTV also ran a voter awareness campaign; Census Bureau statistics show an increase of two million young voters between the 1988 and 1992 elections.
For this year's effort, MTV has added the bus, and is again working with Rock the Vote, an independent nonprofit youth organization. As of the last week of March, about 8,000 people have been registered.
To publicize the tour, called "Choose or Lose," MTV has home pages on the internet where interviews and the daily progress of the bus are posted, and each candidate's agenda is outlined. Potential voters can read about such issues as taxes or proposed cuts in Federal education grants. (The web address is: http://mtv.com/chooseorlose.)
Radio stations across the country are doing public-service announcements about the bus tour.

HEADLINE: Israeli Opposition Chief Making Comeback

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, March 29

 BODY:
After the assassination of Yitzhak Rabin in November, it seemed there was nothing Benjamin Netanyahu could say that Israelis cared to hear.
In the grief of the moment, the very fact that Mr. Netanyahu, the leader of the conservative Likud Party, had opposed Mr. Rabin's peace policies seemed a profanation of the fallen Prime Minister's memory. Mr. Netanyahu's image as a smooth operator and slick talker made him seem unworthy compared with Mr. Rabin's old-fashioned candor and soldierly roughness. 
 Now, after a new wave of suicide bombings, people are listening again, especially when Mr. Netanyahu, referring to the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, ridicules "the idea that Arafat will be our subcontractor to fight terrorism," or expounds his campaign theme of "peace with security."
Bibi, the nickname by which Mr. Netanyahu is universally known in Israel, is back. He is hammering away at Prime Minister Shimon Peres and the Labor Party with the cascade of catchy slogans, crisp sound-bites and punchy interviews that have earned him the sobriquet, "the first American politician in Israel."
That characterization has some basis in fact. Mr. Netanyahu attended high school and two colleges in the United States -- the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Harvard -- and served in Washington and at the United Nations before returning to parlay the political tools he had acquired in the United States into a meteoric political career.
His mastery of communications, which he has said he learned from watching President Ronald Reagan, coupled with his grasp of American-style personal campaigning and his charm and good looks, introduced a whole new style of Israeli politics.
At the same time, his fluent and accentless American English made him a fixture on American television as an exponent of the Israeli conservative cause.
In the aftermath of Mr. Rabin's assassination, Mr. Netanyahu's career seemed to come to a crashing halt. His purported association with the violent slogans of the extreme right prompted Mr. Rabin's grieving widow, Leah, to shun Mr. Netanyahu's hand at graveside. Public opinion polls showed him trailing so badly that Mr. Peres decided it would be a sound move politically to advance national elections from October 1996 to May 29 this year, and members of Mr. Netanyahu's party hinted that their chances might be better if he stepped aside.
All that changed with the four suicide bombings and the profound fear they revived among many Israelis that the peace with the Palestinians was not bringing them what they most wanted: security.
This is Mr. Netanyahu's theme. In the immediate aftermath of the bombings, he was cautious to avoid any notion that he was seeking to capitalize on the disaster. He gave his support to the Government and the steps it was taking, and he ordered his followers to show restraint.
But as soon as the campaign for the May election resumed, the gloves came off. "The Labor Government had a chance to bring peace, and we see what sort of peace it is," Mr. Netanyahu told his party's central committee. "We must put our defense back in our own hands and give our security forces the freedom to hit where and when they deem right. Peace with the Arabs begins with security for the Jews."
From the political limbo of last winter, when he languished as far as 30 points behind Mr. Peres in popularity polls, Mr. Netanyahu has revived as a real contender to win the vote for prime minister in the election. Today, polls have him neck-and-neck with Mr. Peres.
Likud spokesmen deny that it was solely the bombings that turned Mr. Netanyahu's fortunes, noting that he had been ahead of Mr. Rabin in the polls before the assassination and that he had been regaining lost ground before the new series of bombings began on Feb. 25. Indeed, the Israeli public is notoriously given to broad swings after major crises, and nobody expected the conservatives to stay down forever.
But there is little question that the bombings brought public attention back to security, the central issue of Israeli politics, and turned the race into a critical referendum on how the Israelis want to proceed in shaping coexistence with the Palestinians.
The theme is closely linked to Mr. Netanyahu's career. The event that served more than any other to shift him from a business career to politics was the heroic death of his older brother, Yonatan, who was killed commanding the Israeli rescue of hostages in Entebbe, Uganda, in July 1976.
That led Mr. Netanyahu, then 27, to organize conferences on international terrorism, which brought him to the attention of Moshe Arens, then the Ambassador to the United States, who invited him to Washington as his deputy. Mr. Netanyahu next became Israel's chief delegate to the United Nations.
By the time he returned to Israel in 1988 as Deputy Foreign Minister, he was a serious player in Likud politics. His innumerable appearances as Israel's spokesman during the Persian Gulf War in 1991, and again during the Middle East peace conference in Madrid, established him as a national celebrity. In 1993, after Likud's loss in national elections, Mr. Netanyahu, 43, was elected the party's leader.
Now, at 46, he stands as the youngest politician ever to seek the office of prime minister here, and as the first to reject the traditional paternalism and clubbiness of Israeli politics in favor of direct, personal and professionally packaged appeals to voters. His opponent, Mr. Peres, is 72, and was active in politics before Mr. Netanyahu, or Israel, was born.
Whether Mr. Netanyahu's youth and style will prove as successful in the election as they were in winning the Likud leadership will become known only on May 29. Personal, American-style campaigning is still relatively new to Israel; and in the intimacy of a small and disputatious nation, sound-bites quickly wear thin.
A large part of Mr. Netanyahu's challenge is to convince voters that there is more to him than slogans, to dispel the suspicion of his abilities that persists despite his business degree from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and two published books, one on Israel and another on international terrorism.
Many political commentators have also noted that for all his attacks on Labor's peace policies, Mr. Netanyahu has not made clear how his government would differ from Labor's in handling the Palestinians.
In an interview, he said that he would not seek to roll back the existing agreements, but that he would provide a "firmer hand at the till" and thus achieve "a more durable peace."
But beyond the promise of a firmer hand, it was difficult to find substantive differences between his views and those of Mr. Peres.
"What I would do is to continue negotiating with the Palestinians, providing they fulfill the basic conditions of the peace," he said. "We would negotiate in such a way that the Palestinians would run their own affairs, but we would have responsibility against terrorism and foreign threats."
On Jewish settlements, Mr. Netanyahu declared that "clear red lines" should be drawn between Palestinian self-rule areas and Israeli areas. On building a barrier between the West Bank and Israel, he declared that he supported the idea of separation for security reasons, but not as part of a long-term peace.
If Mr. Netanyahu sometimes sounded like Mr. Peres, Mr. Peres has come to sound increasingly like Mr. Netanyahu since the bombings. The Prime Minister has taken a severe stance toward the Palestinians, vowing to maintain pressure on Mr. Arafat until he crushes the Islamic militants of Hamas and ordering the houses of terror suspects demolished.
The convergence of the candidates reflects the common wisdom that the May election will be decided by a large and wavering bloc of centrist voters, who generally want peace but are primarily worried about security, especially since the deaths of 62 people in the four bombings.
Mr. Peres's major challenge in the campaign is to overcome his image as being soft on security, while Mr. Netanyahu's is to convince the voters that he is not against making peace.
The race is also the first in which the prime minister will be elected directly, and not as head of a party slate. That has made each candidate's personality more of an issue than in the past, and both are vulnerable.
While Mr. Netanyahu has not convinced voters he has depth or strong principles, Mr. Peres has acquired a solid record of achievements and a reputation as a visionary intellectual. But he has never gained the trust or personal affection of voters.
And while Mr. Peres is unchallenged as leader of Labor, Mr. Netanyahu presides over a coalition that includes bitter rivals. Three years ago, he was forced to admit having an extramarital affair after anonymous rivals threatened to release a compromising videotape. No tape was ever produced, but Mr. Netanyahu accused his long-term rival, David Levy, of orchestrating the scandal. Mr. Levy subsequently quit Likud to form his own Sephardic-based party, but recently returned after being promised that he would be foreign minister in a Likud government.
Despite his fuzziness on the peace issue and his other problems, Mr. Netanyahu becomes positively professorial when expounding his faith in a free-market economy.
"We are mobile and have a strong scientific and technological base courtesy of the army and so have the best resources for launching forward into the technological and communications industries of the 21st century," he said. He calls for "privatization of state industry, deregulation with a vengeance, and the release of public lands into the housing market."
These are messages that many of his prosperous peers in the 40-something bracket and below are likely to embrace, and that any future Government will have to consider.

HEADLINE: How 3 Young Voters See the Election and the Choices

BYLINE: By DONATELLA LORCH 

 BODY:

April Smith, 21
'Clinton Is the Lesser Of Two Evils'
Ms. Smith said that she believed that this year's Republican candidates were spouting platitudes, and that she would vote for Mr. Clinton. 
 Yet she supports the Republican push for lower taxes and smaller Government and opposes abortion.
But Ms. Smith, like Mr. Rogers, is deeply concerned about education cuts. Last year, at the end of her sophomore year at the University of North Texas at Denton, she dropped out because she did not have money for the $2,400-a-year tuition, despite holding down two part-time jobs.
She now works 40 hours a week as a saleswoman in Gordon's jewelry store at the Denton mall and manages to save $100 a month. She can only go back to college, she said, if she gets financial aid.
"The Republicans seem to be more for the upper class instead of the poor or the elderly," Ms. Smith said. "Clinton is the lesser of two evils."
Ms. Smith also said she was worried about the environment. "I plan on having kids," she said. "Will there be a planet?"
Health care is another issue that concerns Ms. Smith, who said she had a strict Southern Baptist upbringing in Naples, Tex. Her parents helped her financially the first year in college, but now she is independent of them.
Her health insurance has a $500 deductible, and she fears that if she had an accident or became sick, her dreams of going to college could be put back years or wiped out.
 
Carlos Hernandez, 24
'Liberal Leaning,' But Feeling Fed Up
With a degree in international affairs from Georgetown University, Mr. Hernandez is the associate director of the National Hispanic Institute, a nonprofit organization in Maxwell, Tex., that conducts leadership training programs for Hispanic youths. He said he was just as passionate in his beliefs as those under 30 were in the 1960's.
He earns in the $20,000 range, he said. To save money and pay off a college debt of $15,000, he has moved in with his sister. He said he did not want to be like his parents whose savings were wiped out when they sent him to college.
Mr. Hernandez, a first-generation Mexican-American, said that he was "liberal leaning" but hated being labeled and was fed up with politicians. Nonetheless, he has voted every year and will this time, he said, probably for President Clinton because the Democratic agenda was closest to his concerns.
Still, he said he was disappointed with the President's performance on health care and welfare. And he added that Gen. Colin L. Powell would have been an attractive option.
Mr. Hernandez's father died of a heart attack at 48 so he said he worried about his own health and benefits. He said that he wanted to see his siblings and relatives go to college but that Republican cuts in education might make that dream impossible. The budget deficit gnaws at him, he said.
"I think we're mortgaging our future," he said in an interview at a restaurant in Austin. "As a young responsible citizen of this country, I'm responsible for balancing my checkbook. It's very difficult to run a government or a business if 40 percent of your payments are debt payments."
He does not believe the Government is responsible for providing him with a job but he believes it should provide training for those who do not have the chance for an education.
Like many other young people, Mr. Hernandez said his philosophy and beliefs were gleaned from his parents' experiences. His mother, a migrant cotton picker, was the first in her family to put herself through college.
And his father left Mexico to grow up in the projects of Brownsville, Tex., where he would break into people's houses to steal cans of tuna. The church changed his father's life and he put himself through college and earned a degree in electrical engineering.
"I'm just a Mexican-American concerned about where my community is going," Mr. Hernandez said.
 
Kevin Rogers, 23
10 Years Ago, 'A Common Goal'
Mr. Rogers has taken a year off from studying philosophy and political science at the University of Central Arkansas in Conway to work full time at the college bookstore. Next fall he plans to transfer to a bigger college in California, he said. The youngest of six children from a Southern Baptist family in Hot Springs, Ark., he and a brother are the only ones to have gone to college.
"I could leave college and go home and live a comfortable life," he said. "But that's a dead end."
Mr. Rogers talked of friends who are struggling to make ends meet in college only to return to their hometowns to work low-paid jobs. And he said he was worried about cuts in education threatened by the Republicans and wanted better benefits for college students. At the same time, he said he supported downsizing of the Federal government.
Like many in his age group, he finds himself thinking conservative on economic questions, and more liberal on social issues.
"I think 10 years ago, we as a generation had more of a common goal to fight over," he said. "Now there are so many stands to be had. It really divides up a generation."
 DONATELLA LORCH

HEADLINE: Intelligence Experts Meet to Combat Mideast Terrorism

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 29

 BODY:
In a follow-up to the Middle East summit meeting at Sharm el Sheik, Egypt, political and intelligence experts from 29 countries and organizations, including Israel and the Palestinian Authority, met today at the State Department to draft specific recommendations to fight terrorism.
The recommendations, on topics ranging from intelligence-sharing to methods for detecting false passports and hampering fund-raising by terrorist organizations, are to be presented at a meeting of foreign ministers on April 22 in Luxembourg, American officials said. 
 Officials also announced that an emergency meeting would be held April 12 in Brussels to speed aid for the Palestinians, who have received only small amounts of the $1.8 billion they have been promised over the past two years.
Four recent suicide bombings have created new questions in the American Congress about continued aid to Yasir Arafat and his Palestinian Authority, unless it cracks down harder on terrorists and alters the charter of the Palestine Liberation Organization, as promised, to eliminate a pledge to destroy Israel.
The original summit meeting was hastily called for March 13, in response to the bombings in Israel, which killed 62 people, led to a suspension of peace negotiations between Israel and Syria and prompted Israel to close its borders with the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.
The bombings damaged the election prospects of Prime Minister Shimon Peres of Israel by refocusing attention on Israelis' concerns about the security risks that would come from peace with Syria and with a more complete handing over of control in the West Bank to the Palestinian Authority.
The border closing, intended to stop suicide bombers from entering Israel, has caused significant economic distress. There have been reports of hunger among Palestinians who have been prevented from going to jobs in Israel.
The two-day meeting here was planned to focus on the details of the complicated fight against terrorist groups. But it also became a forum for the Palestinians and some Arab and European nations to criticize Israel for its harsh measures against Palestinians, participants said.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher helped broker a modest relaxation of the border closing. The easing, announced on Thursday, is allowing shipments of construction materials and some other items to be moved across the borders.
"We must find ways to support the Palestinian people as they, too, suffer the consequences" of the bombings, Mr. Christopher said.
Israeli officials attending the conference here said Israel had already begun to relax the border closing before today's action. They said the United States had worked hard to keep the focus of the conference on terrorism, which all the countries attending have reason to fear.
"We shouldn't regress from this period of finding peace to the period of armed conflict," one Israeli official said.
He expressed concern, though, whether much could be accomplished in such a large forum.
Information sharing, for instance, is a fine idea in principle, he said, but really represents information trading, which is best practiced on a smaller scale, "not in such a big bazaar." Otherwise, he said, "everyone thinks they are giving up too much and not getting anything in return."
Some of the topics for which committees are preparing proposals are how to promote cooperation among law-enforcement agencies, how to use extradition laws more energetically, how to enhance border controls -- with specific focus on the detection of forged documents and how to help to train the Palestinians in anti-terrorism and police tactics.
Syria and Lebanon refused to come to this meeting, as they had refused to attend the Sharm el Sheik summit talks.
At the meeting here, American officials urged Arab allies like Saudi Arabia, Jordan and Egypt to shut down public offices of organizations like Hamas, which took responsibility for three of the four bombings, and to work to cut off contributions to Hamas.
Europeans, the French in particular, have criticized what they see as the American "obsession" with Iran's possible role in promoting terrorism, saying Hamas -- unlike some other militant groups -- has indigenous roots, local grievances and little funding from Iran. "Terrorism will be over when Palestinians feel they have their rights recognized," one senior French official said.
A group of Arab-Americans, representing 14 organizations in 13 states met in Washington today under the sponsorship of the Arab American Institute. They said they were sympathetic to the Clinton Administration's desire to assuage Israeli fears, but that there had been a lack of similar measures to boost Palestinian confidence. In a statement, they said they opposed terrorism of all kinds, criticized Israeli collective punishment measures in the West Bank and called for more aid and job creation there to promote peace.
Speaking of the State Department meeting, Nicholas Burns, the Department's spokesman said that, "Given all the emotions on the agenda, it went pretty well." The aims of the conference were always multiple, he said, with the intention of working on fighting terrorism but also of recreating among Israelis and Palestinians the willingness to press ahead toward a comprehensive peace.
"We have to make the effort to create the kind of climate that allows the peace process to continue," he said.

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Adjusting Its Consumer Price Index

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 29

 BODY:
The Government said today that it was adjusting the Consumer Price Index to correct a fault in its measurements of inflation.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics said the modifications to the index would shave about one-tenth of 1 percentage point off the annual rate of inflation. 
 That change will translate into about $1 a month less for the average Social Security recipient, whose benefits are adjusted annually based on how much consumer prices increase. If the change had been in place last year, it would have meant the average monthly benefit would have been increased $17 instead of $18 in January.
While even small changes in the Consumer Price Index can result in big savings in those benefit programs like Social Security that are adjusted for inflation, the Clinton Administration based its new budget plan on an even bigger revision. The new budget assumed that the annual increase in consumer prices would be reduced by two-tenths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

For-Profit Hospital Chain To Buy Blue Cross Business
Columbia-HCA Healthcare agreed to buy the main business of Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Ohio for $299.5 million, in the first sale of a Blue Cross company to a for-profit hospital chain. The takeover could open the door for similar deals by a number of nonprofit Blue Cross plans that are struggling. 
 The deal would place Columbia-HCA in the unusual role of being both a provider of health care and a middleman serving employers and consumers. It would increase pressure on hospitals to reduce costs. [Page 1.]
 
Citibank Data on Mexican Sought
Federal law-enforcement agencies have subpoenaed records from Citibank's New York offices in an effort to assist Mexico with its investigation of Raul Salinas de Gortari, the brother of Mexico's former President, according to Government officials and bankers. They said Citibank itself is not under investigation. [39.]
 
Congress Extends Budgets
Congress voted enough money for Federal offices without 1996 budgets to finance them until April 24. Without the stipend, various Cabinet departments and offices ranging from NASA to the E.P.A., would have had to shut down beginning today. [1.]
 
Dow Ends Quarter Up 9%
Computer-guided sell orders lowered stock prices in the final half-hour of trading. The Dow ended off 43.71 points, at 5,587.14, but finished the first quarter up 9 percent, or 470 points. Other market indicators were mixed yesterday. [41.]
 
Bond buyers emerged and prices rose. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond slipped to 6.67 percent, from 6.72 percent. [40.]
 
Pacific Gas Stock Tumbles
Shares of Pacific Gas and Electric fell 10 percent after the company proposed speeding up its depreciation of power-generating assets in return for freezing customer rates for five years. While Pacific Gas said the accelerated depreciation could save it billions of dollars, analysts lowered their earnings estimates and warned that the dividend might be cut. [47.]
 
Speedier Action on Cancer Drugs
The White House is trying to speed the F.D.A.'s approval of drugs treating cancer, and said the regulatory changes would apply to at least 100 drugs now under study. [1.]
 
Abbott Labs in Acquisition
Abbott Labs agreed to make an $876 million acquisition of Medisense Inc., which makes kits for diabetes patients to test their blood glucose levels. The move is Abbott's first venture into the diabetes market, which accounts for 10 percent of all diagnostic testing. [39.]
 
New-Home Sales Turn Down
New-home sales slid 1.3 percent in February, in their first decline in four months. Sales rose in the Northeast, South and West, but plunged in the Midwest, where harsh weather quieted activity. Despite the drop, January and February may be the best sales months of the year, with mortgage rates now rising. [40.]
 
In Rare Move, Toyota to Buy Stock
 Toyota said it would spend upwards of $1 billion to buy back its stock. In the U.S., companies buy up some of their shares to lift their stock price, but the practice has been practically unheard of in Japan. Now things are slowly changing. [38.]
 
Auto Suppliers to Merge
Motor Wheel agreed to buy Hayes Wheels for $560 million, creating a supplier of wheel and brake parts with sales of $1 billion. [39.]
 
Ruling Sets Back Electric Cars
The automobile and oil industries won a victory against electric cars in a ruling by the California air quality board. [6.]
 
Europeans Offer Help on Mad Cows
European leaders promised aid to Britain to combat mad-cow disease and to reclaim its export market in beef. They clearly hope the matter won't spill over into important negotiations about the future of Europe. [3.]
 
Big Bidder Quits Wireless Auction
Another big bidder, Go Communications, dropped out of Washington's auction of wireless communication licenses. [39.]
 
Dollar at 2-Year High vs. Yen
The dollar jumped to 107.27 yen, its highest level in two years, despite a big rise in the trade deficit. [36.]
