HEADLINE: The View From: Dover Plains;
With Riders of the 6:33: A Train Like No Other

BYLINE: By LYNN AMES 

DATELINE: DOVER PLAINS, N.Y.

 BODY:
PHIL CELENTANO commutes to Manhattan every day not unusual except for the fact that he lives in the Berkshire Mountains of Massachusetts.
A 40-year-old collections manager for a telecommunications company, he wakes up each morning at 4 o'clock in his house in Lee, just north of Stockbridge. After a quick breakfast, he drives for an hour and a half to Dover Plains in Dutchess County. There, he boards the 6:33. The train, on Metro-North's Harlem Line, arrives at Grand Central Terminal at 8:26. 
 At the end of the day, Mr. Celentano catches the 5:16 out of Grand Central. He steps off the train at Dover Plains at 7:12 and drives back to Lee, generally getting home around 9 o'clock. By 10 o'clock, he said, he is fast asleep.
Mr. Celentano's routine elicits astonished gasps from those who find that any commute -- even a short one from, say, Scarsdale or White Plains -- gets to be a bit of a grind after a while. On the 6:33, however, he is far from alone. True, he is known as the guy from Massachusetts, the one making the longest trip, but there are plenty of people who commute almost as far. They live in northern Connecticut, in towns like Sharon, New Preston and Kent, and in Columbia and Dutchess Counties in New York. Before the first light has barely touched the sky, they are in their seats, reading newspapers, using laptop computers, chatting with one another. Most remarkable perhaps, they enjoy it.
"This train is like no other," Mary Jane Zukowski, a nurse paralegal who lives in Millbrook, said as she settled into her seat on the 6:33 on a recent morning. "There's a great sense of camaraderie -- everyone knows each other."
Indeed, the long-distance commuters seem to revel in their stamina, their discipline, the choices they have made to live in rural hamlets. Over and over they spoke of their fondness for quaint villages, wide-open vistas, farm-like settings and friendly neighbors.
"My neighbors are cows," said Sue Edelstein, a 43-year-old marketing director whose chic outfit and chiffon scarf seemed more suited to Manhattan than her Gaylordsville, Conn., home. "We lived in Brooklyn until a year and a half ago, and I would never move back." Like many others who made the move to the country, she worries that more people will follow suit and spoil the atmosphere. "We got involved with a citizens group that's trying to stop a big-chain supermarket from going up near us," she said. "It also worries me that they're going to build a platform at the Dover Plains station, which will look like a regular station anywhere. Now, we can actually walk across the track. It is a quaint little stop in a quaint little town."
But the stops along the Harlem Line's northernmost route are no longer "quaint little towns," Donald N. Nelson, president of Metro-North, said. Putnam, Dutchess and Columbia Counties are "where the affordable housing is now," he said. The annual ridership from Dover Plains to Grand Central has risen in the last decade from 41,892 to 199,707.
A total of 20 trains -- 10 each way -- make the daily run, the earliest leaving Dover Plains at 5:31 and the last leaving Grand Central at 9:49. Dover Plains is 77 miles from Manhattan; this summer, Metro-North will extend its service 5 miles north to Wassaic. "That way, we'll start getting them from Maine," Dan Brucker, a Metro-North spokesman, said with a laugh.
Metro-North also plans to renovate five stations, including the one in Dover Plains. Currently, this stop is as picturesque as a Norman Rockwell painting: one set of trains, one train (a two-car train at 5:31; six cars at 6:33), a small, shingled station no longer in use. On either side of the tracks are village streets, lined with brick and clapboard buildings.
One of these is Geo's Deli, a breakfast and lunch spot where the owner, George Dougherty, serves strawberry- and chocolate-flavored cream cheese on bagels, coffee, buttered rolls, and the like. His customers are local folk who live and work in or near town as well as commuters and Metro-North personnel. Mike Fagan, the conductor on the 6:33, and William Rohrig, the train's engineer, and Tom Mabie, its brakeman, take the same table every day.
Mr. Fagan is not only well known at Geo's, he is something of a celebrity on his train. Passengers repeatedly said that it is his gregarious nature -- he is on a first-name basis with all the regulars -- that give thistrain its personality. Mr. Fagan has even organized several dinners at local restaurants, attended by riders of the 6:33.
"Everyone knows Mike, and Mike knows everyone," Ms. Edelstein said. "This is the friendliest train in the world."
It is not only friendliness that makes the 6:33 so popular. Economic realities have pushed home buyers farther and farther up the line. A five-bedroom Colonial-style house with two fireplaces on an acre and a half in Millerton in Dutchess County is offered in a real estate guide for $189,000. The price for a comparable home in Westchester would probably be two or three times that. A four-bedroom ranch in Dover Plains is on the market for $89,500.
Robert Bailey, a 40-year-old commercial real estate broker, recently moved from Chappaqua to Amenia in Dutchess County. The cost of living, he said, is "a lot lower." He also said Chappaqua had become too slick, "too suburban," an ironic comment about a village once considered the epitome of country quaint. "Chappaqua has gotten hard edged and materialistic," he said. "People who moved there in recent years have high expectations but a low level of contribution. There is no sense of community like there is in Amenia." Asked if his longer commute ever made him weary, he replied, "That's the price I pay for living in God's country."
Mr. Celentano also said that he would not trade places with anyone. He and his wife own and live in a bed and breakfast in Lee and, he said, the extraordinary commute is worth the effort. "People think I'm crazy. But really, the trip's not all that bad -- I sleep the whole way. I used to commute from Farmingdale, L. I. I think that short ride on the Long Island Rail Road was harder than this. Hey, everybody does what they have to do."

SECTION: Section 9; Page 11; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1234 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Watchung Power Center Proposed at Lockheed Site

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: WATCHUNG

 BODY:
FOR more than 30 years, the 85-acre Lockheed Electronics complex was a constant sight alongside Route 22 in the Somerset County Borough of Watchung. But in 1990 it closed, leaving behind a prime, albeit polluted, piece of property.
To maximize its redevelopment potential borough officials, working with Lockheed Electronics (a subsidiary of what is now Lockheed Martin Corporation), rezoned the site in 1994 from industrial to highway commercial use. This permits retail on its site along a main shopping corridor in Union and Somerset Counties. 
 And Lockheed Electronics set out to meet the state law requiring that the site, which contained levels of trichloreoethylene -- a solvent for fats, oils and waxes, be cleaned before it is redeveloped.
Since then 75 acres of the site have been cleaned, the remaining 10 acres are being cleaned and much of the old complex has been razed. Now a developer is proposing to turn the 75 acres into a 750,000-square-foot shopping center, despite a softening in the retail market and the bankruptcies of some national discounters.
The proposal, which still must receive approvals from the borough's planning board, underscores several characteristics of contemporary commercial development. One is the trend toward power centers. Watchung Square, as the project is known, would meet the definition of a power center that the International Council of Shopping Centers, based in Manhattan, uses: an open-air retail strip with 250,000 to 750,000 square feet of space and three or more large speciality stores.
Such centers are growing rapidly, increasing nationally over the last year by 60 percent to 461 centers, from 287 in 1994. At the same time, only seven regional malls with more than 800,000 square feet of space were built, according to the council.
"It is the way of the future and the type of development that makes sense in today's environment," said Sal A. Davino, president of Watchung Square Associates, the corporate entity created to develop the project. Mr. Davino, a long-time shopping center developer, also heads Fidelity Land Development Corporation in Chatham.
Plans for Watchung Square call for the $75 million open-air center, designed by architect Patrick Marchetta of Lyndhurst, to comprise a group of six low-rise buildings, instead of one interconnecting strip of stores, scattered near the edges of the sloping site. It would have a 127,442-square-foot Home Depot and a 123,680-square-foot Target department store, a Minneapolis-based chain that is entering the New Jersey retail market.
There would also be a 66,000-square-foot supermarket, a 14-screen theater, some 10 smaller shops and a restaurant, as well as parking for 3,300 cars in front of the stores and concentrated at the site's core.
The project is also indicative of the recycling of old industrial sites to new uses, which follows the aims of the state's Development and Redevelopment Plan. The plan encourages growth where highways and utilities are in place and discourages it in less developed areas.
And it speaks to the long-standing struggle many communities across the state face -- how to diversify their economic bases while still preserving residents' quality of life.
Anthony F. Addario, the Mayor of Watchung, said that the closing of Lockheed, among the larger of the borough's revenue producers, was a blow and that the retail center, which he said was about a $50 million ratable, would "help keep the lid on property taxes." He said that a retail use on the site "blends right in with Route 22."
Still, some residents feel the town may be too eager in its pursuit of ratables. A citizens group called Concerned Homeowners of Watchung was formed last August in response to the project, with more than 100 members. It wants to see how the shopping center "impacts Watchung and its residents," said R. Lawrence Chory, a 17-year resident who is a co-founder.
MR. CHORY said his group's main concerns were the project's scale, its tenant mix and the additional traffic it would create. He said it also felt that so large a project would require more municipal services that the revenue it would generate would not cover. Residents of neighboring North Plainfield are also concerned about the project's impact, including noise and water runoff, as are local officials there and in nearby Green Brook, he added.
Mr. Davino said the plan had already been changed to try to address some of the issues. In one revision the buffer zone between the project and the residences has been enlarged by 25 feet to 125 feet. He also said that some $3 million in off-site road improvements were planned to accommodate the project. They include the installation of a traffic light, improvements to nine intersections, and the widening of a stretch of Route 22 to six lanes from four.
Watchung Square is the largest development proposed in decades in the 6.2-square-mile borough. Its site is one of the few large tracts available for development along the half-mile stretch of Route 22 in the town, where retail stores are the prevailing land use.
Finding that size tract in a established retail area is rare, said Mr. Davino, noting that it sits between the highway shopping hub in Union Township and the Bridgewater Commons Mall in Bridgewater.
"It is a true niche market," he said, noting that the area's demographics could support retail. Some 213,500 people with an average household income of $68,927 live within a five-mile radius of the proposed center, he said, and 64,710 cars pass the site each day. Mr. Davino said most of the tenants have signed contracts to be in the center, where he said rents were expected to range from $15 to $24 a square foot.
Retail brokers agree that the area is ripe for development. "It is one of the rare places in New Jersey where it feels as though there should be a regional mall -- but it's missing," said Richard Brunelli, president of a brokerage in Old Bridge bearing his name.
He puts the vacancy rate in strip centers and free-standing stores along the entire 21-mile Route 22 corridor, from Union to Somerville at 5.4 percent, up from 3.9 percent a year ago. Mr. Brunelli said most of the vacancies were in smaller stores not big boxes, "which are driving the market" and reflect "consumer preferences for more convenient shopping." The vacancy rate in the six major Northern New Jersey corridors is 6.1 percent.
"By and large residents recognize that the borough lost Lockheed and that you don't just let 75 acres along Route 22 go to waste," said Donald V. Speeney, chairman of the borough's planning board. "We're working through the issues."
MR. CHORY said that the goal of his citizen's group "is not to stop Watchung Square but to downsize it to a scale that is appropriate for the site and for Watchung." Right now, he said, the project is three-quarters the size of Bridgewater Commons Mall, which he said was excessive.
A more reasonable scale project might be 600,000 square feet minus the movie theater, he said, adding that there should be some attempt to keep open the remaining 10 acres, which is not part of the current project
Mr. Speeney, chairman of the planning board, said that was a concept that had recently come under discussion. Mayor Addario added that he was confident that after all the sides are heard Watchung will have a project that it "can live with."

LENGTH: 1238 words

HEADLINE: Construction of $1 Million 'Main Line' Homes Surges

BYLINE: By DAVID J. WALLACE 

DATELINE: RADNOR, Pa.

 BODY:
A SURGE in the construction of homes selling for $1 million or more is under way in the exclusive Main Line, about a dozen communities northwest of Philadelphia and within a 20-minute drive of downtown.
Developable land in these communities -- among them, Bryn Mawr, Rosemont, Wayne and Gladwyne -- is scarce and local approvals are difficult and time-consuming. But in recent months, builders have overcome the hurdles to subdivision approval in Lower Merion and Radnor Townships, which embrace several smaller communities. The result is that about 50 new houses are either being built or are in preconstruction marketing. 
 The largest new development is the 66-acre Brooke Farm, in St. Davids (part of Radnor Township), once the undeveloped property of the late Joseph N. DuBarry 4th, a prominent lawyer who died in 1993. The three-year-old, 29-house project is a joint venture of three developers. Nelson Vaughn, president of N. Vaughn & Sons of Devon, Pa., one of the builders, said the property -- worth about $8 million with its subdivision approval in place, he said -- would require about $2 million in improvements, including roads, sewer hookups and underground stormwater runoff lines.
Mr. Vaughn said the DuBarry family was willing to accept deferred payment for the property, taking instead a percentage of the sale price of each home. This, Mr. Vaughn said, would give the DuBarrys more than they would have realized for selling the unimproved property and the developers would be unfettered by the carrying charges had a loan been required to buy the land.
So far, two homes at Brooke Farm, priced at $1.1 million and $1.3 million, were sold by Mr. Vaughn's partners, B.J. Drueding Builders of St. Davids and Pohlig Builders of Malvern. There are deposits on four other sites, said Mr. Vaughn. "This will probably be the premier address in this area for a long time," he said. "There aren't many other areas with this location and natural beauty available for new construction. It has both woods and meadow and we were able to save most of the wooded area by putting the homes in the center of the site."
Many Brooke Farm homes are on three-quarter-acre lots that are narrow at the street front but wider at the rear yard.
B.J. Drueding, president of the company that bears his name, said he expected that it would be four years before all the homes were completed and sold. Roads will be paved by May, he said, and the sole model home should be finished by June 1.
BECAUSE it is so hard to get approvals for a subdivision, builders must be willing and able to take a long-term risk. Gaining all the clearances needed to begin construction may take as much as three years, said Todd Pohlig, president of Pohlig Builders. The DuBarry family obtained the subdivision approval for Brooke Farm before selling the site to the builders.
"A good number of large estates came in for subdivision approval just before I got here nine years ago," said Robert Crawford, township manager for Radnor Township. "But every subdivision here is a different process. The review process is often very lengthy and we get a lot of public input."
Voter approval of a $10 million bond issue last year to finance open space preservation and periodic moratoriums on new sewer connections several years ago slowed development, said Lawrence Flick, president of Roach Wheeler Realtors in Devon, a Main Line community. But the shrinking number of available building sites means that former country estates of elite families are undergoing a generational change, as families or heirs sell them to developers if they cannot find a single buyer for a multi-acre property and single residence.
Originally developed in the late 1800's, the Main Line was a refuge from the industrializing city, said Roger Moss, director of the Athenaeum, Philadelphia's library for architecture and rare books. Most of its houses are distinctive, built of rugged looking gray Wissahickon schist stone, which was quarried locally, and the quality of workmanship was high.
Nowadays, Mr. Moss said, "people simply can't afford to build with the kinds of hand-wrought ironwork and leaded windows that were quite common before the Depression."
Today's buyers want the best of both Old World and new construction, said Cynthia Roberts, associate broker at Roach Wheeler, with traditional English manor facades and mature landscaping as well as large rooms with oversize windows and new building technology. The Main Line has a 22-month supply of homes valued at $1 million or more and the popularity of new homes can make older ones a hard sell, she said.
"Certain areas are almost recession-proof," Ms. Roberts said. "but we haven't sold homes in those neighborhoods as quickly as they've come on the market. The cost of ground is so fiercely expensive and the cost of getting a development through township approvals means the builder is forced to market a home at a tremendous price. And a newer home in the lower price ranges in some communities just doesn't exist."
Less than a mile separates homes costing $100,000 and others worth $1 million in Wayne and Bryn Mawr, and students from nearby Haverford College and other schools create an eclectic mix in the town shopping districts. But asking prices moderated following the early-90's recession, Ms. Roberts said, as sellers recognized the relatively flat property values of older homes.
In Lower Merion Township, only about two dozen homes sell for more than $500,000 each year, according to statistics compiled by Realist Inc., a Philadelphia real estate database service. That number dipped to 14 in 1993 but the average price reached $744,000 that year; in 1995, there were 26 sales averaging $700,957. In Radnor Township last year, 76 homes were sold for more than $500,000 -- at an average price of $642,000; in 1994, there were 42 sales at an average of $799,000.
Buyers of new homes on the Main Line are passing up pastures for smaller yards and insisting on modern room layouts and technology, said Louis Nemeth, who is building three homes at Fortenbaugh Woods, a five-acre site here owned by Samuel Fortenbaugh, a Philadelphia attorney. The homes will range in price from $790,000 to $1 million, Mr. Nemeth said.
ONE of Mr. Nemeth's buyers, Toby Charrington, who has lived on the Main Line all his life, plans to sell the Nemeth-designed home he owns in Haverford. He expects to move into his new home in the fall.
"We needed some more room upstairs and came close to adding two new bedrooms and two new bathrooms for our children," said Mr. Charrington of his Haverford home. "We looked at all sorts of houses and made bids on two that would have required a lot of work. My wife preferred a turnkey house and when we heard about this opportunity, we didn't want to miss out."
Mr. Charrington's home will be the second in the Nemeth project, after the 6,000-square-foot model home. That home has four bedrooms and eight bathrooms, with an entire floor that can be a suite for a live-in nanny or visitors. Mr. Nemeth, who has 22 years of experience as a developer and an office in nearby Ardmore, Pa., said he had the patience needed to build on the Main Line. "It's a complicated issue to go through subdivision and convince six or seven different agencies, plus the neighbors," he said. "But owners want to get the most value out of their property by subdividing it."

HEADLINE: On the Track Of a Weekend House That's Affordable

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
THE town of Heath, Mass., is the kind of place where a Nathaniel Hawthorne short story might be filmed. In early spring, its village green appears bleak and pure, an assemblage of white clapboard mid-19th century buildings: a community hall that offers square dancing every other Saturday and a former church without a steeple that now houses the three selectmen, the town clerk, the library and the post office.
Down the street, the old Center School House, its stern white sides also covered with clapboard, is a town museum. 
 "There's no McDonald's here," said Margaret Howland, the president of the Heath Historical Society and the owner of the Deaconess Knapp House, a turn-of-the century shingled cottage in the woods near the green, currently for sale for $69,500.
Though she finds it hard to believe, Mrs. Howland concedes that yes, most people who have looked at her house "are people from out of town, out of state even." But she leaves no doubt in the mind of any outlander who is thinking of Heath as a weekend getaway destination: "Whoever purchases in Heath has to realize there's no store right on the corner, no movie a mile away."
"This is true country living," the historical society president said proudly -- and a bit defiantly.
For those willing to travel an hour or two longer than what many might consider acceptable -- it takes about four hours to drive to Heath from midtown Manhattan -- or for those who will live near, but not in, the pricier towns of northwest Connecticut, or for whom the Hamptons are not the only Long Island address, weekend homes are available for much less money than they might have guessed.
A small white cottage with a fireplace on 12 Berkshire acres and a rutted dirt road near the Heath-Rowe border, for sale at $79,000, might cost triple that amount 30 miles south in Lenox, Mass. A magnificent red 1877 Victorian -- complete with original glassed-front pantry cabinets -- in Falls Village, Conn., might, in neighboring Salisbury, go for double the $375,000 asking price. A shingled 1930's gambrel on a quiet street in Bellport, L.I., is priced at $295,000 -- about half what it might fetch in the village of East Hampton, about 45 minutes farther east.
In Columbia County, N.Y., south of Albany, towns like Chatham and Old Chatham have been "discovered," according to brokers, but prices generally remain lower than they are in comparable towns in neighboring Dutchess or Putnam Counties, which can be an hour or more closer to Manhattan. For many getaway homebuyers, it seems, the difference between arriving at a weekend place at 7:30 Friday night and arriving at 8:30 or 9 is worth a lot of money.
"The drive was the stumbling block -- no question," said Karen Verrill, who with her husband, Charles, a Manhattan literary agent, has bought a stone cottage, on 4.5 acres, that the late theologian Reinhold Niebuhr built in 1933 near the center of Heath.
The Verrills, who have three children and live in Brooklyn, discovered Heath after they answered an advertisement in the Park Slope Food Coop News for a house in nearby Shelburne Falls, a historic riverside town with a burgeoning crafts community. Mr. Verrill mentioned the house to one of his clients, who lives in Ashfield, Mass., and who promptly sent them to look at a place near his own. "We didn't think we wanted to be that far north," said Mrs. Verrill, "but then we heard about the Niebuhr cottage."
WITH directions supplied by the realtor, they drove to the property with their children and wandered around the grounds. Peeking in the windows, they saw a large living room with a fireplace, many small-paned windows and an unrenovated kitchen. From the two porches there was a view of Mount Greylock and a pond.
The next weekend they returned without the children.
The asking price on the seven-room, three-bedroom house was $149,900. They decided they would rent it first with an option to buy. "We thought it was beautiful, but we wanted to see how we liked the town," said Mrs. Verrill, a former dance instructor. "We came to love it. The people are very friendly. There's everyone, from people whose families have been there forever to 60's hippies to university professors -- Williamstown and Bennington are about a half hour away."
In Bellport, L.I., getaway homebuyers can find prices much lower than they are in the Hamptons, and the distance from Manhattan is shorter. Although brokers say that few people who own weekend houses take the train, some Manhattanites keep their cars at their weekend house and travel by train to and from the city, taking a $5 cab ride back and forth to the station.
Most people, however, take the Long Island Expressway. On a recent weekday about noon, it took less than an hour and a half to drive to Bellport, compared with two hours to Southampton. Proponents of Bellport are quick to point out that on a Friday night, the difference can be . . . well, everyone has a story about driving to the Hamptons on a Friday night.
But Bellport is not the Hamptons.
"We're not as upscaly," said Eileen A. Green, who runs a Bellport real estate office. "It's a totally different feel; it's like comparing the Upper East Side of Manhattan to the Upper West Side." Leaving no doubt as to where her sympathies lie, she added: "I consider myself a West Side person."
Bellport also has a more diverse population both economically and racially, she said, and a second-home ownership rate of only 15 percent, as opposed to over 50 percent in the Hamptons.
The racial and economic diversity of Bellport was one reason Donald Bernstein, a Manhattan lawyer, and Jo Ellen Finkel, a doctor, chose Bellport, they said. They had rented for several years in Weston, Conn., a scenic village in northwest Connecticut. "That's about the same distance from Manhattan as Bellport," Mr. Bernstein said. "We wanted to be within striking distance of the city because we use the house for weekends all year round."
The town of Bellport, which has several small beaches for children, also owns a large beach on Fire Island, and Mr. Bernstein said the 10-minute ride on the ferry, used only by Bellport residents and their guests, is one of the summertime treats. "The golf course is also owned by the town," he said, "so you don't have some of the negative aspects of private clubs."
The Bernsteins bought a pristine white colonial-style house, built about 1845, on 2.7 acres in the village. The house is reached by a long drive back from the main street. It had once been the caretaker's house on an estate, and it was moved to its present site in 1992, at which time it was given elegant landscaping, a circular drive and a swimming pool -- along with a new foundation, new plumbing and new electricity.
Although Mr. Bernstein declined to disclose what he paid for the house, houses in similar locations in Bellport usually bring between $600,000 and $700,000. "To get something comparable in the Hamptons, you would pay at least 30 to 50 percent more than we paid," Mr. Bernstein said.
In Bellport, a seeker after the ideal weekend house could pick a tiny vinyl-sided bungalow at the end of the cul-de-sac on the less desirable side of town, complete with fireplace and back lawn ($149,000). The buyer with more to spend might prefer one of the large old shingled houses on a street leading to the water (usually $600,000 to $800,000).
And although Bellport residents stress the town's "low key" outlook, it is not without its own celebrities, Ms. Green said: Charlie Rose, the television interviewer, bought a house about a year ago for $850,000; Isabella Rossellini, the actress, along with the photographers Bruce Weber and Steven Meisel, own property in town.
Every weekender's town, it seems, has its own glossily painted sheen -- or a deliberate lack of one -- and Columbia County's most sought-after towns seem to revel in their sparser, generally more raffish look.
In Chatham, N.Y., besides the shoestore, the tack shop, the kitchen store, the Chinese takeout and the bookstore, there is the Crandall Movie House, currently showing "Mr. Holland's Opus" for a $3 admission charge. "The price just went up from $2.50," said Audrey G. Schoenfeld, a real estate agent.
House prices have leveled off over the last few years, Ms. Schoenfeld said, and are moving slowly upward, especially in the county's "blue chip" towns like Malden Bridge and Old Chatham, hamlets in Chatham, and the Spencertown hamlet in Austerlitz.
The Chathams are smack in the center of horse country, and property often comes with extensive acreage. In Chatham, horse lovers could find a 92-acre Quaker farmstead off Country Road 13 for $645,000. And last year, William and Joy Howe of Scarsdale bought Day-O Farm, once Harry Belafonte's compound, on 140 acres for $870,000.
The mid-19th-century white house has grace but is not overwhelming in size. There is a pool, a pool house with sleeping quarters, an elaborate billiards hall above the garage, a refined smaller house near the road for the caretaker, and a new guest house high on a ridge.
But even in the Chathams, there is room for weekenders seeking something less than an estate. Last year, Lauren Letelier and Chris Atkins, a young couple from New York City, found an 1833 saltbox on Shaker Museum Road in Malden Bridge, known as one of the nicest roads in town, for only $130,000. Now the two are up to their necks in sheetrock dust as they supervise a team of workers who, judging from the camaraderie, have become their friends.
And in Claverack, a town with a more blue-collar character, Garrick Utley, the broadcaster, is selling his former stagecoach tavern on the Old Post Road, with five-and-a-half acres -- a primitive masterpiece with a stream -- for $349,000. One woman from the area, who is house hunting and had heard about the house, said she eliminated it for two reasons: She doesn't like Claverack, and she has been told the house needs a lot of work.
But it has been restored to its early and esthetically correct condition. The wide floorboards have been left unsanded, mantles have been taken down to their original shades of blue and green, kitchen cupboards have been custom built from old boards in a ruined mill across the street. Actually, the house comes with several high-tech features, including an automatic irrigation system fed from the stream.
MOVING closer to the posh northwestern corner of Connecticut, there is an 1800 center-hall house just outside Millerton, N.Y., in Dutchess County, with a primitive Palladian window and a tennis court across the road. The house comes with 17 acres; the owners are asking $685,000.
Robinson Leech, who owns a real estate company in Lakeville, Conn., and who has listed the house, said that a similar house in Salisbury or Sharon -- two highly groomed, highly priced Litchfield County villages only 10 minutes away -- might come on the market for anywhere from $795,000 to $895,000 "and might sell for $650,000." He estimated that the Millerton house, which has been on the market about a year, might eventually trade in the "mid-fives."
Why the difference? Partly taxes, Mr. Leech said. New York has a piggy-backed school tax, which brings the Millerton property's taxes to just over $6,000 a year. (Taxes for a 47-acre farm in Sharon with carriage barns and stable are $4,700.)
But there is also a more esthetic difference. While the old colonial-style house is in a historic district and surrounded by lovely homes, Millerton has a main street with a Burger King, several car dealerships, a movie theater, oil-change shops, a diesel tune-up station and a car wash, among other businesses.
"Many people run over the line to get their oil changed," said Mr. Leech, primly.
About six miles from Salisbury is Falls Village, a tiny town with no strip malls or diesel tune-up places, a charming enclave where the prices reflect a central point: It isn't Sharon or Salisbury.
In Falls Village, which like the other towns is a little more than two hours from New York City, a wreck of a farmhouse and an old red barn on 78 acres on a winding, hilly side road sold last fall for $350,000. And another is for sale. On the same road, Undermountain Road, there is a 1900's Cape Cod-style house -- this one in good condition -- with five rooms, totaling 1,700 to 1,800 square feet.
This house comes with 15 acres on both sides of the road, a separate 18- by 30-foot library "house" or guest room and a 24- by 50-foot kennel/garage, all for $350,000. An additional 75 acres is available for $2,000 an acre. The listing sheet on the house points out that development of much of the surrounding land is restricted -- another advantage to owning second-home property in this part of Connecticut.
"There is an emphasis on preserving farmland, and the state has actually bought the easements on a great many of the properties here," said John G. Borden, president of Albert Borden Realtors on Lakeville's Main Street. In Salisbury, he said, fully 20 percent of the land is in conservation, either through easements bought by the state or easements or land donated by individual owners. (The state, he said, pays anywhere from $3,000 to $9,000 an acre, depending on appraisals, which are often fiercely negotiated.)
One estate that recently sold for $650,000 -- the 148-acre Stillwater Farm -- is so restricted that the property can never be subdivided, according to Mr. Borden, whose father started selling real estate here in 1950.
One property currently for sale is a 1900 gambrel barn with only one and a half acres that abuts the Sharon Reservoir and overlooks hundreds of protected acres. The 6,500-square-foot, 11-room barn with its breath-catching views was redone over two decades ago, and its interior -- full of beiges and chrome and built-ins -- is a testament to that period.
"It certainly does look like the 70's," conceded Mr. Borden, who pointed out that the price -- now reduced to $375,000 from $445,000 -- reflects the redecorating that many buyers might wish to undertake. (As a comparison, a 19th-century Federal-style farmhouse on 5.7 acres of lawn and trees on Sugar Hill Road in Salisbury, also with a pool, is for sale for $695,000.)
THE market here, according to local realtors, is as flat as the second-home market almost everywhere in the region (an exception is apparently the Hamptons, where agents say prices are up 15 percent over last year).
Nevertheless, Mr. Borden said that at least the most expensive properties were starting to move: in the last two years, there were a dozen sales in the area for more than $1 million, and three properties sold for more than $3 million.
But there are plenty of buyers with nowhere near $3 million to spend.
"We didn't think we could pay as much as we did for the house in Heath," said Mrs. Verrill, who paid $140,000 in January. "But, well, my husband made one very good deal, and then we could."
Mr. Verrill said he preferred to think of the cottage as a "second home, not a weekend home, so we don't have the pressure of thinking we have to go every weekend."
A weekend in the cottage with three children, ages 8 to 12, makes inviting weekend guests "not always advisable," he said, and the four-hour drive is "an impediment which allows us to be generous with our invitations, in full confidence that no one will take us up on our offers."
Buying groceries is a problem the Verrills haven't quite solved. They are debating between loading up the car in Park Slope or stopping at one of the two supermarkets about 15 or 20 minutes from the house. Things like doing the laundry and plowing the snow are still an adventure. "There's a wonderful Laundromat nearby, and we're still dazzled by the sight of 12 driers," he said with a laugh.
"We really didn't think too much about it beforehand," he added. "We flat out fell in love with the town and then we flat out fell in love with the house."
For others who don't mind the four-hour drive, there's still the 1820 Colonial overlooking the mountains, with 12 acres, available for $75,000. "Winterize it," reads the listing sheet from Upton-Massamont Realtors in Shelburne Falls, "and you're only a hop, skip and a jump from excellent skiing. This one is loaded with rural charm."

HEADLINE: JERSEY;
The End of History, the Start of Tourism

BYLINE: By JOE SHARKEY 

 BODY:
DR. JOSEPH SALVATORE, the chairman of the State Historical Commission, felt a little awkward the other morning. He was standing alone beside a winding road with a picket sign that said: "Gov. Whitman: Don't Let the Commission Become History."
He waved the sign when the car bearing Mrs. Whitman glided by, delivering her up the hill to the Seasons Resort at Great Gorge in McAfee. The Governor had come to give the keynote address at the 1996 New Jersey Conference on Tourism, where she spoke glowingly about the "unlimited possibilities" awaiting corporations that join the state in "partnerships" to redefine the culture of tourism. 
 Dr. Salvatore, a soft-spoken 65-year-old orthopedic surgeon and lifelong student of history, knows that this redefinition means the end of 28 years of scholarly contribution to New Jersey tourism by the Historical Commission, which provides small grants for academic research, seminars and publications -- the down-in-the-stacks academic work that builds the foundation for tourism at historic sites.
Now, with Disney writing history for tourism, the commission has been criticized as having no "public visibility." This year, the commission's budget was $772,000. Governor Whitman has decreed that it be abolished in her new budget.
"As of July 1, we're dead," Dr. Salvatore said. "The Whitman administration desires a change in the way history is being presented. They want more of what it called public history -- historical re-enactments, that kind of thing."
Mark Lender, a historian at Kean College who has worked with the commission, added, "What we're losing is the scholarly infrastructure, the work promot ing an intelligent blend of history and tourism."
This work is indeed without glamour, he acknowledged. "You don't throw a wine-and-cheese party for the officials when somebody publishes a bibliography. Nobody gives a gala when a manuscript guide comes out."
More than ever, today's domestic tourist economy is driven by entertainment events. As they juggle work and family schedules, Americans have been been taking shorter, but more frequent, tourist trips.
In New Jersey, the seashore accounts for well over half of the $23 billion spent on travel last year. Atlantic City accounted for more than half of the seashore spending. After the shore, the next largest tourism category is called "events" -- sports events concerts, festivals, field trips and exhibits.
Corporate "event" sponsorship now permeates tourism. In 1984, corporate sponsorship of events defined as tourist in nature was $350 million -- 90 percent of it for sports. Last year, corporate sponsorship was $4.7 billion -- 66 percent for sports but 25 percent on destination events like festivals, historical exhibits and cultural entertainment.
Corporate involvement with cultural tourism used to come from company philanthropy departments looking for ways to dignify their image. Now, experts say, the underwriting mostly comes out of market and advertising departments demanding immediate benefits.
During last week's tourism conference in McAfee, corporate marketing dominated much of the talk. At a seminar on how tourist attractions can thrive with corporate tie-ins, John LeBaron, a marketing director for Continental Airlines, spoke enthusiastically of a current benefit of the airline's recent $30 million deal to put its name on the Brendan Byrne Arena: "Having tickets for our clients for the Final Four," he said. Elsewhere, scalpers were reported to be charging up to $8,000 for a ticket to the basketball championship this weekend, since only 1,000 tickets were available to the general public.
While corporate clients at the high end of the new tourism market are favored with wine-and-cheese receptions in skyboxes, the low end -- student field trips -- is also being courted. At a seminar on how to "enter the educational market," Karen S. Traa, the owner of eight McDonald's restaurants in Atlantic County, said that McDonald's, which encourages its managers to join local school boards, has developed an extensive catalogue of cultural materials, as well as a promotional tie-in that offers free coupons for students who visit participating tourist attractions.
"A few years ago, it was very dificult to get involved in school systems," she said. "Now with the budget cuts, it's becoming much easier to build partnerships. It's a terrific key to unlock the door."

HEADLINE: New Takes on the Melting Pot

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
WHEN Judy Sulik moved to Bridgeport from the suburbs a few years ago she went exploring her new hometown and was amazed. Along with the expected Italian restaurants and Irish taverns she found a veritable United Nations of cuisines. Around every corner the native food of yet another ethnic group was being served.
And so, "without leaving my hometown" Mrs. Sulik turned her discovery into a combination international cookbook and restaurant guide, "An Adventure for Your Palate," collecting recipes from Bridgeport's ethnic restaurants introduced by a brief profile of each establishment. 
 Irish and Italian food are represented, but also Brazilian, Bulgarian, Jamaican, Mexican, Portuguese and Thai. Bridgeport, it seems, is surprisingly cosmopolitan. "That's not the image many people have of it," Mrs. Sulik said.
Nor of Connecticut as a whole, for that matter. But in fact, the state is reflecting a 10-year wave of immigration that brought in tens of thousands of new residents from all over the world, even while the total population declined by a few thousand.
The newcomers have brought their music, sports and food, widening horizons in a state that fancies itself "the land of steady habits" and stages most of its official celebrations around historic Yankee traditions.
Typifying the newcomers are four immigrant groups: Brazilians, Irish, Hungarians and Vietnamese.
For example, this month an Irish musical group, Big Geraniums, played "Gaelic rock" in Fairfield. And the large Brazilian population in Danbury held an indoor tournament for soccer, a wildly popular sport in Brazil. In June, both ethnic groups will hold three-day festivals in Connecticut open to the general public.
While recent Irish immigrants add a relatively subtle touch of the modern to the traditions of native-born Irish-Americans, the bouncy samba rhythms and spicy meat dishes served up by the Brazilians are standouts in the new cultural mix.
The Immigration and Naturalization Service recorded 91,489 foreigners entering the United States between 1985 and 1994 who listed Connecticut as their destination, but many of those were single individuals making multiple trips or paying a visit and returning home, so the actual number of resident aliens in the state is certainly smaller.
In the five years starting 1990, according to recent Census Bureau figures, the influx of foreign immigrants was 36,963, statewide. Immigrants interviewed for this article were living in Connecticut throughout the 10-year immigration wave, and their observations confirmed I.N.S. records indicating that arrivals nearly doubled between 1985 and 1991, the peak year, and has tapered down since then, probably due to the state's sluggish economy.
These recent immigrants nearly offset an equally large migration of native-born people out of the state in search of jobs elsewhere. That immigrants replaced native-born residents, rather than just adding to them, intensifies their cultural effect, especially in the cities where most have settled.
"It's not numerically a flood, but it's an important pattern," said Thomas Steahr, professor of demography at the University of Connecticut. Professor Steahr said the traditional ethnic mixture of Connecticut leaned heavily toward western and central Europeans, African-Americans and Puerto Ricans. But the new immigrants are largely from Asia, Africa, South America and eastern Europe.
The Connecticut Department of Education reported that 95 different languages were spoken by children in the state's public schools in the 1994-95 school year. Federal census data lists as major categories, white, African-American, Hispanic, and "other minorities."
"That 'other minorities' category has gotten quite a bit more diverse,' " said Thomas Murphy, a spokesman for the department.
Many new immigrants have come to the state because of Connecticut's growing foreign trade. But more typical are people like Carlos Coelho, who moved to Bridgeport from Governador Valadares, Brazil, in 1983, recently divorced and looking for opportunity. He chose Bridgeport because his sister, Necy Fernandes, a television studio-set decorator for the decorating and home entertaining expert Martha Stewart, lived nearby.
Bridgeport and Danbury are attractive destinations for Brazilians because both cities had long-established Portuguese communities who speak the same language.
When Mr. Coelho arrived there were only about 35 Brazilian families in Bridgeport. Now he estimates its Brazilian population to be about 1,700. Danbury's is even larger, around 4,000, said Fernando Flores, who arrived in 1988 with his wife, Angela, to join relatives.
Mr. Coelho said he watched as Brazilian immigration increased. "From 1987 the population started to grow, and it slowed down in 1992," he said.
They were skilled workers in Brazil. Mr. Coelho was a cash register mechanic, Mr. Flores an electrician and Mrs. Flores a dressmaker. But Brazil's economy was poor and their prospects were dim. After years of working and saving they have opened small businesses of their own. The Flores own a cleaning service and a party decorating business. Mr. Coelho has a travel agency catering primarily to other Brazilians. His brother, Cleber, also operates a travel agency and started the Barriga-Cheia restaurant, which appears in Mrs. Sulik's book. Mr. Coelho has remarried, having met his wife, Glenda, a Chilean immigrant, while learning English in night school.
Their stories are repeated often -- the tales of skilled, educated people who are looking for better lives and join relatives and friends from their native countries who have already established themselves. But with each nationality the motivation to emigrate may be different.
For Irish immigrants, Connecticut offers higher wages. For Hungarians, the social and economic disruptions resulting from the fall of Communism, as well as their new freedom to migrate, are the motivations. For the Vietnamese, Communism still remains, which is cause enough.
Johnny Huynh came to Connecticut in 1986 as a teen-ager, after two aimless years in Arkansas. His uncle, who lived in Stamford, got him a job at Pitney Bowes. Mr. Huynh spent much of his pay bringing the rest of his family to Connecticut, and last summer he opened a restaurant, Pho Que Huong. His family operates the business, and many of his customers are Vietnam War veterans who never lost their taste for Vietnamese food.
Mr. Huynh said Bridgeport is a second American destination for many Vietnamese, who move there from California, New York and the South, and who, like him, believe their chances for success are better in Connecticut. "There's already an established community here, so that's why they come," he said.
Jacqueline Wong, a Vietnamese refugee of Chinese extraction who is Mr. Huynh's fiance, noted that the city's other established groups include Koreans, Taiwanese, Chinese, Cambodians, Laotians and Thais. Each group is very tight-knit, rarely socializing with the others, she said. The University of Bridgeport is the center for inter-group socializing that does occur.
Ms. Wong said each nationality has its own social club that hosts ethnic festivals and parties at which the different Asian groups sample each other's cultures.
At the University of Connecticut in Storrs, the Asian Center, which opened in 1993, is trying to make Asian culture more accessible to native-born state residents, the center's director, Angela Rola, said. It offers exhibits of Asian-American art and history, music, literature and other cultural events, as well as a place for Asian students to socialize.
Ms. Rola said Asians are the largest racial minority at the Storrs campus. Eleven percent of the students are Asian-Americans or Asian nationals. The university offers courses in Hindi, Japanese, Chinese, Vietnamese, Korean and Tagalog, the language of the Philippines. Ms. Rola, a second-generation Filipino, said foreign trade produces demand for the new immigrants.
"I get calls from major corporations to see if we have experts who can give cultural crash courses on different nations in Asia," she said.
Bridgeport and its suburbs have the second-largest concentration of Hungarians in the United States (after Cleveland), making Connecticut a popular destination for newer immigrants.
Joseph F. Balogh, a Stratford resident who is active in the Pannonia American Hungarian Club, which helps these immigrants start new lives, said recent immigrants have fled the high unemployment and crime that troubles post-Communist Hungary. Many of them lived in Romania and Czechoslovakia, before continuing on to the United States. "Most of them have relatives already here," Mr. Balogh said.
Relatively few in number, the Hungarian newcomers quickly absorbed by the older Hungarian immigrant community, dominated by refugees from the 1956 Soviet invasion of Hungary, and make little cultural impact, Mr. Balogh said. But they do add to the audience for Hungarian culture and cuisine. Hungarian orchestras regularly perform at Tomlinson Middle School in Fairfield Center, which is walking distance from the Pearl of Budapest, a Hungarian restaurant.
The impact of the Irish newcomers of the last 10 years reflects change in Ireland itself, according to John Smith and Lena Smith, cousins and partners in the Black Rock Castle, an Irish restaurant that appears in Mrs. Sulik's book.
Mr. Smith said Ireland has moved in the last two decades from an isolated agricultural nation to one strongly involved in tourism and manufacturing, and reforming its educational system. Irish emigres are much better educated and skilled than they were 25 years ago when he and his cousin arrived. "Up to 15 years ago there wouldn't have been many new Irish, and the old folks carried on Irish traditions as they knew them," he said.
Ms. Smith said the newcomers emphasize Irish culture as they have lived it, "rather than just the clubby feeling between people who share a lineage." There's also more demand for importing Irish entertainment, including many of the island's best performers.
Professor Steahr said one of the most remarkable aspects of the immigration is the extent to which it has gone unnoticed by native-born residents. "It takes a period of time before the in-migration begins to be noticeable," he said.
The insular nature of immigrant communities, language barriers and native-born Americans' ignorance of other cultures are all reasons. But Ms. Rola said she believes that eventually people will begin to recognize each other and enjoy their differences. "The buzz word used to be 'melting pot,' but now we're embracing multiculturalism, diversity," she said. "It's got to make a great impact."

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:

FILMS FROM HONG KONG
A comprehensive study of movies made in Hong Kong begins this week at Yale in New Haven. The series, at the Whitney Humanities Center, is free to the public. Co-sponsors include the Yale Council of East Asian Studies, the Hong Kong Economic and Trade office in Manhattan, the Yale-China Association and Yale Film Study Center. 
 Five films made between 1987 and 1994 will be shown over the next two weeks, and on the final day, April 14, Barbara Scharres, director of the film center at the School of the Art Institute in Chicago, will lecture on "Current Trends in Hong Kong Cinema" at 1 P.M. A panel discussion will conclude the series at 7:30 P.M.
The first film, on Tuesday at 7:30, is "A Chinese Ghost Story" with Leslie Cheung (of "Farewell My Concubine") as a tax collector who seeks shelter from a storm in a deserted temple haunted by a beautiful spirit.
"God of Gamblers," on Wednesday at the same time, is one of Hong Kong's highest grossing films.
On April 11 at 7:30, "Green Snake" is the feature, based on a Chinese folk tale and the Beijing opera about two sister snakes who have practiced for centuries to become human.
On April 14 at 2 P.M., "He's a Woman, She's a Man" will be shown -- a comedy about three people falling in love with each other.
The final film, "The Bodyguard From Beijing," concerns a mainland Chinese bodyguard assigned to protect a fashionable Hong Kong woman who is a sequestered witness in a trial. For more information, the numbers are 432-9392 or 432-3426.

JACKIE ROBINSON
"Jackie Robinson and the Integration of Professional Baseball" is the subject to be discussed on Tuesday at 7:30 in the Gengras Student Union of the University of Hartford. The speaker will be Warren Goldstein, author of "Playing for Keeps: A History of Early Baseball," which won the 1989 award for the best book of sports history from the North American Society for Sport History.
Mr. Goldstein, who received advance degrees in American studies from Yale, is to join the University of Hartford faculty as a professor of American history this fall.
The university is at 200 Bloomfield Avenue in West Hartford, and admission is free. The number is (860) 768-4806 for more information.

SHORT SUBJECTS
"All in the Timing," comprising six comic short works, previews on Tuesday at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven. Written by David Ives, the show is said to be the most-produced theater piece of 1995, having had 600 performances at Primary Stages Off Broadway, as well as productions in Vienna, Berlin, Sydney, Montreal, Paris and London. Individual segments include "Sure Thing," concerning romance the second, third and fourth time around, as well as "Words, Words, Words," in which three chimpanzees are locked in a room with three typewriters.
"The Universal Language," is about a language that no one can speak but which turns out to hold the meaning of life. The remaining segments, called "Degas, C'est Moi," "Foreplay, or the Art of the Fugue" and "Variations on the Death of Trotsky," are equally arcane.
Officially opening on April 10, the show will run through May 5. Performances are at 7 P.M. on Tuesday and at 8 P.M. Wednesday through Friday. Saturday performances are at 4 and 8:30; Sunday at 2 and 7. Weekday matinees at 2 P.M. are scheduled on April 17 and May 1. Tickets at $20 to $24 for previews and $28 to $38 for the regular run may be reserved by calling 787-4282.

'UNCLE BOB'
Austin Pendleton, playwright, actor, director and artistic director of the Circle Repertory Theater in Manhattan, will have the title role in his own comedy, "Uncle Bob," opening at the Hutensky Theater, 233 Pearl Street in downtown Hartford on Friday.
Bob, who has AIDS, lives like a hermit, albeit an abrasively funny one, in the West Village in Manhattan. His nephew Josh takes it upon himself to hitchhike to New York from the Midwest to care for his uncle and perhaps resolve some of his own problems.
The play has been produced by Theater Works under the direction of Steve Campo. Performances are on Wednesday through Saturday at 8, Sunday at 2:30, through May 5. Ticket prices range from $16 to $19 with discounts available for students and people over 65. A surcharge of $3 is applied for some seating. The number is 527-7838 for reservations.

CRAFTS CLASSES
 The Brookfield Craft Center, in an old grist mill complex on Route 25, will hold an open house today from 1 to 4 P.M., when 15 artisans will demonstrate skills they teach in year-round classes.
Loom weaving will be demonstrated by Barbara Dull; Jody Hyman will focus on spinning; metal jewelry will be made by Anne Marie Cuiffini, and Hattie Newman will work with beads. Wheel-thrown pottery by Kristin Muller and Chris Alexiades, wood turning on the lathe by Angelo Iafrete, cabinet making by Larry Hendricks, and decorative furniture painting by Carol Sue Roberts are also on the agenda.
A free course will be awarded from a list of visitors who register for the drawing. The number for more information is 775-4526. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: A Proposed Water Sale Stirs Opposition

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
WHY the anger? Why an alliance with New York City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi? At issue is water and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposed sale of the New York City water system to the city's Water Board, a move that the Westchester Chamber of Commerce here opposes. The Chamber of Commerce has joined Mr. Hevesi in his legal fight against the sale.
"Taxation without representation is what it is," said Harold E. Vogt, president and chief executive officer of the Chamber of Commerce. "If the sale goes through it will be at the expense of all Westchester water users, both residential and business. They will be adversely affected. If Mayor Giuliani's plan succeeds, Westchesterites can expect to pay water rate increases of anywhere from $17 million to $45 million over the 30-year term of the bonds sold to finance the sale of the system." 
 Mr. Giuliani hopes to realize $2.3 billion from the sale of the water system to the water board, a quasi-independent agency, which leases the system from the city. The sale will give the city an infusion of much needed cash, said Dennis B. Kremer, head of the Economic Development Department of the County Chamber of Commerce.
Under Mr. Giuliani's plan, the Water Board would raise $2.3 billion through the sale of bonds, but Mr. Hevesi refused to give the approval necessary for the Water Board to sell the bonds.
"What it tells me is that the Mayor needs money badly, and he's trying to find 'creative ways' to raise cash," said Mr. Kremer, a certified public accountant and a partner in the accounting firm of Marshal Granger in Mamaroneck. "There's no question in my mind this is an attempt at creative financing by a government that has a desperate need to find new sources of revenue."
Observing that increases in Westchester water rates do not include projections of other costs like maintenance, which rate payers may be facing over the next 30 years, Mr. Vogt said: "Several aspects of the scheme are even more troubling. For instance, about $1 billion of the sale proceeds would go into New York City's capital improvements fund to pay for things like renovation of the city schools. What that means is that Westchester County businesses and residents will be taxed to pay ongoing New York City financial obligations that are totally unrelated to Westchester County. This sets a very dangerous precedent."
Mr. Giuliani's plan with its imposition of $7 million to $45 million and additional charges and fees for water to the people of Westchester County is contrary to the law, said Andrew J. Goodman, a partner in the Manhattan law firm of Rosner Bresler Goodman & Bucholtz. Mr. Goodman, who lives in Edgemont, is representing the Chamber of Commerce pro bono in the action.
Originally, the Chamber of Commerce was not named as a defendant, Mr. Goodman said. "Because we want to go on record in opposing the sale," he said, "we have filed papers that allow us either to be named as a codefendant in the proceedings or to have our position acknowledged in the official record as a 'friend of the court.' "
Mr. Goodman added: "People in Westchester will be paying for something for which they receive no concomitant benefit. This sets a dangerous precedent."
He emphasized that Mr. Hevesi has opposed and withheld his approval of Mayor Giuliani's plan, which Mr. Hevesi called a financial gimmick that would cause the city to lose direct control of a valuable resource. "The Mayor counteracted by instituting a suit against the Controller to force his approval in court," Mr. Goodman said. "But on March 1, New York County Supreme Court Judge Jane S. Solomon dismissed the complaint. However, on March 12, Mayor Giuliani filed a notice of appeal, so it's not over yet."
The New York City water system, a network of reservoirs, pipelines and sewers, includes the Croton Reservoir and the Catskill water system in Sullivan and Greene Counties. The New York City Water Board buys the water wholesale and sells the water to other water companies and municipalities. They in turn supply water to New York City residents and to 85 percent of Westchester.
"I think people in Westchester should be up in arms about the proposed sale," Mr. Kremer said. "But the reaction from the county and other trade and professional groups has been muted. I imagine because it's not a painful issue yet. When it becomes painful, it will be too late to do anything. The cost of living in Westchester and doing business here will go even higher if the sale goes through."
Mr. Vogt said: "I'm not trying to pass judgment on how Mayor Giuliani solves his financial problems in New York City. I just don't want people in Westchester to have to pay for benefits to New York City. This proposal will have a significant economic impact on Westchester County, and it demands our attention and action."
As for county officials, although they are carefully watching the situation, they are not entirely convinced that Mr. Giuliani's plan would lead to excessive water-rate increases for the county's customers, said Marc Moran, senior assistant to County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke.
"We're not concerned about New York City's attempt to raise money through the sale of the water system; that's their business," Mr. Moran said. "But we are very concerned about any increase in rates the sale would bring to Westchester customers. We have been in touch with Mayor Giuliani, and he has assured us that the sale will not increase rates to Westchester customers. We have asked for detailed information on the exact impact on water users in Westchester, and when we review it, then the County Executive and the County Attorney will decide if there is any role for us to take in the on-going litigation."
Water has always been controversial, said Gerard T. Koeppel, a Manhattan writer whose as yet untitled book on the early history of the New York City water supply will be published by Princeton University Press next year. "For example," he said, "when water supply systems were privately owned, financial interests came before the public interest. In 1799, for instance, when Aaron Burr got control of a water company in New York, he generated enough money from it to start a private bank, which since has evolved into Chase Manhattan Bank."
In the early 1880's when Baltimore had a private water company, Mr. Koeppel said, "the water quality was poor and the rates were excessive."
"By contrast," he continued, "Philadelphia with its public water supply had good water and was considered to be a healthier and more desirable city to live in and to do business in."

HEADLINE: TV RATINGS;
How Violence Might Pay

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "TV Turns to an Era of Self-Control" [March 17], Mark Landler overlooked one aspect of the difficulty of rating programs: the possible economic benefits of a violence rating. 
 As part of the recent National Television Violence Study, research we did here at the University of Wisconsin showed that the label "parental discretion advised" and the M.P.A.A. ratings PG-13 and R significantly increased boys' desire to see programs and movies. The effect was particularly strong among boys 10 to 14 years old. Industry executives may soon weigh this potential market increase against fears of advertiser pullout.
 
JOANNE CANTOR
Madison, Wis.
 
The writer is a professor of communication arts at the University of Wisconsin, Madison.

HEADLINE: YOUNG NEW JERSEY;
Pass the Mackerel and Toss In Some Pasta: Grocery Clerks for a Good Cause

BYLINE: By SUSAN JO KELLER 

DATELINE: HILLSIDE

 BODY:
Coffee cans were flying through the air in one room, pieces of pasta in another. The coffee was headed in the right direction: into boxes of food destined for soup kitchens, homeless shelters and senior citizen centers. And the pasta -- well, it may be inevitable that a little food will fly when 180 eighth graders get together, even for a good cause.
The students had come from four Bergen County communities to work in the 280,000-square-foot Hillside warehouse of the Community Foodbank of New Jersey. But there was more going on than first met the eye. While food was being sorted out -- canned mackerel here, Typhoon Blasters drinks there -- students from different towns, different races and different economic backgrounds were being mixed together. 
 The session on Tuesday took place because Dr. Mat Glowski, principal of the Alpine Public School, thinks it's important to break down stereotypes as the students head for more integrated high schools and eventually into adulthood.
Does one day out of the school year make a difference? Dr. Glowski obviously thinks it does. "They see they can work together," he said. "If you can do it once, you can do it again. It's an example to adults, too."
(He didn't mention -- he didn't have to -- the long-running, often angry debate about how to desegregate Dwight Morrow High School in Englewood and whether the state can force other Bergen County school districts to be part of the solution.)
The noise level told much of the story. As the students, from Englewood, Englewood Cliffs, Tenafly and Alpine, entered the warehouse, they sounded like exactly what they were: teen-agers liberated from the classroom for half a day. In a word, loud.
Things quieted considerably when they were divided into work teams and told to stand beside someone from another school. The goal was to learn that person's name and hobbies, and then tell the rest of the group. Fortunately, the students were also wearing name tags; many of the introductions were mumbled toward the floor, lost in a circle of shuffling feet.
The noise level picked up again when the work started. Voices called out expiration dates on packages, yelled for another box to fill up with iced-tea mix, alerted a supervisor that a damaged item had to go to the "bad box." Predictably, perhaps, girls got down to work more quickly and quietly than boys. Predictably, too, some of the students soon rearranged themselves so they could work and talk with the classmates they had come with. And, yes, a few noodles were flung at friends in the room where students were scooping broken pasta from a box as big as a hot tub and repackaging it in smaller bags.
There were also a few groans about "gross" food. The mackerel would definitely not have been a hit in the school lunchroom. And some of the students assigned to pack detergents and other cleaning products, a dusty and sticky job, looked longingly across the room at classmates who could work without protective aprons and gloves. But that didn't stop them from filling box after box (almost all labeled "bananas") that soon rose in stacks taller than some of the students from pallets on the floor.
And then it was time to get back on the buses and go back to school.
Ninety minutes of work translated into about 2,000 pounds of packaged food, said Meara Nigro, a Foodbank spokeswoman. Combined with the food packed by a group that came the week before, that's enough to fill an 18-wheel tractor trailer truck.
Enough to make a difference? A student on the March 19 field trip told a teacher it was the best he had ever been on because "we're doing something for others." The students there on Tuesday were quick to make the same point, although they were generally silent on whether the day was meeting any of the goals Dr. Glowski had set when he began the Foodbank outings last year. (The picture will be clearer when he reads the surveys they filled out after the trip.)
Kathleen DiChiara, executive director of the Foodbank, had no doubt about the day's value. She counts on volunteers -- more than 6,000 people who contribute 50,000 hours a year -- to help distribute up to 14 million pounds of donated food and grocery items to 1,500 New Jersey charities each year. Based on other groups' experience, she's sure the students went home thinking about the hungry, about one another, about her own deliberately diverse staff. And she knows that some of them, and their parents, will almost certainly be back.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Students packing boxes on a field trip to the Community Foodbank in Hillside. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
FUNDS WATCH

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:

Finding Bargains Against the Flow
T. Rowe Price Equity Income buys stocks with high yields when Wall Street frowns on them and then sells after market sentiment reverses. With this strategy, the fund's longtime manager, Brian Rogers, generated a 32.9 percent return for the year that ended in January. His long-term performance is notable, too. For the last 3, 5 and 10 years, the fund has finished in the top 10 percent of its peer group, according to The Value Line Mutual Fund Advisor, a New York newsletter. 
 Though they are rarely the best performers in soaring markets, equity-income funds tend to provide a cushion for investors in down markets. That is because blue-chip stocks with high yields generally hold up well when there is a so-called flight to quality.
At Mr. Rogers's fund, the typical holding is the stock of a company that has a relatively strong position in its industry but has been a poor performer recently, making its yield high relative to the market.
Right now, Mr. Rogers is selling some of the financial, health care and large consumer stocks that produced last year's strong return, Value Line reported.
He is said to be moving into cyclical issues, which tend to rise with the economy. The prices of cyclical stocks have generally fallen over the last six months because of investor concern about earnings this year.
 
New Managers
Jerry A. Webman, managing director and chief fixed-income strategist at Prudential Mutual Funds, joins Oppenheimer Funds as director of tax-exempt fixed-income investments.
Christine Thompson and Ian Spreadbury have taken over Fidelity Global Bond, succeeding Jonathan Kelly, who remains a foreign bond analyst at Fidelity. Ms. Thompson continues to run the Fidelity Intermediate Bond, United States Bond Index and Target Timeline funds. Mr. Spreadbury has been a portfolio manager for Fidelity International since 1995.
Fidelity Short-Term World Bond has also changed hands. Charles Morrison and Luc Huyghebaert have replaced Scott Kuldell, who remains at Fidelity in fixed-income research. Mr. Morrison also manages three other Fidelity bond funds. Mr. Huyghebaert has been a fixed-income portfolio manager for Fidelity International since 1994.
 
In Brief
AMT Capital merged with Lehman Selected Growth Stock and was renamed AMT Capital Fund U.S. Selected Growth Portfolio.
T. Rowe Price has updated its tax guide, available free by calling (800) 541-8354.
The Liberty Financial Companies, the parent of Stein Roe & Farnham, has agreed to acquire Independent Financial Marketing Group, which specializes in providing mutual fund and annuity marketing programs to financial institutions. And Stein Roe & Farnham is acquiring KJMM Investment Management Company, a San Francisco money manager with $420 million under management.
Twentieth Century Mutual Funds has started a 401(k) investing program for companies with $3 million to $10 million in retirement plan assets.
A free financial planning workbook that stresses "socially responsible" investing is available from Co-op America by calling (800) 713-8086.
On the heels of an increase in fees at Pioneer Mid-Cap, the management fees at Pioneer Fund and Pioneer II are scheduled to rise, subject to shareholder approval.

HEADLINE: ON CAMPUS;
Union Effort by Part-Time College Teachers Bogs Down

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
A year has passed since part-time faculty members at eight state colleges took the first steps toward creating a union, but their quest for higher pay and job security could drag on indefinitely. Last month, an official in the State Attorney General's office set forth a series of reasons why the part-timers, or adjuncts, should not be allowed to bargain collectively.
In a letter to the state's Public Employment Relations Commission, Mary Cupo-Cruz, a senior deputy attorney general, wrote that adjuncts are "nothing more than private consultants" hired for courses that full-time professors do not have the time or expertise to teach. Since state colleges hire adjuncts only on an "as needed" basis, she reasoned, they cannot be considered public employees even if they return to the institutions year after year. 
 "In light of the self-evident status of adjuncts as consultants and independent contractors," Ms. Cupo-Cruz wrote in a letter dated Feb. 28, "it would be fictional to conclude that the status of an adjunct is altered merely on the basis of some arbitrary repetition of services."
If the Attorney General's office had not objected to the unionization effort, the commission would have permitted the adjuncts to elect a bargaining agent this spring. (The agent would probably be the Council of New Jersey State College Locals, which already represents full-time faculty members at the institutions.) But now, the election could not take place until September or later, said Mel Driban, a national representative of the American Federation of Teachers who has been supervising the effort.
Lawyers for the council responded to the state's objections earlier this month, stressing that the organizing effort has legal precedent. The state has already allowed adjuncts at Rutgers, Raritan Valley Community College and Camden County College to join unions. (None of those unions were created without a fight -- the Rutgers part-timers waited three years for an election, and Raritan Valley adjuncts waited six.)
The commission will take the next step, either setting a date for an election or accepting the state's arguments. If it rules in favor of the adjuncts, the state can appeal to the courts.
"I am assuming the arguments put forth by the state are so specious and the precedent is so obvious that PERC will order an election," Mr. Driban said from the council's office in Union, where he has been working on the project since last March.
The council estimates that more than 3,000 adjuncts are teaching at state colleges this year, and while some have full-time jobs in other professions, hundreds eke out a living teaching at three or four schools. They earn $400 a credit hour, and cannot teach more than six credit hours a semester at each institution. So while full-time professors earn between $28,000 and $75,000 a year, part-timers seldom make more than $9,000. They are not entitled to health benefits, offices, phone lines or free parking spaces at the colleges, and they have no job security from one semester to the next.
College administrators say they are sympathetic to the plight of adjuncts, but paying them more would be exceedingly difficult, since state aid to higher education is being cut.
Besides, they say, they are trying to decrease the number of adjuncts teaching anything but highly specialized courses, because students are better served by full-time professors who are on campus all day.
"It certainly is true that part-time faculty generally have been taken advantage of, and collectively they are very well qualified," said Robert Scott, the president of Ramapo College in Mahwah, where adjuncts teach 25 percent of classes, compared to 35 percent several years ago. "But this could have a severe economic impact."
Even though the situation does not look promising for state college adjuncts, the council has already embarked on another project that is even more ambitious: organizing at least 3,500 adjuncts at 17 county colleges. Mr. Driban said 350 adjuncts at Middlesex County College will soon have a chance to sign cards authorizing an election for a bargaining agent -- the same step the state college adjuncts took last year. He said he decided to forge ahead with a second effort because he had received dozens of calls from adjuncts at county colleges, especially those in North Jersey.
Mr. Driban said he will focus on Middlesex County College this semester, but he has also sent questionnaires to adjuncts at other county colleges to gauge their interest. County colleges tend to have more adjuncts than state colleges -- Sussex County College, for example, has 30 full-time faculty members and at least 250 adjuncts, Mr. Driban said. In 1992, the last year for which statistics are available, adjuncts taught 40 percent of community college classes in New Jersey, compared with 27 percent of classes at state colleges.
Hoping to attract attention to their effort, state college adjuncts are planning a demonstration in front of the State House in Trenton on April 24.
