LENGTH: 2584 words

HEADLINE: Slouching Toward Mount Laurel

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

DATELINE: MOUNT LAUREL

 BODY:
IT didn't matter that she was dying of cancer and couldn't walk without help, couldn't breathe without an oxygen tank. Ethel Lawrence insisted on going out on a hot and humid day in June 1994 for a last look at an empty field here that would someday, she hoped, be filled with housing for the poor.
"It was very emotional. She never gave up the hope or the fight," her daughter, Ethel Halley, recalled not long ago. "She just told the people from the state: 'Please help. Please do whatever you can do to build this housing. My wish would be to put the first key in the door.' " 
Ethel Lawrence never got her wish. She died the next month at 68. But two years later, her field of dreams has edged closer to reality, a poignant symbol of the hopes and frustrations associated with the decades-long battle to open up the suburbs.
It has been a quarter of a century since Mrs. Lawrence lent her name to a class-action lawsuit filed by Camden Regional Legal Services against Mount Laurel Township -- a case that became an instant landmark in 1975, when the State Supreme Court struck down the township's zoning code on the ground that requiring houses on large lots discriminated against the poor. (That ruling, which lacked enforcement teeth, was reaffirmed in much stronger terms in 1983.)
While the rulings will forever link the name Mount Laurel with exclusionary zoning and affordable housing, it is less clear whether the results will ever match expectations. In strict numerical terms, Mount Laurel has been a disappointment, resulting in the construction of only 21,000 homes around the state since 1983 -- many of them not in large-lot suburbs at all, but in the very inner cities that the original Mount Laurel plaintiffs wanted to avoid.
But Mount Laurel's effect has been far from merely symbolic. It has left an imprint on almost every institution, every city and town, in New Jersey. It has affected state and local politics, race, economic status, transportation, urban renewal, land use, town-house development, the environment.
"Those rulings put the concept of 'fair share' on the public agenda and forced a wholesale revision of zoning across the state," write the authors of a new book about the case, "Our Town: Race, Housing and the Soul of Suburbia" (Rutgers University Press, 1995). "Their impact reached far beyond New Jersey, affecting policies from Massachusetts to California, as Mount Laurel became the Roe v. Wade of fair housing, the Brown v. Board of Education of exclusionary zoning."
The Mount Laurel debate has died down somewhat since the mid-80's, when Gov. Thomas H. Kean, responding to the Supreme Court's assault on the cherished principle of home rule, called the 1983 decision "communistic." (And Mr. Kean, a moderate Republican, was polite compared with some local officials.) Still, anger persists. Seventy-five communities are still battling developers in court, and many as 80 are procrastinating or ignoring their obligation to provide a fair share of the regional supply of low-cost housing, perhaps hoping the mandate will simply go away.
"We tell them about the horror stories of other towns, and we tell them it's to their advantage to develop a plan," said Shirley M. Bishop, executive director of the State Council on Affordable Housing, which the Legislature established in 1985 to oversee the "fair share" process. "If not, they run the risk of a builder's lawsuit, mounting costs, and all of the emotion."
Even some housing advocates object to the process, saying the council (universally known as COAH, pronounced KOH-uh) puts too much emphasis on numbers and not enough on the needs of the poor. They point out that municipalities can reduce their fair-housing obligations in a variety of ways: by permitting housing for the elderly and rehabilitated housing, and through so-called regional contribution agreements, which allow them to pay urban areas to take some of their obligations off their hands.
"COAH has this shopping list of discounts -- you get a credit-and-a-half for rental housing, and three-quarters of a credit for seniors," said John M. Payne, a professor at Rutgers Law School. "It breeds a lot of cynicism. It's like, 'Double coupon day on Wednesday for affordable housing!' "
And there are questions whether the process has benefited those who need it most. While those who earn up to 80 percent of the median household income are eligible for the low-cost housing provided under Mount Laurel, Ms. Bishop says not everyone can afford it, because even low-cost housing requires down payments, security deposit and other fees.
If the goal was to integrate the suburbs, the rulings have clearly had little impact. The first comprehensive study on who lives in Mount Laurel housing is only now under way (by the Center for Public Service at Seton Hall University). But anecdotal evidence suggests that most people moving into the new low-cost housing are young, working-class and white.
Still, the long and pervasive reach of the Mount Laurel decisions cannot be denied. That became clear in recent visits to three communities whose stories bring together many of the themes of this 25-year controversy.
 
MOUNT LAUREL
Slow, Uneasy Progress
It all started a generation ago when this sprawling Burlington County suburb -- then rural, and with no multifamily housing -- rejected a plan to rezone 32 acres of land for 36 garden apartments. So Ethel Lawrence and other black residents, fearful that their children would not be able to afford to live in their hometown, solicited the help of public interest lawyers to fight the township.
It was an angry time. The Lawrences received volumes of hate mail, had to change their phone number three times and survived gunshots through the bedroom window.
In the end, the town that gave its name to the Mount Laurel cases capitulated, however reluctantly, to the Mount Laurel process. About 150 low-cost units have been built or are under way, out of a "fair share" of 839.
As with other Mount Laurel housing around the state, the builders include the low-cost units in their developments as a condition of getting local approval to build the market-priced housing. Many developers simply absorb the costs, adding them into the price of their market-rate units. And some government subsidies and tax credits are available.
It's hard to distinguish the low-cost units from the others, in a town that now bristles with town houses and new cul-de-sacs. Though there were fears that those units would diminish the value of surrounding property, Dolores Smith, the township's tax assessor, says it hasn't happened. Nor has the new housing appreciably changed Mount Laurel's demographics: in 1970, blacks made up 3.3 percent of the population of 11,000; by 1990, that figure had inched up to 6 percent out of 30,270 residents.
The township's housing obligations are something of a legal hodgepodge: some developers are suing it in court; other tracts are about to be under the jurisdiction of COAH. It is all a bit too much, township officials say. These days, the big theme is density, and what Mount Laurel -- whose population has tripled since 1970 -- can do to cap its growth.
"You have developers taking land and building multifamily housing in the middle of nowhere," said Mike Mouber, the township attorney. "Density adds cost, density adds schoolchildren, density adds police protection, street lighting costs, everything."
Peter O'Connor is also unhappy, but for different reasons. Mr. O'Connor, one of the original Mount Laurel litigants and now executive director of Fair Share Housing Development Inc., in Cherry Hill, says the town has not done enough to make housing available for the truly needy. The township prefers to sell, not rent, its affordable-housing units, he says, adding that it is always looking for ways to reduce its "fair share" obligation.
"If you look at Mount Laurel in isolation, we have been tremendously successful in establishing the legal and administrative structure," he said. "But the difficulty is that we've moved away from the theory and rhetoric. You've peeled away those layers that it's safe to help, and to go further means you have to confront the underlying problems of race, class and morality."
Still, he has some hope. Next year, ground could be broken on the Ethel Robinson Lawrence project: 140-unit low-income apartments on a 63-acre field that is owned by Mr. O'Connor's organization.

NEW BRUNSWICK
Help From Outside
In New Brunswick, a city of 41,000 where the population is 40 percent black and Hispanic, exclusionary zoning is not an issue. But as a result of the regional contribution agreements allowed by the 1985 Fair Housing Act, New Brunswick has become a major beneficiary of the Mount Laurel process.
Some advocates have criticized the agreements as a way for suburbs to keep the poor out of their backyards. But city officials in New Brunswick and elsewhere embraced them as an impetus for urban renewal.
To date, New Brunswick has received $10.8 million from four suburbs -- Warren Township, Bernardsville, Piscataway and Branchburg -- and used the money to build 306 new housing units and rehabilitate 100 more. Across the state, more than 40 municipalities have participated in the program, resulting in a transfer of some $80 million to urban areas, according to the Council on Affordable Housing.
One was Providence Square (shown on the front page), a red-brick former cigar factory, was converted in 1993 into an attractive complex for the elderly. The 98 one-bedroom apartments rent for $400 a month. A 44-unit town-house development was built on two acres that were once the site of a New Jersey Transit bus garage. Those units sold for $22,000 to $55,000.
New Brunswick is trying hard to encourage homeownership, but it has not been easy. At first, it was impossible for potential low-income buyers to qualify for home mortgages, said Christiana Foglio, president of Community Investment Strategies, New Brunswick-based consultants on affordable-housing and economic development projects. Then came the steady slashing of Federal housing programs for the poor under the Reagan and Bush Administrations.
There are now more programs to help first-time buyers, Ms. Foglio said. But critics say the Fair Housing Act has not served the intent of the Mount Laurel doctrine and that the regional contribution agreements ignore the reality that many inner-city residents would like to move to the suburbs.
"We're against any R.C.A.'s because it smacks in the face of everything we've done," said C. Roy Epps, president of the Civic League of Greater New Brunswick, a plaintiff in the second round of Mount Laurel litigation. "We're trying to open up places; they're trying to concentrate people with limited choices where they'll be captured the rest of their lives. If people could have bought their out of busing, they would have done that too."
 
HILLSBOROUGH
A Question of Sprawl
Hillsborough, a 54-square-mile township in Somerset County, is one of many thinly populated towns in the fast-developing rural or exurban parts of New Jersey where affordable housing has only recently become a lightning rod.
So far, Hillsborough has only been marginally affected by the Mount Laurel "fair share" numbers, parceling out 79 units to Phillipsburg under a regional contribution agreement and building 91 rental units within a larger development in the center of town. But now, private local developers are seeking to build a 3,000-unit project for the elderly on 750 acres, with 136 units set aside to meet the "fair share" obligation. (Under state rules, one-quarter of a municipality's affordable-housing obligations can be satisfied by housing for the elderly.)
The Hillsborough project is one of several around the state that have raised fears that fair-housing concerns could override environmental ones. William R. Neil, assistant director of conservation of the New Jersey Audubon Society, says that here and in nearby places like Pohatcong, Bethlehem and Greenwich, housing could be built on fragile farmland.
Traffic is another concern. The rush of housing to the exurbs runs counter to the much-praised State Development and Redevelopment Plan, which aims to discourage sprawl.
"Hillsborough is a test case for how affordable housing and state planning can co-exist," said Barbara L. Lawrence, executive dirctor of New Jersey Future, a planning organization. "Towns don't want to be sued; they don't want to be publicly castigated as anti-affordable-housing. You end up in a situation where you're building in places probably where you shouldn't be bulding."
Even the most ardent affordable-housing advocates concede that it may not be reasonable to expect many more units to be built, because the Mount Laurel process relies so heavily on private developers, and the real estate market has been soft. In 1987, the affordable housing council set a statewide target of 145,000 affordable units; in 1993, it reduced the figure to 86,000, and more reductions are possible.
"Some people think we should be the panacea for all the housing problems in New Jersey, but we can't be," said Ms. Bishop of the council. "We're trying to balance land-use concerns in municipalities, overcome exclusionary zoning problems, and have community awareness and acceptance of housing."
No one expects the Mount Laurel doctrine to be rolled back, though, regardless of the political fashions in Washington or Trenton. Even advocates who have disappointed by the results of Mount Laurel acknowledge that New Jersey has come too far to change course.
"In this business, you have to be optimist," said Professor Payne of Rutgers. "When the final chapter is written, I think we'll be very proud of what's happened and I don't think we'll look at it as a brief utopian interlude that crashed of its own weight; I think it's alive and well, and eventually we'll have a much broader housing policy."
 
A Quarter-Century Later, Segregation Persists
 The first Mount Laurel lawsuit, brought in 1971, aimed to break down zoning barriers that kept poor people, many of them black and Hispanic, from living in the suburbs. An original plaintiff was the N.A.A.C.P. of Southern Burlington County.
 But despite the State Supreme Court's rulings in 1975 and 1983 striking down large-lot zoning and other restrictions as "economic discrimination," the state has hardly grown any less segregated.
 New Jersey has about 1,900 census tracts, with an average of 4,000 people each. In the 1980 Census, the minority population was clustered in about a third of those areas, mainly cities and older suburbs: 29 percent of the census tracts were at least one-fifth black and Hispanic.
 By 1990, as reflected in the map above, that figure was 34 percent, an increase consistent with the statewide increase in the black and Hispanic population. In 1991-92, the Harvard Project on School Desegregation found that New Jersey's schools, whose students closely reflect the general population, were the fourth most segregated in the nation.
 While the census data are now six years old, researchers say little has changed. "I haven't seen anything to suggest that there's been a major change," said John M. Payne, professor of Rutgers Law School. "No. 1, because of the slow growth of housing due to the recession, and No. 2, becuase there has been no evidence to suggest any unusual outward mobility."

HEADLINE: MAKING IT WORK;
It's March Madness, Baby. Sue Them.

BYLINE: By COREY KILGANNON 

 BODY:
MILLIONS of college basketball fans will be watching the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship game on television tomorrow night, but they will not be the only ones experiencing March madness.
All over Manhattan this month, brokers and lawyers are competing for championships in corporate basketball leagues. Cramped gyms, not huge arenas with thousands of screaming fans, are the sites of these heated weeknight battles, where these amateur players release their professional intensity and competitive drive. 
 "Everyone wants to play basketball this time of year," said Jason Moede, a 6-foot-2-inch forward and an economist at the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. "You sit in all weekend long watching the games. It just makes you want to compete."
"People don't realize it, but these leagues have become almost a subculture," said Peter Grean, who quit his law practice to oversee the 140-team Lawyers Basketball League, which he started as a small parochial league in 1970. "Every weeknight, most of the city's gyms are filled with these guys."
"The phones are ringing non-stop this time of year, there's a real buzz," he added. "These guys call a few times a day just for scouting and injury reports, even to see who their ref will be, looking for that advantage."
On the court, each profession seems to have its own style. Brokers and bankers, always shooting for the big prize, like to take the game into their own hands, frequently screaming for the ball on offense. Lawyers tend to concentrate on tenacious defense and argue every call.
"Lawyers in particular know all the rules inside and out," said Mr. Grean's assistant, Dave Walker. "We constantly get calls the day after a game where a player is questioning a technicality of a rule."
Altogether, about 1,000 corporate teams play in city basketball leagues, with about 300 teams involved in playoffs. The players pull off the silk ties and Tommy Hilfiger shirts, change from Ballys to Reeboks, stuff the cellular phones in the gym bags and prepare to do battle on the court, all for the sake of the firm.
"The intensity in these leagues is like that of a tough collegiate game," said Mike Howard, a referee who officiates for the lawyers and corporate leagues when he is not working local college games. "At the top levels, the skills are comparable too."
Steve Cronin, a 29-year-old broker with J.W. Charles Securities, went from playing for Tufts University and a year with a professional team in Israel to a Corporate League championship last year with Troster Singer, a securities trading house. A Manhattan hoops freelancer, Mr. Cronin plays in three leagues, and March finds him racing from gym to gym.
"It's always intense," he said. "You know guys on other teams, rivalries develop and it all comes to a head around now. The competition is excellent: Division I college players, even some ex-pros."
But for John Donahue, a 5-foot-9-inch guard for Barrington Capital, a midtown brokerage house, the allure is more personal.
"Hitting that 3-pointer is like getting a big trade," said Mr. Donahue, a 30-year-old stock broker, as he unclasped his $5,000 Rolex watch and gently draped his $2,000 Giorgio Armani suit over his gym bag before a recent game at Brandeis High School gym. His firm finished 9-1 in the "Rich and Famous" division of the New York Urban Professionals Basketball League last week. The team will start its playoff schedule this week.
"You're playing against guys that are from the same walk of life as you," said Paul Schnell, vice president of sales for the B.W.D. Group, a Long Island insurance brokerage. His team, made up of longtime friends, won the league championship last week in the top division of the New York Corporate Basketball League. "Lawyers, brokers, investment bankers -- you see eye to eye because you're going through similar challenges and pressures at the office," he said. "Some other leagues are more back-office types, you know, like mail-room guys."
"People always love to play ball," he added, "but this time of year, they're more pumped up."
The Fischbein Badillo Wagner Harding firm's 55-46 victory recently over top-seeded Schulte, Roth & Zabel, in the quarterfinals of the Counselors Division of the Lawyers Basketball League, impressed the boss -- senior partner and a courtside regular, Herman Badillo.
"I try to go to as many games as I can," said Mr. Badillo, who is also Mayor Giuliani's special counsel for oversight of school finances. "I hope this is our year to win it all."
After the 9 P.M. game, Fischbein's star center, Dwight Chase, who led all scorers with 14 points, threw his long black overcoat over his uniform and hustled with some teammates out of the Friends Seminary gymnasium at 222 East 16th Street, back to the Midtown office.
The next day, Mr. Badillo summoned Mr. Chase into his office for some serious business, to make sure the center's strained knee was all right for this Tuesday's semifinal game. Clearly, team pride takes precedence over issues like billable hours.
"The intensity is much higher this time of year," said Fischbein's captain, Jeff Mitchell, who said playoff results are regularly published in the firm's bi-weekly newsletter. "Lawyers don't like to lose. They're really competitive, and there's a real loyalty to the firm. No one wants to come into the office a loser -- and people do ask."
"To do business in this city, you've got to go all out," said William Silver, founder of Nu Tech, a systems integration company. "To win in this league, you have to do the same thing. I have two bloody knees right now from diving on the floor last week."
Mr. Silver was preparing a presentation on document management for the city's biggest banks, using little basketballs in his graphics.
"It's March madness, baby," said the 35-year-old forward. "These guys are all brokers and businessmen. We're competing all daylong. Someone's always trying to eat my lunch in the business world and it's no different on the court."

HEADLINE: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;
Who's Afraid of Jobs and Growth?

BYLINE: By ROBERT EISNER; Robert Eisner, professor emeritus at Northwestern University and a former president of the American Economic Association, is the author of "The Misunderstood Economy: What Counts and How to Count It."

 BODY:
BOND and stock markets in shock! Dow plunges 171 points on stunning news of a big gain in jobs in February! Interest rates spike as unemployment drops to 5.5 percent! That was the report a few weeks ago.
But are more jobs bad for the economy? Or just for Wall Street? Or is something else going on? 
 Karl Marx argued that capitalism could not survive without a "reserve army" of unemployed. This was necessary, he said, so that competition from the jobless could hold down wages and allow companies to make the profits that keep them operating. A surprising number of economists buy that analysis, without usually acknowledging its origin. The modern twist they put on it is that low unemployment will bring inflation -- indeed, unbearable inflation. The argument has been refined and embodied in a still-dominant dogma in the dismal science, that of the Nairu, the non-accelerating inflation rate of unemployment, often dubbed the "natural rate" of unemployment.
If unemployment falls below this rate, the doctrine declares, we will not only suffer inflation but, as long as it stays below the rate, inflation will keep rising, ultimately into hyperinflation that threatens the orderly operation of the economy.
What does this have to do with the market's recent gyrations? The key is that our Federal Reserve apparently believes all this and, without necessarily following the economic theory, bond dealers and other investors know the Fed believes this. Hence, news of lower unemployment is taken as a signal that the Fed will be prepared to tighten the screws of monetary controls. It will certainly not nudge interest rates down, as had been expected in response to evidence of a slowing economy. Since that expectation had, in large part, been built into current bond and stock prices, dashing it created market turmoil. The Fed, indeed, confirmed this market perception of its policy by its refusal to lower interest rates last week.
The remarkable, and sad, part is that the Nairu dogma lives on with so little supporting evidence -- even, in fact, as events contradict it. If there is a natural rate of unemployment, God apparently treats his many children differently. In much of Europe, unemployment has been in double digits -- 11 percent in Germany, 12 percent in France and 22 percent in Spain. If those rates are above the Nairu for these countries, the theory says inflation should have turned into accelerating deflation. Clearly, that has not happened.
In Japan, unemployment was long about 2 percent and even now, in a recession, is in the 3 percent range. Where is its accelerating inflation? Or is its natural rate somehow far below everybody else's?
IN the United States, the Congressional Budget Office has prepared Nairu estimates going back to 1947; they have ranged from 5.3 percent then, to 6.3 percent from 1977 to 1980, and 5.8 percent today. But there has been no evidence of continuously accelerating inflation when unemployment was below the Nairu. During the Vietnam War, annual unemployment averages were below 4 percent from 1966 to 1969 and inflation rose -- but only from 3.2 percent to 5.1 percent -- and one could well argue that even this modest increase was a short-run response to a surge in war spending.
I have put the budget office estimates of the Nairu and the presumed consequences to strenuous econometric tests. I have found that, while unemployment above the Nairu seemed to cool inflation, unemployment below the Nairu did not raise it. There is even some evidence that low unemployment lowered it. And Ray Fair of Yale University finds that data for the United States and 29 other countries also reject the conventional concept of the Nairu.
My own results may well be explained by several factors. At low unemployment, workers are doing well, frequently benefiting from overtime pay, and have little desire to upset the apple cart by pushing up wages. Further, productivity is high and costs are low, with production lines full. And companies hesitate to raise prices when potential competitors, also rich with cash, may try to move in.
Most recently, unemployment has been below the Nairu from October 1994 on, and inflation has, if anything, been moving down. As unemployment fell to 5.5 percent last month, consumer prices rose only two-tenths of 1 percent and wholesale prices fell by that amount. A number of suggested corrections to official figures would put inflation over the last year close to zero.
Tied to the Nairu dogma is the dismal argument that economic growth cannot be allowed to become too rapid. According to this view, annual economic growth of more than 2.5 percent can be achieved only by reducing unemployment, but further reductions now would supposedly bring us accelerating inflation. Thus the stubborn resistance in the Fed, and among some political leaders, to pursuing policies focusing on faster growth.
By a principle called Okun's Law, named for Arthur M. Okun, who was chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers for President Lyndon B. Johnson, each percentage-point reduction in unemployment is associated with at least two percentage points more in output as the labor force is utilized more intensively. That indicates that if the unemployment rate fell a percentage point a year for the next two years, to 3.5 percent, we would have four percentage points more in ouput, or $300 billion, by 1998.
Think what that would mean for every problem of the economy, real or imagined. In five years, it would bring a painless reduction of $180 billion in the annual deficit, as tax revenues increased, without raising tax rates, and unemployment and welfare outlays declined.
So let the Fed -- and all our policy makers -- divest themselves of the dogma that unemployment can be too low, and rather promote maximum employment and economic growth. And as Wall Street witnesses that growth and perceives that the Fed is not trying to stop it with higher interest rates, we might well expect the Dow, and not inflation, to go ever higher and higher.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;
Blockbuster Blooms in a Longtime Video Wasteland

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS 

 BODY:
For years, Harlem residents have complained that their community suffers from a case of benign neglect when it comes to life's amenities. Until recently, basic conveniences like pizza delivery were unavailable to the area's predominantly black population. Videos were rented at a handful of mom and pop general stores -- with relatively small selections -- or bootlegged through an open-air market of street vendors.
But Blockbuster Video has come to Harlem, and its arrival is being touted by leading voices in the community as one indication that Harlem itself has arrived. 
 The video chain recently opened a store on 125th Street, between Frederick Douglass Boulevard and Lenox Avenues, Harlem's main commercial strip. It is the first video chain to establish a presence since Roy's left four years ago. Beyond the 20 to 30 new jobs created by the store's opening, residents say Blockbuster, the largest video renter in the world, is just what the area needs to restore its economic vibrancy and lure middle-class residents.
"This gives the people of Harlem a sense that their community counts," said Warren S. Whitlock, deputy executive director of the Harlem Community Development Corporation, which helped broker the deal with Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation. The organization is now working to lure Domino's Pizza. In addition, a plan is moving forward on developing a six-story retail complex -- including a movie house and ice rink -- on another parcel on 125th Street.
Wally Knief, corporate communications manager for Blockbuster, said the new location, the chain's 69th store in New York, made sense from a business standpoint.
"There are 43,000 households within three-quarters of a mile of the site," said Mr. Knief. "There's a great deal of foot traffic, a subway exit and the State Office Building is next door."
About 1,500 people had obtained membership cards in the two weeks since the store opened, according to Frank Groce, the store's manager. He said the store, open from 10 A.M. to midnight seven days a week, is averaging 150 applications a day.
Customers browsing through the selection of 15,000 videos and 1,000 video games commented on the chain's arrival.
"There were those who said we'd steal the videos off the shelves or couldn't be trusted to return them," said Louis B. Love, a disabled veteran who uses a wheelchair and lives on West 145th Street. Before the store came to Harlem, he had to travel to the Blockbuster store on East 96th Street to rent videos. "Blockbuster was willing to take a chance," he said, "and that says a lot."
Rose Riley looked like a kid in a candy store. "Who needs to go to the movies?" she said. LENA WILLIAMS

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CARROL GARDENS;
'Mayor' Who Refused to Run

BYLINE: By MARK FRANCIS COHEN 

 BODY:
Salvatore (Buddy) Scotto looks so much like Mayor Giuliani that strangers often mistake him for the Mayor. But Mr. Scotto seldom encounters strangers when strolling, driving, or just standing in his neighborhood. Many locals refer to Mr. Scotto as the Mayor of Carroll Gardens.
"He's gotten that name because he is someone people in the community look to and respect," said Assemblywoman Eileen Dugan. "He never says no to anyone. It never ceases to amaze me." 
 "Buddy, I don't know what to do," a woman implores as Mr. Scotto prepares to leave the funeral home he owns on One Place. "My daughter wants to join the Air Force."
"She should," Mr. Scotto says, buttoning his coat. "But we'll talk later."
Mr. Scotto, 67, is a man people lean on, recruit, draft and appeal to. It's a position that has let him leverage deals and move politicians.
He first started working to improve his neighborhood so that long-time residents would not flee. Since then, he has been a remarkable force behind the elections of several politicians, a new sewage treatment plant, a senior citizens center, low- and middle-income housing and two local community development corporations.
"He has got incredible energy," said City Councilman Stephen DiBrienza. "I think one extra ingredient that makes him effective is the nature of Buddy's profession. As a funeral parlor director, he comes into contact with people in their time of need."
Still, Mr. Scotto has gone to great lengths to avoid becoming a politician himself. In 1975, he quietly registered as a Republican so that the local Democratic reform club -- the one he helped start -- wouldn't put him on the ballot.
Ironically, Republican leaders, aware of his influence in the community, enlisted him as a delegate to the Republican National Convention the next year. Mr. Scotto accepted because he wanted to go to a national convention. Since he did not favor any of the Republican candidates, he announced he was going to the convention uncommitted.
Within weeks, he got a call from Vice President Nelson Rockefeller demanding his support. So, Mr. Scotto said he would only give his support if he got Federal financing to clean up the sewage-spoiled Gowanus Canal. After a few visits to the White House, Federal money was appropriated for the project.
The 15 more years it eventually took to complete the Red Hook sewage treatment plant was a lesson about politics for Mr. Scotto, who began a dogged effort in the 1980's to start community-based organizations.
He is still on what some see as a quixotic quest to make the Gowanus Canal a pristine waterway that could sustain open-air cafes, small craft and fishing. He has vowed to swim it one day. MARK FRANCIS COHEN

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Short-Sellers Are Lonely Hunters, but Is Their Bounty Near?

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
TRYING to profit from overvalued stocks has never been easy. But given the roaring bull market of recent years, the task has become onerous, and that has made a hard job even harder for short-sellers. These professionals hunt for sky-high equities and, by borrowing shares, sell them at the lofty price while later paying the lower price to which they expect the stock to tumble. They pocket the difference -- or pay it, if they guessed wrong.
Despite short-sellers' recent bad luck, investors in a soaring market can still learn from them. Indeed, if the Dow falters, their perspectives may be much in demand. So we paid a visit recently to Michael Katz and Geoffrey Hulme, partners who manage a total of $30 million in Reynard Partners and Glenrock Global Partners in Manhattan. Reynard is a short-selling fund, and Glenrock is a hedge fund that is half short, half long. 
 Q. Let me first ask you for some personal perspective. You describe 1995 as something of a murderous year for short-sellers. How did you fare?
KATZ -- Well, it's a good news-bad news story. I'll begin with the good news. The good news is that we think, according to what the professional scorekeepers tell us, we probably fared better than anybody else last year in our pure short-selling fund. The bad news, though, is that we still lost about 4 percent in Reynard before fees. [Glenrock was up 17 percent in 1995.] And we don't get paid on relative performance. We get paid on absolute performance.
Now to give you the points of reference. The stock market was up 37 percent, and from what I understand the average short-selling fund lost 26 percent last year.
Incidentally, 1995 was not the first bad year. We've been in a battle mode for five years.
Q. -- How much do you have in your short fund?
KATZ -- About $12 million.
Q. -- How has the number changed recently?
KATZ -- The pure short-selling business has been the most out-of-favor strategy you can imagine. In 1990 we made 68 percent when the market was essentially flat for the year. So around that time everybody wanted to invest in short funds. But the general interest at the moment is minimal. Most people believe that the market will never drop.
Q. -- Given recent market volatility, is it possible that the short-sellers' time has come?
KATZ -- We thought so time and time and again over the past five years. It again looks like it. I mean you have signs like a very choppy market at record valuations. You have all sorts of phenomena that so-called technicians are better at explaining, so we're a little hopeful.
HULME -- One thing we've learned is that when it seems like things are getting aligned for a little easier environment, we make sure we're short stocks and not short markets. We really try to stay very stock-specific and hope that the environment helps us even more.
Q. -- Last year, many short-sellers were hurt by technology and biotech stocks. What were your positions in them?
KATZ -- We had positions in both types. In biotech we did lose some money, but not a lot, because we were partially hedged.
Q. -- I don't think anyone expected '95 to be as healthy as it was for biotech.
HULME -- Some real things were happening, but it didn't have to flow in to all the other companies.
KATZ -- And in technology we had a lot more. We were actually quite heavily invested in technology, I'd say to the tune of 18 to 20 percent.
HULME -- At the end of the year. Throughout the year, say 10 or 15.
KATZ -- As for technology, it raises the whole issue of risk control. Technology looked appetizing for the better part of '94 already and then in '95 it really took off. And in a sense that, if all we were doing were valuations, and shorting high-priced stocks, we would have gone in then. But that's not what we do.
We typically seek three things: high valuations, researchable fundamental problems -- business problems -- and some sort of event horizon, to develop a time line.
This plan serves two purposes. It gives us a trigger. If a certain piece of news comes out, then people will look at this differently and the stock will come down.
The other thing is to check our own thesis along the way. Are we right? If we expect this to happen, does it happen? If it isn't happening, why? Are we wrong? That sort of thing.
So that is the reason we didn't short many technology stocks early last year, even though our fingers were itching to pull the trigger.
Q. -- What other strategies do you follow to protect your position?
KATZ -- What we spend our time with is fundamental research. We read. We devour paper.
HULME -- We make research trips that we think other people don't make. We try to get much primary, objective, unbiased information from the industry.
KATZ -- We talk to lots of competitors, suppliers, clients, consultants, trade associations, trade journals. And so forth and so forth.
But intertwined with that is always the focus that we want to know the fundamentals of the business. We want to know what problems a business has.
The difficult thing on the short side is that if a stock goes against you, it gets bigger as a part of your portfolio.
HULME -- So when some things we hoped would happen didn't happen, we cut the positions. You wanted a balance sheet to get worse; it didn't get worse. You wanted a new product to fail; it didn't fail. Or maybe it got some news out of nowhere that's positive.
Q. -- How is '96 shaping up for you so far?
KATZ -- Well, so far, we've lost some ground. I think we're down between 3.5 and 4 percent, something like that. That's always painful. Again, for perspective, the Dow's up about 10 percent.
Q. -- You are one of the few short-sellers with an international position. What are you doing there?
KATZ -- International investments have been extremely helpful for two reasons. No. 1, we've been able to find ideas where there aren't many other people interested on the short side. There is much less competition internationally for us. The second is that it has kept us out of trouble, having about a third of our capital in shorts outside the U.S.
HULME -- It's important to remember, again, we're not short for those markets. We're short for individual situations.
Our No. 1-performing situation last year was Eurotunnel. It's basically a situation where they generate 500 million of interest expense a year and, last year, I think, they did about 300 million in revenue. This year they might do 500 million. So who knows, maybe in the third year they have more revenue than interest expenses. I'm not talking about any operating costs here or anything.
KATZ -- Also, the company suspended paying interest late last year.
Q. -- How much did you make on this one?
KATZ -- In dollars? I don't even know. But in percent, we were short the stock before last year. We were short the stock going into last year, probably in the 40's on average in francs. It's now 6. By the way, I think Eurotunnel as a construction project is a wonderful thing. But the way it was financed and the delays and screw-ups along the way have just made it a totally untenable situation. They owe way too much money and the shareholders were taken for a ride.
HULME -- No pun intended.
Q. -- Besides Eurotunnel, where else did you do well internationally?
KATZ -- Euro Disney is another one where we have a very long history. We've been in that since '92.
HULME -- When the gates opened we started to short the stock. We really try to look for these situations where it's no longer a concept, it's a real thing.
KATZ -- As long as it's a concept and there's nothing to measure anything by, brokers will get it anywhere they want. They'll hype it. They'll have all sorts of fantasies about it. But once it's opened, every day the register is open and it rings or it doesn't ring.
HULME -- Often, analysts make very top-down models: "So many people in France. So many will visit Euro Disney. It's going to cost this, and they're buying this many."
KATZ -- "Plus there are 80 million people in Germany, and 10 percent of them own a car," or whatever.
HULME -- And then the reality enters, but in between it's very difficult because people believe those numbers.
KATZ -- By 1994 it was clear that under the old structure Euro Disney was essentially insolvent, a similar story to Eurotunnel. It had much too much debt. So at that time they essentially did an informal, prepackaged bankruptcy, if you will. The banks essentially agreed to a moratorium on interest, took some equity. And there was a huge equity dilution.
HULME -- And U.S. Disney decided to defer its fees.
KATZ -- And now the recapitalization, which was done over two years ago, is not enough. Many of their interest payments and lease payments and royalties to Disney are coming due again.
Q. -- The payments are coming back?
HULME -- Coming back like a boomerang. They might not come back in the same percentages, but they are coming back.
KATZ -- Internationally, we also have a significant exposure in Japan to manufacturers of semiconductors, in particular DRAM chips. And Hong Kong, where we have had a presence since '94, approximately. We have some situations in the United Kingdom and Canada.
The problem with many international markets is that we can't borrow stocks. That's a technical requirement for short-selling. You have to find someone to lend them to you.
Q. -- What other analyses do you perform?
KATZ -- We spend a lot of time thinking about who are our opponents in the market. Let's say opponent analysis, meaning, who buys stock from us?
In short-selling, very often you're dealing with unsavory characters on the other side. Many companies are "promote jobs." In the worst case, they're complete frauds. In many cases, they are not frauds but certainly wide exaggerations of potential and plays on people's gullibility. And more often than not in this kind of company there is effectively a cabal of brokers with management that inflates the stock. We have to be very careful with whom we're dealing. Sometimes those people's abilities to manipulate prices are astonishing.
I don't want to say that everything we short has unsavory people on the other side. Many, if not the majority of our shorts, simply have very bad business fundamentals.
We also think long and hard about what sort of exogenous risk factors our stocks are exposed to. In an airline, you could pick several, but I would say oil, the price of gasoline, is the most important. And then see how exposed we are in the portfolio to that exogenous risk.
Q. -- Any advice you want to give investors about today's market?
KATZ -- The market is at heights that it has never before reached in 120 years, in terms of valuation.
HULME -- In the past 14 months, January '95 to February '96, the market is up 50 percent; 37 percent last year and 10 percent on top of that this year comes out to 50 percent. It's an absolutely staggering number, considering particularly that at the beginning of '95 it was expensive.
KATZ -- Brokers, and others, justify it by saying this time is different than prior overvaluations. And people buy it. The American investor has as many stocks in his or her portfolio, as a percentage of household liquidity, as during the highest of the highs in the late 60's. The last time it was that high was just prior to a series of vicious bear markets.
Even so, there is something much worse than that now. The crash of '87, for instance, did not do anything to the economy, mostly because the average consumer didn't own any stocks, I believe. So when they lost a lot of money in the crash they didn't stop buying; it didn't matter to them. Now, everybody owns stocks through mutual funds. And it's not just that they own them for their savings accounts or for money that they can afford to lose. They put their pensions in them now.
I would say if there's any accident in the market today, you'll have absolutely massive repercussions on the economy because so many "regular" guys will lose so much of their savings and their pensions.
Under these circumstances, is this the time to gamble the farm on mutual funds or stocks, when all of the historical evidence is against you?
Q. -- As a short-seller, what are your top picks now?
HULME -- One is North American Vaccine. It's a biotech company that's developing a pertussis, or whooping cough, vaccine. We believe that in the trials the vaccine showed the lowest efficacy versus three other vaccines. There are three very large multinational companies doing this. We also believe North American is behind in the F.D.A. approval process, that it has no ready manufacturing capability. We believe it has a dangerously low cash position, about two quarters of cash left. Insiders have been selling their shares over the last few months. And the market cap of the company, which is nearly $520 million, is almost twice the worldwide revenue opportunity for this type of vaccine.
It's a perplexing situation. There is this phenomenon of money flowing into the biotech sector and people with a checklist saying: "Let's find a company that is in Phase 3 trials. This company's in Phase 3 trials. Let's find a company with a novel product. Well, this company has one."
They go through it this way and they do the work a little bit, but they don't do it the whole way. And a rising tide lifts all boats.
HULME -- Glaxo is another situation. The products that account for nearly 65 percent of its revenues were flat last year, and those include Zantac, an anti-ulcer drug, and Zovirax, an antiviral drug. And about 40 percent of the 65 percent in the next 18 months will lose patent protection. Meanwhile, the stock is valued on a price-earnings basis like several other large pharmaceutical companies that don't have the same affliction.
Q. -- What else are you shorting?
KATZ -- Micron Technology, a semiconductor stock. All they essentially make is memory chips. As late as last fall, neither it nor anybody else in the industry -- and certainly not the brokers -- was admitting that the market was dropping. Everybody knew that there were dozens of plants, large-capacity chip plants, being built all over the world, in Korea, Taiwan. Nobody was willing to admit that this was a problem.
Suddenly, in October or November, we got news that the price for memory chips was dramatically weakening. Everybody thought they were still at $14 and suddenly they were selling at $12, which seems so dramatic. And then they kept accelerating. And week after week we get these reports. Then they cascaded down to $5 and have bounced to $7 or $8 right now.
Micron made money like they were printing it for years because the normal big annual decline for the price of new chips didn't happen. They could just sell those chips at extremely high margins for an inordinately long time. And so the stock, even at the height of it, didn't look that expensive based on the prospective price-earnings ratio.
Q. -- Are there any particular kinds of companies that are candidates for shorting?
HULME -- There are a few: recently public companies, or those that have done lots of offerings. And then there are companies that are passing through the "dream reality" stage.
KATZ -- Insider selling is a very frequent tip-off. I mean, we often find that we get attracted to ideas of highflying stocks and suddenly we see insiders selling or doing secondary offerings. And so you get a feeling. It's not in and of itself a reason to short anything, but it's often something to be examined. Several of these companies are one-product companies.
HULME -- One-product companies are another way to limit our risk. They limit what we need to be right about, and we can get our arms around them and they can't reinvent themselves.
KATZ -- The nature of good short ideas, or what makes a short idea, is not static. It depends very much on what else is going on in the market and the economy and so forth. For instance, five, six years ago, we had large concentrations in stocks that were extremely leveraged, as a result of the leveraged-acquisition boom of the 80's. They were in no position to pay their debt. And that worked very well.
Then, of course, over the succeeding years, everybody recapitalized and that whole debt motif went away. But many things are just one-of-a-kind, special situations that you can't really impose a category on.
HULME -- Theme investing is often a way to get killed in short-selling.
KATZ -- Yes, exactly. Good point.
HULME -- Death by analogy. It can be very dangerous.
Q. -- What should investors think about short-selling?
HULME -- I think short-selling is a rational strategy, and we think there's a place in a well-diversified portfolio for it.
KATZ -- More than that, we think we're going to make a lot of money. While we've lived through the past five years, we think it has been a historical anomaly. I mean, markets have risen faster, more frothily, more speculatively and with fewer setbacks than at any time that I can think of.
There's another thing. Prior to the past five years, short-sellers were making high absolute rates of return even in bull markets. The 80's were a good period, even though it was a raging bull market. Something else decoupled in the past five years; I suspect it's an anomaly. It'll come back into sync. You can't long have a rational strategy where reasonably intelligent and hard-working people get their head handed to them year after year, while investors who are running with the pack make a lot of money without work and without . . .
HULME -- He was thinking of something mean.
Q. -- And you had to catch him. It's good there are two of you there.
KATZ -- Yeah, well, we have our healthy debates.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael Katz, left, and Geoffrey Hulme see recent volatility in the sky-high stock market as a possible good sign for short-selling. (Carol Halebian for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3361 words

HEADLINE: Lost in Toyland

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
STANDING on the top floor of the Toys "R" Us store in Santa Monica, Calif., far above the endless racks of Monopoly games, Barbie dolls and coloring books, Diane Summers Craig was very much alone.
"Hello? Hello? Is anyone here?" Ms. Craig called out as she perused a deserted aisle of computer software. 
 At last, a clerk wandered over to help her, but acknowledged that she did not really know the differences among the computer programs for sale. The clerk added with a polite smile, "Someone will be here in a minute to help you." Frustrated, Ms. Craig mumbled something about not having a minute, but waited for several of them anyway.
Another clerk came, but help was not forthcoming. "No one here really knows anything," huffed the mother of two young children before turning on her heel and leaving.
Wall Street has known for quite a while that the world's largest toy retailer is troubled. After 16 consecutive years of uninterrupted growth, the company's earnings took a 72 percent nose dive in the fiscal year that ended on Feb. 2, to $148 million, largely due to a hefty restructuring charge.
Further, in a bull market in which the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has risen more than 40 percent since the beginning of 1995, the stock price of Toys "R" Us has declined about 11 percent. Company shares, which went for $42.875 at the end of 1993, stagnated in the $20's for most of 1995, and closed Friday on the New York Stock Exchange at $27, down 25 cents. Add it up, and the company has lost a staggering $5.2 billion in market value, weighing in at $7.5 billion from a pinnacle of $12.7 billion.
Michael Goldstein, the chief executive of Toys "R" Us, has big plans to stem the bleeding. But he is caught in the classic quandary of the turnaround artist: if he spends too much on revamping his stores, he could wreck his already shaky profit margins; if he spends too little, his efforts may come to naught.
The company's fall from grace didn't happen overnight. In 1990, retail analysts treated Toys "R" Us as almost sacrosanct, projecting earnings growth of 25 percent a year.
Yet the company has come close to that target only once in the last six years -- and then only after two lackluster ones.
Analysts give a variety of reasons for the reversal of fortune at Toys "R" Us, which just over a decade ago was rolling over its competition like a Tonka truck lumbering down a grassy suburban hillside.
They speak of discount stores like Wal-Mart and Target ratcheting up the competitive pressure; of a dearth of creative new toys; of the fading popularity of the Power Ranger action figures, which accounted for huge sales the previous year.
But it is perhaps those retail analysts with children, the ones who have made a Saturday afternoon venture into that dizzying landscape of bikes, bath toys and a ubiquitous giraffe named Jeffrey, who know what parents indifferent to issues of market cap have known for years: while Toys "R" Us has what they're looking for, getting it can come at a cost to their sanity.
"I don't know a single retailer about which I hear as many complaints as Toys "R" Us," said Barry Bryant, an analyst at Rodman & Renshaw and the father of a 3-year-old son. "You never know where anything is, and there is no one to help. And to make matters worse, children are enticed in there as if they were walking through one long candy store. All of these things combine to create a uniquely unpleasant shopping experience for the parent."
The supermarket style of selling playthings has always been the Toys "R" Us trademark. Shoppers squeeze through charmless, colorless aisles, and pick through rows of crayons, doll houses, video games and action figures, strung together like so many sausages, displayed often without care or accessibility.
Merchandise is often piled so high it is impossible to reach, particularly while holding a wailing 3-year-old whose eyes are wildly fixated on Mr. Potato Head.
And if a sales clerk can be unearthed, chances are his or her job is to stock, not to serve. "I usually feel like I am getting a price break and a lot of selection," said Cindy Read, a program administrator in Louisville, Ky.,. "But I don't look forward to going in there, seeing all these families fighting over toys. People are tired, parents seem annoyed -- that is why I don't take my son there."
By offering a giant selection with very low prices and plenty of inventory, Toys "R" Us has been able to get away with this no-frills, service-short shopping experience, and to do so in a way that has made shoppers all around the country abandon the competition, if begrudgingly.
But times are changing in the world of fun and games, and parents have grown decreasingly tolerant of the lack of attention and the chaotic arrangements at Toys "R" Us, especially when they can find some of the goods for the same price, or better, at general discount stores.
Further, a growing number of so-called educational toy stores have cropped up, offering soothing worlds of purple carpeting and television screens to plop children in front of while mom and dad shop. And nibbling away on the baby end of the business is Baby Superstores, a 63-store chain based in Duncan, S.C.
TOYS "R" US has caught on to all of this, and is finally fighting back with new store formats, including one with the sole mission of challenging Baby Superstores. But can the giant that built its war chest through pre-emptive strikes do as well playing catch-up?
When asked about his company's earnings trouble during a recent interview in his office in Paramus, N.J., Mr. Goldstein looked a bit like a basketball coach who just watched his team get pummeled in a playoff.
"It hurt," he said of the recent profit plunge. "Particularly for a company like ours that never experienced a decline in earnings. It was a rude awakening."
Then the coach recovers and plays to the fans. "But it energized us to do a better job," he said, smiling. "We see a lot of options in 1996."
Toys "R" Us has enjoyed a glittering history. The country's first category killer -- industry argot for giant warehouse-style stores that offer the most of one type of merchandise -- it toppled Child World, Kiddie City Toys and countless regional stores during the 1980's. It now easily dominates the market, with more than $9 billion in annual sales and 650 stores in the United States.
Even after the company's expansion slowed in the early 90's, the prospect of overseas growth kept investors' hopes alive. Several analysts remember conference calls in 1993 in which Toys "R" Us executives promised gains of as much as 50 percent in the company's international business. But many of the stores have failed to deliver. "We gave projections, and we didn't meet them," Mr. Goldstein said.
Each foreign market threw its own curveball at Toys "R" Us: a sluggish economy in Germany, a Christmastime strike in France and strong local competition in Australia.
But while those forces were beyond its control, the company also made some strategic missteps, like choosing poor locations, and failing to negotiate prices on merchandise and real estate.
WITH its fortunes sagging at home and abroad last year, the retailer desperately needed a hot Christmas. Instead, it got slammed when no new video or toy products arose to rival the phenomenal success the previous year of the Power Ranger action figures and the spinoffs from the Disney hit movie "The Lion King." Worse, discount stores slashed prices, forcing everyone to sell toys at a loss.
After the disappointing holiday season, Toys "R" Us announced that it would take an after-tax restructuring charge of $270 million, equivalent to $397 million pretax, to close 22 stores in the United States and Europe and to consolidate distribution and administrative offices. Company officials acknowledge that the charge includes other sundry expenses, like inventory write-downs. While the restructuring announcement caused them embarrassment, the charge makes it much easier for the company to achieve its fiscal 1997 earnings targets.
A disclosure in January that the Federal Trade Commission had targeted Toys "R" Us in an antitrust investigation only made matters worse. The inquiry stemmed from complaints by wholesale clubs that the big retailer unfairly used its marketing power to discourage manufacturers from selling popular toys to them.
Mr. Goldstein neither confirmed nor denied the accusations.
Most analysts scoff at the investigation as a Washington sideshow, but antitrust lawyers are less dismissive. "It is quite serious," said Richard M. Steuer, a partner at the law firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler in New York. "There are few categories where you have a retailer with as much power as Toys is perceived to have, so however it comes out is likely to set a precedent for other categories."
The F.T.C. is expected to conclude the investigation within a month.
But Toys "R" Us has even larger themes to wrestle with. Like many retailers that enjoyed boom days a decade ago, it must find new ways to lure in 1990's shoppers who have become accustomed to price wars and their spoils, and who are eager for fresh concepts and new merchandise. In the 80's, all a retailer had to be was big and omnipresent. Now, it really needs to be clever.
This has sent the entire industry to the analyst's couch: Every retailer wants to know what it has done wrong, and how it can be better, more self-aware and more of a participant in its relationships with shoppers. But seducing new shoppers does not come by tweaking existing concepts -- it comes from reinventing them. This is the challenge for Toys "R" Us.
To fend off interlopers and make its stores more inviting, Toys "R" Us is fighting back in three ways. First, it plans to roll out new stores known as Concept 2000, in both new locations and existing sites. These stores will be an aesthetic antidote to the current spaces, which have the charm of a tenement basement.
The 45,000-square-foot stores will have wider aisles and lower racks, so shoppers can see where things are and reach the merchandise. Each store will have a skylight. Colored tiles will replace the current gray floors, and fixtures will be festooned with colorful toyland icons. Employees who assemble bikes will do so in an open space, Santa's-workshop style, in the back of the store. The first of 16 Concept 2000 stores will go up in Raritan, N.J., this year.
Then there's Babies "R" Us, a superstore devoted to the needs of the under-5 set. There will be furniture, clothing, diapers and formula, complete room models in the back and the all-important baby registry. Eight to 10 of these stores will pop up in 1996, the first in Westbury, L.I.
Plan C brings together various ideas. In 1996, the company will put up two yet-to-be-named megastores: 90,000 square feet of toys and baby offerings that marry all of the stores' concepts, including Kids "R" Us, under one roof. All Toys "R" Us stores are meant to have better customer service.
In the front of the giant marts, there will be a food vendor, most likely a McDonald's; a party room; a haircut salon, and a photo studio, all leased to franchisers. Elsewhere, there will be entertainment centers, breast-feeding rooms and a "castle" containing little girls' fitting rooms smack next to traditional girls' toys, intended to encourage cross-shopping.
"This is a big change from what we have been doing," said Mr. Goldstein, standing next to models of the three stores that sit alone on a table in a conference room. "We think it is going to be great for us."
AS Mr. Goldstein tells it, the fix he has in mind doesn't have to tie up a lot of cash and wreck margins. But much as he would like, he can't have it both ways. If the roll-out is so guarded and snail-like, how much good can it really do and how long will it take?
"It is quite expensive," Mr. Goldstein said, looking into the model of the Concept 2000. "We would like to remodel all of our stores this way, but it depends on sales increases."
He declined to say exactly how much this will cost, but analysts estimate that the company's capital expenditure budget in the current fiscal year will run in the neighborhood of $650 million, well over the $586 million the company spent last year..
How much the company ultimately spends on the overhaul "is absolutely material," said Peter Kupferberg, a portfolio manager at Gofen & Glossberg in Chicago, whose firm has slowly unloaded much of its holdings in the stock. "If they can't stick to their numbers, that will only push margins further."
At $27 a share, or 15 times next year's estimated earnings, about equal to what the overall market fetches, Toys "R" Us stock is not worth buying unless the company's management can keep sales growing at about 11 percent a year -- and fatten net margins back over 5 percent, more than triple last year's dismal performance. This will be no easy trick if the company is also paying for expensive make-overs.
Many investors think that Toys "R" Us has gone about as far as it can in the United States, where it has captured about 23 percent of the $23 billion toy-and-video market.
In their view, it will need strong international growth to push earnings growth.
"They can put up these new stores, but they are pretty saturated," said Greg Jackson, a portfolio manager at Yacktman Asset Management in Chicago, which has invested about $1.3 million in Toys "R" Us. "The tremendous growth potential is international, particularly in Japan."
He said Toys "R" Us did not have a Kmart or a Wal-Mart to do to it overseaswhat they did to it here. The company has 37 stores in Japan and will add 14 more this year, putting it in a dominant position in that market, too.
ANOTHER drag on domestic growth could be shopper inertia. "The perception of bad customer service at Toys was built up over many years and I think even at places where you've seen improvement, shoppers may not see it right away," said Sean P. McGowan, a retail analyst at Gerard Klauer Mattison.
Mr. Jackson said he was looking for the shares to increase by about $8 to about $35 over the next 18 months as the company's earnings growth rebounds. "If you compare it historically, this stock is extremely cheap." he said. "But we are looking at slower growth rates for the future."
For investors, the questions remain: Why did Toys "R" Us wait so long to explore new opportunities, and can the same team that got them into this jam lead them out? "We first started to think of making changes in late 1994," Mr. Goldstein said. "We saw a number of things happening. The expansion of Baby Superstores, of educational stores and the price aggressiveness of discount stores. We looked at all that and said, 'To meet the challenge going forward, what should we do?' "
Yet it seems odd that it took the folks at corporate headquarters until the end of 1994 to turn their thoughts to these issues, given that the discount chains have been turning on the heat since the early 1990's, educational stores have been rolling out since the beginning of the decade and the Baby Superstores concept was well under way by then, too.
"It is clear they should have done this five years ago," said Mr. Bryant of Rodman & Renshaw.
What is more, plenty of other retailers who don't even sell toys figured out long ago that parents needed a place to park tots. Ikea, the Swedish discount-furniture chain that invaded the United States a few years ago, has huge playrooms just waiting to be destroyed in its warehouse-like megastores. Barnes & Noble Jr. has live entertainment and readings for little shoppers. Even supermarkets often offer entertainment for kids, like rides for a quarter out front.
EVEN smaller companies have figured out the lure of pure fun. Noodle Kidoodle, an educational toy store based on Long Island, has a big-screen television that shows children's videos, and offers in-store use of computers to try out software. No one accuses this company of being short on cash, given its propensity for stock buybacks and its solid balance sheet. But Toys "R" Us is not used to pouring money into aesthetic improvements, and the addition of better and more workers on the floor will certainly take a bite out of the balance sheet.
Clearly, keeping costs in check is no easy task. Toys "R" Us beefed up its advertising budget by 10 percent last year, and will do so the same in 1996. Selling, general and administrative costs crept up from 19 percent to 20 percent of sales last year. "Mystery shoppers" now visit stores and report back to management on customer service.
And to help reduce the hopeless clutter of its stores, Toys "R" Us has also said it will reduce its store offerings from 15,000 to 11,000 items.
In a nod to stores like Zany Brainy, Noodle Kidoodle and Learningsmith, all regional toy stores offering wholesome playthings, Toys "R" Us will throw more educational toys into the mix and make the current ones more visible.
While Mr. Goldstein has always played down the threat factor of educational stores, shoppers seem to love them. In a recent visit to Natural Wonders, an educational store in Louisville, Doris Walker cruised the serene ailes with her 9-year-old granddaughter, Whitney Kelsey.
"I can see the appeal," said Mrs. Walker. "Everything is touchable."
Paring down the merchandise and rolling out new stores will take buying genius, and some spectators wonder if Mr. Goldstein and the president of his stores, Robert C. Nakasone, could use some help.
Mr. Nakasone comes from the supermarket industry, a background that many analysts say has worked for Toys "R" Us, with its emphasis on keeping a tight cost structure, but also against it by perpetuating a warehouse mentality in the display of goods. "They sell toys like cabbages," Mr. Bryant said.
While executive-search firm executives tend to praise the entire Toys "R" Us team, it is getting a little long in the tooth. True, to help start its expansion plan, it has called on outside consultants and even hired a new merchandising manager for Kids "R" Us. But all the top executives have been at the company for at least five years. Mr. Goldstein has been around for 13 years, and Mr. Nakasone for 11.
"The two senior people running this business are in finance and operations," said a person who works closely with the company and spoke on condition of anonymity. "What is essential now is that a strong merchandising acumen come into this."
Mr. Goldstein said he felt that his company has "the best merchandising team around," and didt seemed moved by the idea of hiring new people for the executive suite.
So what's the investor to make of all this? Given the maturity of the domestic business, the growing number of competitors breathing down the company's neck and the uncertainty abroad, investors are resigned to one fact: "It's never going to be the growth stock it once was," said Marina Carlson, a portfolio manager at Strong Capital in Milwaukee, which holds around a million Toys "R" Us shares. Nonetheless, she thinks the stock has potential for growth.
"We'd be happy at 10 to 12 percent," she said.
Several product introductions -- like new Star Wars figures, fresh Nintendo 64 videos and toys that spin off the films "101 Dalmatians," "Toy Story," and "Space Jam" -- should bolster Toys "R" Us this year. And the retailer is counting -- perhaps incorrectly -- on discounters to let up on the price wars, and for shoppers to catch on quickly to the store's operational changes.
MR. GOLDSTEIN does not seemed fazed by hard times. The company's headquarters in Paramus are just a few miles from one of the busiest Toys "R" Us stores in the country. Inside, Mr. Goldstein's office walls are plastered with framed comic strips and drawings that celebrate his company and its world-renowned name.
"This one is from the time we were really big," he said almost reverently, pulling at the corner of a framed old news clip. "And we'll be there again." But for now, the models of his dreams sit on a table in a silent conference room, eerily alone.

HEADLINE: Living Helpless and in Hope;
It's Not Easy Being 'Jose'

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: MAZATLAN, Mexico

 BODY:
THERE are nearly 100 million Mexicans below the Rio Grande, but in the heat of an American election campaign they often are reduced to cliches.
For the American who fears for his job, there is just "Jose," a malevolent and suspicious partner who would take what the United States has. For the businessman who worries about his investment, there is only a corrupt and indifferent Mexican system to be wary of. For a candidate who plays on fears, there is nothing but an unwelcome neighbor whose very language and culture are threats. 
 The truth is that even for the Mexicans themselves, these times are a puzzle. But in trying to understand the complexity of their lives, there is perhaps one good place to start: the perpetual coexistence, for most, of both hope and helplessness.
Consider the experience of a small group of women in this shrimp-catching port on the central Pacific coast.
These are hard times for Mexicans, as they struggle through ferocious economics and poisonous politics, and it became especially so last Sept. 14 in Mazatlan, when the luck of the shrimp men just ran out.
It was the season when men bet their lives against the weather to make the first catch, which provides 70 percent of the yearly harvest they export to the United States. Last September a tempest called Ismael sent to the bottom some 200 men on 50 boats, one of them called The Hurricane. Survivors said a government weather warning came too late.
Six months after the storm, some of the widows have formed what is probably the first women's fishing cooperative in Mexico. They have petitioned the Government to turn over three old shrimp boats confiscated in drug raids. The women will rely on relatives to do the actual fishing.
But now they have to contend with the infamous Mexican system -- which is indeed corrupt and indifferent. And this is what is difficult for people north of the Rio Grande to understand. The Mexican people tolerate this system, but they do not trust it. It is, in a way, part of their fate to put up with it, like the hurricanes.
So the women can only wait for the boats to be released to them.
Casilda Rodriguez Morales, whose husband and son went down on The Hurricane, refuses to despair. With luck, she says, the three ships will put to sea in September.
She remembers the morning when she last talked, quietly in her still-dark kitchen, with her husband Arcadio and their 17-year-old son Mauricio. "We were saving for a washing machine," she says. The men had been forced back to port by a refrigeration problem on their boat. "Mami, there are many shrimp," Mauricio told her. A good catch could bring $3,000 -- enough for the washer and to finish the small house they are building.
"Many, many shrimp."
And then they were gone.
Anyone who has seen a Mexican construction site, where men dressed in rags scamper up rough ladders shouldering five-gallon tin cans of wet cement, knows that Mexicans accept hardship. In some Indian communities, corn stalks must be bent during the rainy reason so the rain slips off the husks and does not rot the corn. This is made into a lesson for life: In order to survive, a person must accept hardship and be willing to be bent.
So now, surviving on a $60-dollar-a- month pension, Casilda Rodriguez and her five remaining children expect little help from outside their family or the extended family of the shrimp cooperative. She is not surprised that the Government is dragging its feet on the legal process of giving up the three boats, which are docked at Mazatlan under Navy guard.
"We stupidly support the party at election time and then afterwards they forget us completely," said Rosario Gonzalez, another shrimp women whose husband was trapped in an air-bubble in his overturned boat but died when a diver, contracted by the government, cut open an escape hole and let the air slip out.
 
 
 
Not Expecting Welfare
 So these are women who have learned not to expect the Government to solve their problems; at best they hope for permission -- as with the three confiscated boats -- to help themselves.
It is hardly the stereotype so often presented in the United States of Mexicans seeking to pour across the border to take advantage of welfare. "Look, if we could one day have relationships among citizens in the States and citizens in Mexico, we would both be surprised at what we are," said Vicente Fox, a central state governor and prominent opposition politician. "Unfortunately, the only relationship now is through politics, and that's completely deviated from what we really are."
Outsiders often say that Mexico is hard to understand; a European ambassador here says serving in revolutionary Iran was easier than being in Mexico the last four years. For the sense of tragedy itself is complicated. Forged in the clash of Indian warriors and Spanish conquistadors, and unable to declare either side winner or loser, the Mexicans have from the beginning seen defeat as unavoidable, but not permanent.
 
 
 
A National Depression

And the Mexican character today is not simply stiff upper lips and valor. There is corruption and indolence, and an almost primitive violence in much of life. And after more than 15 months of the worst economic depression in 60 years, some prominent Mexicans, like the columnist Raymundo Riva Palacio, think Mexicans suffer from a national depression.
These heirs of Mexico's revolution have taken this crisis calmly. For over the decades they have been lulled into acceptance by an overpowering triumvirate: single-party government, milquetoast labor unions and the powerful television network Televisa, which finds reporting on real crime distasteful even as it fills soap operas with rape, murder and betrayal.
There may be no more practical symbol of the way Mexicans understand the relationship between hardship and hope than the block-and-concrete houses in which most poor Mexicans live. The walls of the ground floor go up first, and then steel bars are set in concrete to form corner posts. The bars extend several feet above the roof line and are capped with Coke bottles to keep them from rusting.
These are called "los castillos" -- the castles -- and they represent a hope, not in the system or the Government, but simply in the possibility that someday things will get better and that there will be enough money to build a second floor.
Casilda Rodriguez's husband left that September morning promising her that this would be the year to finish their house.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rosario Gonzales, left, Rosalina Sanchez Perez, center, and Maria de Jesus Miramontes set out to inspect hoped-for boats (right). (Keith Dannemiller/SABA, for The New York Times)
