HEADLINE: Counties Make Big Reductions In Home Relief

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 29

 BODY:
When Chris Scott applied for welfare last month, his case manager handed him a pamphlet that laid out strict guidelines he had to follow. It had a bland title, "Job Search Handbook," but to Mr. Scott it read like a manifesto for sharply curtailing public assistance -- a movement that is taking hold in counties across New York.
The pamphlet emphasized that people who want to get welfare in Albany County must first look for a job, enroll in a training program or participate in workfare. It also warned that anyone who violated the most minor of regulations would lose benefits. And that is what happened to Mr. Scott when his case manager accused him of not hunting aggressively for a job. 
 "They're just taking the whole situation entirely too far," said Mr. Scott, 25, an unemployed painter, after unsuccessfully appealing the decision at the county welfare office the other day.
Officials in Albany County disagreed, saying that they had a right to demand that welfare applicants like Mr. Scott try to find work. This newly hardened attitude is not unique to Albany County. Across the state, county officials are imposing broad new constraints on Home Relief, the program for childless adults that has existed in some form in the state since the Depression.
While Federal and state leaders continue to debate new restrictions on welfare, the county officials -- both Republicans and Democrats -- are pushing ahead on their own, stiffening requirements by using state laws that have been on the books for years but were rarely enforced.
They are being joined by officials in New York City, which has reduced its Home Relief rolls by 26.9 percent in the last 13 months. The city is so large that it administers welfare on its own.
Albany County has cut the number of people on Home Relief 76.2 percent, to 690 last month, from 2,900 in December 1993, county officials said. In 1993, the state and county spent $11 million on Home Relief in Albany County. Last year, that figure dropped to $5.4 million.
"The model is this: We talk about your last day on welfare on your first day on welfare," said Ross A. Prinzo Jr., Commissioner of Social Services in Albany County.
The campaign by the counties to trim the Home Relief rolls comes as these programs are under attack across the country. In recent years, several states, including Michigan, Illinois and Ohio, have cut welfare for able-bodied, childless adults, either doing away with these benefits altogether or setting time limits on how long people can receive them.
As a result, New York is one of the few states that still has no time limits on Home Relief, according to the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a research organization in Washington.
Gov. George E. Pataki wants to change that, calling in his proposed budget for a 60-day limit on Home Relief for people who can work. The Governor is also seeking to scale back the other major welfare program, Aid to Families With Dependent Children, but that is more complicated because A.F.D.C. is federally mandated and new rules must emanate from Washington.
Home Relief is a state program not subject to Federal guidelines. It is also generally easier to require Home Relief recipients to look for jobs because welfare officials do not have to worry about issues like child care; most Home Relief recipients do not support young children.
It is not clear whether the Legislature, particularly the Democrats who control the State Assembly, will agree to the Governor's proposed time limits on Home Relief. But even without them, many counties are already trying to move able-bodied recipients into jobs within 60 days.
Over all, efforts by the state's 57 counties and New York City have reversed a sharp rise in the Home Relief rolls that began in the 1980's.
The monthly average of Home Relief recipients in New York jumped to 388,088 in 1993 from 174,306 in 1981, according to the State Department of Social Services. But in 1995's first 11 months, that average dropped to 343,069. And in December, the figure fell to 279,230.
The crackdowns are drawing pointed attacks from advocates for the poor, who maintain that officials are so bent on reducing spending that they are using technicalities to shove people off welfare.
The advocates warn that these policies could backfire because people who were once on welfare could end up in homeless shelters, on the streets or in emergency rooms -- situations that often cost more than public assistance.
"They are using every dotted 'i' and crossed 't' that they can find, knowing full well that it makes no sense," said Anne Erickson, legislative coordinator for the Greater Upstate Law Project, a lobbying group for poor people. "They know that jobs are not there and they are sending them out on wild goose chases and waiting for them to fail so they can reduce their rolls."
For example, Mr. Scott, the unemployed painter, lost his benefits when he broke the rules on job searches. He was told that he had to file applications with 12 employers within two weeks. He went to 12, thinking that he had filled the requirements. But then his case manager told him that all 12 employers had to be hiring and that because only 6 were, he had failed and his case was immediately closed.
Mr. Scott maintains that he did not know that all the employers had to be hiring; county welfare officials said they had made that clear to him.
New York City has about 75 percent of the state's Home Relief population, and under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the city has been aggressively trying to reduce its rolls. The number of Home Relief recipients dropped in the city to 218,168 last January from 298,560 in December 1994, according to the city's Human Resources Administration.
While the city has gained attention for cutting welfare, some counties have made even bigger strides.
Besides Albany County -- which has a Democratic County Executive, Michael G. Breslin -- Suffolk, Westchester and Allegany Counties, which are led by Republicans, have also sharply cut their Home Relief rolls. Suffolk has lowered its tally 29.3 percent, to 3,274 last December, from 4,633 in January 1994, officials said. Another county with Democratic leadership, Erie, has also made significant reductions.
The Governor and the State Legislature have influenced this shift in welfare, instituting new policies like fingerprinting applicants to reduce fraud. And last June, the Legislature passed new rules intended to insure that able-bodied welfare recipients look for jobs and participate in workfare. But it is clear from a day spent at a welfare office in Albany County that many local officials have seized the initiative.
Take the pamphlet that Mr. Scott was handed when he requested welfare. The state published it several years ago, but before 1993, many counties either did not use it or did not abide by the regulations it describes.
These days, almost every person on welfare in Albany County must carry a copy of the pamphlet on job searches and have potential employers sign it to prove that the recipient really did come by. The rules have left some applicants grumbling, but others said they supported the county.
Will Grant, 29, applied for welfare last month to help pay his rent and was told that within two weeks he had to seek work from at least 12 employers who were hiring. He did, and soon found a part-time job as a custodian.
"People come here with an attitude, and they expect certain things," he said. "This motivates you. It makes you want to do something. You can't just sit around. Even if you get a part-time job, it's better than nothing."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
It's Spring, and Seeds Are Sown for Ice Rinks

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

DATELINE: ELMSFORD

 BODY:
NOW that the crocuses are up and spring is in the air it seems an odd time to be discussing ice skating. But ground will be broken next month for a twin rink complex open to the public in Elmsford, the first to be built in Westchester in 21 years.
The rinks, which will be National Hockey League size and operate year-round, should be ready for use by the end of summer, according to Philip C. King, director of leasing for Baker Properties, of Pleasantville, which is developing the project. 
 The 70,000-square-foot building housing the rinks, snack bar, lockers and showers will be built in the Fairview Corporate Park, where there is also a golf-driving range. Across the street is a sports entertainment center and a miniature-car racing track. The varied operations form a recreational hub along the heavily commercial Route 9A.
"Route 9A is probably one of the ugliest strips in town," said Paul J. Feiner, the Greenburgh Town Supervisor. "Now it's becoming a real center for recreation. There are also several retail projects that have been proposed for the area. I predict that in five years, it will be one of the nicest places in town."
The Golden Bear Driving Range, which opened in 1993, is a two-tiered heated building comprising a golf driving range and two 18-hole miniature golf courses. The building and surrounding property take up 25 acres. "We looked all over Westchester," said Dominic Chang, president of Family Golf Centers of Melville, L.I., which owns the complex. "It was extremely difficult to find this much land that was zoned commercial."
Across the street is Sportime U.S.A., which opened in 1989. It has batting cages, pool and billiard tables, a virtual reality baseball game and a children's playground with rides.
"Our market is primarily young kids," said Jack Stahl, general manager. He added that professional ball players also come by to work out. "We get a lot of professional baseball players," he said. Mike Torres, a former New York Yankee, and Anthony Mason, the New York Knicks basketball player, have both been in to use the batting cages, Mr. Stahl said.
Directly beneath Sportime U.S.A. is Elmsford Raceway, formerly the lone recreational facility in the area. Offering model-car racing on tracks, it has been in business since 1966.
MR. CHANG said he's pleased about the addition of the ice-skating rinks. "We're the anchor of what's becoming a recreational center," he said, referring to his driving range. "Our whole concept is family entertainment, and the rinks will certainly help bring more families to the area."
The 80-acre Fairview Corporate Park is also home to several industrial concerns, such as a Coca-Cola bottling plant and a Federal Express sorting operation. "Out of the 80 acres, 17 are still available for development," said Mr. King of Baker Properties.
Fittingly, the corporate park's property was the Fairview Country Club as recently as the 60's, when it was converted to a light-industrial park, Mr. King said. Baker Properties purchased the park in 1985, "just when the whole economy changed," he added.
"In a different economic climate," Mr. King said, "the first choice would be to build office buildings in the park. But with the market in Westchester as it is now, that's not a good choice."
In contrast, the rinks represent little risk, Mr. King said. "This is a terrific use and a great addition to the park," he said. "It's not a speculative use. There's a real demand for this facility."
There are already four public rinks in Westchester -- the indoor Hommocks Park Ice Rink in Mamaroneck and Playland Ice Casino in Rye (the practice rink for the New York Rangers) and the outdoor Ebersole Ice Rink in White Plains and E.J. Murray Skating Center in Yonkers.
The two new rinks will be 85 by 200 feet, less that the Olympic size 100 by 200 feet. "These rinks will allow for the expansion of local school teams and allow other leagues to form," Mr. King said.
As any hockey parent knows, getting a child to practice can mean predawn excursions to get precious ice time. Older players are often relegated to playing at midnight.
According to USA Hockey, the national governing body for ice hockey, 24,555 teams registered with the organization during the 1994-1995 season, compared with 14,962 teams in 1990-1991, an increase of 64 percent.
"This is one project that if it didn't get approved people in town would have killed me," Mr. Feiner said. "Since I've been supervisor, this is the most excited I've been about a project. This is something that children, teen-agers and adults can enjoy."
In better times, such a project might even have been attempted by the town itself, he said. "With reduced revenues, this a way for the town to have recreation and improvement along the 9A corridor with no cost to the taxpayer."
OTHER towns in Westchester are equally enthusiastic about the addition of ice-skating rinks. Linda Puglisi, supervisor of the town of Cortland, has been trying to persuade the National Hockey League to build an ice-skating complex in her town.
According to Ms. Puglisi, the league has been looking for sites to build an Olympic-size ice skating rink, an N.H.L.-size rink and a roller-hockey rink. It has been in touch with her about a possible site in Sprout Brook Park. In addition, she recently wrote to the league recommending three privately owned sites on Route 9A, near the soon-to-be-built Cortlandt train station, and two on Route 6. Each site is at least 10 acres, she said. "They need at least 8 to 10 acres for what they have in mind."
According to Ms. Puglisi, the N.H.L. wants the complex for children's hockey leagues, professional hockey exhibitions, figure skating, lessons and a building for Rollerblade skating. "Their main purpose is to encourage youngsters to get into hockey," she said.
In addition, the town hopes to build a new rink near the 404,235-square-foot Cortlandt Town Center shopping complex proposed in Mohegan.
Ms. Puglisi asked the developer, CBL & Associates Properties of Chattanooga, Tenn., to set aside one acre for the town's use. "Our recreation committee advised us that an ice-skating rink would be the best use," she said.

HEADLINE: The Princess and a Plea: More Money

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
ON the day Lady Diana Spencer married into the House of Windsor in 1981, her good fortune appeared to be boundless. Hardly out of her teens, she decommissioned the world's foremost bachelor and signed on to produce the next heir of a monarchy whose wealth is conservatively estimated at more than $8 billion. Fifteen years later, her divorce nearly a fait accompli, the Princess of Wales faces a reversal of fortune.
British newspapers report that Princess Diana is to receive $22.5 million, enough to generate $1 million a year for life, with annual increases to cover inflation, plus a castle and staff. While that sum might be princely for commoners, compared to the settlements of other people who married into great wealth and then divorced, hers averages $1.6 million for each year of marriage. Her ex-Prince Charming looks like a piker. 
 But British law protects Charles's assets with a so-called "millionaire's law," which enables a wealthy spouse to make a cheap divorce settlement, unlike American law, which embodies the concept of shared wealth. His sister-in-law, the Duchess of York, is yet to divorce her husband, Andrew, although it is reported that she and her daughters will get a lump sum of $3 million, two-thirds to go into a trust fund for the girls, plus tuition and about $37,000 in yearly maintenance.
Princess Diana can only dream about divorce American style. Consider the settlement obtained by Amy Irving, the actress. She reportedly received close to $100 million for her marriage to Steven Spielberg, which last less than three and a half years -- or about 18 times as much, per year of marriage, as Princess Diana stands to receive.
In a country that is settlement friendly in marital law, California, the home of community property, is the promised land. Frank Swertlow, a "Hard Copy" correspondent who follows the money of film industry leaders, said a half dozen divorces involving movie stars and directors in the past year have produced settlements bigger than Princess Diana's. "The best way to make money is a good Hollywood divorce," Mr. Swertlow said.
Kevin Costner's wife, Cindy, reportedly is seeking $40 million from him after 16 years of marriage. Tom Arnold is getting "millions and millions and millions," says Roseanne, his former wife of four years.
The Princess, however, did better than Ivan F. Boesky, the arbitrager convicted of insider trading. After almost 30 years of marriage to his wife, Seema Silberstein, a hotel heiress, Mr. Boesky received a mansion worth $2.5 million, $180,000 a year for life plus a lump sum of $20 million. The lump works out to $689,000 per year of marriage, or less than half what Princess Diana expects for each year of hers.
Raoul Felder, a Manhattan divorce lawyer who specializes in divorces of the rich and famous, said he was surprised at the paltry terms of the royal divorce. "Princess Di gets a castle and staff and so forth," Mr. Felder said, "but the cash is not very much considering her bills, which include $250,000 a year for clothing."
Mr. Felder said he would have expected a settlement more in line with what Patricia Kluge received in 1991 when her marriage to John W. Kluge ended after nine years. At the time Forbes magazine ranked Mr. Kluge as the richest American, with a net worth of $5.2 billion.
Mrs. Kluge received a 45-room Georgian mansion on 9.9 acres, surrounded by Mr. Kluge's 10,000-acre farm near Charlottesville, Va., and $1 billion. Invested very conservatively in 30-year Treasury bonds, that sum would throw off $66 million a year at current interest rates, giving Mrs. Kluge a far more comfortable annual income than the Princess will have.
Such payment streams are common in cases where one partner has much more money than the other, said Kathleen Miller, a financial planner in Bellevue, Wash., who has helped more than 2,000 men and women negotiate divorce settlements. Mrs. Miller, the author of "Fair Share Divorce for Women" (Miller Advisors, 1995), said that when the Princess began leaking details of her marriage and giving a television interview about her life with Price Charles "she was negotiating the business terms of their divorce."
Threats of disclosure often produce more money, Mrs. Miller said.
If that was Princess Diana's intention, her strategy appears to have produced a relatively modest payoff. But then again, if one of her sons becomes king, all bets may be off.

HEADLINE: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION: CHOOSING SIDES

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI 

 BODY:
PHAT X. CHIEM UNDERSTOOD well why many of his fellow Vietnamese-american students on the University of California's campus here opposed affirmative action.
 
 In 1979, he fled Saigon with his mother. Like tens of thousands of South Vietnamese refugees, they settled in Orange County, living in Costa Mesa, just a quick drive up the freeway from Irvine. When it came time for college, Mr. Chiem's high schools grades were good enough to get him into U.C.L.A. But given the limits of his mother's wages as a factory worker, and the expense of living in Los Angeles, Mr. Chiem decided instead to stay home and commute to Irvine.
 Many in his old circle of high school friends - strictly other Vietnamese-Americans - also enrolled at school. And they hoped that by the spring of 1998, when the University of California has said it will stop using race as a factor in admissions for African-American, Hispanic and American Indian applicants, the acceptance odds would rise for Asian-Americans like them.
 But at Irvine, Mr. Chiem made a second group of friends through his work on the campus newspaper. Most of them were whites. He quit the pre-med track to major in English. He spent the next few years covering the campus's different racial and ethnic groups, and spent summers in Fresno and Seattle as a reporting intern. By last year when he was elected editor in chief of the paper, The New University, Mr. Chiem's view of community had changed. And so had his views on affirmative action.
 "Will Vietnamese-Americans benefit by the elimination of affirmative action?" said Mr. Chiem, now 21 and a senior, as he sat in a tree-lined plaza next tot he main library. "Yes, I think so. But my concern is, are we then going to have a campus that's all Asian-American and white? When you have a campus where the population of African-Americans is 2 percent, it's hard to say we should eliminate affirmative action to increase the number of Asian-Americans."
 Many Asian-Americans have found themselves torn over the ban on affirmative action at the nation's leading state-run university system. Last July, under pressure from Gov. Pete Wilson,t he Board of Regents decided that the new admission policies would focus on academic achievement but would still allow the nine campuses to consider the impact of an applicant's dis-advantaged economic background.
 The new criteria are expected to boost the number of Asian-Americans, who generally have the highest grades and test scores of any racial group, and to hurt African-American and Hispanic applicants.
 Binh Nguyen, 21, has been Mr. Chiem's best friend since they were 12. Mr. Nguyen admired his friend's individualism and the ease with which he moved in mainstream campus life. Mr. Nguyen's family, who arrived in the United States from Saigon in 1975, considered the medical profession the ideal, safest road to success in America. So an older sister graduated from George Washington University medical school, and an older brother is studying medicine at U.C.L.A.
 At Irvine, Mr. Nguyen was planning to be a fifth-year senior next year to boost his 3.4 grade-point average before applying to medical school. He was worried that for an Asian-American like him, getting into a University of California medical school would be hard. He also worried for Khang Lai and Nhat Tran, friends of his and Mr. Chiem's, who were applying to medical school this year and whose G.P.A.'s were higher than his own.
 "Without affirmative action, it would help me to get into med school," Mr. Nguyen said. "Affirmative action is kind of needed, but for me as an applicant, I would personally not support it. I would look at affirmative action more on an individual basis, how if affects me, rather than how it affects other minority groups. I wouldn't think how it affects all Asians. I wouldn't think that big. I would extend it to my friends. I would say Khang and Naht are qualified. And if they didn't get in and they're qualified, I would be bummed."
 For Asian-Americans the issue often comes down to this: Do they look out for their own interests? Or do they broaden their sense of community to include the interests of African-Americans and Hispanics? It is a particularly difficult question for what continues to be a largely immigrant population, already split along ethnic, generational, linguistic and income lines.
 AT one end are Chinese-Americans and Japanese-Americans who have been in the United States for a century and whose income and educational levels are above the national average. At the other economic end are Vietnamese, Laotians and Cambodians who came ias refugees in the 1970's and 1980's; many of them are illiterate in their own language. In the vast middle: the Chinese, Koreans, Indians, Filipinos, many of them professional, who have come to the United States since 1965. The difference in opinions over affirmative action can also be heard at the dinner table: between the parent who mixes only with fellow immigrants and the child who attends a college with a diverse student body.
 And while Asians are not the only minority immigrant group in this country with such divisions, their disproportionately high numbers in higher edcuation and their resulting exclusion from the race-based affirmative action initiatives do serve to put them in a special position. Many believe that Asian-Americans' potential political strength is weakened by their internal divisions.
 "Even at Berkeley, Asian-Americans are apthetic or disagree with one another," said Justin Fong, 21, a junion who has organized building takeovers to fight for affirmative action. "It's very difficult to get anthing done."
 The issue of affirmative action in California is further complicated by the California Civil Rights Initiative, a proposed state amendment that would ban race-based affirmative action in government hiring and contracting. The state will vote on it in November.
 "We recognize the problem with the U.C. systme. Now we're being excluded because of affirmative action," said Charles Kim, executive director of the Los Angeles-based Korean-American coalition, which, like other Asian-American civil rights organizations, is fighting the amendment. "But at this point, affirmative action is one way to achieve social and economic equiality. At this point, for example, if you take a look at the managerial level, we're severely underrepresented."
 In the 1980's, education seemed to be the one issue that did unify Asian-Americans.
 Congress lifted stringent quotas on immigration from Asia and Latin American in 1965 and gave preference to immigrants closely related to citizens. Their numbers increased so much that they now represent the largest groups of foreign-born residents in this country. By the late 1980's, many children of those post-1965 Asian immigrants had reached college age and were becoming a growing share of the student populations at mnay of the nation's elite universities.
 At the time, many Asian-American academics and advocates charged that institutions like Stanford, Berkeley, Harvard and Brown were informally capping the number of Asian-Americans they admitted. The universities, advocates said, were re-erecting the unofficial quotas that two generations earlier had kept the gorwing number of qualified Jews from their campuses. The universitites largely denied these accusations, arguing instead that Asian applicants tended to be concentrated in the sciences and tended not to be the offspring of alumni.
 Between 1988 and 1995, 16 out of 40 of the complaints filed with the Department of Education involving Asian-Americans and admissions at colleges or universities resulted in decisions favoring the complainant, according to a report by the United States General Accounting Office released in December. That proportion was far higher than for any other racial group.
 Today, many Asian-Americans say that it is the affirmative action policies at public institutions like the University of California that perpetuate the practice of denying them educational opportunities they have rightly won.
 "When I was young, I had hard time getting things because I was Japanese, and now it's the other way around," said S. Stephen Nakashima, 73, a University of California Regent who voted to ban race-based affirmative action. "You're Japanese, you're doing well, and they won't accpet you."
 "Back then," Mr. Nakashima said, referring to American society before addirmative action policies was created in the 1960's, "the discrimination was against Asians, blacks and Chicanos. Now it's against the whites and Asians."
 The Supreme Court decided last May that race-based scholarships were unconstitutional. In January, Colorado began giving out only class-based scholarships. University systems in several states also are reviewing how they grant scholarships. And Arizona's state university system is considering eliminating race as a factor in it admissions.
 But it is in California, home to 40 percent of the nation's 774,000 Asian-American college and university students in 1994 (New York was a distant second with 8 percent), that Asian-Americans must navigate affirative action's politically treacherous waters.
 Although Asian-Americans are only 10 percent of California's population, they make up about a third of the undergraduates in the state system. They are the largest racial group at Irvine, Riverside and the system's two most competitive universities, U.C.L.A. and Berkeley. And in city college systems and in community colleges across the state, they make up a disproportionately high score of the student population. Event he percentage of Asian faculty, which is only about 4 percent throughout the country, according to the United States Department of Education, is about 20 percent in the University of California.
 Worried about the effects of the end of affirmative action, many educators are groping for ways to maintain the racial diversity of their campuses. Berkeley's Chancellor, Chang-Lin Tien, a Chinese-American, is the only Asian-American head of a U.C. campus. (See Related essay on Page 30.) Chancellor Tien, who opposes the ban on affirmative action, said his university has pledged $1 million annually over five years to help disadvantaged youths from the San francisco area's major urban school districts qualify for entrance.
 . . .
 AT IRVINE, the university's unusual racial mix has spawned nicknames that, depending on who tells the joke, can be self-mocking or resentful. What does U.C.I. stand for? "The University of Chinese Immigrants" or "The University of Civics and Integras," after the Hondas and Acuras that are the favorite cars of many Asian-Americans on campus.
 A Waylkway near the student center is plastered with a poster in Korean and English, announcing a sports match between a Korean-American students' association for those who speak Korean and a Korean-American association for those who do not. Inside the food court, students can order Chinese food and sushi. The food court also is a favorite hangout for many members of the five Asian sororities and fraternities, while the tables just outside are popular among those how belong to white Greek societies. Unaffiliated Asian-Americans are partial to the cafe.
 Yet there also is a cross-cultural center on campus housing three umbrella groups whose purpose is to unify African-American, Hispanic and Asian-American students. And there is mixing of students even in the carings on a tree. On a eucalyptus behind the plaza, a heart is carved with "Jenn & Thanh," the latter being a Vietnamese male name; next to it are the Vietnamese and English names of two women, "Xuan & Marla."
 Not too long ago, Michelle Tsui was flipping through old family albums and recognized several photos of herself - at age 1 - in front of Irvine's main library. She realized that her parents, among the first wave of Chinese immigrants to move to Orange County just as U.C. Irvine was founded in 1965, had clear intentions.
 "My parents visited the campus because even back then they wanted me to study here," said Ms. Tsui, 22, who last year became the first Asian-American to be elected president of U.C. Irvine's student government.
 Manuel N. Gomez, now a vice chancellor who has been at Irvine since 1972, said many Asian immigrant families, like Ms. Tsui's gravitated to Orange County because of the university.
 The racial makeup of the campus reflects in part the change in Orange County over the last two decades from largely white population to one with one of the most diverse conentrations of Asian immigrants. Sarting in the early 1970's, Chinese immigrants settled throughout the area, followed by Vietnamese refugees and Korean immigrants, who eventually built a Little Saigon and a Koreatown in the cities of Garden Grove and Westminster. Irvine is also just 50 miles south of Los Angeles's population of both recent and more established Asian-American gorups.
 Phuong Pham, 22, a senior who heads a Vietnamese-American students organization, said she is a minority among Vietnamese-Americans in supporting affirmative action. Even though she came to this country only in 1982, after spending her early childhood in Saigon, where she and her mother sold matches on the street to support themselves, Ms. Pham said she does not share what she described as her fellow Vietnamese-Americans' narrow view of community.
 "They tell me, 'We came here with almost no English and we've worked hard to be proficient. We're on survival mode. So how can we think of other groups?' " Ms. Pham said. "I tell them, 'now that you're proficient in English, stop being selfish and work with other groups. You should go beyond survival mode.' "
 Sunny Lee, 22, immigrated from South Korea at the age of 6 and grew up in largely white community in San Bernardino. Drawn to Irvine's large Asian-American population, she was surprised to discover others with the same length and style of hair, and a few with the same length and style of hair, and a few with the same first and last name as hers. But perhaps most surprising, she said, was learning about the deep divisions among Irvine's Asian-American students.
 Because of Irvine's large immigrant population, the Asian-American students' varying levels of assimilation was one such divide, ranging from those who were "fresh off the boat" to those who were so "white-washed," she said, that they joined Irvine's white fraternities and sororities, instead of the Asian ones.
 To bridge those divides, Ms. Lee is the social chair-woman of the Asian/Pacific Student Association, an umbrella group for 19 of the campus's Asian-American organizations. The association considers itself nonpolitical, although its officers support affirmative action.
 "This alliance was created in 1984 so that the heads of the organizations would know what the others were doing," she said, "but it's difficult."
 Perhaps because the Asian-Americans on campus are politically disorganized or undecided about affirmative action, Irvine has not experienced the protests over its elimination like those at U.C.L.A. or Berkeley. In the fall, a small group of Hispanic students at Irvine, supported by advocates from off campus, held a hunger strike. But the strikers ended up attracting little support among Asian-American students, many of whom said they felt alienated by the strikers' extremism.
 On a recent evening, about 60 people gathered at the cross-cultural center to listen to Ms. Lee and other Asian-American student leaders talk at a meeting for the Asian/Pacific Student Association. The messages were hardly political, but he underlying attempt at unity was clear. Students stood and explained what their organizations were doing, inviting others to functions. Four groups lobbied for membership in the umbrella organization.
 The next day, Stephanie Essig, 21, a black biology major from Oakland who was sitting in the African-American student union at the cross-cultural center, said she was surprised at the Asian-Americans' political disunity. "Thye have the potential to be so politically powerful on this campus," she said.
 For her, she said, life would be the same if she were on a campus with 53 percent whites. What mattered was the small number of other African-American students. Despite her 3.7 grade point average at a Cathloc high school and her score of 1,200 out of 1,600 on her Scholastic Assessment Test, she thought white and Asian-American students viewed her a having slipped into Irvine because of affirmative action.
 .. .
 AND THEN THERE are the Regents. It was Ward Connerly, an African-American businessman and Regent who proposed the July vote banning affirmative action in admissions. Mr. Nakashima, joined by the other Asian-American Regent, David Lee, a Chinese-American, voted with Mr. Connerly. Mr. Lee has spoken little about his decision. Not so Mr. Nakashima.
 Because of his Japanese ancestry, Mr. Nakashima was interned in a United States Government camp during World War II. He graduated from Berkeley in 1948 and began seeking jobs as a certified public accountant. Companies, he recalled, refused to hire him. And so Mr. Nakashima went to Berkeley's Boalt Hall School of Law.. Eventually he built a successful law practice in San Jose, and in 1989 he was appointed to the University of California's Board of Regents by former Gov. George Deukmejian.
 Mr. Nakashima said the new admission policies will concentrate Asian-Americans at Berkeley and U.C.L.A. and shift African-American and Hispanic students to the other campuses.
 "The young black and Chicano students should enter the rights schools," said Mr. Nakashima, whose children and grandchildren also attended the state's public universities. "If a young black student gets into Berkeley or U.C.L.A. and has a 3.4 average, and has to compete against 4.0's, what is he going to do? He can't compete."
 The University of California guarantees a place at one of its campuses to the top 12.5 percent of high school seniors int he state. But although 13 percent of whites, 5 percent of African-American seniors and 4 percent of Hipsanic students qualified in 1990, 32 percent of Asians-Americans did. The data, which the state collects twice a decade, are expected to show a further rise in qualifying Asian-Americans for 1995.
 Starting for the spring enrollment of 1998, grades and scores on the S.A.T. test alone will determine 50 to 75 percent of students accepted, compared with the current levels of 40 to 60 percent. For the remaining slots, admission officers will instead weight an applicant's socioeconomic background.
 An internal report in May 1995, based on a computer simulation, predicted that such a change would result in a 15 to 25 percent overall rise of Asian-Americans at the University of California, and as much as 25 to 35 percent increase at Berkeley and U.C.L.A., where 75 percent of students would be admitted on merit. The number of whites would remain about the same, but Hispanic students would dip 5 to 15 percent and African-Americans would drop somewhere between 40 and 50 percent.
 The report acknowledges that the outcome may not be so stark. But it is clear, said Terry Colvin, a spokesman for the university of California, that the new policy will boost Asian-American enrollment.
 Lance T. Izumi, a fellow at the San Francisco-based Pacific Research Institute who testified at the hearings before the Board of Regents' decision in July, said the current race-based policies especially harm newer Asian-American group. The newer groups, like Vietnamese or Cambodians, are lumped in with more affluent Asian-Americans who, if rejected at a public university, can arfford to turn elsewhere, said Mr. Izumi, 37, whose grandparents came from Japan.
 In a study of the acceptance rates of 519 U.C. Irvine students who applied to the University of California's five medical schools in 1993, the Pacific Research Institute found that black and some Hispanic applicants were admitted at more than twice the rate of Vietnamese-American applicants whose grades were higher. The Vietnamese-Americans were excluded from the race-based affirmative action policies, even though 49 out of the 107 Vietnamese-American applicants were considered economically disadvantaged. The study found that other Asian groups were also admitted at lower rates.
Because Asian-Americans of all economic levels often are able to compete academically, Mr. Izumi said, only true competition, will benefit them.
 A recent ruling by a Federal appeals court overturning the affirmative-action program at the University of Texas School of Law also argued for such competition, saying that the school failed to show justification for giving preference to some races.
JERRY KANG believes that affirmative action produces more pluses than minuses for society.
 Mr. Kang was born in South Korea and grew up near Chicago. He went to Harvard as an undergraduate and also studied law there. Now 27, and an acting law professor at U.C.L.A., he has written law articles on affirmative action. Simply put, he supports it.
 "I usually explain that all people of color have benefited from the civil rights movement," he said. "Then I explain why affirmative action can be good for the future. Different races rubbing shoulders, that's good. If someone's going to be less racist to blacks, then they're going to be less racist toward Asian-Americans. But it's difficult, especially with immigrant parents who don't even think in those terms. In Korean culture, there tends to be a belief that if you don't succeed, it's your fault."
Polls show Asian-Americans in California split down the middle on affirmative action. Like at Irvine, their internal divisions have weakened their political influence.
 Nationally, the most outspoken and ardent supporters of affirmative action often might be Chinese-American and Japanese-American academics, who were born in the United States and went to college during the 1960's or 1970's. As heads of organizations, they become spokesmen for the largely politically unorganized Asian-American population. As teachers, they become advisers to students on campuses.
But their critics argue that they represent a privileged class out of touch with the needs of recent arrivals. According to the Washington-based Urban Institute, 66 percent of the 7.3 million Asian-Americans in this country were born overseas.
"The academics and activists are stuck in the 1960's and don't represent the views of most Asian-Americans," said Arthur Hu, a Chinese-American computer software engineer in Seattle, who neccessary info?keeps a home page on the Internet's World Wide Web to expound on his opposition to anti-affirmative action views.
 Mr. Hu, 37, graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1981. He set up the page (http://www.halcyon.com/arthurhu) in October, out of his home office, which is lined with bookshelves jammed with articles on affirmative action and books on Asian-Americans. Since the fall, Mr. Hu said he has received about three to four E-mail messages a week, many of them from Asian-Americans who told him they were glad to hear a conservative Asian-American voice.
 In San Francisco, a group of Chinese families, most of them immigrants, is suing the school district, which had capped at 40 percent the share of Chinese-American students allowed to enroll at its most prestigious school, Lowell High School. The district also imposed a higher cut-off on the entrance exams for the Chinese, while allowing lower qualifying marks for whites, other Asians, blacks and Hispanics.
 In February, the school district set the same cut-off on entrance exams for 80 percent of all students, but still kept the 40 percent cap for any one ethnic group. Chinese students now are slightly over that cap. For the remaining 20 percent, an applicant's socioeconomically disadvantaged background, as well as other factors, are considered.
Lee Cheng, a 24-year-old Chinese-American student at Berkeley's Boalt Hall School of Law, who attended Lowell before going to Harvard, is among those representing the Chinese families.
 The lawsuit seeks to abolish the quotas, which were set up in 1982 following a lawsuit by the San Francisco chapter of of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. Opponents of the change, including some Asian-Americans, say that the elimination of the current policy would turn Lowell into a virtually all-Chinese school.
"Typically, the Asian-American opponents of school reform tend to be English-speaking only, recipients of quote-unquote higher education," said Mr. Cheng, who was born in San Francisco but returned to Taiwan with his family for some years. When the family returned from Taiwan, they settled in Pacifica, a blue-collar suburb of San Francisco. His mother now works as an accountant; his father as a librarian. Mr. Cheng recalls frequently being beat up by white peers who called him "Chinaman."
 "I don't really see them being representatives of Asian-Americans who are recent immigrants," he said of Asian-American academics and activists who support affirmative action. "It's unfortunate they tend to speak English more because the press jumps to them as spokesmen."
 Almost all of the national Asian-American civil rights organizations publicly support race-based affirmative action, but admit that they do not have the grass-roots support that their African-American and Hispanic counterparts do.
The Organization of Chinese Americans, a lobbying group headquartered in Washington and founded in 1973, endorsed affirmative action in higher education. But it has refrained from taking a position in the Lowell High School case, even though the San Francisco chapter is supportive of the Chinese families.
 The Lowell case, said Daphne Kwok, the group's executive director, is "one of the most emotional and divisive issues in the organization's history."
 Asian-American advocates for affirmative action say that it is precisely this disunity that threatens their long-term success in a state with shrinking resources and in a national economy where a college degree is increasingly the only passport to a good job. If Asian-Americans account for a third of the students at the University of California but only 10 percent of the state's taxpayers, they say, the imbalance will result in an inevitable backlash.
 They also argue that white conservatives are using Asian-Americans to divide the country's racial minorities by pointing out that Asian-Americans have succeeded in education without affirmative action and by labeling them a model minority -- thereby indirectly criticizing blacks and Hispanics. Asian-Americans, they say, must building alliances with Hispanics and blacks to fight for equality on all levels of American society.
 Frank H. Wu, 28, a Chinese-American who grew up in Cleveland, last fall became the first Asian-American to teach at the law school of historically black Howard University. He took the position, he said, partly to show how Asian-Americans and black Americans could work together.
 "African-Americans and Asian-Americans have frequently come into contact with each other in situations of conflict," Mr. Wu said. "But it doesn't have to be that way. African- Americans and Asian-Americans have a common interest in fighting racism."
In some ways, Lillian Galedo, executive director of the Berkeley-based Filipinos for Affirmative Action, echoed those sentiments.
 "A lot depends on whether you view yourself as a citizen of the whole "or whether you just view yourself as an individual, and you're looking out for your own interests, your family and the relatives you're supporting back home."
Filipino immigrants, she said, who are about 65 to 70 percent of the Filipino-Americans in the United States, tended to view affirmative action as harmful to their interests. But the American-born Filipino-Americans, aware of the country's racial history, could identify with blacks and Hispanics, and understood affirmative action's intent of creating a balanced society.
Beyond education, those who oppose anti-affirmative action advocates, like Mr. Izumi from the Pacific Research Institute, argue that Asian-Americans are underrepresented at higher levels of many companies because their numbers in the United States have increased significantly only in the last two decades. He and others say that Asian-Americans' success in education ultimately will be enough to lead to a similar one in the workplace.
 But Asian-American proponents of affirmative action point to Marcy Li Wang as evidence that, except for their success in being admitted to colleges, Asian-Americans need more than time to achieve equality in the workplace. And higher education is a key area.
 Ms. Wang was an assistant professor of architecture at Berkeley from 1979 to 1988. After she was denied tenure, she sued saying it was because she is a Chinese-American woman. In January, after a 10-year legal battle, Ms. Wang, 44, won a $1 million settlement from the university, which admitted no wrongdoing. Ms. Wang now works for a private architecture firm in Berkeley.
"A big complaint is that Asian academics do not speak English properly," said Ms. Wang, who was born in the United States. "But they have no problems hiring Europeans with heavy accents. That's considered charming."
 Although Asian-Americans held about 20 percent of the academic positions in the University of California in the fall of 1994, they made up only about 4 percent of faculty members at colleges and universities nationwide in the 1993-1994 academic year.
 Early this month, at a conference in San Francisco sponsored by the Asian and Pacific Americans in Higher Education, about 500 academics and students (the largest gathering in the organization's nine-year history) spent three days discussing everything from Filipino-Americans at Berkeley, to the state of community colleges in California , and Asian-American and student activism.
 Many of the participants raised the paradox of Asian-Americans' success in education: many numbers but little influence.
 Ling-Chi Wang (no relation to Ms. Wang), an Asian-American studies professor at Berkeley who organized the conference, said that Asian-American students, once in college, receive fewer services, including everything from counseling to curriculum. For example, he said, the lack of Asian-American studies courses, especially in colleges outside the West Coast, was a glaring example of how Asian-American students were being treated unequally in higher education. Even though the number of Asian-American students at Ivy League universities is about twice the number of black students, he said, places like Harvard and Princeton offered strong programs in African-American studies but often not a single course in Asian-American studies.
 There are signs that things are changing, he said.
 Some universities on the East Cost are hiring or seeking their first faculty member in Asian-American studies partly because coalitions of Asian-American, Hispanic and black students in the last year held sit-ins and protests aton several campuses, including at Princeton and Columbia, demanding courses and faculty in ethnic studies.
 Some argue that i's only the first step.
 Herbert Yamanishi, 52, the executive director of the Japanese American Citizens League, the oldest Asian civil rights organization in the country, said that Asian-Americans' cultural reverence forof education often blinds them to the real goal of equality in the rest of society.
"The one thing we need to understand in America," Mr. Yamanishi said, "is that pure academic success does not mean success in America."

HEADLINE: Queens Old-Timers Uneasy As Asian Influence Grows

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

 BODY:
Ethel Chen, considering a run for the New York City Council, sat in her office above the teeming Asian hub of Flushing, counting the Chous, Hsiehs and Lins on the voter rolls. Blocks away, Chun Soo Pyun, a potential candidate for the same seat, was tallying the Kims, Choys and Rhees.
Mrs. Chen, who is Chinese-American and a Democrat, and Mr. Pyun, who is Korean-American and a Republican, found many of their compatriots in the voter registry -- double the number there just five years ago, but far from enough for a victory built on Asian-American votes alone. "If I run with Giuliani," said Mr. Pyun, eyeing an alliance with the Republican Mayor, "I might get some pretty good coattails there." 
 Both Mrs. Chen and Mr. Pyun are among the aspiring politicians looking to break through the barriers that have kept Asians, the city's fastest-growing immigrant group, from attaining political office. Their struggle is especially fierce in Flushing, the city's leading magnet for Asian immigrants, whose longtime Councilwoman, Julia Harrison, is sometimes hostile in her remarks about the immigrants and where many longtime residents are quick to express unease about them.
When Mrs. Harrison, 75, describes what Asian immigrants have meant to Flushing over the last decade, she talks about criminal smugglers and Asian robbers. ("I don't know if they're Korean or Chinese," she said. "I can't tell by the name.") She talks about rude merchants and illegal aliens who depress the wages of American working people.
Her discomfort with the new immigrants reflects that of many of her elderly white constituents, who say they have come to feel increasingly out of place in their own neighborhood as growing numbers of Asian-Americans have settled there, speaking languages the old-timers don't understand and selling foods they have never tasted.
Mrs. Harrison's comments would be less surprising in California, epicenter of the backlash against immigrants, than in New York, which prides itself on welcoming them. She said in an interview that the sudden and transforming arrival of Asian-American businesses -- which city planners and immigration experts say revitalized a declining Flushing in the 1980's -- was "an invasion, not an assimilation."
Those new immigrants, she said, were not like her grandfather, who arrived hungry at Ellis Island early in the century from Transylvania. "They did not come because of a potato famine or because some czar was conducting a pogrom," she said. "They were more like colonizers than immigrants. They sure as hell had a lot of money, and they sure as hell knew how to buy property and jack up rents of retail shops and drive people out."
She added, "The money came first. The paupers followed, smuggled in and bilked by their own kind."
Many politically active Asian-Americans chose their words gingerly when discussing the Councilwoman, who, solidly entrenched in Flushing, got her start in politics there organizing for Eugene J. McCarthy's Presidential run in 1968. But Pauline Chu, who is president of the Chinese-American Parents Association in Flushing and who lost a race to Mrs. Harrison in 1991, is more open.
"She never supported us in this area," Mrs. Chu said. "She should bridge the gap and make peace. We are here. We're hard-working. We pay taxes. Why don't we deserve the right? If smart politicians don't take care of us, later on they'll be sorry. Eventually, we'll be in power. Her voters are aging. Asians are growing and becoming voters."
 
Still a Minority, For a While, at Least
More and more of the Asian-Americans in Flushing are indeed becoming voters -- a trend that will only gain momentum over the next two years as a huge bubble of citizenship seekers become Americans.
Even so, they are still very much in the minority. In the 20th Council District in 1990, almost one-third of the residents, but only 6.7 percent of registered voters, were of Asian origin. Five years later, after an influx of thousands more Asian immigrants, the Asian-American share of registered voters is 12.3 percent, according to Marc Lapidus, a political consultant who was research coordinator for the City Districting Commission in 1991.
The barriers to Asian-American political power in New York and across the nation are formidable. While the first Dominican-born and Jamaican-born Council members were elected in 1991, no Asian-American in the city has ever been elected to the Council, the State Assembly, the State Senate or the United States Congress.
Several factors have conspired to undermine the political clout of the Asian-American population: ethnic heterogeneity; low voter registration rates; a large percentage of registered independents, who are therefore unable to vote in contested party primaries, and the absorption of many would-be voters in the all-consuming struggle to survive economically.
Nevertheless, the sheer magnitude of the Asian influx has the potential to break down barriers in coming years. By 2000, 1 in 10 New Yorkers, and almost 1 in 5 Queens residents, will be of Asian origin, city planners estimate.
Flushing is emblematic of the change. Once a destination for whites of various ethnic backgrounds, it is home to an ever-growing concentration of Taiwanese, Koreans and Indians. The thronged immigrant marketplaces are lined with shops that spill out onto the sidewalks, selling crabs, carp, Chinese long beans and bok choy.
 
Unfamiliar Ways 'Don't Sit Well'
But the growth of the Asian community in Flushing, part of the urban life cycle that has played out ceaselessly over the city's immigrant history, is proving painful, even traumatic, for many elderly white voters, who reared their children in Flushing and once regarded it as theirs -- and who still make up one-quarter of the district's voters.
Rose Wierzbicki, 65, and her husband, Gedda, 79, miss the idle conversation they used to have with the kosher butcher and the shopkeeper who made them pastrami sandwiches. Jack Rubin, 81, says he is uncomfortable going into Asian stores. "Everything is changing," he said.
As Mrs. Harrison put it, "It's very discombobulating, very upsetting. We all recognize that change is part of life, but it doesn't sit well."
The old-timers' feelings of displacement often center on the Asian marketplaces, where the shelves are lined with jars of unfamiliar condiments and the vegetable bins are filled with fare they see as exotic.
In the late 1980's, Mrs. Harrison proposed an ordinance to require shopkeepers to post signs in English as well as their native languages. But she stopped pushing the measure when she found out that a similar law had been passed in 1905, during an earlier wave of immigration.
"I was perceived as anti-Asian, a bigot," she said. "I was trying to soothe the way for the community integrating."
Mrs. Harrison drives to the Waldbaum's in College Point to do her grocery shopping. On a recent walk in downtown Flushing, she paused at a greengrocer's and sniffed a bunch of Chinese broccoli covered with delicate yellow buds. "I think it's dandelion," she said. She examined a star fruit and asked, "What is this? Papaya?"
The Councilwoman does not seem to worry too much about how many Asian-American or immigrant votes she wins, though half the population of her district is foreign-born. Asked who goes to the polls, she said, "The little old men and ladies in walkers and wheelchairs, and that's the truth."
The clash between the old and the new Flushing is reflected in bread-and-butter political issues. Mrs. Harrison opposed the construction of a state-of-the-art four-story library (the old one was perfectly adequate, she said) and of a new entrance to the Flushing No. 7 subway station (the changes would disrupt street traffic, she said). Mrs. Chen and Mr. Pyun strongly support both projects.
Neither issue is explicitly about immigration. But the subway is a lifeline to jobs for immigrants, and the library is a portal to learning and advancement. "These services have a very important role for immigrants," said Madhulika Khandelwal, a research historian at the Asian-American Center at Queens College. "If you're investing in these things, you're investing in the future."
Since 1991, Mrs. Harrison has had Chinese and Korean challengers; she has trounced them all. Her dominance has stirred divisions among politically active Asian-Americans in Flushing about how best to gain influence.
Augustine Chen, a physics professor at St. John's University and past president of the Chinese-American Voters Association in Flushing, said he decided in 1993 that the best chance was to gain Mrs. Harrison's confidence by working for her re-election. He did the tedious work of checking the signatures on Ethel Chen's petition lists, helping to knock her off the ballot in her campaign against Mrs. Harrison.
In retrospect, he said, he does not believe his strategy helped him win Mrs. Harrison's ear.
"I'm very disappointed," he said. "I worked very hard to support her. I stepped on many people's toes. It didn't pay off. She does not need to listen, because Asians do not have the votes. I cannot fault her. Most politicians are like this."
Mrs. Chen, 57, who retired last year after 25 years as a librarian with the New York Public Library and who was appointed a Democratic district leader at large in Queens by party regulars in 1993, is angry about what she sees as Mr. Chen's betrayal. "We call him a traitor to the community," she said. "When he walks, people spit on the floor."
"He wanted to go to the existing power," she added. "This is the wrong philosophy. I say this is a democratic system. We have to have competition."
 
Teaching the Value Of Voting Power
Many local Korean- and Chinese-American civic groups are trying to teach the immigrants about America's electoral process. They are gearing up to register voters once the weather warms up.
"Jewish people, especially seniors, do come out to vote," said Meilin Tan, a district leader for the Republican Party from Flushing. "Asians haven't yet learned to vote as a group. So the Jewish people have a bigger voice. We in the Republican Party have to strive to educate people."
Only about 20 percent of the citizens of Asian origin had registered to vote in 1995. This registration rate was by far the lowest for any ethnic group, according to the city's Voter Assistance Commission. In Queens, because so many Asians are not yet citizens, it meant that only about 4 percent of adults of Asian descent were registered voters in 1995.
And of those who are registered to vote, more than one-third pick no political party, compared with only one-fifth of all registered voters. This means, come primary time, that those voters would be unable to cast a ballot for Mrs. Chen even if they wanted to, further limiting her chances against Mrs. Harrison.
Mrs. Chen's volunteers have already addressed envelopes to the independent voters, whom she is asking to become Democrats.
At an even more basic level, the volunteers must often explain to immigrants why they need to register. In Taiwan, adults have only to go to the polls to vote, and until the last couple of years, there was no such thing as a party primary there.
By the numbers, Asian-American voting strength in the city is still weak, but the potential for geometric growth is there. Sol Nachemin, the 82-year-old son of Russian immigrants, takes the long view. He has lived in Flushing since 1954 and watched it change. His kind are dying out, he said, and the Asians' turn is coming, as inevitably as earlier immigrants had theirs.
"I got to tell you," he said, "I have a sneaking admiration for them. They're hard-working. They're good business people. At the library, I see all these Oriental kids sitting around the table doing their homework. It reminds me of the Jewish kids of my generation.
"I have no doubt. They'll start feeling their oats politically. And one of these days, you'll see a Korean or Chinese Councilman."
 

CORRECTION-DATE: April 12, 1996, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article on March 31 about the involvement of Asian immigrants in New York City politics misstated the percentage of adults of Asian descent in Queens who were registered to vote in 1995. It is 11.6 percent, according to the city's Voter Assistance Commission, not 4 percent.

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
The City That Poor Richard Could Afford

BYLINE: By SUSAN SPANO

 BODY:
"IT is necessary for me to be extremely frugal for some time," wrote a green young Benjamin Franklin in 1726 on his return to Philadelphia after a brief stay in London. Taking a note from him, I found a thrifty way to get to the City of Brotherly Love in mid-January. I did it not by walking across New Jersey (as Franklin once did) or by buying a $60 off-peak, round-trip ticket on Amtrak, but by taking a New Jersey Transit train from Pennsylvania Station in New York; in Trenton, I transferred to an R7 Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority train to Suburban Station, in the heart of Philadelphia's Center City. The trip took two and a half hours, an hour longer than Amtrak would have. But the connection was easy and the off-peak round-trip ticket cost just $24.
I wouldn't call the trip through the junkyards and grim-looking neighborhoods north of Philadelphia scenic. Still, sitting by a rain-lashed window on the R7, I reasoned that there's a lot more to Philly than you can see from the train tracks -- like its orchestra, art museums, elegant squares and sites evoking some of the greatest moments in American history. Foul weather would trim the lines at the Liberty Bell, I hoped, and maybe flush out a few good off-season deals on meals, lodging and entertainment. 
 Ascending to street level at Suburban Station I found leftover banks of dirty snow, harried commuters and broken umbrellas that looked like butterflies on the sidewalks. The spacecraft-shaped Philadelphia Visitors Bureau lay just across 16th Street, so I stopped in and purchased five mass transit tokens for $1.15 each -- a good buy, since it costs $1.60 to take most buses if you pay in cash.
I boarded the No. 76 bus, a special tourist line that costs just 50 cents, passing Philadelphia's most marvelous architectural gewgaw, the much-embellished Second Empire City Hall at the intersection of Market and Broad Streets, with a 547-foot tower surmounted by a statue of William Penn -- the British Quaker who founded Philadelphia in 1682 -- by Alexander Milne Calder, grandfather of the modern sculptor.
At Liberty Bell Pavilion, a modernistic glass-walled structure with the great cracked bell inside, the bus jogged a block south to Chestnut Street. There I got a first glimpse of Independence Hall, where Thomas Jefferson's draft of the Declaration of Independence was passed by the Second Continental Congress on July 4, 1776, and 11 years later George Washington, seated in a chair with a rising sun carved on its back, presided over the debate on a proposed Constitution.
The bus let me off in front of the Society Hill Hotel at Third and Chestnut Streets, an intersection surrounded by many of the three dozen buildings and sites that make up the 45-acre Independence National Historic Park. To the south lay the leafy lanes and dignified brick row houses of Society Hill, a bastion of power and wealth in the second half of the 18th century, when Philadelphia was the biggest and most important city in North America; to the north, Old City's coffee bars, galleries and nightclubs, lining narrow cobblestone alleys seemingly cut from the same pattern as those in the City of London; and to the east the Delaware River.
This was just where I wanted to be, though I had to reconcile myself to paying for the central location. Several weeks earlier I had called hotels in the neighborhood, finding even the special weekend rates offered for doubles by the Omni at Independence Park ($115) and the Society Hill Sheraton ($103) too rich for my blood. The least expensive room I could find in the immediate area was a single for $85 (including breakfast) at the Society Hill Hotel, with 12 rooms above a popular restaurant. So I booked it for two nights and planned to spend my last night at the Latham Hotel near ritzy Rittenhouse Square, which was offering a Holiday Saver rate of $89.
A waiter at the downstairs bar of the Society Hill Hotel checked me in, charged me for two nights in advance and gave me the key to room 307, which had nice green wallpaper, a fancily draped window and high ceilings, but was so small that the double bed took up most of the floor space. The size didn't bother me, though the bed's rickety headboard, closet's sticking door, and blackish-green splotches (mold, I assumed) on the tiled ceiling in the shower did. Still, lacking alternatives, I stayed. It was growing late, and I wanted to get to the box office of the Walnut Street Theater, about a seven-block walk west, where half-price tickets for Brian Friel's play "Philadelphia, Here I Come!" went on sale at 6 P.M. sharp.
Later, with a $14 theater ticket in my pocket, I ordered the satisfying $10.95 lobster dinner special at Ralph Jr.'s, a noisy, affable corner bar on Chestnut and Second Street and then washed the melted butter off my fingers before making my way back to the theater. The play was about a young Irishman with scores to settle at home before emigrating to Phildelphia, and the walls of the lobby were lined with pictures of performers who had played the old theater (founded in 1809), including one of a lovely ingenue named Helen Hayes. Afterward a nightcap seemed in order, so I ordered a Dewar's on the rocks, $5 with tip, at the bar on the ground floor of my hotel, listening in as a very candid bartender told the man next to me not to bother ordering the bean soup.
Nor, in the end, could I recommend the Society Hill Hotel. For one thing, the pipe beneath the sink in my bathroom leaked, and for another, halfway through the night a decorative metal ball fell off the headboard and hit me on the head when I rolled in my sleep. Unfortunately, the place has a 48-hour cancellation policy, which meant I'd be stuck paying for my second night even if I left. But the next morning I told the innkeeper I just had to check out, and even took him on a tour of the room's trouble spots. This ultimately got me the promise of a refund for the second night, though as of mid-March, the credit had not appeared on my charge card statement. Then I packed my bag and scooted over to the Best Western Independence Park Inn around the corner, where I got a double room on the fifth floor with a huge bathroom, handsome reproduction Federal furniture and a television with remote control for a special rate of $89, including breakfasts that morning and the next. (When I called the hotel before my trip, the lowest rate quoted was a weekend rate of $99.)
Frankly, I hate to pay more than $75 a night at a hotel, even when the room is as nice as the one I later stayed in at the Latham. That hotel has 138 rooms and suites, an air of slightly faded elegance, helpful doormen dressed in riding breeches and guest privileges at the nearby Panorama Health Club, where there's a swimming pool and hot tub surrounded by lofty windows. So even in the off-season the city defeated me in my search for hotel bargains. But in other ways, Philadelphia prices would have contented Benjamin Franklin himself. For instance, most of the sites within the Independence National Historic Park can be toured free. Each one illuminates a different theme from the early history of the republic (visiting the park made me feel like a grade schooler on a field trip).
On a cold, blustery Saturday morning, I took a chronological approach by strolling past reconstructed City Tavern, a handsome brick edifice on Second Street built in 1773, where radicals like John Adams and Patrick Henry talked about the rights of man while eating mutton joints and sherry trifles.
Two blocks away on Chestnut Street, I paused to appreciate the perfect Georgian silhouette of Carpenter's Hall, where the First Continental Congress leveled economic sanctions against Mother England. Then it was on to Independence Hall, though my heart sank when I learned that heating and cooling system renovations had temporarily closed Assembly Hall, meaning I didn't get to see President Washington's rising sun chair or the inkwell into which he dipped his pen when signing the Constitution.
But I saw the Liberty Bell, which was lugged off to Allentown in 1777 so that Redcoats under Gen. William Howe, who occupied Philadelphia for a year during the revolution, couldn't melt it down for cannonballs; stopped beneath the steel girders of the "ghost structure" in Franklin Place that mark the site of the great statesman and maxim writer's Market Street home and in the subterranean museum there learned that at the age of 14 Franklin invented swimming slippers; toured Powel House, an elegant Georgian mansion built in 1765, just south of the park (admission $3), with Chippendale chairs, moody blue Delft tiles around the fireplace in the master bedroom, and a delightful second-floor ballroom; and then wandered around Society Hill, lunching on a huge Philly cheese steak sandwich (for about $4) at the counter of Simon's Steaks on South Street.
THAT night, a $4 ticket admitted me to the amphitheater section at a Philadelphia Orchestra concert in the Academy of Music, where, way up in my chandelier-level seat, the acoustics were splendid. The program included a Glazunov violin concerto played by an 18-year-old guest soloist named Leila Josefowicz. Bending gracefully into her instrument and gowned in black from, she looked like something out of Charlotte Bronte or a perfume advertisement.
Afterward, I descended to the basement of one of Philadelphia's most famous -- and expensive -- restaurants, Le Bec-Fin on Walnut Street, because I'd heard that in the pretty little Bar Lyonnais downstairs, prices were much lower than in the fancy dining room upstairs. Over stuffed roast quail and a glass of white wine (for $25), I made friends with the couple next to me, who offered me delectable tidbits from their mixed dessert plate. Returning to my hotel, I admired the illuminated summits of Center City's skycrapers from a seat on the Chestnut Street bus.
During the day, however, an older, lower, pristine white spire persistently drew my gaze -- that of the 250-year-old Christ Church just north of Market Street where William Penn, abandoning the Society of Friends, was baptized into the Anglican faith. During the Sunday morning service, light streamed through the huge Palladian window in front, and the Gospel was taken from the Book of Matthew.
Afterward I had a delicious Sunday brunch of eggs Florentine ($6) at the chic Continental Restaurant and Martini Bar two blocks away, decorated with green vinyl and giant fake toothpick-pierced olives.
The rest of my Sunday was devoted to visiting the Barnes Foundation (admission $5) in the suburb of Merion, about 45 minutes' ride on the No. 44 bus. Though the foundation's reopening in November after a three-year renovation had attracted attention, the place was uncrowded.
Dr. Albert Coombs Barnes started collecting works, primarily by early modern French painters, around the turn of the century, ultimately aiming to establish an art school with a radical pedagogical approach. At the foundation Dr. Barnes's 800 paintings are displayed in dense, nonchronological groupings (jumbling together styles as diverse as Mannerism and Impressionism), accompanied by intriguingly shaped antique keys, latches and hinges -- all to teach lessons about the technical components of painting, such as form, color and the rendering of light. The result can be a little befuddling (which is why I benefited from the audio tour, which rents for $4).
Still, I saw paintings I never knew existed by some of my favorite artists, like "The Artist's Family" by Renoir (1896) and "Nude and Bear" by Rousseau (1901).
By Monday morning I was sated, even though in a long weekend I'd barely scratched the surface of Philadelphia's attractions. Just before boarding the R7 back to Trenton, I took the free elevator up to the observation deck in City Hall. Though it was a little foggy I could easily see for miles in all directions, toward some of the sights I had missed like the Philadelphia Museum of Art, the 1876 Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts and Reading Terminal and trendy Manayunk. To see all these I'd need another visit, and the boundless energy of Benjamin Franklin.
 
The bottom line in Ben Franklin's town
I spent an average of $146 a day while in Philadelphia, with $88 of that going toward accommodations (or $100, including tax).
 
 Getting There
New Jersey Transit, (201) 762-5100, has trains that run between Penn Station in New York and Trenton for $14 round trip, off-peak (or $18.90 peak, Monday to Friday 6 to 9 P.M., to New York only). At Trenton you can change to a Southeast Pennsylvania Transit System (Septa) commuter train, with downtown Philadelphia stops at 30th Street Station, Suburban Station and Market East; the round-trip Trenton-Philadelphia Septa fare is $10.
Schedules of Septa trains with New Jersey Transit connections and other information on Philadelphia's mass transit system (like Phlash tourist buses and the Penn's Landing Trolley) are available by calling (215) 580-7800.
It's a good idea to purchase both the Septa and New Jersey Transit tickets at the New Jersey Transit ticket window in Penn Station, since the connection in Trenton is usually rather tight.
The round-trip, unreserved fare between New York and Philadelphia on Amtrak, (800) 872-7245, is $60, $78 peak (Friday and Sunday from 11 A.M. to 11 P.M.); reserved round-trip tickets cost $66, $86 peak, and Metroliners cost $104 on the weekend, $130 during the week.
 
 Sights
The Philadelphia Visitors Center, (800) 537-7676, is at 16th Street and John F. Kennedy Boulevard; there is also a satellite office inside the Visitors Center for Independence National Historical Park, (215) 597-8974, on Second Street between Chestnut and Walnut Streets.
Half-price tickets for productions at the Walnut Street Theater, Ninth and Walnut Streets, (215) 574-3550, go on sale at the box office from 6 to 6:30 P.M. the day of the performance. "She Stoops to Conquer" is playing to April 14, and then "Cabaret" April 27 to June 9.
Tickets for the amphitheater level for the Philadelphia Orchestra at the Academy of Music, (215) 893-1999, at Broad and Locust Streets, are available at the amphitheater box office on the Locust Street side of the building one hour before Friday afternoon (usually at 2) and evening (at 8) and Saturday (8 P.M.) concerts; the cost is $4, and each person is limited to two tickets. Other tickets are $12 to $79. The season is September to May.
The Barnes Foundation is at 300 North Latches Lane, Merion, (610) 667-0290. Open Thursday, 12:30 to 5 P.M.; Friday, Saturday and Sunday, 9:30 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission is $5.
 
 Places to Stay
The Society Hill Hotel, 301 Chestnut Street, (215) 925-1919, fax (215) 925-3780, has 12 rooms, six of which are suites, ranging in price from $85 to $150, including a Continental breakfast.
The Best Western Independence Park Inn, 235 Chestnut Street, (800) 528-1234 or (215) 922-4443, fax (215) 922-4487, has 36 rooms for $105 to $155, including tea and Continental breakfast.
Rates at the Latham Hotel, 17th and Walnut Streets, (800) 528-4261, fax (215) 568-0110, with 138 rooms and suites, range from $165 to $240.
The Bank Street Hostel, 32 South Bank Street, (800) 392-4678, fax (215) 922-4082, has dormitory-style accommodations for $18 a night ($15 for American Youth Hostel members) right in the heart of the historic area. And the Shippen Way Inn, 418 Bainbridge Street, (800) 245-4873, has nine rooms, all with private bath, in two historic homes about a 10-minute walk south of Independence National Historic Park; rates range from $70 to $105, including Continental breakfast.
 
Places to Eat
Ralph Jr.'s, 201 South Chestnut Street (at Second Street); (215) 925-2440.
Simon's Steaks, Third and South Streets.
Bar Lyonnais, 1523 Walnut Street; (215) 567-1000.
Continental Restaurant and Martini Bar, 138 Market Street; (215) 923-6069. S. S.

 CORRECTION:
The Frugal Traveler column on March 31, about Philadelphia, referred incorrectly to a change in William Penn's religious affiliation. Baptized an Anglican as an infant, he joined the Society of Friends at age 23. He did not convert from the Society of Friends to the Anglican church.
